column2: Grand Central Terminal is being fitted for its first set of escalators.

When rain freezes on trees and shrubs, as it did last week, limbs snap from the excess weight of ice. As soon as the weather permits, all woody plants should have a thorough check. Corrective pruning and sawing off of damaged limbs now will help the plants to regain their proper posture.

Telephone poles, snow-padded hillsides and the bare, beseeching arms of trees raced past the windows of a remarkable seminar on religious ethics in business yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UPI)-- Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and its subsidiaries plan to spend about $76,000,000 on expansion projects and normal construction this year, the concern announced today.

Eight reputed members of a multimillion dollar gambling ring were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury under the recently enacted Federal law to stamp out organized interstate gambling operations.

Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company has authorized an issue of $75,000,000 of thirty-nine year debentures for competitive bidding about May 1. A registration statement is to be prepared for filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ben S. Gilmer, president, announced yesterday.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), reduced prices of home heating oil, Diesel fuel and kerosene yesterday by three-tenths of a cent a gallon for all methods of delivery along the East Coast.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 26 --Prince Souvanna Phouma, neutralist Premier designate of Laos, said today he was satisfied that five days of talks with Right-wing leaders here had shown him "more clearly the way to a solution of the Laotian problem."
The jaunty and resplendent Bohemian waxwing, a local rarity, has unaccountably started turning up in northeastern states.

THE HAGUE, the Nether lands, Feb. 26--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that the dispute over Netherlands New Guinea could be settled peacefully if the Dutch and Indonesians talked it over in a reasonable manner.

Robert H. Bishop 3d, a Cleveland producer, has decided not to appear here tomorrow before Bernard J. O'Connell, Commissioner of Licenses. Recently, Mr. Bishop charged at a hearing of the House Subcommittee on Education that ticket racketeering, tax-free benefit tickets and tax regulations were ruining Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- President Kennedy told employes of the Voice of America today that their job was to tell the truth about the United States, even when it put the nation in a bad light.
The professional debut of Joseph (Ace) Falu, prize fighter, ended fourteen seconds after it had begun last night under thirteen 1,000-watt bulbs in the St. Nicholas Arena ring.
Henceforth, children, waddling is for ducks. The Board of Education instructed all schools over the week-end to drop any exercises involving a sustained squatting position.

APPARENTLY, the Indian phrase is true. The white man does speak "with a forked tongue."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- Treasury bill rates tumbled on today's sale of the regular weekly issues, to their lowest levels since the final issues of 1961.

The seriousness of the Brazilian situation-- economic, political and social--is now so evident, so well documented and so near to a critical showdown that it keeps forcing itself on everyone in the Western Hemisphere connected with Latin-American affairs. An economic collapse (equivalent to bankruptcy in a commercial firm) or a political explosion, or both, has moved from the field of possibility into probability.
A new approach to the teaching of mathematics from kindergarten through the six elementary school grades was announced yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 26-- George Soll of Roslyn Heights, a lawyer who is on the Nassau County Charter Revision Commission, was named today as the Democratic candidate for Congress in the new Third District. The designation was made by the Democratic County Executive Committee.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)--Reverie Knoll Farm's Sharp Count ran past the 3-4 favorite, Summer Savory, on the stretch turn and drew out to a five-length victory in the Virgin Islands Purse at Hialeah today. A crowd of 19,380 watched.

The "Red Skelton Show" will be expanded to an hour next fall and televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Tuesdays from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M. The show is now presented from 9 to 9:30 each Tuesday.

EXHIBITIONS in the galleries come and go like a tide. Sometimes the week is borne in a high wave of three or four excellent shows. At other times, weeks can pass with tides close to the low watermark. Though some good artists are reviewed today, the tide was going out.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26--Baseball valiants from other times and other places tools their first workouts today in the gray flannel of the New York Mets.
A computer capable of operating while exposed to intense radiation is being developed for the Air Force.
Buyers of large amounts of mutual fund shares have been queried in recent days by investigators who said they represented the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 26-- For the first time, something like a national discussion on the possibility of West Germany's renouncing the eastern territories lost in World War II is under way in this country.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP)--A late burst of general short covering lifted nearly all grain contracts sharply today on the Board of Trade.
IOWA CITY, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Unbeaten Ohio State erased a 6-point half-time deficit and scored a 72-62 basketball victory over Iowa tonight, clinching its third straight Big Ten Conference title.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 26--Dr. John Baptist D'Albora, a physician and specialist in gastroenterology, died today after a brief illness at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre. He was 71 years old and lived at 49 Chestnut Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The index of primary market prices declined one-tenth of one per cent to 119.3 per cent of its 194749 base during the week ended Feb. 20, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Decreases were registered in all major areas--farm products, processed foods, and industrial commodities.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26--American maritime unions asked the Venezuelan Government yesterday to lift its embargo against American ships that are equipped to load and unload cargoes in huge containers.

A HOUSE is not a home unless it reveals a secret. The task of the architect is to extract this hidden Information from his client and to incorporate it in the design of the house being built. So believes Leonardo Ricci, an Italian architect who is visiting New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26-- The underworld, which often obliged the rest of society by practicing mutual mayhem, appears to be using more urbane methods these days to dispose of its internal problems.

Four architecture experts turned a practiced eye yesterday on what's wrong and what's right with modern churches.
FLORENCE, S.C., Feb. 26 --Federal Judge Ashton H. Williams died here yesterday of a heart ailment at the age of 70.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26--George Meany served notice on Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg today to stay out of labor-management collective bargaining except in a peacemaking capacity.

MANY a housewife's diet comes unstuck when she prepares a particularly appetizing meal for the family. It is difficult to labor in the vicinity of cooking aromas and then sit down to a glass of 900calorie diet, or a scoop of cold cottage cheese, or even a wellthought-out, well-balanced diet meal. There are times when even the most stalwart calorie counter must relax and eat something forbidden--like a stew or some rich preparation of fish.

MILFORD, Conn., Feb. 26 (AP)--The Very Rev. Charles J. Callan, the first Americanborn priest to be appointed consultor of the Pontifical Biblical Commission, died today in Milford Hospital at the age of 84.

On April 5 five private residences in Manhattan will be open to visitors. On the following Thursday, April 12, five more private residences will be open, again for the benefit of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

BOYNTON BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)--Ralph W. Gwinn, a former United States Representative from New York, died today of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.
NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 27 (UPI)--Holy Cross defeated Boston College tonight, 86--75, for its eighteenth basketball victory in twenty-two games.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27--The fortunes of ballplayers often take unpredictable turns.

Arthur Schwebel, New York realty investor and syndicator, has leased the Times Square Hotel at the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Fortythird Street for ninety years. The lease, which includes an option for purchase, involves rentals aggregating more than $30,000,000.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 27-- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said tonight that high ethical practices by American busines were essential to the strengthening of ties between the Unitd States and the uncommitted nations.
ROME, Feb. 27 (Reuters)-- Gen. Gastone Gambarra, who commanded Italian troops aiding Generalissimo Francisco Franco in the Spanish Civil War, died here today at the age of 71.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) --Senators were told today that it would be possible for an unfriendly nation to jam a global communications satellite system, at least in its early stages.

A new attack on the housing problem in New York City is announced at City Hall with a fanfare suggesting that Mayor Wagner and his aides view it as a major program. It puts enlarged emphasis on conservation and improvement of existing housing, and makes the city administration of rent control a powerful instrument to that end. The objective is "a slumless city."

Richard Lewisohn Jr., leader of New York County's banner Republican district, urged last night a postponement "for at least two weeks" of the special county committee meeting called for tomorrow night to set up a new county leadership.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. warned Congress today that men would lose their lives in the new national endeavor of manned exploration of space and the moon.

The Children's Aid Society this month opened one of the most perplexing campaigns in its 110-year history--how to convince the youth of the city's slums that policemen are their friends, not their enemies.
BOSTON, Feb. 27--American textile manufacturers were advised today to take advantage of an "umbrella" provided by the recently completed textile agreement among nineteen nations.

Dr. Herbert Rosinski, German-born military expert and consultant on military affairs and international politics, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 1 Gracie Terrace.
ALBANY, Feb, 27--A Queens Democratic Senator accused Mayor Wagner today of "political expediency" and "lack of integrity" in advocating a bonus for Korean war veterans.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The Soviet Union delivered notes today to the United States, Britain and France protesting that the three Western powers are treating West Berlin as a part of West Germany. The United States, British and French Embassies here declined to give details of the protest.

ORAN, Algeria, Feb. 27-- The Algerian National Liberation Front has issued orders to its Moslem followers to avoid reprisals or demonstrations against Europeans in Oran once the French-Algerian cease-fire is signed.
TOKYO, Feb. 27 (AP)-- Yoshito Yoshida, president of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Reorganized, Ltd. died yesterday at his home after a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
AN 18-year-old Brazilian swept into a room at the Overseas Press Club yesterday, slipped off her mink coat and posed for a raft of photogphers as if she had been doing it all her life and she has.
A CITY law signed by Mayor Wagner last week ruled that hamburger must consist only of fresh, chopped beef with not more than 30 per cent fat.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 27--The Israeli Government presented its largest budget today. It provides for increased expenditures for defense and for a project to divert the waters of the Jordan River.

ALBANY, Feb. 27--A complete rewriting of the conservation article in the State Constitution to permit broader recreation uses of large parts of the forest preserve has been proposed by two upstate Republican lawmakers.

Industry sources expressed firm opposition yesterday to Government intervention in labor-management contract negotiations to the extent advocated by Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg. The management men almost unanimously said that they did not think the Secretary's approach was compatible with free collective bargaining.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) --Senator Hugh Scott said today that he would step out as a candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Pennsylvania if the party endorsed Representative William W. Scranton as its candidate.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 27-- The "east" fought the "west" today in a community war to decide the path of interstate Route 87, a proposed twenty-nine-mile Federal-state expressway in Westchester and southern Putnam Counties.
NEW DELHI, India, Wednesday, Feb. 28--The ruling Congress party appeared today to be maintaining its overwhelming majority in the Indian Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- President Kennedy prodded Congress in a special message today to set up a self-financed system of health insurance for the aged under Social Security.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27 --Harvard routed Princeton, 10--0, at Watson Rink tonight and clinched its seventh Ivy League hockey championship in the last nine years. Gene Kinasewich, the Crimson's leading point-maker, scored four goals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)--Secretary of Slate Dean Rusk has accepted the Australian Government's invitation to attend the eleventh conference of the Anzus Pact nations May 7 in Canberra, the State Department announced today.
Clarion Concerts, which have been an adornment to the New York music season since their founding, last night completed their fifth season at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- The Justice Department asked today for a full hearing on the proposal of the scheduled airlines to charge substantially reduced fares for international group travel.

Aldens, Inc., declared yesterday an initial quarterly dividend of 20 cents on the new common, payable on April 1 to holders of record of March 9. The company split two-for-one in January.

Charges were made in Washington yesterday that New York City was not meeting its responsibilities in dealing with narcotics addiction. They were vigorously denied here last night by health, enforcement and administrative officials.
Perry M. Shoemaker has resigned as chairman of the beleaguered Erie-Lackawanna Railroad to become president in April of the much smaller but equally troubled Central Railroad of New Jersey.

In a rebound from a succession of dreary markets, Wall Street started a brisk recovery yesterday. It lasted until 2 P.M. when news of the indictment of the chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange for income tax evasion was made public.

Sales of the Radio Corporation of America last year exceeded $1,500,000,000 for the first time in its company's forty-two-year history, David Sarnoff, chairman, and Elmer W. TUNIS, Feb. 27--A communique announcing approval by the Algerian nationalist parliament of the peace accords with France may be expected tomorrow or Thursday.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 27 --Geraldine Farrar, the former opera star, will celebrate her eightieth birthday tomorrow at her home here.

Down at Daytona Beach, Fla., yesterday the advance contingent of a field of more than 600 motorcyclists entered in the annual championship events of the American Motorcycle Association began practicing on the International Speedway courses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- President Kennedy cabled President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam today to express his gratification "that you are safe and unharmed" after the air attack on the Presidential Palace in Saigon.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 --The latest postponement of Mrs. John F. Kennedy's visit to India has been at considerable cost to both Indians and Americans.

David Rockefeller, board chairman or the Chase National Bank, was proposed for first vice president of the National Republican Club yesterday by the club's nominating committee. Thus far unopposed in the April 24 election, the Governor's youngest brother would be making his political debut in the office.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 (UPI) --Twenty-five Cuban families arrived today to begin new lives here, Their arrival marked the start of a nation-wide effort to resettle the 100,000 refugees who are jamming the Miami, Fla., area.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 27 (AP)--Gov. John B. Swainson wrote President Kennedy today that Michigan's participation in the Federal program of medical care for the aged had been "a significant failure."

A freeze of at least eight and a half months on rent increases in rooming houses and singleroom-occupancy buildings is mandated in the city's rent control bill. The measure, which would be effective May 1, will be introduced in the City Council next Tuesday.
Elia Kazan, who seldom settles for less than a Pulitzer Prize-winning author to write his scripts, has completed his first original screen play.

A $362,297 judgment was filed yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, against three men, including Sanford J. Moore, a juke-box operator now under indictment on a charge of conspiring to obstruct justice in a Brooklyn court case.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 27--In this capital the term "New Frontier" means the month-oldGovernment of Premier Wasfi al-Tall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- William L. Mitchell, Commissioner of Social Security, will seek retirement this year.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 28--Only one of thirteen school budgets defeated by Bergen County voters two weeks ago was approved in new balloting last night and today.

New York City is usually complaining that it doesn't have enough home rule--i.e., freedom to govern itself without interference from Albany. Now the Wagner administration and others are complaining of too much home rule in the unasked grant last year by the Legislature of mere permission to charge tuition at the City University. A repeal of this grant is now being sought.
A proposed revision of State Senate district lines in Manhattan has been submitted to the Legislature for incorporation into a possible state-wide legislature reapportionment bill.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 28-- Franz Josef Strauss, West German Defense Minister, said yesterday that it was wrong to think he opposed Washington's concept of a "pause" should hostilities break out in Europe.
Dr. Josephine C. Lawney, a former medical missionary in China for the Woman's American Baptist Foreign Mission Society, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. She was 80 years old.
The stock market's latest rally turned out to be brief. After a rise on Tuesday, prices closed yesterday just about where they opened. There was a slight loss on average.
ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 28-- Daniel A. Leary, board chairman of the Motor Finance Corporation in Newark, died today in his home at 213 Elmwynd Drive here. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 21:
The appointment of Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves and former Gov. Elmo Smith of Oregon as co-chairmen of the American Cancer Society's 1962 fund-raising and educational crusade was announced yesterday.

Dave Balon, a rookie center, saved the New York Rangers from what could have been a costly defeat last night when he scored late in the third period to give the Blues a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

A group of Republican district leaders was told last night that Governor Rockefeller would recognize Joseph Gimma as the party's Manhattan spokesman if he should succeed Bernard Newman as county chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The State Department faces a large-scale departure of senior Foreign Service officers on May 31 because of a deadline set by Congress in two laws that provide higher retirement pay.

Dewey Carver, New York realty investor, and his son, Michael S. Carver, have bought the motor truck terminal at the southwest corner of Washington and Charles Streets. The property was sold for all cash by the Continental Transportation Lines, Inc., of Pittsburgh.
Two would-be primary aluminum producers have put off a $50,000,000 smelter project, at least for awhile.
The directors of the E.W. Bliss Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock. They also announced their intention to increase the dividend on the new stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)--Rogers W. Tubby, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, said today that "dampening down" of language in military speeches was carried out under guidelines established by President Kennedy and Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to provide state subsidies so that low-income families could move into middleincome apartments, chiefly in New York City.
Gabriella Tucci sang her first Metropolitan Opera Aida last night, in the company's eighth performance of the opera this season. Cornell MacNeil sang his first Amonasro of the season.

The Algerian conflict has now reached "the ultimate phase." There are minor points still to clear up but, barring accidents, a cease-fire can be expected soon, followed by an Algerian referendum in April and, in all likelihood, general elections in France.

Efforts to ferret out facts were frustrated in the main during yesterday's boxing luncheon at Gilhuly's Restaurant as nine intermediaries did all the talking for the announced principals--Paolo Rosi of the Bronx and Manuel Alvarez of Argentina. Naturally, utter confusion dominated the dining room.

ONE of the surprising things about Pat Frank's "How to Survive the H-Bomb and Why,"* is the high incidence of looters he seems to expect among the survivors after the world has been blown to contaminated bits.

AS often noted in this department, champion bridge players usually know every aspect of the standard technique of the game. In fact, while the average player strives to learn technique as a goal, the champion considers mastery of technique to be only a starting point.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 28 (AP) --One factor in the selection of Joe Foss as commissioner of the new American Football League was his "connections in Washington," Lamar Hunt testified today.

SO you'd like to own a racehorse? So you'd like to swagger into the paddock at Belmont and officiously issue dicta to bored jockeys and find out what happens in the mysterious world behind the sign that reads Turf and Field Club? Or perhaps you savor the idea of some awe-struck railbird asking in breathless anticipation whether you think your horse has a chance in the fifth.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A certificate of suicide was issued today in the death yesterday of William A.M. Burden 3d. He was found shot in the head in his automobile.
LONDON, Feb. 28--The British are disturbed by United States opposition to the linking of European neutral nations with the European Common Market.
The fiftieth annual appeal of the Neediest Cases Fund closed yesterday, setting records in both the number of donors-- 14,953--and the amount they gave--$582,563.46.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Following are excerpts from the Presidential Railroad Commission's own summary of its 500page report to President Kennedy today:

AUSTRALIA is not particularly noted for its painters. But Sidney Nolan, an Australian whose recent work is on view at Durlacher Brothers, 11 East Fiftyseventh Street, is an excellent artist. He has taken the often inglorious traditions of his huge; almost untenanted continent, and made art out of them.

MRS. MICHAEL RING is a young New Yorker who maintains that she is only an ordinary cook, but whose cuisine is roundly admired by many, both in and out of the food field. If, as her friends declare, she has a sharpened interest in food, it may be the challenge posed by her husband shortly after they were married.

TUNIS, Feb. 28--The ministers of the Algerian Provisional Government returned here today with full powers from their parliament to conclude a cease-fire in the seven year-old rebellion against France.
While the stock market may not have been soaring lately with the nation's astronautical hopes, the minds of some Wall Street men have been very much on space.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Pentagon appeared to be embroiled today in a struggle between the Air Force and the Administration on two strategic-weapon programs.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 28 (UPI)--Australia's America's Cup challenge yacht was named Gretel in a formal ceremony today at the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron.
LONDON, Feb. 28--Stock market prices again moved narrowly here today and demand was selective among the equities.
LONDON, Feb. 28--The Soviet Union wants to expand the current East-West talks on Berlin into discussion of a general settlement on Germany and Central Europe, authoritative sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A thorough overhaul of railroad labor practices, revised wage structures and modernized working conditions was demanded today in a report to President Kennedy.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 28--A 17-year-old high school girl has found that it pays to go to original sources for term paper material.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg reiterated today that the Federal Government should state "unhesitatingly and at all times" the national interest involved in labor-industry disputes, and should help the parties settle their differences accordingly.
New York City will show the world today what it thinks of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., the first American to go into orbit.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--A proposal to have the Port of New York Authority build a World Trade Center in Manhattan and expand the facilities of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad was approved by the State Senate today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 28 --The Board of Education here has announced a plan for relocating students of the predominantly Negro Glenfield Junior High School, but is meeting opposition from Negro groups in this community.
The American Home Products Corporation set records in sales and earnings for the ninth consecutive year in 1961, Alvin G. Brush, chairman, reported yesterday.
Tor Nilsen, playing his final game for City College, set a school record of 48 points last night as the Beaver five defeated Bridgeport 96-83, at Wingate gymnasium.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 28 --Thirteen Protestant church leaders will visit the Soviet Union for three weeks this summer as guests of the Russian Orthodox Church.
MRS. IRENE COREY, a theatrical designer who be lieves that it does not matter whether a costume is comfortable, said recently that the head-to-toe look is even more important on-stage than off.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy returned from his month's tour around the world today and said he was "encouraged" by the prospects for freedom.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)--Prices farmers received for their crops and livestock rose four-tenths of 1 per cent in the month that ended Feb. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.
TRENTON, Feb. 28--Gov. Richard J. Hughes predicted today that "very clear solutions" to any New Jersey school integration problems would be worked out.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York urged legislation yesterday that would "unequivocably" require joint administration of the three new courts to be set up here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Failure of March delivery tenders to develop as expected attracted short covering in grain futures transactions today on the Board of Trade. Most contracts finished about steady to firm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The Army said today that it was developing a small radar device that could be held like a submachine gun and aimed to spot moving targets a mile away.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 123--Although many reviews of Webster's Third New International Dictionary have been savage, Dr. Philip B. Gove, the editor in chief, remains convinced that his editorial principles are sound.

A Lutheran theologian, sitting on a stage where at night Thelonious Monk plays jazz on a baby grand, told clergymen yesterday that there was no direct connection between jazz and the precepts of the church.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., is required to maintain "adequate" service on its bus routes under varying state and city franchises and certificates. It has $500,000 on deposit with the city Controller to guarantee faithful performance.
Stocks scored a small gain on average in dull trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month.
The volume of new bonds offered publicly here in February were the highest since June, 1961. The value of new equity offerings, on the other hand, fell to its lowest level since November, 1958.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28--Mickey Mantle set out on his twelfth campaign as a Yankee today and he made the start an auspicious one.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has canceled plans to present four hour-long television shows later this year. The change affects two shows on the National Broadcasting Company, one on the American Broadcasting Company and one on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls will be the beneficiary of next Tuesday's performance of "The Golden Apple" at the York Playhouse. Tickets may be obtained from Mrs. Gillette Boland at 232 East Sixty-second Street.
When Mae Timer returned to her Long Island home from college one winter week-end in 1956 and asked her father, Albert, for ski equipment, he showed extreme disinterest.

Of late, something new has been added to television public affairs shows--namely, sponsors.
TUNIS, Feb. 28--A change in the warfare in Algeria is taking place as formal peace comes closer, according to the Algerian Nationalist press service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- President Kennedy has decided that the United States will resume nuclear-weapons tests in the atmosphere, officials said today. They added that an announcement of the decision, which was expected in a few days, was simply a matter of wording and timing.

The State of Tennessee sold yesterday $12,275,000 of improvement bonds due serially from 1963 to 1982 to the First Boston Corporation and Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, on terms representing an interest cost of 2.9611 per cent.

A further increase of 3,583,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Total supplies were 217,111,000 barrels on last Friday, compared with 213,528,000 a week earlier and 221,098,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) --A State Department official said today that United States leadership in establishing a commercial satellite communications system would demonstrate "our open and cooperative approach in the peaceful uses of space."

All phases of ticket distribution affecting Broadway shows are being investigated by License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell to uncover any scalping practices. He announced yesterday that the examination, which was started secretly last week, involves theatre owners, producers and ticket brokers.
CARBONDALE, Ill., Feb. 28 --For thirty years Charles Sanders worked as a pick-andshovel coal miner in the deep shaft mines around Herrin.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) --Project Mercury officials will apparently tighten security to prevent unscheduled freight, such as wads of $1 bills, from being secreted aboard astronauts' spaceships.
LONDON, Feb. 28--Britain announced today a Constitutional change for Northern Rhodesia that would lead to African control of the country's Legislative Council.
MIAMI, Feb. 28--Seven Thirty made her way through two rivals in the final yards today and won the $51,100 Black Helen Handicap by a neck.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--The Justice Department filed today a strongly worded memorandum in the thirteen-year-old antitrust case against E.I.du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

The report of the Presidential commission on railroad work-rules represents the most exhaustive evaluation ever made of the archaic manning requirements and pay practices that have helped wreck the financial health of the nation's railroads. The recommendations offer a sound basis for eliminating manpower waste and modernizing the rail wage structure.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Senate, with minor bipartisan opposition, approved today the administration's bill to create a state authority for atomic research and development.

CASA GRANDE, Ariz., Feb. 28 (UPI)--Billy Pierce, a southpaw pitcher, suffered a cut right check today when he was struck by a ball thrown by a catcher, Ed Bailey, during practice at the San Francisco Giants camp.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Feb. 28--A safe-driving guide for motorists to show the differences between driving on superhighways and on regular roads was issued today by the New Jersey Highway Authority.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28-- Raymond W. Ickes, lawyer and son of the late Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, has been elected president of Pacific Far East Lines, succeeding Clarence G. Morse.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28--S. J. Perelman, whose search for humor has led him to strange places and fantastic ideas, talked today of his debut in the curious world of the television series.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The last judicial prop under the effort of Southern states to evade or delay racial desegregation of public transportation facilities by means of conflicting local laws was swept away by the Supreme Court in its unanimous, peremptory (per curiam) ruling of Feb. 26. The Court said sharply it had "settled beyond question that no state" can "require" this discrimination.

ILYA SEMYONOVICH CHERNYCHEV, Moscow's Ambassador to Brazil, has a passion for anonymity. But he has not always been able to maintain it during his ascent of the Soviet diplomatic ladder and four years of service with the United Nations.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--A selection of fifty titles has been chosen by the Notable Books Council of the American Library Association as the outstanding books published in 1961 for adult readers.

Plans to bring a planeload of foreign players to the United States for the national tennis championships in August under the sponsorship of the Peopleto-People Sports Committee have brought forth more than $25,000 in private contributions to finance the undertaking.

BRASILIA, Feb. 28--The first ambassador the Soviet Union has sent to Brazil in fifteen years presented his credentials today. He also presented a message of peaceful coexistence from Premier Khrushchev to President Joao Goulart.
MUROC, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP)--A man in a steel cocoon bladed away from a speeding B-58 bomber, then parachuted safely to earth in a test of a new escape capsule today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Thursday, March 1--A suggestion that the attempt to assassinate President Ngo Dinh Diem on Tuesday might have been more broadly based than was first supposed was seen yesterday in a call by National Assembly leaders for stern repressive measures.

IF nothing succeeds like success, then the National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden must be considered successful. The show makes money for its entrepreneurs; it makes money for most of its participating dealers; it draws huge crowds.
LONDON, Feb. 28--Britain repaid today a further 75,000,000 ($210,000,000) of the $1,500,000,000 she borrowed from the International Monetary Fund last August.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28--A leading Soviet architect declared today that atomic shelters were a "chimera."
PARIS, Feb. 28--The final negotiations for peace in Algeria will probably take place this week-end. A cease-fire is expected to be proclaimed by March 8.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Congressional Republicans finally began today the long labor of drafting a "declaration of principles" to guide them through the coming election campaign.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines agreed yesterday to postpone until noon today the layoff of twenty-nine employes. The action temporarily prevented a strike yesterday afternoon by the Transport Workers Union.
John W. McCormack, Speaker of the House, will make the principal address at this year's Bronx Democratic fund-raising dinner.

IRA LEVIN takes a long, slow route to reach his ulti mate destination in "General Seeger." Indeed, for the greater part of the evening at the Lyceum, where his play opened last night, you are convinced that he is headed in another direction.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--The state will open its first rehabilitation camp for youth tomorrow in an isolated forest area near Rensselaerville, N.Y.

ORAN, Algeria, Feb. 28-- Four European extremists killed a young French soldier and gravely wounded another today while attempting to seize their weapons in the crowded European center of town.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The general level of consumer prices continued steady in January for the fourth month in a row, the Labor Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Senator Kenneth B. Keating of New York has scored the television coup of the Congressional season.

MONTREAL, March 1 (Canadian Press) Dr. Wilder Penfield, 71-year-old neurosurgeon, returned by air tonight from Moscow and described the condition of the Russian scientist, Lev Davidovich Landau, as slightly improved but the prognosis "grave."
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Broadcasters were urged today to voice their opinions in editorials on the air.

PSYCHIATRY is a jealous mistress for many patients. It often demands prodigious outlays of time and money and involves the patient and physician in a deep, intense and exclusive relationship that has been likened to marriage.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 Alexander H. Atkinson, the British author who came to the United States after writing a book about this country, died here yesterday in his home at 308 South Quince Street. His age was 46.
WASHINGTON, March 1 A Republican proposal to give Congress a veto over tariff reductions would impose "an almost impossible disability" on tariff negotiations, the Administration believes.
WARSAW, March 1 A New York business man, William L. Brett, has been held in Warsaw jail for nearly three weeks on a charge of an illegal currency transaction.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) The Administration asked Congress today to break a "vicious circle" of low pay and poor training for teachers.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today, that "we are trying to get our friends" in Latin America to speed their activity in the Alliance for Progress.

PIPERSVILLE, Pa., March 1 Mr. and Mrs. Davis T. Dunbar Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Selden Dunbar, to Christopher David Illick. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Illick Jr. of Coopersburg. A June wedding is planned.

The $180,000,000 financing of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority was completed yesterday when representatives of the investment banking group that offered the bonds gave a check for $177,000,000, representing the net proceeds, to William F. Callahan, chairman of the authority.

New York poured out its unstinting affection for Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. yesterday with every art and artifice of spectacle with bands and banners and bunting, with chimes and cheers, and with a blizzard of paper so thick at times that only specks of buildings could be seen through it.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., March 1 T. Kenneth Hoffman of 2001 Brookside Drive, supervisor of medical underwriters for the Prudential Insurance Company, Newark, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a short illness.

LONDON, March 1 Twelve leading churchmen, including four bishops of the Church of England, appealed to the Government tonight to be prepared to renounce Britain's nuclear weapons in the cause of nuclear disarmament.

Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union picked up 1 points in two adjourned games he played in the world interzonal chess tournament yesterday, according to a report from Sweden. Petrosian thus tied his countryman, Ewfim Geller, for second place.

ALBANY, March 1 The right of grocery stores to sell Bayer aspirin without state approval and without employing a pharmacist was upheld today by the Court of Appeals.

GENEVA, March 1 (AP) Alain Calmat of France won the European men's figure-skating championship tonight after a brilliant and imaginative display of free skating.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee applied a 2 per cent cut today to the first Congressional money bill of 1962.

KANSAS CITY, March 1 (AP) The National Council of Churches called today for an interfaith meeting on interracial justice in observance of the 100th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation.

A news item of interest to business men and investors in the United States often can have a wide effect elsewhere. This was proved yesterday in Australia, when brokers traded thousands, of oil company shares for their customers and themselves.

THE winter wind has been hard on the vegetable crop, but at last a slight reverse trend is noted. Escarole has dropped 2 cents to a general price of 23 cents a pound, and iceberg lettuce shed 4 cents this week to 25 cents a head.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) The Civil Aeronautics Board blamed an airline captain today for a crash in 1960 that killed all twelve persons aboard a DC-4.

A 42-year-old man who pleaded guilty to an assault charge eighteen years ago but never appeared for sentencing, thinking his case had been disposed of, received a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions Court.

Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges has been asked to review a Maritime Subsidy Board action described as "a shocking specimen of public prodigality."
TRENTON, March 1 Frederick M. Raubinger, State Commissioner of Education, today upheld the 1958 dismissal by the Jersey City Board of Education of forty of its employes.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Procter Gamble Company, Cincinnati, agreed today to a Federal Trade Commission demand that it drop certain claims from its advertisements for Crest toothpaste.

JERSEY CITY, March 1 Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Wilson have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wilson's sister, Miss Dorethy Anita Hughes, to Richard Alexander McGrath. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard John McGrath of Jersey City and Allenhurst.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1 The Tiara Ball, a dinner dance, took place here this evening in the Everglades Club. Proceeds will be used for the building fund of Good Samaritan Hospital. Guests overflowed into all the public rooms and the dining hall, where a seated dinner was served.
