Orders for machine tools, the machines used to make machines, went up in the domestic market in January, but orders from abroad fell so sharply that the over-all total dropped.

Thomas Gleason, chief organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association, said he was "thrown out" of Panama City, Panama, at 4:50 A.M. yesterday by policemen who acted on orders of Tomas Jacome, Governor of the Province of Panama.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Mrs. John F. Kennedy returned to Washington tonight after a Florida visit extended to a week to help her recover from a persistent but minor sinus infection.
HIGHLAND, Ill., March 1 (AP) Dr. S.A. Kayar, a physician who informed his patients in a January newspaper announcement that he had an incurable cancer, died of the illness today. He was 41 years old.
BOSTON, March 1 Middle Atlantic ports were granted time today to appeal against rail freight-rate parity with northern ports.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the fighting in South Vietnam could end overnight if Communist nations would leave that country alone.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) President Kennedy nominated three admirals for promotion today.
ENCINO, Calif., March 1 Roscoe Ates, the comedian, died here today of lung cancer at West Valley Community Hospital. He was 67 years old.
Drug and chemical company executives were told yesterday that President Kennedy's liberal trade proposals would increase their share of world markets.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 1 This old Colonial town, once an important stop on the King's Highway, moved today to preserve its past.
The pilot and passengers of a plane that took off directly behind the American Airlines Astrojet that crashed yesterday said the jet had dived into Jamaica Bay and disintegrated before catching fire.
RANGOON, Burma, Friday, March 2 The Burmese Army took over the country in a bloodless coup early today.
WASHINGTON, March 1 The House Armed Services Committee has voted to "direct" the Pentagon to proceed with Air Force proposals for production of the controversial B-70 supersonic bomber.

Jack P. Schleifer and Edward Gettinger, realty investors heading a syndicate, have taken title to Carteret Arms, a fifteen-story apartment building at 333 West State Street in Trenton. The seller was the Rutgers Construction Company, which erected the building in 1960.

KAMPALA, Uganda, March 1 (Reuters) Tribal dancers whirled and leaped for four hours here today as this East African protectorate celebrated the advent of internal selfgovernment after seventy-two years of British rule.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Following are excerpts from the State Department's transcript of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dean Rusk:
The Transport Workers Union went on strike yesterday against the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines after the company had laid off twenty-nine employes.
Trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday was moderate, and there were about as many price gains as losses.
Production of automobiles in this country so far in 1962 is about 50 per cent above the 1961 level.
To our regret, President Kennedy reportedly has decided it is necessary to resume nuclear weapons tests in the atmosphere.

Andy Hebenton, a right wing for the New York Rangers, received a watch from his team yesterday for having played in 497 consecutive games over the last seven seasons. The presentation was made during a luncheon at Leone's.
"General Seeger" closed after its second performance last night at the Lyceum Theatre. Ann Harding and George C. Scott were starred in the Ira Levin drama.
Pete Hamill of The New York Post and Lewis H. Lapham of The New York Herald Tribune were honored yesterday by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 1 Military activity in Laos has been considerably reduced in the last two weeks, an informed United States military source said here today.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 1 John Crosby, son of a co-founder of the parent firm of General Mills, Inc., and himself former president of the predecessor firm, died here today. He was 94 years old.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 1 Urho Kekkonen began his second six-year term as President today with a plea to all Finns to avoid saying or doing anything that might complicate Finnish-Soviet relations.

THE winning play in the deal shown today is the- matically the same as in a deal played in England last fall by Sam Fry Jr., of New York, selected by Kenneth Konstam of The Sunday Times of London as the bestplayed hand of the year.
The problem was how to succeed in getting tickets for the astronaut, to the sell-out musical "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" It took four day's to solve it.

WASHINGTON, March 1, Federal programs for peanuts and peanut butter are costing the Government in price supports almost as much as construction subsidies for the nation's "fourth arm of defense the merchant marine," Edwin M. Hood, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said today.
TEANECK, N.J., March 1 Five hundred seniors in Teaneck High School who have endured, tolerated or enjoyed Shakespeare in type for three years saw his work on stage this morning.

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's ruling Congress party maintained an overwhelming majority in Parliament as the counting of votes in India's elections continued today, but its strength in eight of the country's fifteen state legislatures was reduced.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 1 (AP) A fragment of an Atlas rocket found on a South African farm was identified here today as a chunk from the booster that lofted Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. into orbit.

MEXICO CITY, March 1 Mrs. Nancy Oakes von Hoyningen-Huene, daughter of Eunice Lady Oakes of Dale House, Nassau, the Bahamas, and the late Sir Harry Oakes, was married here this afternoon to Patrick Tritton, a British importer of typewriters and fire-fighting equipment.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) President Kennedy announced today his selection of fifteen citizens to be members of the General Arvisory Committee of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.
Cotton futures were steady to 35 cents a bale up on the New York Cotton Exchange.

In music as in everything else these days changes come fast. Works that were written only a half-dozen years ago seem to lie in the distant past and quickly acquire new perspectives. So it appeared last night at the Composers' Showcase in the Museum of Modern Art, where the most recent music dated from 1957 and one work went back as far as 1950.

The Small Business Administration is questioning four of the ten investments Midland Capital Corporation has made in companies under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board took on a new Solomon's role today in allocating work assignments between groups of employes competing for the same jobs.
Eastern Air Lines has proposed sharply reduced coach excursion fares between major Northern cities and Florida from April 30 through Dec. 14.

In an effort to avert another Congo the United Nations General Assembly just before adjournment set up a five-man commission to oversee preparations for the independence of the Congo's neighbor, the Belgian trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi. The Assembly specifically approved retention of Belgian personnel after independence if necessary. Furthermore, a U.N. commission that supervised recent elections in the territory had only praise for Belgian cooperation.
CHICAGO, March 1 Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy handed down today his final judgment in the Government's thirteenyear-old antitrust suit against E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company sold $7,306,578,000 in life insurance last year, for a 5 per cent gain over policies sold in 1960, according to the annual report, released yesterday. Frederic ...
An implication that Republicans were trying to seize court jobs in legislating changes in New York City courts caused a clash yesterday at a public hearing by a joint legislative committee.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 28 Societe Minire du Becke, the Belgian diamond-mining company that provides revenue for the South Kasai region, is prepared to give a full accounting on demand to the central Government of the Congo.

The chairman of the executive committee of the Cities Service Company, Mr. Jones, was a close friend and frequent golfing and quail-shooting companion of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Mr. Jones was 70 years old and lived at 1 Sutton Place South.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)? A Federal District judge ruled today that both Trans World Airlines and United Airlines were liable for a collision of two airliners over the Grand Canyon on June 30, 1956. The crash killed 128 persons.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 1 President Mohammad Ayub khan gave Pakistan a new Constitution tonight.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 1 (UPI) Former Chief Justice Eduardo Read Barreras has resigned from the seven-member Dominican junta for personal reasons, it was announced today.
LONDON, March 1 The police admitted today that Bobbies threw some demonstrators into Trafalgar Square's fountains last fall.
Broad buying of prime-risk, fixed-income securities by pension funds, banks and other investing institutions carried the bond market to higher prices all along the line yesterday.
The seven-story apartment house at 38-25 Parsons Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the Ropar Realty Corporation to an investing client of Martin Teichman, lawyer.

Committee members have been announced for a "Tribute to George Gershwin" on March 18. The concert at Carnegie Hall will feature the Symphony of the Air, under the direction of Paul Taubman, with stars of music, stage and screen.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, March 1 Dr. Hastings K. Banda, the Nyasaland African political leader, declared today that federation of this British protectorate with Rhodesia "is dead and everyone knows it."
NORWALK, Conn., March 1 The city hall building committee has approved preliminary plans for a new city hall to be built in Veterans Memorial Park.
Mrs. Viola Spiess Flannery Nadelman, widow of Elie Nadelman, noted sculptor, died Tuesday in her home at 4715 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, at the age of 84.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 1 (AP) Joseph Macklar Tone of West Hartford, long-time state official, died today at Hartford Hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) President Kennedy's plan to give Federal scholarships to medical and dental students was rejected today by the House Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 1 If President Kennedy's proposed program of Federal aid to stamp out certain diseases goes into operation it will be extended to measles when an effective vaccine is found and approved. Such approval is likely this year.
PITTSBURGH, March 1 (AP) The steel negotiations' "selfimposed" target date for reaching agreement on a contract came and went today with no agreement.

THE Esterhazy Orchestra, which made its debut here in January, last night presented a second successful concert at Town Hall. True to the purposes suggested by its name, the ensemble devoted itself chiefly to music of and near Haydn.
United States Smelting Refing and Mining Company faces the threat of a proxy fight as the result of a notice filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington yesterday.
New York County Republicans turned over the county leadership last night to Joseph A. Gimma, a 54-year-old stockbroker, and Vincent F. Albano Jr., a 47-year-old bank vice president.

MIAMI, March 1 Beau Purple refused to fade in the stretch today. Instead, Jack Dreyfus' 5year-old horse sped away from the rest of the field and won today's feature race by ten lengths. The result was hardly a surprise: Beau Purple was the even-money favorite with the 16,700 fans.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 1 (AP) Duke, Clemson, Wake Forest and South Carolina won first-round games today in the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.
WHEN cold weather hits New York, one of the first victims is fashion. Unless it is snowing or sleeting, most women brave the bitter wind with bare heads, unprotected ankles and miserable expressions.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 1 A delicate Mozart melody echoed through a simulated drawing room in the Ludlum Elementary School here yesterday as a group of pupils prepared for a concert of eighteenth-century music.

THE tragedy and celebration that marked yester day in New York was covered with tact and thoroughness by many branches of the broadcasting industry. For set owners at home and for reporters speaking over the air the morning posed an exacting emotional transition from sorrow over the crash of the jet airliner to cheers for Marine Corps Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr.
LONDON, March 1 Prices of equities continued their aimless drift on the stock market here today.

SOMERS, N.Y., March 1 Elissa Bludau's sporting class elephant Old Bet won "Best of Show" in a breeze this morning. It outclassed 250 other airborne entries in the seventeenth annual Somers Kite Day feature at Primrose Grammar School.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 Some years ago there appeared a book entitled "Lucky to Be a Yankee." With Joe DiMaggio the author, it made some interesting reading.
WASHINGTON, March 1 The Roman Catholic Church began a national campaign today to discourage participation in extreme anti-Communist movements such as the John Birch Society.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 1 (UPI) All the city schools in Chattanooga, the last major city in Tennessee without any desegregation, today were ordered desegregated by 1968 by United States District Judge Frank Wilson.
WASHINGTON, March 1 A British nuclear device was tested today in an underground explosion at the atomic proving grounds in Nevada.

BAINBRIDGE, Ga., March 1 A bass fisherman is much like a trout fanatic, a salmon pursuer or a blue fish chaser. He will travel long distances, endure discomforts that would shrivel a lesser man, neglect his family and job and expend his money on lures by the gross.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 (AP) The United States District Court today gave the trustees of the New Haven Railroad permission to lease new passenger cars from the Port of New York Authority.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 1 (UPI) A Negro began work today as a section head in the State Employment Security Division. It was the first time a Negro had held a position at this level in Arkansas.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 Miss Edna V. Moffett, Professor Emeritus of History at Wellesley College, died last night in the Mount Auburn Hospital. She was 92 years old.
Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, has announced the promotion of four Barnard faculty members to the rank of full professor. The appointments are effective on July 1.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 1 Dr. Grenelle B. Tompkins, who practiced medicine in Flemington for more than half a century, died Tuesday morning in the Hunterdon Medical Center at the age of 79.

WASHINGTON, March 1 President Kennedy urged Congress today to authorize a $1,000,000,000 expansion of Federal recreational areas over eight years. Half the cost would be financed by repayable Treasury loans.
WHEN William Henry McKeon became a law clerk, he rearranged on his own the entire office of his employe, George M. Michaels.
WASHINGTON, March 1 The Senate quickly approved a stop-gap $2,000,000,000 increase in the national debt limit today and sent the bill to the White House.

RICHMOND, Va., March 1 (AP) Favored West Virginia scored a 97-75 first-round victory over Richmond tonight in the Southern Conference basketball tournament. Rod Thorn led the Mountaineers with 30 points.
Two hundred girls from Prospect Heights High School, Brooklyn, who had been refused permission to see the Glenn parade, created a spectacle of their own yesterday.

Mrs. Eloise C. Bishop Fiorillo, a sculptor and textile designer, died Tuesday in the Harkness Pavilion at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 40. She was the wife of Joaquin Fiorillo, director of development for the Protestant Council of New York, and lived at 272 East Tenth Street.
A West Side landlord was fined $500 in Housing Court yesterday for violations in a rooming house he said he had managed for only three months.

BALTIMORE, March 1 (AP) The National Football League's attorney, Gerhard A. Gesell, asked today exactly what markets the American Football League was contending that the N.F.L. had tried to monopolize.

Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., and its subsidiary had a consolidated net income last year of $3,033,867, equal to 43 cents a share, compared with $2,723,070, or 39 cents a share, in 1960, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
A collection of about fifteen works by the late Arshile Gorky were reported last night to have been lost in the crash of the jet airliner in Jamaica Bay.
Despite the counter-attraction of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., the stock market yesterday managed both modest volume and a more than modest gain. By the time the Sanitation ...
President Kennedy's report to the American people on nuclear-weapons testing and disarmament will be carried live tonight on radio and television.

Mildred G. Johnson, president of the Air Shopping Service Corporation at 502 East Seventy-ninth Street and the first stewardess of Eastern Air Lines, died Tuesday in French Hospital after a brief illness. Her age was 55. She lived at 208 East Ninety-sixth Street.

TOKYO, Friday, March 2 (AP) Masayoshi Ohira, chief Cabinet Secretary, said today the United States had been in contact with Japan on the question of resuming atmospherical nuclear tests in the Pacific.
SALISBURY, N.C., March 1 (AP)?Thirteen of seventeen Livingstone College students were convicted here today of trespass charges stemming from demonstrations against segregation at two movie theatres.
WASHINGTON, March 1?A suggestion that access to Berlin be placed under the administration of an international authority was put forth by Secretary of State Dean Rusk...

IF "3 X 3" is "an evening of comedy," as it describes itself, humor has not outgrown its swaddling clothes. "3 X 3" is even bad at arithmetic. If you were to assemble all the risible moments in each of the three one-actors presented last night at the Maidman and by an act of generosity united them into one piece, you would not have a solidly funny playlet.
Production of lumber in the nation totaled 225,320,000 board feet in the week ended Saturday, according to reports received from regional associations.

TRIALS that will lead to a defender of the America's Cup will not begin until early in June, but in a sense the strug- gle for Columbia has been going on since last spring. It started when Paul V. Shields, ...
Bank clearings in the twentysix leading cities of the nation totaled $25,576,360,000 in the holiday week ended Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1 The United Nations announced tonight the resignation of the highest-ranking Soviet member of the Secretariat, Georgi P. Arkadyev, Under Secretary for Political and Security Council Affairs. He is resigning for personal reasons, including the illness of his wife, and will return to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March (AP) The Federal Reserve System announced today it had purchased the equivalent of $50,000,000 in French francs for possible future use in defending the dollar.
The Georgia State Highway Authority borrowed $35,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance road construction.
PARIS, March 1 The final round of negotiations for peace in Algeria may be long and initially secret instead of short and formal as originally expected, French sources said today.

Bayside's high-flying Commodores, who survived the first round by their hectic, last-second victory over Jamaica last Tuesday, romped to a 63-53 triumph over Richmond Hill to gain the quarter-finals yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
Yesterday's jet crash at Idlewild, taking ninety-five lives, was the worst involving a single United States commercial airliner and the fifth worst air disaster in history.

Fist fights in the cheering sections were almost as common as free throws on the court at Madison Square Garden last night while New York University was routing Manhattan College, 88 73, in basketball.

BOSTON, March 1 (UPI) Ron Murphy's second-period score and the third-period goaltending of Glen Hall tonight led the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-4 victory and ran the Boston Bruins' string to sixteen games without a victory.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that there has been "no rush" of applications for retirement by foreign service officers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 1 Dr. Edward L. Siegel of this city, assistant chief psychologist at the Veterans Administration Hospital here, died Tuesday of a heart attack in the Hospital of the Good Shepherd. He was 43 years old.
Clear away the show titles the credits, the program announcements and all the other nonentertainment clutter inserted by television networks between programs.

The members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra issued a statement yesterday in support of Lester Salomon the French-horn player whose dismissal from the orchestra was substained on Tuesday by Theodore W. Kheel, the arbitrator appointed to weigh the issues by Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg.
Ninety-five persons were killed yesterday in a jet airliner crash in Jamaica Bay. It was the highest toll involving a single commercial airplane in the nation's history.
Despite an increase in sales last year, net income of Texas Instruments, Inc., fell to $9,446,386 from $15,488,209 in 1960, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 1 New College, a non-sectarian, non-segregated, co-educational college being built here, announced today an unrestricted gift of $1,000,000. It was made by Mr. and Mrs. Honore Palmer of Sarasota.
WASHINGTON, March 1 The United States will make another effort this spring to satisfy its European allies' desires for more responsibility over nuclear weapons on their territory.
Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., the man who found a lonesome privacy in space, had a hard time finding privacy in New York yesterday.

Events today: "Macbeth," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Fordham University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:40; Mitchell Andrews, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Netherlands Chamber Choir, Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30.
Time, height and distance will be the targets again tonight for the spiked-shoe sharpshooters who have rewritten so much of the record book during this eventful indoor track and field campaign.

Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. said yesterday that he and his fellow astronauts were puzzled over the cause of the air crash in which ninety-five persons were killed in Jamaica Bay shortly before the astronauts' arrival for the city's ticker-tape welcome.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 Richard M. Nixon received a blast from a rival and was left with only one competitor today for the Republican nomination for Governor.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 Faustino Harrison became President today of Uruguay's nine-man executive body, the National Council of Government. He succeeded Eduardo Victor Haedo.
MIAMI, March 1 Bob Lippincott of Riverton, N.J., today became the second member of his boat-building family to win a major sailing championship on Biscayne Bay within a week. But he just made it.
UTICA, N.Y., March 1 (AP) A four-week trial of the Aluminum Company of America and the Rome Cable Corporation on antitrust charges ended today. But a decision was several months off.

GENEVA, March 1?The Nobel Foundation, which itself awards a peace prize, was named today as the first recipient of the annual peace prize of the newly created Balzan Foundation. The prize carries a cash award of 1,000,000 Swiss francs ($232,500).
WASHINGTON, March 1 Rail and truck freight loadings last week were substantially above year-ago levels, but were behind volumes recorded for the preceding week of this year.
Mrs. John H. Glenn Jr. sat at the colonel's side through New York's roaring welcome to him yesterday, confetti in the veil of her hat, a bouquet of American Beauty roses in her lap.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Friday, March 2 South Vietnamese fighter planes and United States Army helicopters, grounded since the assassination attempt on President Ngo Dinh Diem Tuesday, were allowed to return to combat action this morning.

The people of New York came by the millions yesterday to do honor to Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. with a shrieking, screaming, cheering, adoring welcome that verged on the hysterical, and sometimes on the dangerous.
The World Trade Center proposed for the lower West Side of Manhattan was opposed yesterday in a broad indictment issued by the Downtown West Businessmen's Association.
The National Broadcasting Company has decided to schedule Jack Paar's new hour-long weekly television show on Fridays from 10 to 11 P.M. The program is expected to make its debut Sept. 14 or 21.
WARSAW, March 1 John Moors Cabot, the new United States Ambassador to Poland, resumed today the United States' secret diplomatic discussions with Communist China, now in their eighth year.
GEORGE BERNARD SHAW said that he was "too industrious by acquired habit to stop working. I work as my father drank."

Business loans at major New York commercial banks fell by $7,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the week of 1961 there was a gain of $56,000,000.
The Southern California Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in 1961 for revenues and sales, power generation and peak demand, additions to generating capacity and net income.
Millions of dollars in insurance claims and years of litigation over damages are expected to arise from yesterday's airliner crash in Jamaica Bay.
Two members of the cast in last night's Metropolitan Opera performance of "Turandot" were new to their roles this season. Teresa Stratas sang the Liu, and William Wildermann appeared as Timur.
Sonny Liston, who once said he would be willing to fight Floyd Patterson "for nothing," now says he wants a lot more than that. But he may end up holding the punching bag.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) Grain futures added small gains on the Board of Trade today, although pressure was increasing at the close in spots.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 26 The desert kingdom of Jordan is turning to Kuwait, one of the smallest and richest of Arab states, in hopes of financing an ambitious new development program.

William H. McKeon, a 41year-old Auburn, N.Y., lawyer, was chosen yesterday to replace Michael H. Prendergast of Haverstraw as Democratic state chairman. He was immediately confronted with a legal challenge to the validity of his election.
WASHINGTON, March 1 President Kennedy will address the nation tomorrow night on "nuclear testing and disarmament," the White House announced today.

Ernest Lappano, Assistant District Attorney of New York County, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 4915 Broadway.
MACON, Ga., March 1 (AP) Federal Judge W.A. Bootle struck down today all Georgia laws or parts of laws that enable bus companies to practice racial segregation on buses.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) The civilian space agency fired early this evening a sodium vapor cloud visible for hundreds of miles along the Eastern seaboard.

ALBANY, March 1 The Court of Appeals held today that a drunken driving suspect could not escape the penalty for refusing the take a blood test just because his request to consult a lawyer first was denied.

Despite a spate of snowy and rainy days, sales by the major department stores in the metropolitan area last month were 3 per cent ahead of figures for February, 1961. This was indicated by a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 The Screen Actors Guild has come to the assistance of producers who have been grumbling privately about the unprofessional habits of some stars.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1 Foreign Minister Koca Popovic will fly to Cairo tomorrow for talks with Egyptian officials.

Mansfield Industries, Inc., Chicago manufacturer of photographic equipment, yesterday signed an agreement to acquire the Argus Cameras division of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., effective April 29. Sylvania is a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronic Corporation.
President Kennedy called upon the Federal Aviation Agency yesterday to do all it could to prevent a repetition of the airliner disaster near Idlewild.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 1 Dean Acheson, former United States Secretary of State, presented today to the International Court of Justice the contention of Cambodia that a piece of her territory around an old temple has been illegally occupied by Thailand.

A former detective and a former patrolman were indicted here yesterday on charges of attempting to shake down an ex-convict. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said the policemen had demanded $500 from the man in exchange for not "framing" him and arresting him on a charge of possessing burglars' tools.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, offered the Senate today what he called an "affirmative, conservative legislative program."

LIMA, Peru, March 1 The Government began sending relief supplies and personnel today to the village of Conchucos, which was partly buried by a mud slide yesterday. Sixty persons were reported dead or missing in the avalanche, which followed a period of heavy rain. Conchucos is a typical Andean farming community on the western slope of the mountains, 125 miles east of Chimbote, Peru's steel center.
The election of Wayne M. Hoffman, vice president for sales of the New York Central Railroad, to the new position of executive vice president, was announced yesterday by Alfred E. Perlman, president.

The lure for the majority of women who work is neither the glamour nor the psychological need. The basic reason is economic necessity, according to Mrs. Esther Peterson, Assistant Secretary of Labor and Director of the Women's Bureau in Washington.

WASHINGTON, March 1 The opposition expressed in industry to an active role by government in collective bargaining is traceable only in part to bitter political experience. There are also purely selfish reasons to account for the opposition. For example:
A National Association of Independent Schools with more than 700 members in forty states was formed here yesterday by the merger of two mayor national organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation and other Government investigators are conducting an inquiry into reported mishandling of warehouse supplies owned by the Public Health Service.

The small apartment in a modern housing development is home to many New Yorkers. However, such an apartment, because its layout is similar to others, tends to have an impersonal quality. Dolores Engle, an interior designer, has avoided this pitfall by decorating ...
MEMBERS of the Vacation Exchange Club are able to cut a major vacation expense. They swap homes.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Following are excerpts from the booklet "Communism: Threat to Freedom" by the Rev. John F. Cronin, which was published today by the National Catholic Welfare Conference:
ROME, March 1 George Marek, vice president and general manager of RCA Victor of America, opened a $500,000 studio building near here today that "could possibly become the recording center of Europe."

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) Senator George A. Smathers introduced a bill today calling for construction of a monument at Cape Canaveral, Fla., to commemorate the United States' first manned orbital flight.

President Kennedy's message to Congress on the nation's health needs is a minimal program to cope with the opportunities and problems posed, respectively, by rapid advances in medical science and by the socio-economic evolution of America's population.
Off Broadway expressed annoyance, and in one instance anger, yesterday over the charge by a prominent Broadway producer that its prices were too high.
The introduction of coinoperated dry-cleaning establishments here would bring in $50,000,000 in new business, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals was told yesterday at a public hearing.

MACAO, Feb. 26 This tiny Portuguese settlement's pattern of successful coexistence with the neighboring colossus of Communist China is exemplified in the person of a multimillionaire gold trader named Ho Yin, celebrated here as a "Communist capitalist," or vice versa. Mr. Ho represents the Chinese...
For the second straight year, Jerry Lucas of Ohio State yesterday was named the college basketball player of the year by The Associated Press.
MACON, Ga., March 2 (UPI) Negroes kept bus boycotts in force here and at industrial Albany, Ga., today despite announced desegregation of buses here and employment of a Negro bus driver at Albany.

MIAMI, March 2 As the result of a double negative, Mrs Moody Jolley's Ridan may be the favorite in the Flamingo Stakes tomorrow. The speedy son of Nantallah was the overnight choice at 9 5 in the illustrious test because of the nolo contendere status of Sir Gaylord and Decidedly.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Aida" at 2 P.M, and "Orfeo ed Euridice" at 8; New York Philharmonic, Andre Kostelanetz, conductor, Ogden Nash, narrator, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Odetta, folk singer, Town Hall, 8:30; Mikulas Grosz, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; American Brass Ensemble, Judson Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey and a delegation from Camden asked the Navy today to award a contract for a nuclear frigate to the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden. The ship is expected to cost more than $50,000,000.
Pilots on Pan American World Airways have called off a strike scheduled to start Tuesday and have resumed contract talks with the company.
NEW HAVEN, March 2 Yale scored a 81-66 victory over Dartmouth tonight and won its first Ivy League basketball crown in five years.

JUGTOWN, N.C., March 2 (UPI) Mrs. Juliana Royster Busbee, whose discovery of an unusual orange pie plate at a county fair in 1917 led to the revival of the craft of pottery making in this state, died today at her log cabin home, She was 85 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 2 A process patented this week makes possible a wide variety of plastic foam articles including ice buckets, toys, building insulation, life pre servers, surfboards and even boats.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) An increase of $225,000,000 in the cost of building its long-range missile bases came as no surprise, the Air Force said today, because in such trail-blazing efforts the cost is hard to estimate.

IF things looked different yesterday afternoon at the New York Philharmonic concert, they were. Leopold Stokowski was conducting, and when he is on the podium it is anybody's guess as to how the orchestra will be arranged.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 28 Israel's plans for diverting waters of the Jordan to the Negev, her semi-desert southern region, have again evoked Arab counter-moves.
A sharp rise in cocoa futures prices on the New York Cocoa Exchange was the highlight of commodities trading here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 2 President Kennedy said tonight he had ordered a resumption of nuclear tests in the atmosphere in late April unless the Soviet Union agreed in the interim to an iron-clad treaty banning all tests.

SUNDAY'S roast, served a second time in the week that follows, may get a favor able reception. But if it appears a third time, it is not likely to be popular unless it has been dressed up in some manner.

BERLIN, March 2 Allied officials believe that the Soviet action barring the United States commandant here from entering East Berlin presages an intensified campaign against the, West's position in Berlin.
Protestant women in 145 countries will mark the seventysixth annual World Day of Prayer next Friday. This year's theme is "For God So Loved the World."
The Air Force has awarded four contracts totaling $31,537,261 to the Curtiss-Wright Corporation for the production of R-3350 piston engines and parts and J-65 jet engines.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Three rockets were fired at Wallops Island, Va., at dawn today in a series of tests to measure atmospheric conditions at high altitudes.

HONG KONG, Saturday, March 3 Communist China announced today that the meeting of the National People's Congress scheduled to open Monday had been postponed. Hsinhua, the official Chinese Communist press agency, in announcing the move, gave no new date for the meeting.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) Norman Rothman, 46 years old, of Miami Beach, Fla., one of four men on trial on charges of dealing in bonds from a $12,000,000 Canadian burglary, was acquitted today on an order by the presiding judge.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) A possible revolution in electricity such as lighting whole cities with the aid of harmless bacteria was foreseen today with the unveiling of a radio transmitter powered by bacteria.
An oratorio, said to be the first written espeically for television, will be performed on the American Broadcasting Company network Sunday, April 22.

TODAY'S exhibitions are situated around the two poles of purism and heavily tainted realism. This draws attention to the abyss between two types of artist, and indeed between two types of temperament. Depending on his own temperament, the reader can begin at the beginning or the middle of this column.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 2 County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson today disclosed some details of his proposed Department of County Development, designed to help attract new industry to Nassau County.
CHICAGO, March 2 Dr. Maurice H. Goldblatt, director of the art galleries at the University oP Notre Dame, died today in Michael Reese Hospital here. He was 77 years old.

The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday ordered an investigation to determine whether either the Missouri Pacific Railroad or the Louisville and Nashville Railroad has acquired control of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad in violation of Federal law.

The sixty-fifth birthday of the American composer Henry Cowell, and the fiftieth anniversary of his first concert, will be celebrated by a number of events here this month. The birthday occurs on March 11, and the concert anniversary falls on the next day.

Dr. Sumner Ives, Professor of English at Syracuse University, who wrote a preliminary review praising Webster's Third New Intenational Dictionary, defended "the total dictionary" yesterday. But he conceded that there were grounds for criticism.

The Junior League of New York filled the Grand Ballroom of the Astor last night with music sweet and hot, old and new and music with a Latin beat. The tuneful invasion was the league's eleventh annual Mardi Gras Ball, and its theme was "Times and Tempos."
President Kennedy's message to Congress on conservation showed, as did his similar message a year ago, a fine grasp of the interrelationship of our natural resources.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 2 (AP) Michigan State's freestyle relay team led an assault today on American swimming records in the Big Ten championships.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 2 (UPI) Neil S. McCarthy's Royal Attack enjoyed the favorite's role today as fourteen colts and one filly awaited tomorrow's Santa Anita Derby, the top early-season test for 3-year-olds in the West. If all fifteen start, the gross value will be $152,100.
Governor Rockefeller and Senator Kenneth B. Keating appealed to Republicans last night to put aside quarrels over abstractions and seek solutions to real problems.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 2 (UPI) Wall Doxey Sr., a former United States Senator and Representative from Mississippi, died today of pneumonia at Baptist Hospital. He was 69 years old.

W. Alton Jones, executive committee chairman of the Cities Service Company, was carrying $55,690 in cash and $7,000 in travelers checks when he was killed in the American Airlines jet crash here Thursday. The bills ranged in denominations up to $10,000.

Sir Frank Packer, head of the syndicate that owns the Australian yacht Gretel, will be among those attending a dinner at the New York Yacht Club on May 17, the club announced yesterday through its secretary, W. Mahlon Dickerson.

Dr. Linus C. Pauling, Nobel Prize winner and an outspoken opponent of all nuclear weapons testing, said yesterday he had sent a telegram to President Kennedy that termed any resumption of such tests in the atmosphere by the United States a "monstrous immorality."
Tammany Hall, a political institution virtually as old as the Federal Government, appears to be dead.
Travertine from Italy and marble form a Greek island will embellish an aluminum-andglass office skyscraper about to rise in Baltimore
ESTES PARK, Colo., March 2 (AP) Louis T. Reichers, early aviator and author, died today in his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

HERSHEY, Pa., March 2 (AP) Wilt Chamberlain set a National Basketball Asssociation scoring record of 100 points tonight as the Philadelphia Warriors defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 169 147. The combined score was an association record, too.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 2 The Board of Education last night canceled an election scheduled for March 13 on a $1,360,000 school bond issue.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, advocated tonight increased draft calls and redoubled recruiting drives to keep military manpower at existing levels.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 2 The Government of Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan comfortably survived an opposition motion of censure last night.
Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. spent a relatively quiet afternoon with his family here yesterday following his visit to the United Nations. In the evening he went to the theatre.

Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Sales, Inc., has announced a revision in its pricing schedules for aluminum used in can manufacturing, to align prices "on a more orderly basis covering the complete range of end uses."

Condemnation proceedings by the city against Fifth Avenue Coach Lines will be based on a section of the General Municipal Law that authorizes municipalities to condemn personal property to serve the public purpose.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 2 Richardson Dilworth, former Mayor of Philadelphia, was chosen the Democratic organization's candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Unless there is an unexpected change of view, the Department of Justice will not appeal the final judgment handed down yesterday in the antitrust case against E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2 Powerful elements of the armed forces, the press and political parties are rallying to the support of President Joao Goulart to help make his coming trip to the United States a success.
Bobby Fischer of New York clinched victory yesterday in the twenty-first round of the world interzonel chess tournament in Stockholm, according to a report from the Swedish capital.

The small but ardent group who are pushing for a revival of the operas of Jules Massenet must have had a busy but frustrating time last night. Not one, but two, of his operas were being done "Cendrillon" at Stuyvesant High School and "Werther" at the Manhattan School of Music.

The net earnings of the companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group last year amounted to 187,000,000, or $523,600,000, according to a preliminary estimate made yesterday by the parent concerns. This compares with 177,500,000, or $497,000,000, in 1960.
Edward N. Costikyan, a 37year-old trial lawyer, was elected leader of the New York County Democratic Executive Committee yesterday over the opposition of the party's reform wing.
TOKYO, March 2 Japan's labor unions are preparing for two spring offensives, one against the employers and one against each other.
LONDON, March 2 (AP) James F. Horrabin, creator of Britain's longest-running newspaper comic strip, died today. He was 77 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. had a reception at the United Nations today such as has never been given to a chief of state.
ALBANY, March 2 Governor Rockefeller proposed today the creation of a new state agency to finance the rehabilitation of substandard housing.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2 The Brazilian Government has begun a campaign to attract from Africa European farmers experienced in tropical and irrigation agriculture.

NEW CONCORD, Ohio, March 2 This normally quiet little college town in the rolling hills of eastern Ohio waited impatiently today to give a rousing welcome home tomorrow to its most famous son, Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr.
Mayor Wagner announced last night that the city would act to take over the routes of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines and to acquire by condemnation the facilities needed to operate them.
As President Ayub Khan ended one military dictatorship in Pakistan, General Ne Win reestablished another in Burma.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2 Getting traded from a pennant winner to a hopeless second-division entry can be a jolt to a ballplayer, especially a pitcher. However, take it from Tex Clevenger, making the hop the other way can have its problems, too.
CHESTER, N.J., March 2 Dr. Frank Fritts of Fox Chase Road, lawyer and author, died today at Morristown Memorial Hospital, at the age of 75.
ALGIERS, March 2 Violence erupted in the Casbah today when Moslem snipers fired at French troops from windows and housetops. The soldiers reacted fiercely.

LONDON, March 2 An outstanding feature of an otherwise aimless stock market here today was the strength of oil shares. This followed the announcement by the Royal DutchShell group of markedly improved earnings in the last quarter of 1961.
Tenants at the Osborne apartment house known as the "residential Carnegie Hall" because of the musicians that live there have banded together to purchase it and turn it into a cooperative.
ROME, March 2 Premier Amintore Fanfani pledged his new Center-Left Government tonight to support of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and of European integration.
Michael H. Prendergast fought in Supreme Court yesterday to retain the chairmanship of the State Democratic Committee, which voted him out of office Thursday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 2 A principal purpose of the atmospheric test series authorized by President Kennedy will be to determine the feasibility of using high-altitude nuclear explosions to knock out ballistic missile warheads and to jam enemy radar and radio communications.

AROLLS ROYCE drove up to a converted garage in White Plains on a recent Saturday afternoon. The woman in the back seat left the car and disappeared briefly inside. When she returned she was struggling with a wing chair, which her chauffeur strapped to the roof of the automobile before they drove away.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Saturday, March 3 United States Army helicopters, grounded since Tuesday's attempt by two Vietnamese Air Force pilots to assassinate President Ngo Dinh Diem, carried Vietnamese troops to a minor victory yesterday against Viet Cong Communist forces.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that he expected to propose soon several recreation areas for Eastern states with dense populations.
SETAUKET, L.I., March 2 Pierrepont E. Twitchell, lawyer and Suffolk County civic leader, died here today in his home. His age was 67.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) Willis J. Ballinger, former economics professor and newspaper editorial writer, died here yesterday. He was 60 years old.

The Alleghany Corporation, which usually holds its annual meetings on the first Monday of May, announced yesterday that this year's meeting would be held on April 9. The move cuts to one week the time left for either of the holding company's two large stockholders to buy enough additional stock to acquire majority control.
President Ayub Khan has made good his pledge to terminate his dictatorship and restore representative government in Pakistan.
W.E. Hutton Co. and associates have offered to the public 163,600 common shares of Columbus Plastic Products, Inc., at $15.75 a share.
TULSA, Okla., March 2 (AP) Does ancient maritime law, applicable to sailing ships, storms at sea and piracy, hold for over-ocean flights in private airplanes?
There was little or no talk of merg er between the Pennsylvania Rail road and the New 1893.

Seventeen years ago, man unleashed the power of the atom. He thereby took into his mortal hands the power of self-extinction. Throughout the years that have followed, under three successive Presidents, the United States has sought to banish this weapon from the arsenals of individual nations.
Hould-up men in Manhattan and Staten Island took $6,200 yesterday in two payroll robberies.
Two children playing with matches started a fire yesterday morning in a seven-story apartment house that spread into a four-alarm blaze. It raced for more than an hour.
Because a justice's wife cut her hand with a bread knife, her husband must keep secret his decision in a medical malpractice case and a surgeon must stand trial a second time.

Tom O'Hara, who pushed Jim Beatty in a 4:00.9 mile two weeks ago, proved last night he could force pace as well as follow it. The plucky, 19-year-old Loyola of Chicago sophomore, in front for all eleven laps, took the Frank A. Brennan Columbian mile in 4 minutes 5.6 seconds.
THE New Democratic Club put on a skit in March, 1961, using no stage props other than a pair of dark glasses, a derby, four chairs and a table.

Doubts were expressed after the first Salvation Army Band concert at the Brooklyn Lyceum on a June night seventyfive years ago. "This is merely a fad," said one listener. "The timbrel and the drum are the Army's only instruments."
The seven wives of the seven astronauts gave a seven-minute interview yesterday at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.
For the 1,500,000 weekday bus riders of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines the strike that started Thursday is an inconvenience, but George Maybury finds it a calamity.
Vera Wang, a 12-year-old wisp of an ice ballerina, won the junior ladies singles title in the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships last night.

Met with Representative T. Ashton Thompson and Louisiana Mardi Gras queens; met with White House News Photographers Association an nual awards winners; saw John B. Martin, new Ambassador to the Dominican Republic; met with Congressional leaders; saw Netherlands Foreign Minister Joseph Luns; made radio-TV address on nuclear testing and disarmament.

New details on two forthcoming French films, a pair of current undertakings and a backlog of two completed pictures were given yesterday by Jacques Bar, arriving here from Paris on a talent-scouting trip to the West Coast.
Stockholders in Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., at a special meeting here yesterday approved a merger of Patino into a racetrack subsidiary.

HUNDREDS of bridge teachers might find this deal acceptable as a lesson hand, and hundreds of spectators at the recent world championships played at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel whispered to one another about the "obvious mistake" made by one of the world champions who played the South hand, but there was more behind the play than met the spectators' eyes.
LONDON, Saturday, March 3 Herbert Gunn, former editor of three nationally circulated newspapers and managing editor of two others, died in London early today. His age was 57.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) The director of the Bureau of Mines believes that an Administration proposal to transport coal by pipeline could make it competitive with oil on the East Coast.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 2 (AP) Clemson's Tigers rallied from 12 points back tonight and whipped second-seeded Duke, 77 72, in the semi-finals of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Edward R. Murrow, chief of the United States Information Agency, said today that the Soviet way is the way of required orthodoxy.
Benjamin Weinstein of 2690 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, was released on $2,000 bail in Housing Court yesterday after pleading not guilty in four cases. Trials were scheduled for next Wednesday.
The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 391-93 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-ninth Street, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation, Morris Karp, president.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 Whether they live at high altitudes or on the coastal flats, Peruvians need more meat and dairy products than domestic cattle there can supply.
Mayor Wagner's inability to attend the first public meeting of his Committee on Worker Exploitation led to its sudden adjournment yesterday after a thirty-minute session.
PITTSBURGH, March 2 (AP) Walter Kiesling, a thirty-fiveyear veteran of the National Football League, died at Divine Providence Hospital today after a long illness. He was 58 years old.
The system of perimeter heating of homes, which has become popular along the East Coast, is now being introduced in California.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 2 (AP) Phil Voas of Syracuse and Bill Pfingstag of Navy carried off the first honors today in the opening session of the thirty-fifth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Gymanastics League championship.

WASHINGTON March 2 Average prices in primary markets fell 0.2 per cent to 119.1 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today. Decreases were reported for both farm products and industrial commodities. Prices of processed foods averaged higher.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) Democrats and Republicans disagreed today over the significance of Congressmen's polls of voter sentiment on Presiden Kennedy's proposal for medical care for the aged.

Beauticians and manicurists were told yesterday that they might clean, trim, buff and polish toenails but not cut corns and calluses. This, the Court of Special Sessions ruled, was for podiatrists to do.

Proxies participated in another brisk sparring session yesterday in an effort to arrange a heavyweight title defense by Floyd Patterson against Sonny Liston this year. It was a nodecision exercise, but the champion's negotiators appeared to be well ahead on points.
RANGOON, Burma, March 2 Gen. Ne Win told the Burmese people in a radio broadcast today that the army had taken over the country because of the deteriorating situation in Burma.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 Consistent expansion of stocks of surplus coffee at least until 1965 is foreseen as probable by the Food and Agriculture Organization in view of existing conditions.

In the Chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Isabella Goodrich Breckinridge became the bride of Arthur Myron, Dubow. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving performed the ceremony.

New products for the home owner, ranging from fall-out shelters to pastel aluminum siding, went on display at the New York Coliseum yesterday, as Robert C. Weaver, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, opened the Twentieth Annual National Home Improvement Trade Exposition.
FRANKFURT, Germany, March 2 (AP) "I'm heading out into that Arizona desert to be a bum for two years," Thornton Wilder said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 2 A program that would provide scholarships to physically handicapped men of foreign countries for training in the United States as instructors in watchmaking and precision instrument techniques was announced here today.
The Soviet Union yesterday leased the largest single foreign-government site at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair.
Two major civic groups said yesterday that two proposed "minor" changes in the new City Charter would strip the City Council of some of its broad legislative power.

PARIS, March 2 For seven years, as a result of their defeat by Communist guerrillas in Indochina, French officers have assiduously studied a doctrine which they call "revolutionary warfare." What we are now seeing in Algeria is the first effort by some of these officers to overthrow their Government by the methods they have been teaching in senior military academies.

A new line-up of foreign soccer teams, including Elfsborg, the champion of Sweden last year, is slated to compete in the third annual International Soccer League tournament opening on May 20 with a double-header in Downing Stadium.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 2 (UPI) The Czechoslovak hockey team has decided to play in the world amateur championship here and in Denver, starting on Thursday.

John Kenneth Galbraith. United States Ambassador to India, discusses the problems of foreign aid in "Economic Development in Perspective." Mr. Galbraith shows that the appropriate form of help for countries in different stages of development is not always the same.
LONDON, March 25 While Britain is yielding the rest of her empire, she proclaimed a new colony tonight much of it under Antarctic ice.
The ups and downs of dividends catch the interest of most investors like nothing else except earnings. Lately, most dividend action has been up.

David D. Henry, director of the African Scholarship Program of American Universities, advised the heads of the nation's leading secondary school yesterday against bringing young Africans to their institutions.

The solemn decision to resume American nuclear testing in the atmosphere was announced and fully explained to the American people and to the world last night by President Kennedy; and coupled with it was one more appeal to Premier Khrushchev to agree to a genuine "breakthrough to peace" that could still avert renewal of the nuclear armaments race.
PITTSBURGH, March 2 Steel negotiators broke off talks tonight, dashing hopes for a quick labor accord in the basic steel industry.
PARIS, March 2 The Secret Army Organization's terrorist network in France has been badly mauled in recent weeks by the Government's security drive.
Alaska, the forty-ninth state and the closest United States "real estate" to the Soviet Union, is something of a military stepchild.
New York University virtually clinched its tenth metropolitan collegiate swimming championship in twelve years last night by capturing four of seven events at the Violets' Quigley Pool in the Bronx.

BONN, Germany, March 2 Chancellor Adenauer called home his Ambassador in Moscow, Dr. Hans Kroll, today and made public a telegram ordering him to come to Bonn immediately. The Ambassador is expected to reach here Tuesday.

The sound the Netherlands Chamber Choir of Amsterdam makes is virtually ideal, and the group put that sound to good use in a delectable program in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night. Felix de Nobel is the notable conductor of the ensemble.
Following is a transcript of remarks made by Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. yesterday at the United Nations:
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 Neil Chrisley, playing right field on the junior varsity, rapped out three base hits and drove in three runs today in the New York Mets' first intrasquad game.
Cotton futures were 5 cents off to $1 a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

President Kennedy announced to the nation last night that he had ordered a resumption of atmospheric nuclear tests in late April unless the Soviet Union agreed by then to an iron-clad treaty banning all nuclear tests. In a radio-television address from his White House office, he said that "no single decision of this Administration has been more thoroughly or more thoughtfully weighed."
The bullish sentiment that carried bond prices this week to the highest levels in months was unabated yesterday as the week's trading came to a close.
(UPI) Carry Back today headed a field of eleven entered in the $50,000-added New Orleans Handicap to be run tomorrow at the Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Investors who hold almost $5,100,000,000 of Government bonds maturing in two to ten years have arranged to exchange them for bonds maturing between 1971 and the end of the century, the Treasury reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 2 A spokesman for the transportation industry urged President Kennedy today to resist attempts to block transport mergers.

I have just completed a sixhour discussion of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines strike with members of the Board of Estimate, the Transit Advisory Commission, the Transit Authority, the impartial arbiter of the transit industry and city legal representatives.
Stocks made early gains, faltered and then recovered some of their losses yesterday in a lifeless session of the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was 2,976,970 shares, against 2,960,000 on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, March 2 Sargent Shriver said today that Communists had borrowed the English words Peace Corps to identify groups of their own.

DESPITE the development of safety devices for refrigera tors to protect children trapped inside, a grave hazard still exists. According to the publication "Family Safety," published by the National Safety Council, recent test results announced by the National Bureau of Standards show that many children make no attempt to escape from the inside of a refrigerator.

Once again Northrop Knox of Buffalo and Jimmy Bostwick of Westbury, L.I., will meet in the final of the amateur court tennis championship of the United States. The match will start at 12:30 P.M. at the Racquet and Tennis Club today.
Many Southern Negro women "imported" by New York employment agencies to work as maids are being defrauded and mistreated by the agencies, a conference was told here yesterday.

The Eighteenth National Antiques Show will continue at Madison Square Garden through Thursday, Exhibits range from collections of old coins and buttons to pipe organs and a steam calliope, Eight room settings are on view. Visitors may bring their own antiques to the show for an appraisal, which costs $1. Proceeds will be donated to the National Association for Retarded Children. The show is open from 1 to 11 P. M. daily. Admission is $1.55.
CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI) The American Medical Association reported today on a new drug that reduced high blood pressure in thirty-one of thirtythree severe cases.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the eleven domestic trunk airlines today to put into effect immediately their program to penalize passengers who reserve space and fail to use it. At the same time the C.A.B. authorized penalties for airlines that fail to provide seats to ticket holders.
A call for a new type of downtown apartment house, incorporating features now found only in suburban apartments, has been issued by a Baltimore developer.

F. SCOTT FITZGERALD, SINCLAIR LEWIS and other celebrated Minne-... sota authors have not told us all that can be said about their native state. None can. But Evan Jones sketches a fine lot of history in his excellent contribution to the Rivers of America Series, "The Minnesota."

FORT BRAGG, N.C., March 2 Maj. Gen. Theodore John Conway, commanding general of the Eighty-second Airbone Division, and Mrs. Conway have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Quinn Conway, to Second Lieut. Walter Ray Willms, of the Army. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter James Willms of Columbus, Tex.
NEW DELHI, India, March 2 The Communist party of India appeared today to have improved its position slightly in the country's third general elections.

WASHINGTON, March 2--The Federal Housing Administration announced today an agreement whereby it would refuse to do business with any individual or company that volated a state's non-discrimination law in housing.

Edward S. Silver, District Attorney of Kings County, said yesterday a grand jury was trying to decide whether the Brooklyn Home Builders Institute should be indicted on charges of "untrue and misleading advertising."

The political parties in state and city, and especially the Democrats, are busy installing new chairmen, for one reason or another. To qualify for state or county leadership the requirements are varied and exacting.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Gus O. Basham, chief examiner for the Federal Maritime Commission, today found five United States-flag ship lines "technically" guilty of a rate-making violation but discontinued their case without ordering any penalties.
The prevailing theory emerging yesterday was that failure in the control system had caused the crash of the American Airlines jet here Thursday in which ninety-five persons were killed.

The three-day dock workers' boycott of Panamanian cargo was canceled yesterday after the International Longshoremen's Association was faced with a series of suits for violation of contract and for $400,000 in damage to spoiled fruit.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) A major expansion is under way in housing for the elderly with Government-insured mortgages.
A rental apartment house containing only large suites is rising at 1020 Park Avenue, on the northwest corner of Eightyfifth Street.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) A light selling pressure in the grain futures market developed soon before the close today to trim slight gains but still left prices generally steady to firm.
Mitchell Andrews presented a piano program of first-class interest at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

Wall Street will get a breather next week in new financing. After a number of active weeks topped off last week with $300,000,000 in fixed interest offerings, this week's major debt issues total just over $60,000,000.
New York University cap tured its tenth metropolitan intercollegiate swimming championship in twelve years last night at the Quigley Pool in the Bronx.

The thorny issue of whether or not schools should share with parents their children's IQ's and achievement test scores is highlighted by results of a questionnaire recently circulated to 1,633 teachers by the National Education Association.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 3 Former Senator William F. Knowland broke a long silence today to picture himself as a victim of "the big lie technique" in his unsuccessful campaign for Governor of California in 1958.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 3 Rio's world-famous carnival, in full swing today, revolves essentially around neighborhood "gangs."

SUSPENDED luminous or acoustical style ceilings can now be easily put up by any home handyman. Consisting of translucent plastic sheets or acoustical panels (or a combination of both) suspended in a new type aluminum grid system, these suspended ceilings can be used to cover up a badly cracked or unsightly ceiling, or to lower an exceptional high ceiling.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Dr. Joseph M.A.H. Luns, Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, said today that his talks with United States officials had increased the prospect of direct Dutch-Indonesian talks on the New Guinea dispute.

A provisional list of entries for the Florida International Twelve-Hour Grand Prix to be run at Sebring, Fla., on March 24 shows twenty makes of cars and the top international driving stars ready for the event.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 3 Miss Carolyn Bunting Lewis and Stewart Samuel Richmond plan to be married in June.
Prime office space is at a premium in most of the world's business capitals, but in Japan's large cities the demand for space is so great that it is difficult to find quarters, even in old buildings.
HOUSTON, March 3 The short, happy life of an important scientific theory ended at a conference that concluded here today.
THE 1962 national intercollegiate bridge tournament was completed last week in 180 games played on different college campuses (and the Harvard Yard) throughout the United States.
VIENNA, March 3 The board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency has approved technical assistance programs to be carried out in 1962 in twenty-five member states.

MONTREAL TransCanada Air Lines, which reduced and adjusted its passen ger fares a little over a year ago in the hope of increasing traffic and revenues, has reluctantly concluded that it must raise its economy-class rates in order to cut the spread between first-class and economy fares.
DEMAREST, N.J., March 3 The merits of consolidating Bergen County's seventy municipalities into a comparatively few large cities were debated here this week before the Republican Mayors Association.
VIENNA, March 2 Most of the East European Communist countries have become alarmed at a drastic fall in their birth rates and sharp increases in abortions.

THE rivalry and conflict between Communist China and the Soviet Union constitute one of the most remarkable and most neglected dramas of our day. It was ignored for so long that it seemed to erupt suddenly and, for many skeptical Americans, suspiciously. Others found it a tale so wondrous that they embraced it hopefully and embroidered it romantically.

Cheering, screaming Fordham fans carried Coach John Bach and a junior forward, Bob Melvin, off the court last night after the Rams had defeated their arch rival, Manhattan, 68 66, for the first time in four years.

Along with growing national recognition of the importance of college teachers, their salaries are improving but slowly.

ROCK RAPIDS, Iowa Here in Lyon County in northwestern Iowa, a land of few tourists and more than 370,000 acres of farms, the Rock Rapids Chamber of Commerce is sponsoring a free farm tour to bring "country neighborliness" to any and all visitors who happen by.

Maybe partridges perch in pear trees at Christmas in some places, as the old song says, but in our part of the world they mark the latter part of winter by perching in apple trees. When the countryman is startled by the loud whir of wings beating from his dooryard apple tree toward the woodlot, he knows it is early March. The partridges have been down to the house for an apple bud salad.

Noncallable preferred stock is not so sacred and beyond redemption as some investors may have thought. Last week National Biscuit Company, which since 1898 has had a highly respected issue of cumulative 7 per cent preferred stock, decided to get rid of it despite the "noncallable" adjective attached all these years to its name.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3 Lawrence Peter Berra, the noted outfielder, gazed appreciatively around the spanking new ball park that the Yankees are using as their training grounds this spring. The Bombers have switched locale from sleepy old St. Petersburg to the Gold Coast of Florida, where everything is lush and expensive.

In January, the Labor Department reported last week, the average consumer price level was unchanged for the fourth straight month. That is a remarkable record of stability. Last month, the index for average prices held at 104.5 per cent of the 1957-59 level. In the last year, prices, as measured by this key barometer, have risen only two-thirds of 1 per cent.

MORE than 200 exhibitors of photographic prod ucts, an increase of 15 per cent over last year's total, Will be represented at the thirty-eighth annual Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association trade show and convention, which opens at the Conrad Hilton Hotel in Chicago tomorrow for a week's run.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., The annual pilgrimage of college students to this resort city during spring vacations is expected to take place as usual this year, but under restrictions. Last year, some of the more ebullient students clashed with the police, made news headlines and scarred up so much unfavorable comment among residents and visitors alike that there was a serious question whether the welcome sign would be posted this year.

Charley Barr of St. John's surpassed the pole-vault record by a foot yesterday in the conclusion of the twentieth annual championship of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association at icy Ohio Field in the Bronx.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 4 --A boisterous convention of the California Republican Assembly adopted today a watereddown version of a resolution aimed at Robert H.W. Welch Jr. and his John Birch Society.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 4--Henry F. Tiedemann of Pecksland Road, chairman of Theodore Tiedemann Sons, Inc., of 351 Park Avenue South, New York, a textile manufacturing firm, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 87 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- Thomas Jefferson had his Poplar Forest. Rutherford Hayes had his Spiegel Grove. For Theodore Roosevelt it was Sagamore Hill.
LONDON, Monday, March 5 --A chartered British airliner with 110 persons aboard crashed into a thick jungle swamp yesterday while taking off in a storm at Douala on the west coast of Africa.
MOSCOW, March 4--Premier Khrushchev is expected to open the plenary meeting of the Soviet Communist party's Central Committee tomorrow with a major speech on the reorganization of Soviet agriculture.

The New York Rangers lost again last night to the Detroit Red Wings, the team they must beat to gain the fourth and last berth in the Stanley Cup playoffs. The score of the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden was 4--2.

Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated in a narrow, irregular range last week. At the close of the period on Friday prices were in a mixed range from $1.20 lower to 75 cents higher a bale.
Thieves broke into a National Biscuit Company warehouse in Brooklyn Saturday night or early yesterday and stole a safe with $8,000 to $10,000 in it. They carried it away in a company truck.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 4--Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Doherty have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Eastwood Doherty, to Philip Reed of Oscoda, Mich., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stuart R. Reed of Englewood and Sussex.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4--With an impressively well-defined and atmospheric production of John Webster's "The Duchess of Malfi," the McCarter Theatre Company plunged this week-end into its winter-spring drama series.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 4 (AP)--Comdr. William S. Busik, a former Navy halfback and basketball star, was named by the academy today as director of athletics.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Administration officials don't say it publicly, but they want the ceiling on the national debt removed.
Mutual funds keep popping up in the most unexpected places.
Norwegian shipowners, who are still ordering new tanker tonnage, have been warned by their major customer that they are "gambling" at ever increasing long odds.

The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that restrictions imposed on the speeeh of military personnel to "prevent a mistaken belief that they are stating Government policy" raised no question of civil liberties.
WARSAW, March 4--Poland will watch intently for signs of how the political winds are blowing in Moscow when the Soviet Communist party's Central Committee convenes tomorrow.
BEDFORD, N.Y., March 4-- Jenny Holmes of Scarsdale, N. Y., captured the horsemanship honors of the Sunnyfield Farm indoor horse show today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 --James E. Webb, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said today that a program for training additional astronauts would be ready for announcement in about three weeks.
ALGIERS, Monday, March 5--Almost continuous bomb blasts and gunfire, beginning before dawn, shook Algiers for several hours today.
During the New York City Opera Company's spring season, which begins on March 22, seventeen singers will make their debuts: five sopranos, two mezzos, four tenors, five bassbaritones and one child.
