More than 17,000 airmen of the Alaskan Air Command man the extreme outposts of freedom in North America.
A new Soviet loan has been announced for the African republic of Guinea.

GROTON, Mass., March 4-- The bells of St. John's Chapel at Groton School here rang out today what is believed to be the first half peal ever achieved by a bell-ringing team composed solely of Americans.

Constance Caracciola and Donald Parent, teen-agers representing the Skating Club of New York, won the silver dance trophy yesterday on the final day of the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships at Iceland's rink.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Adoption of an Air Force plan to produce the controversial B-70 bomber in quantity would be a "serious waste of the na tion's resources," Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today.

THE proper safari wardrobe, as numbers of American women traveling in India or Africa are discovering, is sturdy and conservative. The only debatable fashion point is whether to stalk a beast in khaki or jungle green.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., March 4 (AP)--"Hunger strikers" at near-by Fort Bragg will go into the field tomorrow to begin three days of training. They will have no opportunity to eat at the post exchange or civilian restaurants should they want to.

CHICAGO, March 4--The Soviet Union's research and training program in geography has numerous weaknesses, including extremely crude maps, but it has extensive scope and massive support, a group of American geographers reported concerning their visit to the Soviet Union.

MIAMI, March 4--Historians will file this year's Flamingo race in the fileand-forget folder. It was ill-starred all the way even though it once had looked as if it would present the clearest possible picture of the 3-year-old situation. All the favorites for the Kentucky Derby and the other triple crown classics were entered. A month ago it seemed that this one would be recorded as the greatest of all Flamingos.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today he had become convinced that only a health care plan financed under the Social Security system could win the votes to become law. He made the assertion on a television show transcribed for broadcast in his state.

After a whlirwind of changes, the House Ways and Means Committee voted on its proposed revisions in the income tax law last week. While the committee's final version does not repeal stockholder tax credits and exclusions, important concessions to the Kennedy Administration in the foreign tax area did much to bring the bill in line with the President's requests.

New York is a hospitable city, but it can get along without the brand of bus nonoperation supplied by Harry Weinberg, the visiting transit entrepreneur from Texas. In the two weeks since he climbed into the driver's seat in the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines Mr. Weinberg has shown no sense of obligation to riders or employes.
Henry A. Barnes, the city's new Traffic Commissioner, put up a "go slow" sign yesterday --for himself.

One of the world's prime copper-bearing zones and two big mining groups that pry the metal from the soil and rock of Central Africa are crucial elements in the economy of Northern Rhodesia, scene of a new political storm.

DR. EMILE BENOIT has a congenital faith in the possibilities of international cooperation. He explained it in a dedication to a book: "To my mother and to the memory of my father, who, together, first showed me the felicity of a European union."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 4--Ch. Orchid Lane's Ku Lee, a 5-year-old red sable dog, regained the best-of-breed award of the Pekingese Club of America specialty tonight and in the process extended a remarkable string of successes for his owner.
LONDON, March 4--A collection of impressionist pictures and bronzes owned by the late Sir Alexander Korda, the film producer, will be offered for sale at Sotheby's in June, it was announced today.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 4--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Earl Sheffield of Camden and Fisher's Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Sheffield's daughter, Miss Helen Baldwin, to Frank Adair Bonsal Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bonsal of Glyndon, Md.

Paired with Mario Bertok of Yugoslavia in the twenty-second and semi-final round of the world interzonal chess tournament in Stockholm yesterday, Bobby Fischer of New York, who has already clinched first place and has qualified for the challenger's tournament, increased his score to 17-4, according to a report received from the Swedish capital.
The acquisition of the Silver Burdett Company, a textbook publishing concern, by Time, Inc., was announced over the week-end.

The system debt of the Pennsylvania Railroad last year was reduced by nearly $17,900,000, according to the road's report for 1961. At the yearend, the road's long-term debt of leased lines and subsidiary companies amounted to $835,202,185, compared with $853,098,669, a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- The Congressional session goes into its third month this week with little accomplished and slight prospect for much progress in sight.
The weather men at New York International Airport are finding the Tiros satellites a boon in preparing forecasts for airline pilots and operations officials.
Freedom House endorsed yesterday President Kennedy's decision to resume nuclear testing in the atmosphere unless the Soviet Union signs a treaty to prohibit tests before late April.

MARTHA GRAHAM and her superb company opened their season at the Broadway Theatre last night with all flags flying.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands. THE travel bug, an invigo rating although expensive infection that has reached epidemic proportions in the last decade, breeds a hardy virus of its own. Known as shopping fever, this complaint has a telltale symptom, the itch.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 4 (UPI)--Percy A. Brown, of suburban Kingston, a restaurateur, banker and utilities executive, died today at WilkesBarre General Hospital of a stroke. He was 78 years old.
UNION, N.J., March 4--A general-alarm fire swept the main storage shed of the Jaeger Lumber and Supply Company on Morris Avenue here shortly before 8 o'clock tonight.
WHEN a child about the age of 3 discovers the magic of vivid coloring materials, his fascination may turn to frustration if an unwise parent tries to restrict his ideas or to restrain his motions.

FORT MEADE, Md., March 4--The marriage of Miss Dinah Brown, daughter of Lieut. Col. John M. Brown, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Brown of Sillery Bay, Pasadena, to Lawrence Howard Witchel took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Witchel of Hollis, Queens, New York.
Dr. Donald Keene, Professor of Japanese at Columbia University, has been awarded the Kikuchi Kan Prize for distinguished achievement in Japanese letters.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4--Winter fans, perhaps the most critical observers of free baseball, gave tacit approval today to the New York Mets. They couldn't think of anything bad to say.
OSLO, Norway, March 4 (AP)--Bud Werner of Steamboat Springs, Colo., captured men's combined honors in the Holmenkollen Ski Festival today after a third-place finish in the slalom.

CHICAGO, March 4--The National Catholic Conference for Interracial Justice said today there were no ethical grounds by which country clubs and other such groups and fraternities could justify excluding qualified citizens from membership because of race, religion or ethnic origin.

The owners of the 10,800-ton Lebanese flagship Suerte were convinced last week that they had a misnomer on their hands.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 4--Voters of this college town will decide tomorrow between a national director of the John Birch Society and his Unitarian minister in an election for trustee of the public library.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 4--Herman Altschule of 46 Runyon Avenue, Deal, an electrical research engineer died yesterday in the Monmouth Medical Center here after a long illness. He was 48 years old.

CHICO, Calif., March 4--An Air Force attempt to photograph the heavens free of atmosphere failed today when the first huge balloon of the Project Stargazer series burst over the High Sierra.

Ethel Griffies, co-star of "Write Me a Murder," received last night a citation commemorating her eighty-first anniversary as an actress. The citation was presented by the cast of the play at a special performance at the Belasco Theatre for the benefit of the Actor's Fund.
ALBANY, March 4, (AP)-- Federal, state and local spending for public welfare programs in New York State rose 12 percent last year to $534,000,000.

It was a day of titles won and tournament berths decided, of upsets and exciting finishes. But no matter how you bounce it, college basketball's biggest news on a big Saturday was Wisconsin's victory over Ohio State.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Extensive research in nuclear testing in Nevada in the last five months has confirmed the conclusions of United States scientists on the difficulties of detecting clandestine underground explosions of nuclear weapons.
LONDON, March 4--Except for dealings in Courtaulds shares, business on the stock market last week was dull.
Two hundred determined men dressed in loose white jackets and trousers and with colored ribbons around their waists gathered yesterday to push, pull and grapple with one another for seven hours.
The State Commissioner of Housing and Urban Renewal was accused yesterday of failing in his duty to prevent discrimination in urban renewal programs.
BOSTON, March 4 (UPI)-- Red Kelly and George Armstrong scored two goals apiece tonight to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-1 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.
What two small business men in two different sections of New York have to say points up one of the most serious relocation problems in the city's housing and redevelopment programs.
The appointment of Irving Jacobs, who had served as controller of the United Jewish Appeal for the last eleven years, as controller of Yeshiva University was announced yesterday.

Support for the objectives of President Kennedy's trade program, which is aimed mainly at reciprocal tariff reduction with the European Common Market, was announced over the weekend by the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 4--Mrs. Henry P. Davison of Appledore, Mill River Road, and John Stuart Martin of Great Meadows, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mrs. Susan Martin Henry, to B. Danforth Ely. He is the son of Mrs. Alfred Ely of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Mr. Ely.
State Senator MacNeil Mitchell said yesterday that the state would take back authority over New York's rent control laws if the city administration failed to administer them responsibly.
Two members of the Senate Judiciary Committee expressed different views yesterday on the desirability of easing the Federal ban on wiretapping.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)--Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York., proposed today that a high-level agency be created to coordinate all trade matters. Mr. Keating said such an agency would assist Americans in international trade.

Hearings on the proposed postal rate increase are scheduled to get under way tomorrow before the Senate Post Office Committee, and the Senators would do well to brace themselves for some stormy sessions.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 4 --President Ngo Dinh Diem told the nation today that the South Vietnamese Air Force had his confidence despite the "isolated action of a few insane traitors" who bombed his palace last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The chief United States disarmament official said today that his Government and that of Britain were not now willing to accept any less extensive inspection on Soviet territory than previously envisaged for a treaty prohibiting tests of nuclear weapons.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 4 (AP)--Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, and East Germany's President, Walter Ulbricht, opened the Leipzig Industrial Fair today.
The State Department hopes to broaden its cultural exchange activities this year with a plan to help support performers from abroad who want to make nonprofit tours of the United States.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 4--Some 120 volunteers moved the 123 residents of the Daughters of Israel Pleasant Valley Home to new quarters here today.

THE conversion of radio stations WINS and WHN to the so-called "good music" format attests to the decline in rock 'n' roll that has been going on for some time. While a softer and more sophisticated form of rock 'n' roll appears likely to become a lasting part of popular music, there is hardly any question that the peak of the fad has passed.

Widespread concern about budget changes proposed by the Wagner administration through Charter amendments now before the Legislature led yesterday to the calling of a Senate hearing on the question here this week.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 4--Uneasiness is developing here over indications that the Government of Prime Minister Cheddi Jagan is taking steps to develop trade with the Communist bloc.
BOGOR, Indonesia, March 4 (UPI)--President Sukarno met today with his top military and government officials and announced he would carry out a major shuffle of his Cabinet in the "immediate future."
LEBANON, Pa., March 4-- Roberto Haberman, a founder of the Mexican Federation of Labor, died Friday in the Veterans Administration Hospital here at the age of 79.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 4 (AP)--Dr. Arthur H. Compton, the physicist, was reported in critical condition here today after having suffered a stroke late yesterday.

Wilt Chamberlain, who scored 100 points against the New York Knickerbockers Friday night in Hershey, Pa., didn't come close to that total yesterday. He did manage to make 58 points, however, as he and the other Philadelphia Warriors beat the Knicks, 129--128, at Madison Square Garden.
Three men were killed early yesterday in three separate highway accidents in Queens. Nine persons were injured in one of the accidents and two were injured in another.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 4 (AP)--The Government of Prince Boun Oum, feeling a pinch caused by the United States' suspension of aid, has borrowed 300,000,000 kip ($3,750,000) from the National Bank to meet monthly expenditures, informed sources said today.

Lucille Ball will star in a new filmed comedy series to be televised next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The program will appear on Mondays from 8:30 to 9 P.M. The executive producer will be Desi Arnaz, the comedienne's former husband, who co-starred with her in "I Love Lucy."
A ten-hour sitdown protest against the United States' decision to resume atmospheric nuclear testing has been planned for today at the headquarters here of the Atomic Energy Commission.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 (AP)--Norway's 20year-old Olympic champion, Peder Lunde Jr., won the second heat by ninety seconds today in the Flying Dutchman Class world sailing championship.

THE Metropolitan Opera pays its respects to Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice" every so often. This is as it should be in the case of a work of such stature and beauty, even though its particular eighteenth-century style does not recommend it to audiences with a seemingly conditioned and insatiable appetite for Verdi and Puccini.

BOSTON, March 4 (AP)-- The Boston Celtics dissipated a 124-point lead, fell behind by as much as 14, then rallied today to defeat the St. Louis Hawks, 123--120, in a National Basketball Association game.
BALTIMORE, March 4-- Baltimore has been selected as the shipping point of a complete steel mill to be sent piecemeal to Turkey over a twoyear period starting in April.
The merger of the privately controlled University of Buffalo with the State University of New York is expected to become final this week, but the Buffalo officials are not happy.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner both appear to regard housing and rent control as a major issue for this fall's state election campaign. They are in active competition now to obtain the political credit for recognizing the evils of the present situation and sponsoring programs to ameliorate it.

PARIS, March 4--Democracies, as we know from ancient Athens, are ungrateful institutions and the more vibrant their leaders, the more sharply they are attacked. We have only to remember the vivid criticisms of George Washington during his second term or the alacrity with which the English people dismissed Churchill after Germany's defeat.

There is always a poignant story behind a "compassionate" transfer for Armed Forces personnel. Corporal John Casey's story is no exception. John, 21, was stationed at Fort Benning, Ga. His father's heart condition turned critical. Doctors felt it important that John be stationed closer to home.

A thirty-five-ton floating derrick will be used today in an effort to recover the instrumentladen cockpit section of the Boeing 707 jet that plunged into Jamaica Bay on Thursday, killing all ninety-five persons aboard.

The British have now announced a completely redesigned Constitution for Northern Rhodesia. The protectorate is one of the three parts of the Central African Federation: Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland are the others.

Lovely sounds, handsomely shaped in the service of superlative music: there is as good a description as anyone could desire for what went on at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Saturday night. The occasion was the first of the spring "Musica Aeterna" series, with Frederic Waldman conducting his fine little orchestra, and Mieczyslaw Horszowski on hand to play two Mozart piano concertos.
La Salle Academy defeated Holy Cross, 47--43, yesterday to gain the Catholic High School Athletic Association basketball championship before a crowd of 5,800 at the St. John's University gymnasium.
Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson disclosed yesterday that he would like to be the Democratic candidate for Queens County Surrogate next fall.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 4 (UPI)--East and West Germany received strict orders from Olympic officials today: Get together and form an allGerman team for the 1964 Olympic Games or don't bother to enter a team at all.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (Ap)--George Romney contended today that he deserved support on racial and labor issues in his drive for the governorship of Michigan. But he called himself an underdog.
Aldona Kepalaite, pianist, made her recital debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
WINNETKA, Ill., March 4-- A wedding on March 24 in all Saints Protestant Episcopal Church in Palo Alto, Calif., is planned by Miss Barbara Judith Gibson and John Martin McClintock.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 4--Dr. Joseph John Stahl, a former president-elect of the Second District Dental Society of New York, died yesterday at his home, 45 Second Street. His age was 60. He had practiced here and in Hempstead.

TUNIS, March 4--Two of the issues to be settled in the final French-Algerian peace talks this week are the membership of a transitional executive body and the size and authority of a domestic police force daring the transition.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, B.W.I., March 4 (AP)--Industrial clashes involving firearms, ancient cutlasses, cable wire and clubs have closed the sugar mill and the rum distillery on this island. Several persons were reported to have been injured.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:
Members of a new Puerto Rican youth group wexe urged yesterday to train themselves for creative and positive leadership in the future of the city.

BROWNSVILLE, Tenn., March 4 (AP)--Two white men who said they had come here to help jobless Negro farmers remained in jail today, but the sheriff, S.T. Hunter, said they probably would be released soon.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 4 (UPI)--Rocky Colavito, who hit forty-five home runs in 1961, ended his holdout with the Detroit Tigers today by signing his 1962 contract for a figure reported near $50,000.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 4 --Miss Ruthsue Weingarten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Weingarten, was married to Joseph J. Moscou this afternoon in Temple Israel here. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. John Moscou of New York and the late Mr. Moscou. Rabbis Harry Nelson and Byram Rubenstein officiated.
NEW DELHI, India, March 4 --In results for 479 of 494 elective seats in the lower house of Parliament, the ruling Congress party has won 348. It held 375 seats in the outgoing Parliament.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4--Dino de Laurentiis, the Italian movie producer, plans to enter the American television market.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The international interest in the orbital feat of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. was in no way demonstrated more convincingly, perhaps, than in the behavior of Washington's diplomatic corps when the astronaut appeared before a joint meeting of Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 4--A United States mission flew to Chile tonight to discuss policies on the Alliance for Progress.

TULLY, N.Y. March 4-- Pepi Gramshammer, almost unknown in the United States until the debut of professional skiing last year, won the giant slalom today as the professionals ended their stand on Song Mountain.

Continued yielding by the city government to "super-pressures" for new and costlier municipal services will result in an expense budget of $3,350,000,000 by 1965-66, the Citizens Budget Commission predicted yesterday. This would be $808,000,000 above the present budget.

Now that the Presidential Railroad Commission has turned in its report urging overhaul of featherbedding labor practices, it would be timely and consistent for the New York Legislature to repeal this state's antiquated "full-crew" laws. These laws for a half century have required overmanning of the railroads.

The messages President Kennedy sent to Congress last week on health and conservation were marked by the grace and clarity that are the adornments of his public papers. Like his earlier messages on such issues as aid to the public schools and the promotion of full employment, they set forth eloquently the need for prompt Congressional action on major domestic problems.

Odetta returned to the stage of Town Hall Saturday night, where she was last heard a year ago. The contralto offered few novelties in programing, but relied mainly on the American folk songs and spirituals that have become identified with her.

PITTSBURGH, March 4-- Steel users continued to hold back on inventory buying last week. Some customers were deferring orders that called for shipment in March. Nearly all were delaying commitments for the second quarter.
The Wagner administration is planning only an interim operation of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, if it takes over the strikebound company.
ALBANY, March 4--A new state commission, still to be created, is expected to look into the possibility of keying state aid to localities directly to an inflation index.

The German soprano Gerda Lammers will make her American debut when she sings the title role in Richard Strauss' "Elelctra" on Friday, March 16, during the Metropolitan Opera's twenty-first week. Mary CurtisVerna will sing her first Metropolitan Turandot next Monday.

TOO many cooks may spoil the arroz con habichuelas but, if they are teen-agers, they can have a lot of fun doing so. Such a group recently assembled in the kitchen of the Church of the Good Neighbor Community Center, 115 East 106th Street.

MILWAUKEE, March 4 (AP)--Local 248 of the United Auto Workers, representing production workers at the main plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, reached agreement with the company on local issues in a six-day-old strike early today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 4-- Emphatic but as yet unofficial protests by Chileans were published here today along with announcement that the British Government was designating part of the Antarctic area opposite South America as a new British colony.

Factory employer of the American Tobacco Company smoke more than the average, yet have a lower death rate than the general population in the same sex, age and racial grouping, according to a report in the March issue of Industrial Medicine and Surgery.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said facetiously tonight that any future comments he might make about Texas would be cleared with Vice President Johnson, on orders of President Kennedy.
Mount Sinai Hospital announced yesterday a gift of $1,250,000 from Henry J. Gaisman to construct a ten-story building for operating rooms, post-operative recovery suites and intensive-care units.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 4-- American and British scientists have questioned a Swedish colleague on the usefulness and safety of a vaccine he has developed for the prevention of cancer in humans.
BOSTON, March 4--Mrs. Hanna Hume Lee Calder, a former Congregational missionary in India, died Thursday. She would have been 84 years old next Sunday.

Under the impact of a drop in sales, net earnings of the National Gypsum Company fell to $21,124,668 for 1961 from $23,492,998 the year before, Melvin H. Baker, chairman, reported in the annual statement issued today.

An expanded program of specialized legal training to meet the increasing load of civil rights cases, both in the South and North, was announced yesterday by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4--"Yes, things do move fast in this game of baseball," said the solidly built little fellow who wears No. 1 on his Yankee uniform.
SEOUL, South Korea (Reuters)--For the first time in its history, South Korea is showing signs this year of developing an active stock market.
"Youth in Search of Significance" is the theme of the thirty-eighth annual conference of the Child Study Association of America, to be held at the Roosevelt Hotel on Monday, March 12.

The student hostility that Attorney General Robert Kennedy encountered at some points during his round-the-world trip arises in large part from misunderstanding and ignorance of this country in many areas abroad. How can we help foreigners understand us better?
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson asked 700 Roman Catholic members of the motion picture industry yesterday to give the Legislature their "advice and suggestions" on how to police immoral films.
SEATTLE, March 4--A fourcar high-speed Monorail made a successful test run here today. It was so quiet that some pedestrians did not realize the train was overhead.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 4 (AP)--Second-seeded Roy Emerson of Australia defeated Manuel Santana of Spain, 4--6, 6--2, 6--3, in the semi-finals of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament today.

A century-old Methodist church in Greenwich Village that has no Sunday school and last year could not afford to open its doors during weekdays in Lent began a program of "resurgence and renaissance" yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 4 Hardy visitors to the Stamford Museum and Nature Center tools an electronic nature tour today.
LIMA, Peru, March 4 (AP) --Hundreds of Indian peasants battled Government troops early today trying to oust them from four big cattle ranches they had seized near Cerro de Pasco, high in the Andes.

RANGOON, Burma, March 4 (AP)--Gen. Ne Win told Burma's political parties today that they could continue to function as long as they did not plot against his Revolutionary Council, which took power in a coup d'etat Friday.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 4-- James H. Reilly Sr., who had been Professor of Physical Education and swimming coach at Rutgers University and a national swimming champion, died yesterday in Auburn Memorial Hospital. His age was 72. He formerly lived in New Brunswick, N.J.

WHITE PLAINS, March 4-- Two-thirds of Westchester's community funds and chests have voted to incorporate as the Westchester Fund and to adopt uniform dates for county-wide solicitations in behalf of essential health and welfare services.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--The White House hopes to end soon some of the secrecy surrounding the nation's stockpile of strategic materials.

DOVER, N.H., March 4--Mr. and Mrs. David C. McIntosh Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret McIntosh, to Philip M. Rhinelander. He is the son of Prof. and Mrs. Philip H. Rhinelander of Stanford, Calif.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 4--With five minutes to play, a midfield brawl involving most of the two teams stopped the Rugby League football game between the SHAPE Indians and a selected French Army team at Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe today. At this stage, the French were leading, 15--7.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, said today that a proposed "All-Republican Conference" would aid campaign strategy but would not make policy for Republican members of Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Mrs. Nanette Holmes Osgood of San Francisco became the bride of William Tyson here yesterday in a private Protestant ceremony.

Premier Khrushchev has now accepted two Western proposals regarding the forthcoming disarmament conference in Geneva: (1) he is willing to open it at the foreign ministers' level, dropping his own plan to start it with a gigantic "summit"; and (2) he agrees to a prior meeting between the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and Soviet Russia on the specific problem of a test ban.
TOKYO, March 5--The nations of Asia were told by United Nations economists today that their countries had failed to meet the economic challenges confronting the continent.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)--Top Federal aviation officials endorsed strict new legislation today designed to force inexperienced and economically faltering concerns out of the nonscheduled airline business.

BOSTON, March 5--Edward J. McCormack Jr., the Massachusetts attorney general, became officially today the first Democratic candidate for United States Senator. He is expected to be challenged shortly by Edward M. Kennedy, an assistand district attorney in Boston.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation has taken another step in its diversification program by acquiring Schaefer, Inc., a Minneapolis manufacturer of low-temperature cabinets for dairy products and frozen foods.

LONDON, March 5 (UPI)-- British Aluminum Company's $103.6-a-ton price cut for its two most widely used types of sheet--its second in six weeks, to make the total reduction in 1962 worth around $155 --is expected to be followed by other main producers in these islands, business commentators said today.

By April all 260 savings and loan associations in California will begin paying 4.75 per cent interest annually on savings. That prediction was made yesterday by Edward L. Johnson president of Financial Federation, Inc., of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--A House subcommittee, described by its chairman today as "caught between the honored dead and the honored dollar," began a study today of a proposal to prohibit further expansion of the national cemetery system.
Four fine musicians and five elegant baroque composers got together last night for a warm and graceful evening of eighteenth-century music at Carnegie Recital Hall.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5--From the standpoint of civic representation, the best horse won the feature race today on the opening program of Gulfstream Park's forty-three-day meeting. The steed in question was The Tongan, a 5-year-old owned by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gunn, and the stakes was the Armed Handicap, run for the seventeenth time.
Adlai E. Stevenson, United States Representative to the United Nations, quickly spiked a report yesterday that he might become a Democratic candidate for the Senate from New York.

Leaders of a " Stand Up for Democracy" rally said yesterday they hoped to attract 5,000 persons to a meeting at St. Nicholas Arena tomorrow night called as a counter to a simultaneous conservative rally at Madison Square Garden.
Churches throughout the city will observe Ash Wednesday tomorrow, beginning the penitential season of Lent.
The Puritan Fashions Corporation of New York has acquired Ruth Walker, Inc., a New York dress manufacturer for an undisclosed sum.

WASHINGTON March 5 (AP)--A Senate Judiciary Subcommittee is expected to recommend confirmation of Dudley B. Bonsal as a Federal District Judge for the Southern District of New York despite the opposition of a New York City lawyer.
ALBANY, March 5--State Controller Arthur Levitt's plan to increase per capita aid to localities at once was overwhelmingly endorsed by a bipartisan group of Mayors and other city officials today.
HONG KONG, March 5--The Hong Kong Government has thrown this British colony's textile industry into an uproar by banning exports to the United States of eight categories of cotton textiles.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 5 --The South Vietnam Air Force has saved two Government outposts from being engulfed by the Viet Cong guerrillas and has inflicted sharp casualties in bombing and strafing the Communist forces.
TRENTON, March 5--Gov. Richard J. Hughes entered St. Francis Hospital here tonight for observation and treatment of a recurrent phlebitis in his right leg.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 5 --A United States Alliance for Progress delegation began a review of Chile's economic and social plans and problems with high Chilean officials today.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher returned yesterday from what he prefers to think of as "my sabbatical from City College."
GENEVA, March 5--A commission of investigation of the International Labor Organization said today that "vestiges" of forced labor existed in Portugal's African territories.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 5--The vast army of well-wishers that Walter O'Malley left behind him in Brooklyn will undoubtedly be grieved to learn that the recent torrential rains in Los Angeles will add an extra $50,000 to the cost of the new Dodger ball park in Chavez Ravine. Before the former Brooklyn club headed into the Florida sunshine for spring train-...

NICE, France, March 5--It was a cold rainy week-end over most of Europe. The downhill race of the French national ski championships was called off. Some tennis tournaments were rained out, including one here, and all the top horses were scratched from an important trotting race at near-by Cagnes.

NEWARK, March 5--The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People took double legal action today in a fight to end alleged segregation practices in the public school system of Orange, N.J.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, put a "must" tag today on a shorter workweek to curb unemployment. He said it had become the nation's first domestic problem. He would reduce the hours without cutting pay.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--A 16-year-old Florida boy who found a way to preserve living nerve tissue for prolonged study was awarded tonight the highest honor in the twenty-first annual Science Talent Search.
Stocks were sloppy and closed a little lower yesterday in a market affected by the collapse of steel wage negotiations and by the pronouncements of minor prophets on the Geneva arms talks.

STUART, Fla., March 5--A ladyfish is as sleek and chic in her own icthyological fashion as any Parisian mannequin. She comes in only one dress--a glittering silver sheath--which makes her bright and smooth and racy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 5--The United States submitted data today to U Thant, Acting Secretary General, on seventy-two objects it launched into space before last Feb. 15.
The Transport Workers Union strike against the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines subsidiary in Westchester was settled last night. Service is to resume this morning.
PARIS, March 5--The French Government announced tonight that it would send no representatives to the disarmament conference opening in Geneva March 11.
ALGIERS, Tuesday, March 6--An undetermined number of Moslem political prisoners were slain in Oran last night when European extremists raided the prison there.
LONDON, March 5 (Reuters) --Representatives of ten nations will meet here tomorrow to discuss the implications of amendments to the United States Shipping Act approved last year by President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- Following are today's opinion of the Supreme Court and the dissenting view of two Justices in which the court held that airports must pay compensation to near-by property owners for noise, vibration and fear caused by low-flying planes:
Thirty-two persons, including eight women, were arrested yesterday after two sitdown demonstrations outside the headquarters here of the Atomic Energy Commission.
Fifty-three residents of Montclair, N.J., last night accepted an invitation to see a free showing of the controversial French film "Les Liaisons Dangereuses."
Columbia University announced yesterday the retirement of Dr. John A. Krout as vice president. Dr. Lawrence H. Chamberlain, a former dean of Columbia College, has been named to succeed him.

A Senator and two Representatives, all of whom have fought over the years for a Federal program that would develop national cultural resources, were agreed yesterday that public support first must be marshaled if such a program is to be realized.
TUNIS, March 5--President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia sipped fruit juice in his office at noon today.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that more than a billion dollars in real estate syndications had been offered to the New York public last year.
Gil Diaz, a Puerto Rican who now lives in New York, lost a split decision to Tony Fortunate of the Bronx in the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Mastery of the printed word is the child's key to the mystery of understanding and of learning. A faulty key--inability to read or to read well--is a fundamental handicap that will affect the child throughout his life, depriving him of countless opportunities as well as pleasures. A so-called "non-reader" is an intellectual cripple.

WASHINGTON, March--5 (AP)--The Supreme Court denied today the right of Indians in the Alaska villages of Kake and Angoon to use fish traps. The court left undecided--pending a decision by the United States Secretary of the Interior --the right of Indians in Metlakatla community to use such traps.
PHILADELPHIA, March 5-- The Court of Common Pleas ruled today that the operator of a newsstand on a busy centercity corner must pay $375 a month rent to the property owner.
ALBANY, March 5--Governor Rockefeller signed into law today the bill permitting New York City to order the resumption of dating of milk containers, effective immediately.
The last of the city's cases involving properties that had been owned or controlled by David B. Solove were disposed of yesterday in Housing Court after five months of delays.

The national fund campaign of the Smith College Development Program has passed the goal of $10,030,000 set for June 30, its chairman reported yesterday. Mrs. Samuel L. Rosenberry, who is also a college trustee, announced that the campaign had raised $10,052,000 to date.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- The Supreme Court held today that airports must compensate owners of near-by property for the noise, vibration and fear caused by low-flying planes.
Ted Bates Co., Inc., will pick up billings estimated at $5,000,000 as a result of a sweeping agency realignment announced yesterday by the Scott Paper Company.

Bruce and Beatrice Blackman Gould have resigned as editors of the Ladies' Home Journal. Curtiss Anderson, 34 years old, was named to succeed Mr. and Mrs. Gould, who had edited the magazine twenty-seven years.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- The Soviet Union has notified the United States that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko will attend the disarmament conference in Geneva.
Seminar on "Projection 1965--the Future of the Port of New York," Council of Regents, St. Francis College, Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, noon. Speakers: Walter Hamshar, George F. Horne.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave temporary approval today to substantially reduced fares for trans-Atlantic travel by groups of twenty-five or more persons on regularly scheduled airlines.
RYE, N.Y., March 5 (AP)-- A judge today dismissed an information brought by a Negro couple against an apartmenthouse owner who they said had denied them an apartment because of their race.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $124,000,000 of temporary loan notes on March 20. The issue will be dated April 10 and will come due Sept. 14. Money from the sale will be used for the temporary financing of twenty-nine Federally aided public housing developments:
The Army as awarded a $3,772,634 classified contract to the Sylvania Products Company, a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

TOKYO, March 5--The Japanese Government told the United States today that it might present claims for any damages suffered by Japanese nationals as a result of American tests of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company is planning to enlarge its tanker berthing facilities at the port of Albany.
HOUSTON, March 5 (AP)-- The Houston Oilers, champions of the American Football League, completed a swap of coaches with the rival National League today by naming Frank (Pop) Ivy their head coach.
A law professor, a certified public accountant, a pharmacist, two packagers of art objects and a luncheonette operator were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on income tax charges.
BONN, Germany, March 5-- Chancellor Adenauer has asked Secretary of State Dean Rusk to stop in Bonn on his way to the disarmament conference in Geneva.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 (AP)--The movie industry and President Kennedy paid tribute to Bob Hope last night for his tireless trips to entertain American service men. The comedian was presented with the Milestone Award at the Screen Producers Guild annual dinner.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 5 (AP)--The Soviet Union signed a trade and aid agreement with East Germany today estimated to be worth about $825,000,000, East German officials announced.
THE ghost of Mary Lincoln, wife of the sixteenth Presi dent of the United States, is stirring again, prompted by remarks made by the present First Lady.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 60 cents a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

DOUALA, Cameroon, March 5--Search teams struggled through African jungle tonight to recover the 111 victims of the worst single-plane disaster in the history of civil aviation --the fiery crash of a chartered flight carrying vacationers to Europe.

Steel production declined last week for the second straight week on expectations, now shaken, for an early settlement of labor terms.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower joined more than 1,100 persons at the funeral service yesterday for W. Alton Jones, who died here Thursday in the crash of an American Airlines jet.
More than 3,000 Manhattan and Bronx garage workers will receive an $11-a-week raise over three years under an arbitration award made public yesterday.

Former President Juscelino Kubitscheck of Brazil said yesterday that "economic orthodoxy" was "inappropriate to the needs of nations like Brazil." He said reforms, such as those advocated by the International Monetary Fund, "might even paralyze our development."

DETROIT, March 5 (AP)-- For the second consecutive month, the Chrysler Corporation, the third largest company in the United States automobile industry, and the American Motors Corporation, the No. 4 company, are planning to build about the same number of cars.

TORONTO, March 5 (Canadian Press)--International Nickel Company of Canada Ltd., had a net profit of $88,777,000 (U.S.) or $3.02 a share in 1961 compared with $80,701,000 and $2.76 in 1960, according to the annual report.
NEW YORK stores are beginning to introduce their adaptations and line-for-line copies of Paris spring fashions. Most of these will be on sale by the end of the month.

Frances Sternhagen and her husband, Thomas Carlin, have joined the cast of "Great Day in the Morning," a new play by Alice Cannon. Jose Quintero has begun rehearsing the cast for a Detroit premiere on March 15. The play is scheduled to reach Broadway March 28.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- The Supreme Court refused today to decide at this time the question of when Government officials may copyright their speeches.
PARIS, March 5--La Nation, a new daily newspaper, began publication here today as the semi-official organ of the Gaullist Union for the New Republic.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 5--Twenty-seven young players--fourteen on the regular roster, thirteen still listed in the minors--were made eligible today for the James P. Dawson Memorial Award, given annually to the outstanding rookie of the Yankee training season.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5 --Almost complete returns in India's elections give Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's ruling Congress party 353 seats in the lower house of Parliament against 132 seats for all other parties.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 5 --Here it was only two weeks before the opening night of the harness racing season, and there wasn't a standard-bred at Roosevelt Raceway this morning. The horse had been replaced by the machine, but the year's best bet was that this was a temporary condition.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--Ed Kline, an Ohio postman, received a standing ovation today from more than 2,000 fellow letter carriers for his walk here from Ohio to dramatize a campaign for a postal pay increase.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Mariano de Yturralde y Orbegoso, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, died today in Doctors Hospital at the age of 57. He had undergone surgery last week.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 5-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall called here this afternoon for a new spirit of "competitive cooperation" between public and private utilities as a necessary new approach to meeting the nation's power needs.

Colorado State University's basketball team, third in the Skyline Conference, accepted a bid yesterday to the National Invitation Tournament. The Rams became the tenth team in the field of twelve that will play at Madison Square Garden beginning March 15.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5--James Joyce's "Ulysses" will be more optimistic as a movie than as a book. But, according to Jack Cardiff, the director, the film will adhere to the basic literary and philosophical values of the novel.

ALBANY, March 5--The Republican majority in the Assembly tonight turned back a Democratic attempt to force from committee legislation mandating free tuition at the four New York City municipal colleges.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--If the United States were to pursue all national goals proposed for this decade, including putting a man on the moon, it might be outspending its income by $150,000,000,000 in 1970, a National Planning Association spokesman said...
Potato futures advanced yesterday on a large trading volume, reverting to the position of strength they had occupied last Tuesday.
More than 20,000 garment workers in five states went out on strike yesterday in a dispute involving dressmaking piece rates.

Sales of the National Dairy Products Corporation, the nation's biggest dairy producer, exceeded one and three-quarter billion dollars for the first time last year, J. Huber Wetenhall, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- The Department of Defense has established the organizational framework for closer military cooperation with the civilian space agency in the exploration of space, including the threeman expedition to the moon.

ASCAASI beaded ball gown that cost $2,250 arrived Feb. 1 at Neiman Marcus in Dallas. It was sold right out of the box. The previous day the Nan Duskin store in Philadelphia received a Norman Norell...

WASHINGTON, March 5--A union that agrees to arbitrate its differences with management has given up the right to strike, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court said that this rule applied whether of not the collective bargaining agreement included a no-strike clause.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 5-- There were reports of moderate progress in Latin-American school systems as a two-week educational conference opened here today under the sponsorship of United Nations organizations.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 5 (AP)--Gene Woodling, Washington's leading hitter and the American League player representative, charged today that Jimmy Piersall, the Senators' highest-salaried player, was receiving special privileges from the club. Woodling demanded a stop to it.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5--In the course of an average spring training day, the New York Mets drink three gallons of purified water, empty ninety bottles of soda pop and sip 500 ounces of hot soup. Whatever liquid is lost in perspiration is wiped away with 200 towels.

MARTHA GRAHAM presented last night the second new work of her season at the Broadway Theatre and kept the record intact by coming up with another winner. And winner is exactly the right word for this one, for it has beauty and charm, a delicate undertone of humor and a wealth of extraordinary movement.

Strikebound Fifth Avenue Avenue Coach Lines' buses are not moving these days, but the stock is active as the two pieces of ticker tape show. Yesterday at the opening the shares (ticker symbol: FCL) were quoted at 20 bid, 24 asked.
The operator of New York's major airports, and therefore the prospective target of any damage suits precipitated by a Supreme Court decision handed down yesterday, is the Port of New York Authority.

DENVER, March 8 (AP)-- The United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit reversed today the convictions of nine present or former officials of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, an independent labor organization.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Award, a statuette affectionately and universally known as Oscar, yesterday received a slap in its gold-plated face.

PITTSBURGH, March 5 (AP) --The house involved in a United States Supreme Court decision today upholding the award to a property owner of damages because of noise made by lowflying aircraft is now known as the St. Phillips Episcopal Church.
Milton Mollen, chairman of the Housing and Redevelopment Board, said yesterday that no more urban renewal projects intended solely for luxury housing would be started in the city.
RANGOON, Burma, March 5, --Many Burmese appear to welcome the return to national leadership of General Ne Win, the military commander who seized control of the Government last Friday.

BALTIMORE, March 5 (AP) --Alleged monopoly of television emerged today as one of the principal issues in the American Football League's $10,080,000 antitrust suit against the National Football League.
The contest between the New York Rangers and the Detroit Red Wings for the fourth and last Stanley Cup play-off berth will resume tonight in Detroit's Olympia Stadium.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported gains in operating revenues for 1961 yesterday. But it said net income had declined.
Rejection by Congress of the Administration's tariff bill would cause much greater economic dislocation than would its enactment, Representative Hale Boggs asserted
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Francis Gary Powers will testify publicly before a Senate committee tomorrow about his experience as a United States U-2 pilot shot down over the Soviet Union.

NEWARK, March 5 (AP)-- Life insurance sales of the Prudential Insurance Company of America dropped in 1961, but records were set in other areas during the year, Louis R. Menagh, president, announced today.
Two major New York City commercial banks appointed new public relations directors yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Two influential Republican Senators moved, today to substitute a short-term loan for President Kennedy's program to buy United Nations bonds.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--The space agency selected the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to provide engineering support for its manned space-flight programs.
The Soviet Union is constructing a wall at the rear of its newly acquired but still unoccupied United Nations mission.
The United Service Organizations and the Army traded awards yesterday at a luncheon opening a two-day meeting of the Eastern Section U.S.O. Conference in the BarbizonPlaza Hotel.

FOR thirty business-like years, David McCord, the Harvard tithing-man, solicited money from the alumni according to the recognized techniques of pressure and repetition. He was successful. Growing weary of organized mendicancy, he then decided to use the English language. He was still successful--perhaps a little more so.

ALBANY, March 5--Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of Bernard Newman, former New York County Republican chairman, to a seat on the state Supreme Court. The post pays $34,500 a year.
About 1,000 persons attended a funeral service yesterday for Admiral and Mrs. Richard L. Conolly, who died Thursday in the crash of an American Airlines jet in Jamaica Bay.

IT is so obvious that many people probably never think of it: the literal meaning of Mardi Gras is fat Tuesday. This is also the translation of Fetter Dienstag, the German name for today. And in Russia he week preceding Lent used to be known as butter week.
Railroad management asked the five train-operating rail labor unions yesterday to begin negotiating March 20 on the basis of the far-reaching report of the Presidential Railroad Commission.

ELISABETHVILLE, The Congo, March 5--Shooting flared today between United Nations troops and the armed forces of Katanga Province, menacing the truce in effect since the battle of Elisabethville last December.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--Senator Kenneth B. Keating called today for an investigation aimed at getting New York a fairer share of military contracts.
LIMA, Peru, March 5 (AP) --The Government called off tonight police attempts to oust Indian peasants from four privately owned cattle ranches they had seized high in the Andes.
JERSEY CITY, March 5-- Blood transfusions were given today to a 2-year-old boy critically ill with anemia, despite the objections of his parents.
The Railroad Marine Workers Commission established by President Kennedy began public hearings yesterday on the manning of tugboats and ferries operated here by the railroads.
PARIS, March 5--France and the rebel Algerian Provisional Government will begin Wednesday a climactic effort to reach a cease-fire agreement within a week to end the Algerian war.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- The regular weekly issues of Treasury bills sold today at larger discount rates than last week's. On last Monday's sale the discount rates were sharply reduced.

MOSCOW, March 5--Premier Khrushchev warned the Soviet people today that the country's Seven-Year Plan for agriculture was "in serious danger." He called for a new system of management and more machinery and fertilizer to double or triple farm output in the next twenty years.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 5--Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. returned here tonight to begin a (series of simulated missions that are expected to further this nation's knowledge of manned space flight. He arrived at Patrick Air Force Base near Cape Canaveral.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Enrique Lister, who led a Communist corps in the Spanish civil war and served as a Soviet general in World War II, is reported to be in a high military command position in Cuba.
Prices of prime-rated bonds held steady yesterday in all areas except among United States Government securities, where slight sell-offs took place in slackened trading.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)--The Department of Justice moved in court today to block the planned merger of the two largest department stores in Milwaukee--Gimbel Brothers, Inc., of New York and Ed. Schuster Co., Inc., of Milwaukee.
Electric operating revenues of domestic subsidiaries of the General Public Utilities Corporation increased 4.7 per cent in 1961, while consolidated net income went up 3.8 per cent.
Another record-breaking spree appears to be in prospect for Madison Square Garden's final jamboree of the highly productive indoor track and field season.
ALBANY, March 5--Mayor Wagner proposed today that apartment owners in New York City be prohibited from renting to adults only.
Mr. and Mrs. Albert Fischer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Sandra Fischer, to Andrew Adler Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel D. Goldman of Rochester, N.Y.
Forty-five men and thirteen home-improvement companies were indicted yesterday by a Federal brand jury in Brooklyn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 5--Clement Williams Williamson has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Gwynneth Williamson, to Frank Rees Smith. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Smith of Flint, Mich.

Mortimer W. Byers, who served as a judge in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York for more than thirty years, died yesterday at his home, 429 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old.
Redemptions topped sales of savings bonds in February for the second month in a row, the Treasury reported yesterday. But accrued discounts on Series E bonds helped lift the total outstanding.
WASHINGTON, March 5-- Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, liberalized public assistance rules today to speed the return of mental patients to their communities.
A joint union-employer plan that cut payroll costs by $1,600,000 was credited yesterday with having saved the ninetyfive-year-old Jacob Ruppert brewery from extinction.
Except for a stool, a ladder, a bed and a bench, there wasn't much scenery on the stage of the auditorium of Junior High School 194 yesterday.

Guests have asked to wear pink, white or red gowns to the Peppermint Ball arranged by the Finch Club of New York for March 23 in the St. Regis Roof. The theme of the dinner dance, Peppermint Land, will be carried out in the decor.

A plausible case can be made for municipal ownership of all mass transit in New York City. It can also be argued convincingly that surface transit--the bus lines, that is--should be a private enterprise operation. Through the years the trend in New York City transit has been toward government ownership. The unification of the subway lines was a massive step in that direction.
The American Broadcasting Company, which postponed last fall's scheduled premiere of "Discovery," a children's program, has set Oct. 1 as the new starting date.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., March 5 (AP)--The Army today reported about normal lunch attendance in the field by New Hampshire National Guard members from near-by Fort Bragg who have been engaging in a so-called "hunger strike."
RICHMOND, Va., March 5-- The Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals ruled today that Prince Edward County had no obligation under state law to reopen its public schools.

A spokesman for the board said no salary agreement could be reached until the amount of state and city aid for education was known.

THE play called the squeeze is generally regarded as bridge at an extremely high level, but an even higher level must be attained when a player anticipates a possible squeeze by his opponent and plays so as to prevent it.
Three national organizations recommended a $10,000,000 Federal appropriation yesterday to eradicate syphilis as a public health problem.

ALBANY, March 6--Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he was trying to find a basis for passage of a bill this year that would permit storekeepers to remain open on Sundays if they observed another day of the week as their sabbath.
Commissioner of Buildings Harold Birns reported yesterday that the wall the Soviet Union was building at its new United Nations mission headquarters would be part of a meeting hall.
CINCINNATI, March 6-- Morison R. Waite, a leading Cincinnati lawyer, died today at the age of 95. He had practiced law here for sixty-nine years.

BO TUC, Vietnam, March 6 --Admiral Harry D. Felt, commander in chief of United States forces in the Pacific, said in Saigon today that South Vietnamese forces had "gone on the offensive" against the Communist Viet Cong.
LOS ANGELES, March 6 (AP)--Dinah Shore filed suit today for a divorce from George Montgomery. The suit charged mental cruelty, but went into no details.
Record sales and "somewhat improved" earnings for the current fiscal year ending in October were forecast yesterday by Robert T. Stevens, president of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile producers.

Conflicts in traffic signs will be eliminated and parking will be strictly enforced on Second Avenue, Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday. He said the two steps would increase the avenue's traffic capacity by 300 per cent.
DETROIT, March 6--New car sales in February aggregated 456,872, for an increase of about 27 per cent from the 360,286 cars sold in the 1961 month, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

Reservists called into service during the Berlin crisis last year face a myriad of technicalities when they make out their income tax returns this year. Still, the job should not be too complicated because, basically, the income tax provisions that civilians face are the same ones the servicemen face.
LOS ANGELES, March 6-- Samuel B. Morris, a consulting engineer and an authority on water, died today at Queen of Angeles Hospital. He was 71 years old.
ALBANY, March 6--The Senate today approved with minor modifications Governor Rockefeller's record spending budget of $2,591,000,000 for the fiscal year starting April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)--The White House said today that President Kennedy had not been in touch with the steel companies or the United Steelworkers Union since negotiations on a new contract were broken off last week.
BONN, Germany, March 6-- Dr. Hans Kroll arrived today and indicated that he did not know whether he would be returning to his post as West Germany's Ambassador in Moscow.
ALBANY, March 6--Governor Rockefeller tonight came out in favor of a bill that would permit limited televising of legislative committee hearings.

Don Burnett, the 26-year-old automotive mechanic who won the American Motorcycle Association's 200-mile classic road race at Daytona International Speedway last Sunday, doesn't want to set the world on fire as a race-rider.

Boys High of Brooklyn, Curtis of Staten Island and Columbus of the Bronx kept their championship hopes alive by scoring victories in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Declining financial support of the United Service Organizations will mean fewer services and clubs for men in uniform, the Eastern Section U.S.O. Conference was told yesterday. The warning was made by Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, the organization's national campaign chairman, who spoke at a luncheon closing a two-day meeting at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 6-- A woman from Glen Head who asserts she is the wife of a priest filed a $2,375,000 suit in State Supreme Court here today against the Roman Catholic Church, Cardinal Spellman, subordinate units of the church and other persons.

PITTSBURGH, March 6-- Samuel Horelick, former president and board chairman of the Pennsylvania Transformer Company and a leader in Jewish philanthropies, died Friday at his winter home in Golden Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 6 (UPI)--President Moise Tshombe of Katanga said today he would leave for Leopoldville on March 15 for talks with Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Central Government on ending Katanga's secession.
The Federal Aviation Agency issued a set of standard takeoff procedures for Boeing jet airliners yesterday.
The 1953 decision to take flowage easements instead of title to the land at Federal floodcontrol reservoirs was one of the strange naturalresource errors of the last Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- Answers to Census Bureau questionaires are confidential, regardless of whether the answers are required by law or are voluntary, according to a Justice Department ruling made public today.

AS usual, the National Or chestral Association, conducted by John Barnett, came up with some unusual items last night. One of them was the earliest piece of music, chronologically speaking, on the program. Gluck was Haydn's senior by a few years, but Haydn composed his "Horn Signal" Symphony before Gluck finished the "Iphigenia in Aulis."
The Actors Equity Association is holding a series of hearings on alleged discrimination against Negroes in Broadway productions.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company criticized today the Administration's proposal for broad ownership of a communication satellite system as unsound, unwieldy and ineffective.
Mr. and Mrs. Haliburton Fales of 1075 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of Mrs. Fales' cousin, Mrs. Millicent Barnard Mills of Greenwich, Conn., to Julian Twells Trenholm of New York.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP)-- The official formation of sports federations in track and field and gymnastics was delayed today until July 5. That ruled out the possibility of a federation track meet in June in opposition to the Amateur Athletic Union national championships.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif. March 6 (AP)--The world's favorite movie stars are Marilyn Monroe and Charlton Heston, in the opinion of fans polled by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

NEWPORT NEWS Va, March 6 (AP)--Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth said today that United States Polaris submarines had marked superiority over Russian submarines in numbers of missiles, range and accuracy.
Attacks on police officers here reached the proportions of a "serious disease" last year, Deputy Police Commissioner Walter Arm said yesterday.
A wife's separation suit was suspended yesterday until the court could determine whether her husband had skied out of its jurisdiction.
The city's move to take over the strikebound Fifth Avenue Coach Lines met a delay yesterday.
A Sandy Hook harbor pliot sailed yesterday on an unplanned-for thirteen-day vacation aboard the liner United States.
ALBANY, March 6--The bistate plan to build a World Trade Center in Manhattan and rehabilitate the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad cleared its last legislative hurdle today.
The city plans to increase its 1962-63 expense budget revenue by about $47,700,000 by collecting the special taxes on general and financial business in three installments, starting August 1.
GENEVA, March 6--The International Commission of Jurists declared today that the Communist-built wall dividing East and West Berlin had "neither legal nor moral jastification."
Seven winners of the fourteenth annual George Polk Memorail Awards for significant achievements in! journalism were announced yesterday by Long Island Universtiy.
Hollywood's self--censorship organization, reversing an earlier decision, has granted a seal of approval to a film repeatedly using words offensive to Negroes.
Col. C. Robert Baines, board chairman of Advertising Distributors of America, Inc., died Monday of a heart ailment in his home at 414 East Fifty-second Street. He was 69 years old.

Gamble-Skogmo, Inc. has acquired an additional 279,952 shares of the General Outdoor Advertising Company, Inc., bringing its holdings in that concern to 590,550 shares, or almost half of the 1,198,928 outstanding common shares. B.C. Gamble, president of the Minneapolis-based company, made the announcement yesterday.
The Board of Health voted at a special meeting yesterday to reinstate a requirement that containers of milk sold in New York City must be dated. The requirement will go into effect again on April 1.

STUART, Fla., March 7 As a state blessed with an abundance of fresh-water lakes and ponds, Florida offers some of the best bass and bream fishing in the south. But it also has problems with some of its waters, and is reclaiming those that hold little appeal for the sportsmen.

Stern's: This store's reproductions of European couturier fashions are termed 'adaptations." However, the few that were shown side by side with the originals at yesterday's preview were as faithfully reproduced as most of the so-called "line for line" copies being shown at other stores. Stern's thirty-seven designs include more Italian creations than can be found elsewhere.

New Frontiersmen speak in cold figures, and that was made plain yesterday when James K. Carr, Undersecretary of the Department of the Interior, said the private electric utility industry would need $130,000,000,000 investment money in the next twenty years.
Cove Vitamin and Pharmaceutical, Inc., denied in court yesterday that it had misbranded CDC (Calories Don't Count) capsules. It said they had been sold only for use in weight control.

Brazil is a dramatic country, so that it is not fanciful to think of a curtain rising on a new and probably exciting act. Janio Quadros, who unaccountably and abruptly resigned from the Presidency last August and went abroad, returned to Brazil yesterday. He is colorful, eccentric, popular and ambitious all of which means the political scene will hum with action.

WASHINGTON, March 7 Administration officials told Congress today that it would be "unconscionable" for the Government to turn over ownership of a communications satellite developed largely at taxpayer expense to a small group of communications companies.

Dr. Carl Iddings, president of the Iddings Paint Company, Inc., Long Island City, Queens, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, in Los Angeles while on a business trip. His age was 67 and he lived at 119 Kensett Road, Munsey Park, Manhasset, L.I.

"Chickadee," a musical based on the life of the late W.C. Fields, has been announced for Broadway next season. It is the work of Clint Powell, West Coast film and television writer who has spent five years of research on the project.

EVERY woman knows that a new dress or coiffure is good therapy. However, the role of fashion and beauty in aiding the mentally ill may have just been demonstrated in a program initiated by the Fashion Group and conducted at the Manhattan State Hospital on Ward's Island.

The Merritt-Chapman and Scott Corporation reported yesterday a net profit for 1961 of $5,847,863, or $1.01 a share. This was in contrast to a net loss of $29,714,509, after a tax refund of $18,350,700 in 1960.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, March 7 Moves to accelerate economic development were announced today by the Tanganyikan Government. Two institutions have been formed by the Government to spur expansion.
MSN ticker symbol for Missile Sites, Inc. crossed the tape yesterday, and the National Stock Exchange was in business.

REVERENT, clear and intelligent were the words for last night's performance of Bach's "The Passion According to St. John" that Robert Shaw led at Carnegie Hall with the Robert Shaw Chorale and Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, March 7 President Kennedy is beginning to make the busy bee look like an idler. He did everything around here today but shinny up the Washington Monument, and it was obviously too cold and icy for that.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France. March 7--Delegations of France and the Algerian rebels sat down together here today to continue negotiations until peace is achieved in Algeria.

The Los Angeles (Calif.) Department of Water and Power, borrowed $16,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance expansion of the utility service system. The money was raised on serial bonds backed by service revenues.

ALBANY, March 7 Commissioner Raymond W. Houston of the state Department of Social Welfare announced today that he would retire July 1. Mr. Houston, who is 61 years old, gave no reason. The cabinet post he has held since 1954 carries an annual salary of $25,486.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)--Winds from one of the worst winter Atlantic storms ever recorded, at a time of normally high tides, combined to produce the devasting high water today on much of the East coast.
LONDON, March 7 "Cigarette smoking is a cause of lung cancer" and probably contributes to the development of other diseases, the Royal College of Physicians reported here today.

The world champion Green Bay Packers topped the National Football League in punt returns during the 1961 season, official league statistics showed yesterday. The Packers' fleet sophomore, Willie Wood, was the individual leader, returning fourteen for 225 yards and a 16.1 average.

A seasonal increase of 2,636,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 206,372,000 barrels, compared with 203,736,000 a week earlier and 206,674,000 a year earlier.

Hubbell Robinson, who resigned from the Columbia Broadcasting System three years ago to become an independent producer, will return to the network on Monday as senior vice president of television programs. He was executive vice president in charge of programs when he resigned.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would seek to determine whether any city agency head was making it difficult for Negro or Puerto Rican employes to rise through the ranks.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 Six young New York Met pitchers displayed varying degrees of mediocrity today in an intrasquad game at Miller Huggins Field. Their performances ranging from merely disappointing to bush league bad underscored the new team's desperate need for pitching strength.
Field trial dogs are better in general than they were thirty years ago, said Henry P. Davis of Magnolia Springs, Ala., during a recent visit to New York.
A defendant in a stock fraud case denied yesterday the Government's accusation that he had paid a $100,000 bribe to the late Senator George H. Bender.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., March 7 Leon G. Rucquoi, former president of Leon G. Rucquoi Associates, Inc., technical advisers to Belgian and Luxembourgian steel and metal-working trace associations, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

PARIS, March 7 Jules Moch French representative on disarmament questions in the United Nations, severely criticized today France's "mistake" in boycotting the disarmament conference opening next Wednesday in Geneva.
The Rangers returned to New York yesterday fully aware that their immediate task was to continue beating the Detroit Red Wings in order to gain the fourth and last Stanley Cup play-off spot.

Potato futures dropped in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The decline followed a sharp rise on Tuesday. The rise was influenced by reports that freezing weather was nearing Florida and Alabama, Cold weather did not develop in the area and the market fell back.

The demand for investmentgrade debt securities carried prices higher in all parts of the bond market yesterday. PHILADELPHIA, March 7 The defending champions, Mrs. Nathan Stauffer and Mrs. John Bottger of Cynwyd, Pa., reached the semi-final round of the women's United States squash racquets doubles tournament today.
New Yorkers are getting more exercise these days. The bus strike is making them walk a bit more, run for taxis with more verve and push a little harder in the subways.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 7 Najeeb E. Halaby, the Federal Aviation Administrator, has proposed three alternative plans for aviation involving Mitchel Field. He recommended that the General Services Administration keep enough land at the base for a future airport or that an educational institution operate an airfield on part of the property.

THE layoffs of the first of the estimated 13,000 employes who will lose their jobs at the Republic Aviation Corporation's plant in Farmingdale, L.I., have thus far had little effect on the community's family life. However, the situation may eventually lead to family tensions, according to Nikolai Gioscia, psychiatrist and director of Nassau County's community mental health services.

Two hundred members of the Student Peace Union staged a rally last night on First Avenue near the United Nations Building to protest the projected resumption of nuclear tests in the atmosphere by the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The House of Representatives approved today a $25,520,000 program of Federal grants for the development and construction of educational television facilities. The vote was 337 to 68.

WASHINGTON, March 7 President Kennedy reported to Congress today that he had cut a wide range of import duties below the "peril-point" level to save United States overseas markets and to avoid collapse of trade negotiations with twentyfour nations.

A 1949 String Quartet by Seymour Shifrin last night provided about the only substance in the third program in the "Music in Our Time" series being given in Kaufmann Concert Hall this season.

A code of conduct for disgruntled boxing managers was articulated yesterday by Melvin L. Krulewitch, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, in an effort to prevent a recurrence of ungentlemanly behavior among spectators.

DES MOINES, March 7 (AP) John Blum of Austin, Minn., took first place in the regular all-events division of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a total of 2,007 for nine games.

The nation's big commercial banks will see their 1962 earnings decline for the second con- secutive year, a large Wall Street investment concern predicted yesterday. Frank L. Elliot, senior bank analyst of Paine, Webber, Jacksor Curtis, said that earnings of the major banks in the country would decline in the first half of the year and would improve in the latter half.

The Square D Company, one of the nation's largest makers of electrical distribution and control equipment, registered record sales and earnings in 1961. F.W. Magin, chairman, and L.G. Maechtlen, president, announced yesterday.
Investigators seeking the cause of last week's jet airliner crash in Jamaica Bay have found evidence indicating that all wing flaps may have been completely retracted at the moment of impact.

Unexcelled Chemical Company has entered the retail discount field by acquiring Twin Fair, Inc., which operates discount department stores in the Buffalo, N.Y., area, James M. Crosby, president of Unexcelled, announced yesterday. Last year the discount chain had sales of between $10,000,000 and $15,- 000,000.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 (AP) The hardy Danish crew of Hans Fogh and Paul Elvstrom strengthened its lead today by winning the fourth heat of the Flying Dutchman world championship.

High noon in the financial district yesterday was a time for many people to forget their workaday tasks for luncheon and maybe a stroll along the Battery.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 7 (Reuters) Katanga's forces and United Nations troops exchanged shots today near the installations. here of the Belgian Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga mining company but there were no casualties, a United Nation spokesman said.

The New York and American Stock exchanges disclosed yesterday the following changes in stockholdings reported by directors, officers and large stockholders of listed companies pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934:

WHITE PLAINS, March 7 Tests of a vaccine that may give prolonged immunity from measles without severe reactions when first injected were begun on 2,000 children today by the Westchester County Health Department.

The Democratic leadership in the House has finally found an issue to get excited about. It has set the stage for a floor vote today on its project to add three superfluous seats to the House's permanent complement of 435.
