WASHINGTON, March 7 President Kennedy asked labor and management in the steel industry today to return to the bargaining table within a week. The steel industry negotiating team and the union wired the President a few hours later that they were ready to resume talks.

Dillon Read Co., Inc., and Johnson, Lemon Co. head a group offering 536,221 common shares of the Potomac Electric Power Company. The shares are being offered to stockholders on a subscription basis, whereby each shareholder may buy one share for each fifteen shares held of record of March 7. The price is $39 a share.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The House Agriculture Committee rejected today President Kennedy's plea to block a cut in dairy price supports. The vote against continuing supports at the present level was 20 to 13.

WASHINGTON, March 7 February showed an increase in employment and an unexpected drop in the jobless. This brightened picture of the economy, reported today by the Labor Department, was followed an hour later by an expression of satisfaction by President Kennedy at his news conference.

MIAMI, March 7 Four years ago the Baltimore Orioles were congratulat- ing themselves on having pulled off the coup of the century. They had outbid every other major league club in the auction for Dave Nicholson, an 18-year-old powerhouse. The cost was high, a $110,000 bonus, but it was worth it. Big Nick would solve their most desperate need for many years to come.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- President Kennedy said today that nothing could be "more unwise" than Congressional action to halt aid to Brazil or other countries because of expropriations of United States property.

BRIELLE, N.J., March 7 Willard Bowman, former associate publisher and managing editor of The Newark StarLedger and a New Jersey civic leader, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 72 years old and lived at 409 Laurel Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The entire membership of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, in a rare display of bipartisan harmony, called today for a conference of the major industrial nations to work out a solution to this country's continuing balance-of-payments problem.
Seventeen West German merchants and purchasing officials visited New York's garment district yesterday and said that they were impressed by Seventh Avenue's bustling activity.

Nearly all street parking meters in the city will be replaced before the end of the year if Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes' plans materialize. He said yesterday that the present meters had value only as scrap metal, and during an early morning tour he showed some examples.

Troy H. Browning, president of the Propeller Club of the United States, called on his colleagues in the maritime world yesterday to work for early passage of legislation designed to "revive a sick industry."
Stockholders of the Mergenthaler Liontype Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved the company's exchange offer to common stockholders of the Electric Autolite Company.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 7 A survey of two Levittown high schools indicated today that parents' wishes have little effect on whether their children smoke. It showed that 69 per cent of the smokers began smoking though their parents disapapproved.

WASHINGTON, March 7 A joint television appearance by President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev has been delayed by agreement until late this year.
LONDON, March 7 Prime Minister Macmillan assured Premier Khrushchev today he would be "ready" to attend disarmament talks at Geneva whenever this was of "positive value."

WASHINGTON, March 7 President Kennedy spoke out today against expanding the B-70 bomber program. But he sidestepped the issue whether Congress had constitutional power to force him to spend more money on such a program.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 7 Preoccupation with the military build-up has overshadowed the economic aid program in embattled South Vietnam. The United States Operations Mission will dispose of about $200,000,000 worth of support of the country's economy this year.
Several candidates for "all" honors in college basketball will demonstrate the skills that have made them famous tonight at Madison Square Garden in a double-header involving four intracity rivals.

WASHINGTON, March 7 President Kennedy joined the list of those asking the services of The Advertising Council today. The council is a public service organization of businesses, advertising agencies, newspapers and magazines, and radio and television stations all the ele- ...

IT was apple-blossom time in Normandy, or thereabouts, and the beautiful countryside was filling up with traveling Americans. Those who arrived by air are studied closely in S.L.A. Marshall's new book, "Night Drop,"' with a preface by Carl Sandburg.

One of advertising's big drawbacks is that it is so far removed from the place where the consumer puts his cash on the line. The advertiser can easily reach the consumer in his living room through television or magazines or newspapers.

THE matter of exercise assumes a greater importance at this, the peak of the cruise season when life once more includes the wearing of figurerevealing bathing suits. And, although exponents of calisthenics are pleased by the increased interest in their services most are quick to point out that exercises accomplish a lot more if they are pursued over a long period of time.

The Ford Foundation plans to sell to the public another huge block of Ford Motor Company stock. The foundation announced yesterday that it was making arrangements to put 2,250,000 shares of Ford common stock on the market in late April.

Cornell MacNeil sang his first Metropolitan Opera Renato last night, in the company's sixth "Un Ballo in Maschera" of the season. In so doing, this superb American baritone may very possibly have had his finest hour.

Pairings were announced yesterday for the first two programs of the National Invitation Tournament scheduled to start Thursday night, March 15, at Madison Square Garden. Wichita, with a won-lost record of 18 8 for the regular college basketball season, will play Dayton (19 6).
LINCOLN, R.I., March 7 (AP) Seven races at Lincoln Downs were shortened to threesixteenths of a mile today after three horses slipped and fell, unseating their riders, in the first race.

Two defendants cited in a $2,375,000 suit by a woman in Glen Head, L.I., charging that her husband, described as a Roman Catholic priest, had been forcibly removed from his family were reported by The Associated Press yesterday to have denied they had anything to do with the case.
ALBANY, March 7 Governor Rockefeller gave a strong endorsement today to a Republican "receivership" bill that would provide a way to remove building violations when owners neglected their property.

IN his present difficulties with the Transport Work ers Union and the city administration, Harry Weinberg, the new board chairman of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., uses the all-embracing pronoun "they" to encompass his opposition.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to permit the Alleghany Corporation to vote the stock it holds in two major railroads. Stock of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad owned by the Allegheny Corporation and now in a voting trust must remain there, the commission said.

The first of Jacques Pirenne's history of man, called "The Tides of History," is planned for American publication on March 21 by Dutton. Subtitled "From the Beginnings to Islam," it has been translated from the French by Lovett Edwards.

TOKYO, March 6--The nations of Asia are looking with nervousness at the trend toward tightly knit economic groupings in other parts of the world, but are still cold to the idea of forming one of their own.

The heavy storm that swept the mid-Atlantic states Tuesday struck again yesterday with high tides and winds along the coast. At least twenty-seven persons were reported dead in its wake as the storm swept out to sea.

SANTOS, Brazil, March 7 Dr. Janio Quadros, who resigned as President of Brazil six months ago, came home today, from self-imposed exile. He received a tumultuous welcome from his supporters and announced that he had come back to lead the people of Brazil to "true independence."

Net earnings of the American Investment Company, St. Louis, a leading consumer finance company, amounted to $7,207,996 or $1.30 a share on 4,908,- 961 shares outstanding last year, L.M. Curtiss, president, reported yesterday. This compared with net earnings of $7,130,576 or $1.37 a share on the 4,800,360 shares outstanding a year earlier.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 The United States is ready to give Chile's economic and social development plans a powerful send-off with immediate grants of an eight-figure sum.

When the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and Soviet Russia meet in Geneva Monday an equally decisive battle bearing on the same problem will open in Congressional hearings in Washington. This battle will be over President Kennedy's program to liberalize trade as an economic basis for a true Atlantic community and a wider free-world community to stand against the Communist challenge.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) The Federal Government was accused today of being "a partner in the program of defying the United States Supreme Court decision in the school desegregation cases."

ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 (UPI) The Alberta Ranches' Four-and-Twenty carried his top impost of 127 pounds to a wire-to-wire victory today at Santa Anita in the $28,600 San Bernardino Handicap and coasted home four lengths in front.
COMMACK, L.I., March 7 (AP) The New York Tapers took a 27-7 lead tonight before scoring a 106-94 American Basketball League victory over the Chicago Majors.

In a general atmosphere of lassitude, stocks moved gently downward yesterday. There was heaviness in both steels and motors and many of the "standard" issues favored by institutional investors were under pressure.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 7 (UPI) Joe Cunningham, a first baseman, acquired from the Cardinals in a winter deal, made his debut with the Chicago White Sox today. He slammed out two hits in a sixinning intrasquad game in which the Cuccinellos defeated the Gutteridges, 7 3.

The Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company announced today the organization of a new company to produce high-grade iron ore pellets from a magnetic jasper deposit on the Marquette Range in Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it was being forced to run faster and faster merely to stay even with the burdens placed upon it by growing public participation in the securities markets.

Railroad tugboats could operate here efficiently and safely with fewer than the three deckhands now employed, an official of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad testified yesterday. The official, Edward D. Doran, the railroad's assistant lighterage superintendent, appeared ...
ALBANY, March 7--A special committee of the Rockefeller adminstration recommended today a reduction of up to $15,000,000 a year in the gross-receipts tax of New York City.

The Port of New York Authority and the American Merchant Marine Institute split yesterday on a proposal to deepen the channel in Jamaica Bay. The authority opposed the proposal. The institute, which usually agrees with the authority on harbor improvement plans, supported it.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Mar. 7 (UPI) Delegates to the congress of the International Ice Hockey Federation today rejected a Soviet attempt to take the designation of world and European championships from the twelve-day hockey tournament opening here.

LONDON, March 7 (Reuters) The Financial Times today accused the United States of setting a bad example in the issue of discrimination in shipping. In an editorial that took a gloomy view of the condition of the shipping industry, the newspaper said:

Gordon (Tip) Lipe, a recreational skier who used heavy rubber bands as bindings as a 9-year-old near his home in Skaneateles, N.I., has invented a device to make safety bindings "safe." Because so-called safety bindings have not proved foolproof, even dealers have had to change their tune in recent years.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 George C. Scott's request to have his name withdrawn as a nominee in the Oscar competition has focused attention on the nominating system and has raised controversial questions in the race for the industry's most important honors.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) The House Rules Committee aproved today a bill to increase the House membership from 435 to 438.

The combination at Madison Square Garden last night was 7 11 as Gotham's two tournament-bound quintets, St. John's and New York University, added to their respective winning streaks before 5,521 fans.
MARTHA GRAHAM last night gave the first per formance in her Broadway Theatre season of her fulllength "Clytemnestra," and such a performance it was as the piece has probably never received before.

BANANAS are one of the easiest to grow of any fruit. They can be planted the year around and the fruit matures continuously. For that reason, a steady supply of bananas arrives here from January through December. The price, about 15 cents a pound, has seldom varied from that figure by more than a penny or two for the last fifteen Years.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) A late flurry of selling trimmed grain futures prices today one the Board of Trade, but most contracts finished in a steady to firm range.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 8 The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association today pledged a fight to revitalize the nation's rural areas by extending the benefits of electric power.
Colorado Springs, March 8 (AP) The United States crushed Norway, 14 2, tonight and hurdled the first barrier in its bid to regain the world amateur hockey championship.
The reaction of foreign traders yesterday to the new trade agreements announced Wednesday by President Kennedy was mildly enthusiastic.

WASHINGTON, March 8 In a coldly statistic analysis, the State Department told today how negotiators for the United states and the European Common Market bargained mutually lower tariff rates on 1,479 items of international trade having a 1960 value of $2,900,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 8 Following are excerpts from a report of the House Armed Services Committee, issued yesterday, dealing with the B-70 bomber and questioning the President's constitutional authority to disregard defense appropriations:

WASHINGTON, March 8 The New York City Ballet, the Robert Shaw Chorale and Benny Goodman's Orchestra will visit the Soviet Union this year. The Bolshoi Theatre Ballet, the Leningrad Philharmonia Symphony Orchestra and the Ukrainian Dance Ensemble will tour several cities in the United States.
LONDON, March 8--The cut in the bank rate from 6 to 5 per cent had a mildly tonic effect on the stock market here today.
Cotton futures were 25 cents up to 5 cents a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Stockholders of the Twin City Rapid Transit Company at their annual meeting yesterday in Minneapolis approved a change in the company's name to Minnesota Enterprises, Inc.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 8 Manager Ralph Houk was a little puzzled today as he put his Yankees through their final game of "simulated baseball" prior to the opening of the exhibition campaign on Saturday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 8 The United States pledged tonight up to $120,000,000 assistance to Chile this year under the Alliance for Progress.

With better news on employment and with prospects for peace on the steel labor front apparently brightening, stocks rose yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices opened a little lower but advanced without a break throughout the day. More than half the gain came between 2 and 3 P.M.

Assemblyman Mark Lane announced yesterday he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Congress in Manhattan's new Nineteenth District. The announcement pitting him against a half dozen other persons, had been expected.
GENEVA, March 8 This center of international organizations was the scene today of a strike of civil servants.
The storm that ravaged the Eastern Seaboard broke a tanker in two early yesterday, 150 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C.

This week's Atlantic Coast storm, which would have been called a hurricane if it had arrived last September but now is regarded as the worst disturbance with the highest tides in the history of recent decades, will change pleasure boating's program for the spring. Mayor Wagner acted yester day to have parts of New York City declared Federal disaster areas because of the damage from this week's storm. He asked Governor Rockefeller to request the action by President Kennedy, which is necessary for various kinds of public aid.
Unpublished novels by Ernest Hemingway possibly four of them and dozens of stories and sketches have been brought to New York by Mrs. Hemingway.

Mayor Wagner, the Board of Estimate and a jammed board chamber looked on yesterday as a meter maker tried twice unsuccessfully to prove that he could "crack" his competitor's vandal-proof Duncan parking meter.

BOWIE, Md., March 8 (AP) A four-horse blanket finish marked the featured seventh race at Bowie Race Course today. John P. Pons' Iris H., running closest to the inside rail, gained a neck victory and paid $8.60 for $2 straight.
The crash-proof flight recorder carried by the American Airlines jet that plunged into Jamaica Bay March 1 was retrieved yesterday from nine feet of water.

CAIRO, March 8 Israel's drive for association with the European Economic Community is complicating the effort of the Kennedy Administration to improve United States relations with the United Arab Republic.

A charity organization that assertedly collected $340,000 to fight cancer and then spent $316,000 of the funds for "promotional expenses" has been temporarily enjoined from soliciting in New York State.
William J. Lederer, author of "A Nation of Sheep" and coauthor of "The Ugly American," will be associated with two television programs next season as a story consultant and writer.
As a result of the inquiry into charges of faulty construction of 150 new private houses in Brooklyn, the City Charter will be amended to improve the supervision of construction on filled land.
The 4-H Club came to New York yesterday on its annual "report to the nation" tour. Among other things, its six members took a look at the livestock in the Children's Zoo in Central Park.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 8 (Reuters) Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, announced tonight he was calling a new general election.

Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley proposed yesterday that an armory in the Yorkville area that now houses polo ponies and horses for the mounted police be torn down for a middle-income housing project.

The pending secondary stock offering by the Howard Johnson Company has been set at 370,000 common shares, according to a registration placed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The stock will be offered for public sale through underwriters headed by Blyth Co.
WARSAW, March 8 Poland's 2,500,000 working women received an accolade from the boss today, and the stay-athome wives and mothers got at least a kind word from their male relatives.
The Ford Foundation, which has just announced plans for the fifth public offering of Ford Motor Company stock, is one of the world's largest philanthropic enterprises.

ONCE upon a time is often the beginning to a fairy tale. However, the phrase is here turned to melancholy usage. For once upon a time Kenneth Armitage, an Englishman from Yorkshire, was a rare and fine sculptor. His new show at Rosenberg's, 20 East Seventy-ninth Street, measures only the distance he has fallen.

SEASONS are getting harder to define all the time. At even relatively humble vegetable stands, spring seems to be here in the form of sturdy stalks of asparagus. Strawberries, normally associated with June, are here from Florida in abundance.
If you were a student on a scholarship grant or a teacher overseas on a Fulbright grant last year, your tax bill may be lower than you think.
MOSCOW, March 8 Lieut. Col. John Glenn Jr., has a new namesake in Guryev, KazakhStan.

World sugar futures were strong yesterday in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The No. 8 contract closed 6 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) up to 1 off on 12,750 tons, the largest volume of the year. The May position was strongest and only the July contract eased.) Almost half the volume was in the October position.

LONDON, March 8 The Government reduced the bank rate today from 6 per cent to 5 per cent. It was the third one-half percentage point cut since the rate was raised from 5 per cent to the crisis level of 7 per cent last July.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 8 The White Sox were scurrying about the field but Al Lopez was relaxing in the dugout and talking about umpires. Tony Cuccinello, the Sefior's chief of staff, rushed over.

ALBANY, March 8 Two Senior Republican legislators proposed today that New York City get a greater share of state school aid than that recommended by a special legislative committee on school financing.
CAI NGAI, Vietnam, March 8 United States Army helicopters carried a Vietnamese battalion in a successful raid today against this Communist stronghold near the southern tip of Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 8 The Navy is taking official notice of the social influence of wives on officers' careers something it has been doing informally for a long time.
The United Presbyterian Church yesterday assailed Right-Wing extremists who disrupt its congregations with charges of Communist infiltration.

Net income of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation last year was $52,546,000, up slightly from 1960 earnings of $52,526,478, despite a 19 per cent cut in retail auto-sales-financing contracts, the report disclosed yesterday.

Shelby County, Tenn., announced plans yesterday to borrow $12,500,000 in the bond market to finance public school construction and other municipal improvements. The bonds will be offered for sale on April 2 and will come due from 1963 to 1987.

Donald W. Alexander, Federal Maritime Administrator, announced yesterday that he had resigned as a member of the executive Committee of the Propeller Club of the United States. The nation-wide organization is devoted to the promotion of the United States-flag merchant marine and allied maritime industries.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (AP) A former priest who is the center of a $2,300,000 suit against the Roman Catholic Church is living quietly and privately in California, his lawyer said today.

LE ROY, N.Y., March 8 Officials of this Western New York village were shaken today by news that the General Foods Corporation plans to close its Jell-O plant here.
CLEVELAND, March 8 The leader of 35,000 locomotive engineers charged today that the Presidential Railroad Commission had caused "the worst labor-management relations" in his union's ninetynine years.
Renewed efforts to convert Ellis Island into a college campus were disclosed yesterday by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 8--Destructive mobs roamed the streets and demonstrated in front of the United States Consulate today in protest against the exiling of a former President and a former armed forces chief.
A direct and forceful challenge to Executive authority over the military has been voiced twice the last week by Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
IN twenty-five years, 75,000 children in various parts of the world have been "adopted" through the Foster Par- ents Plan, Inc. The children are of twenty-seven different nationalities.
WASHINGTON, March 8 A bill to add three seats to the permanent roster of the House of Representatives was killed today on the House floor.
IF music is the true international language, Benny Goodman will never need an interpreter.

One of the characteristics of the agency business that is most bewildering to persons not involved in advertising is the incessant shuffling of accounts. Lawyers and accountants do not lose accounts all the time, the outsiders note, so why do advertising agencies?
The American Stock Exchange may be somewhat gloomy about its public image and its administrative problems, but it has some food earnings news.
TRENTON, March 8 Sixty candidates will run this year for New Jersey's fifteen seats in the House of Representatives.

Public transportation has traditionally been a matter of state concern in New York. So, when an emergency developed that shut down all service in the city on the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines and subsidiary bus routes, it was not surprising that it immediately became a state as well as a city problem.

THE Wiere Brothers, who have been one of vaude ville's more diverting turns for quite a spell, just possibly are going to find themselves with a modest TV hit. One show does not make a series, especially in the realm of situation comedy, but last night's premiere of "Oh, Those Bells" could be a sleeper.
WASHINGTON, March 8 The Federal Reserve System's abandonment of the controversial "bills only" rule for its dealings in the Government securities market has been made more permanent.
Nina Wilcox Putnam, the author of twelve novels and more than 500 short stories, some of which served as the plots for motion pictures, died yesterday in Cuernavaca, Mexico. She was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 8 A Senate Commerce subcommittee was told today that Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges had set a precedent that, if unchallenged, would leave the country "with a lopsided merchant marine."
WASHINGTON, March 8--Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, March 3, were 3 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, March 8 Freight volumes last week were considerably higher than the preceding holiday week and the corresponding week of 1961, the railroad and trucking industries reported today.
PORTLAND, Me., March 8 Governor Rockefeller called tonight for rejection of "defeatist nonsense" in Republican ranks.
Twelve oil producers, lawyers and brokers on trial in Federal District Court on charges of conspiring to commit a stock fraud, completed the opening moves in their defense yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 8 Nonaligned countries were reported today to have arranged a conference this summer to consider problems raised by the economic integration of Western Europe.
An American visiting Europe this spring would not find the gold alloy coin pictured here very useful.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8--Sound Stage 19 at Warner Brothers Studio was a bedlam of pistol shots, pounding hoof-beats and frightened whinnies. A microcosm of the Old Frontier seemingly had gone berserk.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 Casey Stengel drove the New York Mets through a short post-graduate course in baseball's meaningful minutiae today.

The second concert in the fourth annual Town Hall Festival of Music, which took place last night, was something of a birthday party. It honored the centennial of Claude Debussy's birth and the forthcoming eightieth birthday of Igor Stravinsky.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, March 8 French and Algerian rebel negotiators continued their search for peace today but said nothing about their accomplishments.

MOSCOW, March 8 An independent United States film producer and the largest Soviet motion picture studio signed an agreement here today that is expected to lead to the first coproduction of a movie by film makers of the two countries.

ALTHOUGH the reading of books may not be essential for virtue, health or happiness, those who do read books will never understand why some do not. How can anyone bear to miss such incomparable sources of delight, information, understanding, intellectual growth and vicarious experience?
EVERYONE seems to agree that the first year of the New York State Council of the Arts has been a remarkable success.

President Kennedy has just named two Democrats to be judges of the Federal Eastern District Court of Missouri. He had previously made eighty-five judicial appointments, of which eighty-one are Democrats. Of the other four, one is a Liberal party member and three are Republicans serving on the Federal bench as recess appointees of President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, March 8 President Kennedy's plan for the United States to purchase United Nations bonds narrowly survived its first voting test today in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
The Graham-Paige Corporation, an automobile maker that became an investment company, now plans to become a real estate concern and to change its name to the Madison Square Garden Corporation.
The New York Auction Company completed yesterday what it described as the largest mink offering ever presented in North America.

The United States monetary gold stock sustained its biggest weekly loss of 1962 in the week ended Wednesday when a $60,000,000 erosion occurred, according to a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Helen Louise Janosik, daughter of Louis Janosik of New York and the late Mrs. Janosik, to John Roland Winkelmann has been announced by Mr. Janosik. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland E. Winkelmann of Urbana, Ill.

MRS. RIXI MARKUS of England, bridge writer for The Manchester Guardian, who came to the United States for the world championship matches played in February and for the Cavendish Club's invitational pair tournament that followed those matches, was South and declarer in the deal shown today.
Lowell Ross Burch, chairman of the executive committee of the New York Air Brake Company, died yesterday in his home, 1 East Sixty-sixth Street, at the age of 74.

Alfred Reeves, formerly of Larchmont, N.Y., who headed the Automobile Manufacturers Association for more than a quarter of a century, died Wednesday night in the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 86 years old.

The Board of Education last night adopted a record budget of $581,879,187, exclusive of salary increases for teachers. The proposed outlay for the fiscal year beginning July 1 is $85,400,145 higher than in the current year.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to strip the strikebound Fifth Avenue Coach Lines of thirty-eight Manhattan franchises. The vote was a major step toward city operation of the bus routes.
After more than seven years of frustrated hopes, Benny Goodman is being allowed to take his music to the Soviet Union.
LONDON, March 8 The British Government has refused to accept the Labor party's challenge to ask the United States for its evaluation of the importance of British nuclear arms.
The election of Merritt D. Hill, 59 years old, as president and a director of the J.I. Case Company, farm machinery producer, Racine Wis., was announced yesterday by Samuel B. Payne, chairman.
WASHINGTON, March 8 The Administration moved cautiously today to head off a constitutional conflict with the House of Representatives over the B-70 bomber program.

"The bigger they are, the harder they fall," is a sports adage not customarily associated with basketball. But in the quarter-final round of the Public Schools Athletic League championship in Madison Square Garden yesterday 8,000 fans saw the two tallest teams in the city bow to smaller but more determined players.
INDIANTOWN, Fla., March 8 What happens when an angler hits one of the unreasonably dead times when bass keep their large mouths shut for no good or apparent reason?

BOSTON, March 8 (UPI)--Larry Jeffrey scored two goals tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-0 victory over the Boston Bruins. Hank Bassen, the Detroit goalie, recorded his third shutout of the season.

"Hell," he said, "I'd rather run the Pentagon from up here on the Hill."
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, March 8 One of the busiest men in Tanganyika is Julius K. Nyerere, the former Prime Minister.
Protests are mounting against a proposed drastic cut in New York State aid to educational television.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) The Pentagon civilian who guides the troop information program for 3,000,000 Americans in uniform said today he tried to stress patriotism and love of country rather than hatred of the enemy.

ALGIERS, March 8 As negotiators sought to end the Algerian war, French bombers and jet fighters took part today in an artillery, battle between French and Algerian forces that has raged along the border between Algeria and Tunisia for three days.
A group of Fire Island property owners appealed yesterday to President Kennedy for immediate aid to save the area from possible future disaster.

"We Take the Town," the musical starring Robert Preston as Pancho Villa that is making the final stop in its pre-Broadway travels, is about to lose one of its principal players.
New York stores are introducing their collections of copies and adaptations of Paris and other European fashions. Most of the clothes will be available by the middle of the month.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 (AP) Mario Capio of Italy lived up to his reputation as the No. 1 light-air sailor today by winning the fifth heat of the world Flying Dutchman championships.
ALBANY, March 8 Salaries of $25,000 a year for the 173 judges of the new civil and criminal court system for New York City were proposed in legislation filed today.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- The United States Court of Appeals gave clearance today for a three-year experiment with "pay" television.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) The Senate Antitrust Subcommittee today approved, by a 3-2 party-line vote, legislation that would require owners of drug patents to grant manufacturing licenses to other qualified companies after three years of exclusive rights.
A $40,000 oil painting stolen on Long Island was sold in Charleston, S.C., for $175, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday. An art shop owner in Charleston was arrested in the case.

WASHINGTON, March 8 The Federal Maritime Commission has granted approval to a cargo and revenue pooling agreement covering the trade between the West Coast of Italy and New York and other North Atlantic ports.

A REPORT has just come from England that Ter- rence Reese and Boris Schapiro won the British masters' pairs championship. They won by 3 match points from Albert Rose and Nico Gardener, who were members of the British team that played for the world championship in New York last month.

A MATTER OF SUCCESSION,"* by Patrick Cruttwell, is a brightly searching and entertaining parable for our time. The story concerns busy little empire builders, status huntsmen, juniorgrade despots, big men of destiny and courageously innocent bystanders in a nevernever land.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 9--An official in the Congolese Defense Ministry was reported today to have left secretly for the United States to buy four B-26 bombers from an American company.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)--A ruling by the National Labor Relations Board has erased one of the teamsters' Union's biggest organizing victories in recent years.

President Kennedy designated coastal areas of New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland and Virginia as disaster areas yesterday. The action makes the states and local commu- nities eligible for Federal aid to repair damage caused by the three days of high winds and high tides along the Eastern Seaboard earlier this week.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (AP)--Santa Anita's winter meeting ends tomorrow with fifteen horses named for the $100,000 added San Juan Capistrano Handicap.

Boys High gained the final of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship for the fifth time in six years yesterday. In a smoothly played game, the Kangaroos of Brooklyn beat Curtis, 68 to 48, before 5,500 at Madison Square Garden.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 8 --A trip into East Germany is a trip into a cold, gray, lifeless world, a world still showing the devastation of World War II, a world of shortages, a world of unhappy people.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Orfeo ed Euridice" at 2 P.M. and "Rigoletto" at 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Andre Kostelanetz, conductor, Patricia Wilde and Conrad Ludlow, solo dancers, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Murray Brown, dramatic recitations, Town Hall, 8:30; Tradewinds, folk singers, Judson Hall, 8:30.
Home owners plagued with lawn troubles may be able to combat such problems as crab grass, erosion and poor soil with a new product soon--a seeded carpet that can be rolled on.

Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald said yesterday that state legislation based on the Diefendorf Committee report would jeopardize the education of mentally and physically handicapped children.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)--The Army's information chief, Maj. Gen. Charles G. Dodge, underwent questioning today by Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, who sharply criticized the Army's efforts to teach troops about communism.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, March 9--French and Algerian negotiators made progress toward a final peace settlement here today.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP)--Davey Moore, the world featherweight champion, dealt Cisco Andrade the first knockout of his career tonight. He stopped him in the seventh round of their scheduled tenround non-title bout at the Olympic Auditorium.

HARTFORD, March 9 (AP) --Gov. John N. Dempsey went before the Inter-Collegiate Legislature today and urged defeat of a Yale student lawmaker's bill to lower the state's drinking age to 18. The mock legislative session is being held by students from Connecticut universities and colleges.

CLEVELAND, March 9-- Prof. Grace Longwell Coyle, an authority on group social work, died of a heart attack last night at Lakeside Hospital. She was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 9-- When the White House announced today that Maj. Gen. Marshall Sylvester Carter would be the next Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency it underscored his "considerable experience in international affairs."
MADRID, Saturday, March 10 (Reuters)--Juan March, reputed to be the richest man in Spain, died here today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident on Feb. 25. He was 81 years old.

ALGIERS, March 9--At least fifteen Moslems were killed by French soldiers, policemen and armed European civilians in a wild shooting episode in an Oran suburb this afternoon. It was reported that four of the dead were women.
The week's final trading session yesterday saw no abatement of the strong trend in United States Government securities and other high-grade debt investments.

SPARTA, N.J., March 9-- George Lipton, singer, actor director and producer, died today of a heart attack in his home at 150 East Mountain Road. His age was 15.
BEACON, N.Y., March 9-- Dr. John F. McNeill, superintendent of the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home. His age was 73.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 9 (AP)--The Philadelphia Phillies, faced with a picketing threat at home games this season because of segregation at their training camp here, may train elsewhere next spring, John Quinn, the club's general manager, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)--Refusal to answer questions in a grand jury investigation into the activities of the United States Communist party brought James E. Jackson a six-month jail sentence today.

A study of parking and traffic problems near Yankee Stadium when sports events are being held there will be undertaken early next week by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes. He said he was acting on a request made Wednesday by Mayor Wagner.

The Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads formally asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to approve their merger plans. The merger would result in the world's biggest railroad in terms of assets and revenues.

PSYCHIATRIST has called relaxation essential to pre- vent children from growing into "liesure-stricken week-end neurotics," whose headaches, tensions and anxieties are intensified during their free time.

THERE are three ways in which a writer may impart a sense of history: by weaving around its facts a glamorous robe of fiction; by presenting its facts in the light of imagination, of speculation, strictly controlled by reason and truth; by a marshaling of naked evidence, interrupted only by learned analysis and argument. It is the second way which Leonard Cottrell follows here.

WINNETKA, Ill., March 10-- Arch W. Shaw, a former publisher of business magazines, died yesterday in his home here. He was 85 years old.

BRIDGE players have never agreed on what part mathematical reckoning should play in determin ing the proper bid. A few experts consider bridge a game of mathematics, but the majority take an entirely empirical approach. They make bids that have turned out well for them on similar hands and they eschew bids that have failed for them or that they have seen fail for their opponents.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 10 (AP)--Some 100 Negro youths staged a protest march today to a hotel in Oklahoma City.
ALEXANDRIA, United Arab Republic, March 2--Alexandria, founded 2,000 years ago by Alexander the Great, was said in the past to belong more to the Mediterranean than to Egypt.

ATHENS, March 4--A climate of tension has developed on Greece's political scene because of the continued dispute between the Government and the Opposition over the results of the last elections four months ago.

NEW HAVEN, March 10-- Miss Photine S. Eliopoulos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Spyros A. Eliopoulos, became the bride here this afternoon of Walter C. Sterling Jr. He is the son of Judge and Mrs. Sterling of Hillsboro, N. H. The Rev. George Kerames performed the ceremony in St. Barbara's Greek Orthodox Church.

More than 5,000 Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish Girl Scouts celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the movement in the United States with special religious services yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, St. Patrick's Cathedral and Temple Emanu-El.

College basketball has ended its regular season, and tournament action gets under way tonight. But one important nontournament game remains--a contest between two highpowered rivals that holds a key to both major post-season competitions.

The chances seem good that the unfair exclusion of employee in voluntary hospitals and other nonprofit social and educational institutions from the legal right to collective bargaining will end this year. Governor Rockefeller and the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions have endorsed the principle of bringing these workers within the protection of the State Labor Relations Act, and appropriate legislation is expected to move forward under bipartisan auspices in a few days.

The marriage of Miss Sheila Sidon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Sidon of New Hope, Pa., to Irving Silverman took place here yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sussman Silverman of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi William Berkowitz at the Gotham.

Miss Judith Fuhrmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Fuhrmann of Curagao, Netherlands Antilles, and New York, was married here last evening to Sidney A. Zimet. He is the son of Mrs. Henry Zimet of 910 Fifth Avenue and the late Mr. Zimet. Rabbi Emanuel, Jakobovits performed the ceremnny at the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, March 11--Congress begins hearings tomorrow on two of this session's most controversial items--President Kennedy's foreign trade and civil rights proposals.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 (UPI)--The Equitable Assurance Society of America has signed a primary loan commitment of $11,400,000 for the first phase of construction for the proposed California Mart in downtown Los Angeles. The project will cost $50,000,000.

The Art Lloyd Metal Products Corporation has taken a longterm lease on the new factory building occupying tha entire block bounded by Linwood and Essex Streets and Cozine and Fairfield Avenues in the East New York area of Brooklyn. The building has 100,000 square feet of space, including soundproofed and air-conditioned mezzanine offices overlooking the entire plant. The plot is 200 by 500 feet.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 11 (AP)--King Savang Vathana deplored today the United States suspension of financial aid to the Royal Laotian Government. He blamed outsiders for Laos' troubles.
Mrs. Julia Sandford Villard of 825 Fifth Avenue died at her home Saturday after a brief illness. Her age was 85.

Senator Philip A. Hart asserted here yesterday that discriminatory aspects of the nation's immigration laws provided "grist for the propaganda mills of Moscow and Peiping."

SOLITUDE, Utah, March 11 --Dave Gorsuch, the 1960 American Olympian who has been essaying a comeback this season, roared over a precipitous mile-and-three-quarter downhill course today and thrust himself right back into the national skiing picture.
NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (AP)--A Coast Guard helicopter rescued today three crewmen who had been missing in the crash of an Air Force troop career.

ORANGE, N.J., March 11-- The marriage of Miss Maria Psiahas, daughter of Mrs. Theodore John Psiahias of Livingston and the late Mr. Psiahas, to Peter Spiros Ballas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spiros Peter Ballas of Bound Brook, took place here this afternoon.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 11--Patrick Corless, the Bronx tavern owner to whom St. Patrick's Day is about as important as Kerry blue terriers, had occasion to celebrate the grand day a week in advance today.

PITTSBURGH, March 11-- Some steel leaders believe it will take a week or so for mill schedules to reflect inventory thinking of metal users, after the break-off in steel labor negotiations on March 2, and the plan to resume talks next Wednesday.
LOS ANGELES, March 11-- Edward Sobol, producer and director of stage and television shows, died today in St. John's Hospital, Santa Monica, after a five-week illness. He was 70 years old.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11--Sailboats scudded over the glistening blue waters of Tampa Bay just beyond the left field fence of Al Lang Field. They heeled over in the strong breeze which riffled through the encircling palm trees. The wind joshed the swooping pelicans and fly balls. It tempered the 80-degree heat. It made this a delightful day.
Relatively few persons who lost homes and business properties in last week's storm will be able to collect insurance, the Insurance Information Institute said yesterday.

Charles L. Buchanan of 180 West Fifty-eighth Street, a former music, art and drama critic, died at his home yesterday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 11 --Human cells have been altered by exposure to nucleoprotein preparations, it has been reported here at a seminar of the American Cancer Society.

The idea of combining five bassoons in harmonious ensemble does not occur daily to every composer. It did occur to the eighteenth-century German Reinhard Keiser, who used this ensemble, plus harpsichord, as accompaniment for a soprano aria in his opera "Octavia."
LONDON, March 11--Despite a slight reduction in the bank rate, the stock market remained dull last week, with a modest downward trend.

Slowly but surely residents of this city have grown accustomed to harrowing predictions about what will happen under nuclear attack. With cool precision scientific forecasts calculated from ground zero give everyone a rough notion of his chances for survival, injury or annihilation; graphic charts and diagrams show with frightening detail how familiar areas will be wiped out, made uninhabitable or left on the fringes of the holocaust.

The Congo was a mysterious river and country in the time of Livingstone and Stanley, nearly a century ago, and in a different fashion it so remains. It was mysterious then because nobody knew much about it and it is mysterious now because of too many rumors, assertions and contradictions. The mystery of the jungle matches tile mystery of men's hearts and minds.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange scarcely moved in the early part of last week and when they did they were irregular. However, the prices turned firmer before the week was done.

PARIS, March 11--Professional and labor organizations called today for a thirty-minute work stoppage in the Paris region tomorrow to protest against yesterday's Right-Wing terrorist attack in the suburb of Issy-les-Moulineaux.

"Extra dry," a long-time advertising theme for champagnes, is being used in an ad for Callaway towels. This insertion for Callaway Mills, Inc., La Grange, Ga., has as a feature a towel wrapped around a bottle of champagne, both of which offer the quality of "extra dry," the ad says.

BEBRA, Germany, March 11 (AP)--The story of a young West German who carried his East German fiancee to freedom in a trunk was told by the West German police at this town on the border of East Germany today. The couple arrived here by train last night.

Martha Graham was unable to appear last night at the Broadway Theatre because of illness. It was the first time in her entire career that she has ever missed a performance.

Ripple-soled shoes and a broken case of whisky led yesterday to the arrest of a selfstyled "criminologist." The police said he was indeed an expert on crime.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad expects to reduce its net loss this year to some $6,000,000, Milton G. McInnes, president, told shareholders in the road's annual report for 1961. ALGIERS, March 11--French forces concentrated in Algeria's big cities will be on a "prealert" starting at dawn tomorrow to face a potential emergency linked to the cease-fire that is expected shortly.

Net income of the Household Finance Company last year amounted to $26,195,719, equal to $2.77 a share on 9,099,739 shares of common stock outstanding, according to the annual report issued today. This compared with the $23,277,072, or $2.42 a share, cleared for 1960.

People in eastern Westchester and southern Putnam Counties are having road trouble. It will be a wonderful road if the assumption is that all that is necessary is to move motor vehicles through the countryside in large numbers and at high speed.

ABOUT three years ago, a plain, bell-shaped bottle appeared on American perfume counters, unheralded by the usual publicity. It was Canoe, an eau de cologne blended, packaged and sealed in France. The women passed it by; the men and the boys took up the scent.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Wolfe, minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church, and Mrs. Wolfe of 2 East Ninety-third Street, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Debora Wolfe, to Jonathan Bartlett. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bartlett of New York and Essex. Conn.

THE revival of interest in F. Scott Fitzgerald shows no signs of abating. Young readers continue to discover him. Older readers return to his books to see if they are really as good as they once seemed. The odd thing about all this is that the Fitzgerald cult is not purely literary. Many people are more interested in the man than in his books.

BERLIN, March 11--East German border guards near Potsdam fired on a British military car last night, wounding the driver. The other passenger, Lieut. Col. Nicholas P. Browne, a member of the British liaison mission in East Germany, was uninjured.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 11--New Zealanders paid tribute today to the memory of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd. NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 11--Regis High School scored a 60-58 double overtime victory over Bishop Loughlin in the fifth annual Iona College Catholic High School basketball tournament today at O'Connell Gymnasium.
AMSTERDAM, March 11-- Narrow price changes and quiet conditions prevailed on the Amsterdam stock market this week.

WASHINGTON, March 11--At a monthly luncheon here on Feb. 20, a group of men watched a television screen intently. Luncheon was virtually forgotten as they followed the orbital space flight of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr.

Representative William E. Miller, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said yesterday he was unaquainted with the John Birch Society and that the society was not part of the Republican party.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)--Senator Jacob E. Javits, Republican of New York, pictured the Senate today as idling along when, he said, it should be settling a battle over civil rights legislation.

Edward M. Kennedy, the President's 30-year-old brother, said last night that if elected a Senator he would support Federal aid to parochial schools in "areas which might be considered constitutional."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 --The Woodrow Wilson Na tional Fellowship Foundation announced today grants for the first year of graduate study to 1,058 students from 319 colleges in the United States and Canada.

Americans who compose songs have long deserved a better fate than having their works relegated to the last few minutes of a recital program. Two younger composers, Ned Rorem and William Flanagan, have been trying for several years to set matters to rights.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP)-- The Boston Celtics equaled their National Basketball Association record of fifty-nine victories in a season by defeating the Los Angeles Lakers, 119--105, today. Boston closes its regular season against Syracuse here Tuesday night.

The Maritime Administration has approved the entry of the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company into the ranks of the nation's subsidized shipping operators after six and one half years of hearings and legal proceedings.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)--The International Commission for the Prevention of Alcoholism said today that for every nine Americans who began drinking, one would become an alcoholic.

VEGETABLE chowders probably were the invention of some resourceful housewife who wanted to make a hearty soup but found the larder almost bare. Originally, the dish called chowder in this country consisted of salt pork, onions, other vegetables and some kind of fish.

NEW HAVEN, March 11-- Four Henry Fellowships for advanced study at Oxford or Cambridge University in England next year have been awarded to seniors from Yale, Harvard and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Ohrbach's brings back the complete European fashion story and sums it up in wellmade, accurate, reasonably priced copies each season. In several instances, the fabric of the original design is used. Other fabrics are of high quality, which sometimes raises the price of the copy to the $150 to $200 range.

LONDON, March 11--The (Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said today that he believed that "for the time" the Soviet Union and the United States were in agreement on the principles of disarmament.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, March 11--The delegations of the French and Algerian Provisional Governments spent nearly six hours here today discussing the last problems separating them from a ceasefire agreement in the Algerian war.
SHIP BOTTOM, N.J., March 11--Long Beach Island, a sand spit separating Barnegat Bay from the Atlantic Ocean, was digging out from under hundreds of tons of sand and debris today.
LISBON, Portugal, March 11 (AP)--Admiral Manuel Carlos de Quintao Meireles died tonight at the Naval Hospital. His age was 84.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)--William E. Miller, Republican national chairman, said today he saw no signs that Governor Rockefeller's popularity had been harmed by his impending divorce.
Efforts to prepare teen-agers here for employment were indicted yesterday in a report by a nonprofit organization specializing in educational research and the study of delinquency and discrimination.
CHICAGO, March 11--A large labor union has laid the groundwork for a campaign to win collective bargaining contracts that include "active retirement" rights.

Robert Cummings and Audrey Meadows will star in "The Action in New Orleans," an original comedy--romance to be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, April 15, from 10 to 11 P.M. It depicts a confidence man known as the Big Alabama Wonder who tries to extort a million dollars from an Ohio widow.

GENEVA, March 11--The crucial fact to be recognized at the forthcoming disarmament conference is that Russia achieved a weapons break-through during its last nuclear tests. Therefore, unless Moscow agrees to built-in nuclear controll and fair inspection, the United States must resume testing itself. We have to aright the balance before Moscow mass produces its new discoveries in coming years.
Three Verdi operas will receive their last performances of the season during the Metropolitan's twenty-second week beginning Monday, March 19.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11--The New York Mets scored their first victory today, beating the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, in an exhibition game at Al Land Field.

GREENVILLE, Del., March 11--Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Henry Winey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Winey, to Ensign Karl Drew Hartzell Jr., U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hartzell of Lewisburg, Pa.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 11--Jenny Holmes of Scarsdale, N.Y., won hunter seat horsemanship honors in the Secor Farms horse show at the Secor Farms Riding Club's indoor ring today.
Andre Kostelanetz made the third and last appearance of his series as guest conductor with the New York Philharmonic on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.
Alexander Kahn, labor lawyer and general manager and publisher for many years of The Jewish Daily Forward, Yiddish newspaper, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 80 years old.

The appointments of John B. Hale as president and W. M. Harper as vice president and sales manager of AC Automatic Services, the vending and music equipment sales and service division of the Automatic Canteen Company of America, has been announced by the parent company.
Max Harrison, president of the American Maritime Association, has been named mediafor in a dispute between three maritime unions and the American President Line, operators of the mercy ship Hope.

The Huntington-Manning Medal of the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be awarded at 4:30 P.M. today to Florence M. Kelley, Presiding Justice of the Domestic Relations Court of New York City.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 11 (AP)--Doug Sanders staved off a rally by Don Fairfield today and won the $20,000 Pensacola open golf tournament by a stroke. It was the first victory of the year for the 28-year-old native of Cedartown, Ga., and he earned $2,800.
Reports that Vivien Leigh intends to appear in the musical variation of "Tovarich" were confirmed yesterday by Abel Farbman, co-sponsor of the show with Sylvia Harris.
A springlike day attracted large crowds to the International Flower Show at the New York Coliseum yesterday.
Representative Leonard Farbstein, thirty years a legislator, said yesterday he was confident of re-election to Congress this fall from Manhattan's new Nineteenth District.
Construction expenditures of the New York Telephone Company will set a new high in 1962, according to the annual report issued over the week-end.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 11--Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor this year.
Six new films will arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 (AP)--Dartmouth won only three of fourteen Ivy League basketball games, but it produced the league's scoring Champion in Steve Spahn, a junior.

The National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D.C., pursued the Good Neighbor policy in its annual Carnegie Hall concert last night. It presented a brilliant young Brazilian pianist in a rhythmically exciting piano concerto by an Argentine composer.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 11--Suzy Chaffee, 15 years old, from the Killington (Vt.) Ski Club, today won the first running of the Arthur G. Draper Memorial giant slalom on Whiteface Mountain with a time of 1:15.2.
GENEVA, March 11--For a few days anyway, the diplomatic diet for big-power foreign ministers' luncheons and dinners is likely to include Berlin and disarmament.

MEXICO CITY, March 11-- Many formerly difficult problems of Jews have largely disappeared, Dr. Nahum Goldmann said here today, but social upheaval has produced new ones. He particularly cited Cuba and the Soviet Union.
Members of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York have arranged for a cocktail party and dinner on Thursday in the St. Regis Roof to celebrate the 125th anniversary of their alma mater.
LONDON, March 11--Sir Philip Gibbs, author and journalist, died yesterday at the age of 84.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)--President Kennedy returned to Washington tonight.
A priest of the Anglo-Catholic wing of the Protestant Episcopal Church took issue yesterday with the Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rector of lustoric Trinity Church.
Business executives faced with the task of selecting new office space for their companies frequently must decide whether to lease or sublease quarters.
Where is the consumer? That is the question more and more economists ate asking these days, mostly because they know he has money to spare--and to spend--but retail sales do not reflect it.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines went into court yesterday to block the city's cancellation of the permits for thirty-eight Manhattan bus routes.

Emery Roth Sons, architects, have moved to new quarters in 850 Third Avenue, a twenty-story building at Fiftyfirst Street that was designed by the architects for the Uris Buildings Corporation. The lease involves one floor with 14,000 square feet. The architects occupied space on three floors at 400 Park Avenue and other space at 59 East Fifty-fourth Street.

Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases gave its Kathairine Berkan Judd Award last night to Dr. Edith H. Quimby, Emeritus Professor of Radiology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons.
The most difficult problem encountered by municipal officials who must approve new building materials is to obtain factual data to support manufacturers' claims for their products.

MEXICO CITY, March 12-- The status of Algerian Jews under the agreement expected shortly on the future of Algeria has been guaranteed, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, said here today.

Some of the best examples of Scandinavian furniture are included in the Fritz Hansen collection of Danish furniture that goes on display on Lord Taylor's eighth floor today. It is the first time the entire collection has been shown in America. Previously, only individual pieces have been available; some have been seen in museums here.

Elizabeth Speare, author of a book for children entitled "The Bronze Bow," and Marcia Brown, artist of the children's picture book "Once a Mouse," were named the winners yesterday of the John Newbery Medal and Randolph Caldecott Medal of the American Library Association.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 12--The expropriation of a telephone system owned by a United States company in the state of Rio Grande do Sul became a political issue today within the Brazilian armed forces.

ATLANTA, March 12 (AP) --Frank Leahy believes Joe Kuharich will resign as the Notre Dame football coach unless the Irish have a winning season in 1962. The former Notre Dame coach said here today that Kuharich didn't get "a lot out of the boys" last season.
DETROIT, March 12 (AP) --The auto industry continues to build cars at a rate that appears to indicate it is not yet convinced a steel strike can be averted this summer.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- The House Ways and Means Committee gave final formal approval today to its modification of President Kennedy's farranging tax bill.
For the first time in international labor relations a LatinAmerican union moved yesterday to assist a North American union.
Franklin Simon, a leading name in New York retailing for sixty years, reopened for business here yesterday in a new location and with renewed elegance.
MOSCOW, March 12 (AP)-- The Soviet Tennis Federation named seven candidates tonight for the team that will play the Netherlands in May in the Davis Cup eliminations.
DES MOINES, March 12 (AP)--Two Pennsylvanians turned in a 1,266 series today and took over seventh place in the classic doubles division of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

ROSWELL, N.M., March 12 (UPI)--A work stoppage at atlas missile sites ringing Walker Air Force Base here ended today. Operating engineers accepted agreements reached in an all-night bargaining session.
ALBANY, March 12--Commissioner Barnes carried his fight to the Capitol today to exempt New York City from a proposed state-wide uniform traffic-sign law, but he met with only limited success.
NEWARK, March 12 (AP) --The West Side Adult School here prepared a course on survival in a disaster for 400. Only four registered.
Portents of a protracted controversy emerged here yesterday at the opening of a national hearing on a proposal that would authorize the Federal Governmen to regulate the marketing of potatoes.

The Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation, a subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, announced yesterday the election of Howard T. Brinton as chairman and Edgar P. Dunleavy as president. Mr. Brinton will continue as chief executive.
MADRID, March 12--An association is to be established in Madrid to promote a rapprochement between Christians and Sephardic Jews, the descendants of Jews expelled from Spain in 1492.
Dr. Nathaniel Jay Gould, consultant in ophthalmology at Fordham Hospital and the Bronx Eye and Ear Infirmary, died Sunday in his home, 940 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, at the age of 68.
The stars and the writer-director of Broadway's "A Gift of Time," undeterred by the somber drama's lukewarm reviews, are determined to collaborate on a screen adaptation this summer.

ISLAMORADA, Fla., March 12--After the "cold" snap of last week--which to the local fishermen means something like 70 degrees--the fishing has come back well here on the keys, with the boats and anglers going out daily. They head north and west and south through the Bay of Florida, around hundreds of mangrove islands toward the Gulf of Mexico. Or they go east into the Atlantic and the Gulf Stream.
CAGNES-SUR-MER, France, March 12--Trotting in France is not nearly so well organized, so well entrenched nor so rich as thoroughbred racing.

An optimistic conclusion regarding the economic and social consequences of disarmament --if disarmament should ever come--has been reached by the United Nations' expert committee whose report has now been published.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP)-- Frank London Brown, author of the novel "Trumbull Park," died today of bronchial pneumonia in the University of Illinois Educational Research Hospital. He was 34 years old.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 12 (AP)--Charles Aedo of Los Angeles and Dianne White of St. Paul won the senior titles yesterday in the national indoor speed-skating championships. Three hundred races were held in the two-day meet.

DENVER, March 12 (AP)-- Sweden's rugged, fast team routed Finland, 12--2, tonight for its third straight victory in the world hockey tournament. The result set the stage for tomorrow night's game against Canada's unbeaten defenders.
Plans for the Green Shoe Manufacturing Company of Boston to acquire the Weber Shoe Company, Inc., of Tipton, Mo., manufacturer of children's shoes, were announced yesterday.
BOSTON, March 12 (AP)-- Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, 71year-old mother of the President, entered St. Elizabeth's Hospital today and will undergo surgery for a pelvic hernia tomorrow.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 12-- The Shah of Iran will lead an assault tomorrow against a principal bastion of Iranian feudalism.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 12 (AP)-- Five members of the disbanded Trujillo intelligence agency said yesterday that three socially prominent Dominican sisters who were found dead last year had been slain by army agents.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today that he would call up for debate this week a constitutional amendment to abolish poll taxes.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., March 12--For the past nine days here, at an indoor mountain called the Concord Hotel, Emile Griffith has been living the life of a hungry fighter in a $130-aday suite with two television sets and a closet the size of a Y.M.C.A. room.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 12-- Encouraging results have been attained with a new method of treating some types of cancer, it was reported here today at an American Cancer Society's seminar for science writers.

Louis Beryl, a New York insurance broker, is going ahead with his plans for a proxy fight with the management of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company, Boston-based minerals concern.

At a technical meeting here yesterday a biochemist from Columbia University sounded what a colleague termed a "clarion call for prudence" to be exercised by scientists who are asserting that they are near breaking the so-called "code of life."

A motel to be built by Edward Linn, builder, at Exits 14 and 15 on the Connecticut Thruway in Norwalk has been leased to the Courtesy Inn chain. Brodsky, Hoef Adler are the architects. The Lemus Construc tion Corporation is the general contractor.

MOSCOW, March 12--The Soviet Communist leadership appealed to the nation's farmers today to go out and produce. The party call was something like a football-rally pep talk by a coach on the eve of a big game.

Bruce Rae, who died yesterday after fifty-two years of service for this newspaper, was a great newspaper man. He arrived at this distinction by hard work, by unwavering persistence and by natural gifts.
More than 5,000 convicts at four of the state's five maximum security prisons refused to work yesterday to protest a bill on paroles.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 12 --Dr. Pham Huy Quat, an opposition leader, has sent an open letter to the United States Ambassador, Frederick E. Nolting Jr., explaining why many Vietnamese nationalists refuse to cooperate with President Ngo Dinh Diem.

Antonio Marcilla, a former delivery boy for women's highfashion clothes, mixed style with brutality, at St. Nicholas Arena last night as he won a bloody ten-round welterweight decision from Vince Shomo of Manhattan.
ROME, March 12--Four bearded Capuchin monks appeared before a criminal court in Messina, Sicily, today on charges of complicity in homicide, extortion and blackmail.

TOKYO, March 12 (AP)-- The United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East unanimously adopted a resolution today calling on advanced nations to be fair in their trade with less developed countries.
A metal mining company disclosed yesterday it was entering the airline business.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12-- The Curtis Publishing Company of Philadelphia, the grand old lady of the magazine publishing world, may be in for some changes on the corporate level.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The United States Air Force is prepared to fly fighter escorts for commercial planes in the three air corridors between West Germany and West Berlin if Soviet harassment continues, officials here said tonight.
Pan American World Airways signed a multimillion dollar contract yesterday for a world-wide electronic reservations and communications system.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--The White House announced today that President Kennedy would inspect missile sites at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California on March 23.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 12 --William N. Nigey, former owner of a hotel in New York and earlier the banquet manager of the Astor Hotel there, died Friday at his home after a two-month illness. He was 71 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12--The Soviet Union offered today to withhold nuclear weapons, and the information required to produce them, from other countries if the Western powers did the same.

MIAMI, March 12 (AP)-- Ingemar Johansson, the former heavyweight boxing champion, today was granted a ninety-day period in which to appeal a court order directing him to pay the Internal Revenue Service more than $1,000,000 from fight purses.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., has disclosed that Edward V. Rickenbacker, its chairman and chief executive officer, will retire if a proposed merger with American Airlines, Inc., is effected. The merger is now before the Civil Aeronautics Board for approval.

An agreement for some time has seemed near in the dispute between Indonesia and the Netherlands over West New Guinea, but the two powers have been unable to take the final steps necessary for a settlement.
BIG STONE GAP, Va., March 12 (AP)--Gary Powers received a standing ovation today from his neighbors here in southwest Virginia.

After prolonged prodding by architectural and other professional groups, New York has allotted $86,500 for a study of its civic center. The Planning Commission has taken the first step by designating a block within the area as part of a land bank for the city's future administrative needs.

A composition by Dimitri Mitropoulos will be presented at the second annual Mitropoulos memorial concert at 8:30 P.M. Sunday in Carnegie Hall. The concert will also include the debut of the Senior Musicians Symphony.
The first volumes of two series of books about the making of this nation are planned for publication early next month.
Ohio State was named the national college basketball champion yesterday for the second straight year in the season's final polls of The Associated Press and United Press International.

A LITTLE bit of pot-pourri can go a long way and for Claire and Fred Burke it has. The couple have found a small gold mine in mixing dried spices, herbs and flowers from a special recipe that Mrs. Burke developed as a hobby.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)--A union publication said today that the space flight of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. had struck a blow against job discrimination because of age.
As though times weren't tough enough in France, Frenchmen are now faced with another crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)--The Coca-Cola Company, New York City, agreed today to a Federal Trade Commission consent order prohibiting allegedly illegal brokerage payments to purchasers of citrus fruit.

L.L. Colbert, former chairman of the board, president and chairman of the finance committee of the Chrysler Corporation, who resigned these offices last July 27, was the automobile producer's highest paid executive last year.

Mrs. Beatrice Hecht Stone of 630 Park Avenue, wife of Jacob C. Stone, a member of the stock-brokerage house of Asiel Co., died yesterday at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. Her age was 61.

While the big hopes of the seven American astronauts may all be in space, their money is now being solidly committed to earth-bound real estate ventures in Florida, Washington, D.C., and the Grand Bahamas.

SVOLVAER, Northern Norway, March 12 (AP)--A huge plastic balloon from the United States almost caused panic today among Norwegian fishermen in the coastal fishing village of Loedigen, Northern Norway. Its finders said it had been sent up by a scientific station at the University of Minnesota.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, renewed his opposition today to any Federal support for the 1964 New York World's Fair.

George Lincoln Rockwell, leader of the American Nazi party, and Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, have been invited to speak at Hunter College in the Bronx next month by a campus political party.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 12--Dr. Charles B. Roberts, who retired in 1960 after more than a half-century as a dentist in Jersey City and Orange, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 4 Chestnut Street.

OSLO, Norway, March 12 (AP)--The world champion, Helmut Recknagel, and other East German ski jumpers have been refused visas by the Norwegian Foreign Office and will not be able to take part in next Sunday's annual Holmenkollen Ski Festival.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 12--The Detroit Tigers made an unexpected, but electrifying, challenge to the Yankees last sedson and Chinese chronology labels this one as the "Year of the Tiger." The youthful Bengals prepared for it before the exhibition schedule began by engaging in only one workout a day and Manager Bob Scheffing denied that his decision to eschew two-a-day drills had been influenced by earlier exposure to Pepper Martin.

BALTIMORE, March 12 (AP) --A lawyer for the Hunt oil interests in Texas testified in United States District Court today that he tried to persuade National Football League officials not to expand into Dallas.

HAVANA, March 12--Premier Fidel Castro announced tonight nation-wide rationing of rice and beans, basic items in the Cuban diet. He also announced the total rationing of lard and cooking oils, items rationed in most areas since last year.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- President Kennedy nominated Jesse E. Eschbach, a Republican, today to be a United States District judge for northern Indiana.
A two-inch rain, wind and high tides hit the metropolitan area yesterday, adding to the devastation of last week's storm. The rainfall set a record for a March 12 here.

ABOUT at the mid-point of last night's concert hon oring Henry Cowell, at the Juilliard Concert Hall, Mr. Cowell himself came to the piano and played four of his pieces. To many in the audience, it was sheer nostalgia.
BONN, Germany, March 12-- Mr. Erich Mende, chairman of the Free Democratic party, said today he was against a "German disengagement or neutrality for the country."

A five-foot-high bronze statue of Icarus, the mythological Greek flier who went too close to the sun with his wax-fixed wings and fell into the sea, will be presented to the city at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.

PROBABLY since the first coffee bean was roasted com mercially the public's drinking habits have been of concern to coffee producers. And, altruistically or not, they also have pondered brewing methods in the home.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)--An expert on military law said today that command influence over military courts and boards of review had caused some "shocking cases" of poor trial procedure.

JACKSON, Miss., March 12 (UPI)--A hearing on a Negro suit to integrate public facilities in Jackson opened today. The city held that Negroes had chosen a period of high racial tension to challenge segregation.
A woman was accused yesterday of having used her daughter to deliver narcotics. She was arrested by detectives seeking narcotics sources around Thirteenth Street and Avenue B.

In reply to your letter in which you asked about the Soviet Government's opinion concerning the convocation of an international conference to sign a convention banning the use of nuclear weapons, as provided for in the United Nations General Assembly's Resolution 1,653/16 of Nov. 24, 1961, I can state the following:

Several thousand representatives of the electrical industry invaded the Coliseum yesterday to flip switches, turn knobs, strip wires and, more importantly, to place orders, at the sixth National Electrical Industry Show.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 12 (AP)--Australia's former world auto-racing champion, Jack Brabham, today won the Sandown International Cup at the New Rampdown circuit.

Overseas operations of the Ford Motor Company and thirty-six foreign subsidiaries resulted in sales of 722,968 passenger cars last year, an increase of 5.3 per cent over 1960, Henry Ford 2d, chairman, and John Dykstra, president, reported yesterday in the company's annual report.
