CHICAGO, March 12 (UPI) --George S. May, promoter of some of golf's biggest tournaments, died today at his Tam O'Shanter Country Club of a heart attack at the age of 72.
There is a remarkable collection of bonsai to be seen at the International Flower Show at the New York Coliseum this week.

WASHINGTON DEPOT, Conn., March 12--Announcement has been made by Mrs. Fritz Ludwig Amberger of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Hedwig Amberger, to Joshua Brackett of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony H. Brackett.
With little hope of success, reform Democrats will seek to elect one of their number as chairman of the New York County Democratic Executive Committee at a meeting Friday at the Chatham Hotel.
LONDON, March 12--Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., conceded today that it had failed in its bid to obtain control of Courtaulds, Ltd.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 12--Andrew Bache Newcombe, district sales manager for American Airlines in New York, died of a heart attack today at his home, 355 Shore Road. He was 52 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Director of the Food-forPeace Program proposed today that the United States agency provide by 1965 hot lunches for 120,000,000 undernourished school children in under-developed countries.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 12--Premier Jan E. de Quay said tonight that the Netherlands was ready to go ahead with the United Statessponsored negotiations with Indonesia over the Netherlands New Guinea dispute.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 12--Leonel Brizola is a Horatio Alger type. His story, the poor boy who made good, is one Alger might have told, but with a twist written by a Left-wing Brazilian nationist.

TRENTON, March 12--Gov. Richard J. Hughes declined today to consider a proposal for the erection of a jetport in conjunction with an industrial park atop Bowling Green Mountain in northwest Morris County.
Sergius A. Vassiliev, a retired civil engineer, died Sunday at his home, 27 West Sixtyseventh Street. He was 80 years old.
Music of Fela Sowande, an African composer, will be performed by members of the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall on Monday, April 9.

Wingate's Generals beat the Frenchmen of Lafayette, 53--52, in Madison Square Garden yesterday and reached the final round of the Public Schools Athletic League Division I basketball championship. The victors will meet Boys High for the title Friday evening on the same court.

Food shortages in Cuba were reported earlier this month. A British journalist said after a week's stay in Havana that practically nothing but insecticides and sugar were on the shelves of groceries there.

I am sending to the Legislature tonight a message of necessity to permit early consideration of legislation to give the City of New York the powers you have requested to take over the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines by condemnaion.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Federal Government has published from time to time findings by the National Institutes of Health on smoking as a cause of cancer. It has not embarked on a concerted campaign to curb smoking as the Royal College of Physicians has urged the British Government to do.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--Leo Szilard, a physicist who in 1960 thought he might die of cancer within a year, said today that his symptoms had vanished.
WASHINGTON, March 12--The Administration opened its case for broad new tariff-cutting powers today before a favorably inclined Congressional committee.

NEWARK, March 12--The State Department of Education and the Board of Education of Englewood asked the Federal District Court here today to dismiss a complaint alleging racial segregation in Englewood's elementary schools.
SARASOTA, Fla. March 12-- With a flashy display of running, fielding and batting skills, the New York Mets defeated the Chicago White Sox, 8--4, today in an exhibition baseball game at Payne Park.
NEW DELHI, India, March 12--India will strive at the Geneva disarmament conference to reconcile East-West viewpoints for the sake of a "warless world," President Rajendra Prasad said today.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Soviet Union has indicated willingness to cooperate with the United States in the development and use of a weather satellite system, the chief of the Weather Bureau reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)--Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, today accused the Amateur Athletic Union of hurting the United States' cold war effort by blocking an American tour in which an all-star amateur European basketball team would play the professional Harlem Globetrotters.

THE indulged child and his permissive parent occupied the stage center yesterday at the thirty-eighth annual conference of the Child Study Association of America at the Roosevelt Hotel. An estimated 1,400 persons attended the conference.
It was a year ago today that President Kennedy called upon Latin America to join the United States in an "Alliance for Progress."
TRENTON, March 12-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes discussed with school officials from all parts of New Jersey today a legislative program he hoped would do much to alleviate segregation in this state.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)--The Food and Drug Administration is challenging advertising claims of two roastpeanut firms, partly on the ground that many people just can't resist one more handful of peanuts.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 12 (AP)--Nine boys did sweeping today at the State Fair Grounds as the state began a work-counseling program for school dropouts.

The 1962 legislative session has been moving along at a sedate pace, with the Republican leadership trying to avoid any momentous controversies and at the same time taking the adverse heat out of troublesome past issues such as rent control and milk-dating.

BOSTON, March 12--The American Newspaper Guild filed a petition today with the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board here for an election to represent employes at the Plant of DowJones Co. Inc., at Chicopee Falls, Mass.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--Three Democratic and three Republican Senators announced today that they were introducing bills to carry out all the 1961 recommendations of the Civil Rights Commission.

CHICAGO, March 12 (UPI) --The firemen's union today ordered a strike vote against the nation's railroad's to strengthen the union's hand in negotiations against proposed changes in work rules that eventually would eliminate 40,000 firemen's jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--Deputy Defense Secretary Roswell L. Gilpatre took issue today with critics of the fall-out Shelter program. He said shelters could save 40,000,000 to 55,000,000 lives in a nuclear attack.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes has decided after nearly two months on the job that on many streets it is "almost impossible" to enforce parking restrictions against reisdents who think they are entitled to park where they live.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- President Kennedy told Congress today that passage of his proposed improvements in the unemployment compensation system was "especially urgent."

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 --Reserves relinquished their places on the New York University bench to first-stringers tonight and provided the momentum that carried the Violets to a 70-50 triumph over Massachusetts at the Palestra in the opening round of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

Robert W. Dowling is serving as chairman of the City Center Showcase and midnight supper arranged in honor of Mrs. Ruth Houghton Axe. The Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital is sponsor of the event, which will be held at the New York City Center of Music and Drama on May 21.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that steps would be taken immediately to intensify the city's attack on the narcotics problem.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 12 (AP)--The owners of two horse racing publications were arrested today less than an hour after a Federal grand jury indicted them on charges of violating laws against inter-state shipment of gambling materials.
The young woman in the blue and white uniform bent over the hospital patient and...
Passenger platform enclosures will be installed on the suburban bus level of the Port Authority's midtown terminal starting today.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 12 (AP)--Henry Williams of Fleetwood, Pa., won the Jamaica open golf tournament by four strokes yesterday with a 72hole score of 274.
Officials of several Eastern states were accused yesterday of selling out motorists to advocates of toll roads.

RECIFE, Brazil, March 12 --A technical assistance agreement was signed here today by the Governments of Israel and Brazil for the development of water resources and organization of cooperative farming communties in Brazil.
Oslo, Norway, has placed in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission $10,000,000 of sinking fund external loan bonds due April 1, 1977.
Steel production edged upward last week after having declined for two weeks.
LONDON, March 12--Britain's Secretary of State for Air asserted today that the United States Administration attached the "greatest importance" to the Royal Air Force's nuclear weapons.
The appointment of Paul T. O'Keefe, former Deputy Mayor, as Commissioner of Real Estate was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The appointment will take effect on April 1.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner presented clothing yesterday to the Volunteers of America as an advance contribution to a spring salvage drive. The gifts were made at Gracie Mansion to Maj. Joseph Roden, director of men's service activities of the Volunteers. Mrs. Wagner plans to be away from the city on March 21, when the drive will begin.
Plans to open 100 new variety stores, most of them in shopping centers, were announced yesterday by the F. W. Woolworth Company.
The Campbell Soup Company reported yesterday that its sales and earnings set records for the six months ended on Jan. 28.
Officials in the White House and State Department have received a Bronx couple's theory on how to avoid a nuclear war. It combines some of the ancient tactics of feudal lords and Alexander the Great.
MIAMI, Fla., March 12 (AP) --Democratic opponents of candidates endorsed by President Kennedy at a party dinner are telling the President they are unhappy about his "intervention" in a primary.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Treasury's short-term borrowing costs bounded upward on today's sale of the regular weekly issues of thirteen-week and six-month bills, despite an unusually heavy volume of bidding.
Every bridge player will occasionally encounter a hand on which the apparent sacrifice of a sure trump trick is the only winning defense, because it breaks up a crossruff.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, March 12 (Reuters)--A New York harbor pilot was on the return trip tonight of a luxurious trans-Atlantic voyage that began when he couldn't get off the ship in New York.

Saw Aime Forand, former Rhode Island Representative, on medical care for the aged; sent letters to the House and Senate urging permanent changes in the unemployment compensation system; met with Labor Secretary Goldberg and seven labor leaders.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, March 12--The sixth session of hard bargaining by French and Algerian negotiators here today brought a cease-fire in the Algerian war to within a couple of commas of signature.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Administration's plan to abolish the cumbersome sugar import-quota system as part of a new sugar act is meeting serious opposition in Congress and from domestic and foreign producers.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 12--The seventh baby in four days died today at Binghamton General Hospital as the authorities investigated what appeared to be a case of multiple salt poisoning.

Literary moonlighting seems to be a growing trend in the advertising world. More and more copywriters, account executives and other denizens of Madison Avenue are devoting their evening hours to writing novels, plays and other literary works.
Windham Children's Service will celebrate its fifteenth anniversay with a benefit luncheon at the Sheraton-East on April 11.
LONDON, March 12--The Government opened a campaign today to educate the public, especially school children, to the dangers of smoking cigarettes.

An original play by Tad Mosel, "That's Where the Town Is Going!" will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Tuesday, April 17, from 10 to 11 P.M. It is the first TV drama by the author since he won a Pulitzer Prize for "All the Way Home," the Broadway play.

The number of horses already stabled at tracks here went over 1,000 yesterday as preparations continued for the opening next Tuesday of the spring thoroughbred and harness racing campaigns at Aqueduct and Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I.
The two halves of the Liberian tanker Gem were under tow by two salvage vessels and bound for Jacksonville, Fla., the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 12-- President Kennedy has assured Congress that Executive privilege will be invoked only with his specific approval.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--The Girl Scouts celebrated their fiftieh anniversary today with a luncheon for Senators and House members.
Ski enthusiasts returning from a fortnight in the Swiss Alps complained last night that they had been held four hours aboard their chartered jet airliner in Philadelphia.
ALBANY, March 12--State Controller Arthur Levitt announced tonight that he had ordered an independent audit of the books and dealings of the New York City Transit Authority.

Edward T. McCormick, who resigned under fire as president of the American Stock Exchange last Dec. 11, was a guest of Alexander L. Guterma, convicted stock swindler, at Miami in 1955, Guterma testified yesterday in Federal Court here.
The imminent expiration of the Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Program at a time when unemployment is still high and there are large numbers of long-term unemployed makes ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 12 (UPI)--Butler's basketball team upset Bowling Green, 56-- 55, tonight in the first round of the National Collegiate midEast regional tournament. Jerry Williams scored the deciding points on free throws with thirty seconds left.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- President Kennedy accepted today an invitation to speak in New York on Sunday, May 20, at a rally to stimulate public support for his program of medical care for the aged. The rally will be held in Madison Square Garden.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rodman of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rodman's sister, Miss Lila Elson, to Samuel Bader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bader of Larchmont, N.Y. The bride-to-be is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Elson of New York.
WARSAW, March 12--Foreign Minister Adam Rapacki flew to Geneva today prepared to renew Poland's call for an atom-free zone in Europe.

The Elgin Trucking Corporation of Philadelphia has leased the one-story terminal building at 556 Thirty-seventh Street. It will use the building in association with D. L. Delivery, a subsidiary, in an expansion of its New York operations.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 12--If maturity is the yeast of baseball, this could be the year the Boston Red Sox rise again.
The Brooklyn Opera Company will present five Italian operas in its spring season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music starting April 7.

GENEVA, March 12--Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union conferred on the Berlin problem today, but nothing emerged to encourage Western hopes for a settlement of the crisis.

Sixty-four housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration are planning the sale of issues of temporary loan notes, totaling $179,074,000, on March 20. The largest issue will be that of the New York City Authority, which will total $124,000,000.
There was a new Turandot at the Metropolitan opera last last night in the person of Mary Curtis-Verna.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--Despite a slower starting tempo than expected, the Government predicted today that business spending on expansion projects would reach a new record by the end of the year.

The annual spring theatre party in behalf of the Berkshire Farm for Boys will take place at the May 23 evening performance of "Bravo, Giovanni" at the Broadhurst Theatre, where the musical is scheduled to open May 19. It will have Cesare Siepi and Maria, Karnilova as leads.
A two-woman expedition from Roosevelt Hospital was sent over the Canadian border last week-end to recruit nurses.
Individual stocks rather than groups dominated the market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

GUESTS in the St. Regis Hotel are never very far away from the necessities of life. Should they decide to have a cocktail party, ornament a lapel with a new jewel or catch the next jet for Paris, they will discover that the Helene Arpels Boutique is accustomed to such crises.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)--The National Parks Service estimated the cost of acquiring land in ten proposed park areas at $63,750,000 today.
A plea for the training of more Catholic psychiatrists was made here yesterday by the president of the Guild of Catholic Psychiatrists.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP)-- A late selling drive wiped out several gains in the grain futures market today and left prices steady to weak on the Board of Trade.

The fifty-ninth annual American Toy Fair opened here yesterday amid declarations by spokesmen for the industry that this would be "the biggest year" in its history. However, many of the day's 1,869 visiting buyers expressed concern over the increasing number of high-price items.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 12 (UPI)--Mack Jones today hit his fourth home run in three exhibition games as the Milwaukee Braves handed the Cincinnati Reds their third straight defeat, 5-1.
IF Oscar Hammerstein 2d were still here, he would have a special interest in the Oscar Hammerstein Festival at the Forty-Sixth Street Theatre, Sunday evening, April 8.
The first national intercollegiate bowling tournament in which teams meet face to face will be staged at the United States Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs starting April 24.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 (AP)--Brae Burn Farm's Shirley Jones, out of the money in three previous starts this year, defeated favored Chicha by a head today in the featured seventh race at Gulfstream Park. Yar Girl was third, two and a half lengths behind Chicha and a head in front of Marwol.
The directors of the Fluor Corporation, Ltd., omitted the dividend on the capital stock yesterday. The last payment was 5 per cent in stock in December, the only disbursement in 1961.
ALBANY, March 12 (AP)-- Benjamin S. Rosenthal, a Democrat, today was officially declared the winner of a Feb. 20 special election for a Congressional seat in Queens. He won by 264 votes.

GENEVA, March 12--The Soviet Union's latest proposals on disarmament were taken by Secretary of State Dean Rusk and his closest advisers today as confirmation of their suspicion that the disarmament conference here would be primarily a propaganda battle between East and West.
The field of finance has opened up again for Anton E. Homsey, who was expelled as a member of the New York Stock Exchange on charges of fraud in September, 1960.
BERLIN, March 12--The Soviet Union flew four transports in a Berlin air corridor today at times and altitudes coinciding with those of Allied commercial flights.

BERRYVILLE, Va., March 12--Mr. and Mrs. David Rumsey Donovan of Chapel Hill Farm have made known the engagement of Mr. Donovan's daughter, Miss Patricia Hazard Donovan, to Raymond Richard Guest Jr. He is the son of Mr. Guest of Fredericksburg and Mrs. Elizabeth Polk Guest of Washington and Front Royal.

RENO, Nev., March 12 (AP) --Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller's two daughters were with her today at a guest ranch as the wife of New York's Governor heared the end of the six-week residency required for divorce. One daughter, Mrs. Robert L. Pierson, 28 years old, arrived Friday night. Her sister, Mrs. William Strawbridge, came to the Donner Trail Ranch a little more than a week ago.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)--A Federal appeals court postponed indefinitely today the jailing of James E. Jackson, editor of The Worker, for his refusal to testify before a grand jury investigating Communist party activities.
Charles A. Julianelli, a designer of women's shoes, died Saturday of a heart attack in Wickersham Hospital. He was 54 and lived at 130 East End Avenue.

Jane Fonda, daughter of Henry Fonda, who was seen in two Broadway plays ("There Was a Little Girl" and "Invitation to a March"), is to be starred in her third appearance here. She has been signed by Jay Julien for his next entry, "The Fun Couple."
A Pole who hid Jewish fugitives from Nazi troops during the German occupation of Poland asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to forbid the televising of a play based on his experiences.
JERUSALEM, March 12-- Israel published officially today two regulations that might bear on Adolf Eichmann's appeal against his death sentence and on his execution if he loses the appeal.

OTTAWA, March 12 (AP)-- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker told the House of Commons today that nine Canadians had smuggled gold and opium within the Indochina area while serving with international truce supervisory commissions.

WYNNEWOOD, Pa., March 12--A June wedding is planned by Miss Daphne Douglas Bettle and Oscar Yale Lewis Jr. Mr. and Mrs. Griscom Bettle Jr. have made known their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis of Roanoke, Ala.
The vocational training offered at the New York School of Printing was defended yesterday by Don H. Taylor, president of Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York, Inc.

The appointment of Joseph Weber as director of agency relations of the Greater New York Fund was announced yesterday. Mr. Weber, who lives in Bronxville, N.Y., succeeds Paul C. Fahrney, who will remain with the fund as a consultant until the end of the year, when he will retire.

A TELEVISION viewer is not always a person to be trusted. To tidy up his status he may declare in public that he yearns for shows that will fertilize the intellect. Then in the privacy of the parlor he may gently succumb to the half-hour that leaves the mind relatively undisturbed.
LONDON, March 12 (AP)-- Vyacheslav Rogozin, Russian international chess grand master, died yesterday in Moscow, after a long illness, the Soviet press agency, Tass, reported. He was 53 years old.
PARIS, March 12--Imports of the European Economic Community from the United States rose 6 per cent last year.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)--The Judicial Conference of the United States today condemned picture-taking at any Federal trial, as well as broadcasting or television reports from the courtroom.

LONDON, March 12--Most sections of the stock market opened the new account today on a better note. With the view gaining ground that a tough budget is unlikely, buying increased and most sections benefited.

DANIEL BARENBOIM who made his New York debut with the Symphony of the Air five years ago, played last night for a second time with that orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Not only did he score another success, but also he vindicated that ensemble's faith in him.

Union Electric Company and subsidiaries reported operating revenues of $163,709,045 for 1961 against $159,189,239 a year earlier, according to the annual report released yesterday. Net income of $28,454,954, equal to $2.31 a share, compared with $26,921,271, or $2.17 a share, in 1960.
BOSTON, March 12 (AP)-- The Earl of Avon today underwent an operation in which a benign growth was removed from his chest. He was reported in good condition after the surgery.
FOLKESTONE, England, March 12 (AP)--The Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference announced today lower fares for groups during the 1962 thrift period.

"THE LABYRINTH OF SOLITUDE: Life and Thought in Mexico" opens win dows on a neighboring land many tourists love more than they understand. It is by Octavio Paz, a brilliant poet, diplomat, philosopher and--do I repeat myself?--controversialist.
GROSSE POINTE, Mich., March 12--Isabella Holt, a novelist, died today at her home here after a long illness, She was 69 years old and the wife of Haldeman Finnie, a retired steel executive.

BAGUIO, the Philippines, March 12 (UPI)--Vice President Emmanuel Pelaez, warning that the Far East abounds with dangers that could start World War III, called today for a vigorous non-military offensive by the West against communism in the region.
A new investment management concern has been formed here by Lewis B. Cullman and William Leach as principals. The new concern is called Lewis B. Cullman, Inc.
Bond prices surged upward anew yesterday in a session especially brisk in over-the-counter trading of high grade corporate obligations.

GUATEMALA, March 12 (AP)--Guatemala officially has been in three days of mourning for Dr. Adrian Recinos, historian and diplomat who represented his country as ambassador to the United States, Spain and other countries. His age was 81.
ALGIERS, March 12--French military intelligence was understood today to have reported Algerian rebel troop concentrations in southern Morocco.

Sales of the Singer Manufacturing Company for 1961 and for the fourth quarter alone were the highest in the concern's history, raising profits for both periods, the preliminary report disclosed yesterday.

One of the greatest faults of the modern-day theatre--whether on Broadway or in the West End--is "the lack of enunciation," according to Ethel Griffies, British actress now costarring here in "Write Me a Murder."
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 12--Two Frenchmen who are suspected of being members of the French Rightist Secret Army Organization were arrested today while driving from the Belgian-French border.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 12 (UPI)--Cincinnati, the nation's second-ranked college basketball team, defeated Bradley, 61--46, tonight in a play-off game for the right to represent the Missouri Valley Conference in the National Collegiate Tournament.

More than 27,000 square feet of retail store space will soon be available on Broadway between Thirty-third and Thirtyfourth Streets. The space will be offered for rent following a $300,000 renovation program.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 12--Frank A. English, a lawyer here for more than fifty years and a former State Inheritance Supervisor for Union County from 1918 to 1958, died today at Elizabeth General Hospital. His age was 77. He lived at 700 Westminster Avenue.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 12--More than 5,000 persons have applied for passports to leave British Guiana for Britain, Canada, the United States and other countries in the last few weeks. About 4,000 of them want to settle in Britain.

ONCE upon a time department stores were founded so that a woman could find all her needs under one roof. Each item had its own department-- all the hats were in one place, all the luggage in another. Then the department stores got so big that they decided it would be better to have little shops within the big ones.

ALBANY, March 12--Max J. Rubin, president of New York City's Board of Education, agreed today to a change in proposed legislation that would give the City Planning Commission a voice in the selection of future school sites.
CAIRO, March 11--A Congress recently chosen by popular vote will assemble in Cairo early in April to consider a new national charter for the United Arab Republic.

Bruce Rae, a member of the staff of The New York Times for fifty-two years, who was Considered one of the greatest reporters of his time, died yesterday of a stroke in Grand Central Hospital. He was 69 years old.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 12--Bad news continues to pile up for the American League, although the results of exhibition games usually mean little.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 65 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 12--Six possible courses of action to end racial imbalance in the five elementary schools here were presented to the Board of Education tonight.
NEW DELHI, India, March 12--Mrs. John F. Kennedy received a gay and glowing welcome to India today.
ALBANY, March 12--The Senate unanimously approved tonight the administration bill raising the state minimum hourly wage from $1 to $1.25 in two steps. The bill now goes to the Assembly.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., March 12--Mr. and Mrs. David Hall Faile have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy McConnell Faile, to Roger Kress Riley. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manton L. Riley of Canandaigua, N.Y.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 12--Sylvester Young L'Hommedieu of 181 South Street, a dog fancier and former stockbroker, died yesterday in his home. He was 84 years old.
A senior, four juniors and a sophomore were named to the all-Ivy League hockey team yesterday by the league's six coaches.
New York City has made important strides in recent years toward providing equal rights and opportunities for its 1,000,000 Negro residents.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 12 (AP)--Three national officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were refused rooms in a downtown hotel today.

The Houston Corporation and its subsidiaries expect to report a consolidated net income of $201,000 for 1961, W.J. Bowen, president, announced yesterday. This would compare with a 1960 loss of $4,181,000. Mr. Bowen said that the companies' revenues last year rose by 17.3 per cent to $34,681,000.
PARIS, March 12--Public transport was hampered and work in many factories was halted today by a half-hour protest strike against the terrorist tactics of the Secret Army Organization.
Trading was active in both the world and domestic sugar contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. World prices tumbled but domestic quotations inched up.

Eight detectives testified yesterday that they had seen several "known criminals" at the Copacabana night club. They testified at a Police Department hearing called to determine if the night club should have its cabaret license revoked.
ALBANY, March 12--Efforts by New York City to take over the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines set off a sharp political conflict between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner tonight.
Inmates at New York state prisons continued their work boycotts yesterday in protest against changes in parole procedures.
ALBANY, March 13--Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the state speed at least a share of the payments it makes to persons whose land it seizes for public works projects.

Production of paperboard in the nation totaled 350,490 tons in the week ended Saturday, according to the National Paperboard Association. This compared with 349,612 tons in the preceding week and 323,093 tons in the comparable 1961 week.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 13--Fordham Prep advanced to the semi-finals of Iona College's fifth annual Catholic high school basketball tournament tonight by defeating Cardinal Hayes, 60-45.
THIS deal was played in a team-of-four match, so there were two declarers. Each played a contract of six no-trump with the South hand. One declarer made his contract and the other went down.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Following is the text of remarks made by President Kennedy at a reception for Latin-American diplomats at the White House today:
TEANECK, N.J., March 13 --Frank A. Blackledge, a retired foreign auditor for the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He would have been 69 years old today.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 13 --United States Army pilots described today how they prevented a disabled helicopter from falling into Communist hands last Friday by changing its engine under gunfire.
LOS ANGELES, March 13-- Antoinette Zoellner, who with her father and two brothers formed the famous Zoellner String Quartet, died at her home Sunday at the age of 76.

A state-wide survey of 5,700 welfare cases is being undertaken by the new Moreland Commission on Welfare. It will seek to find why the recipients are on relief and whether a "constant eye" is seeking ways to help them become self-supporting.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--President Kennedy learned today how his former political science professor came to vote for him for Senator rather than for another former student who was running against him.

The 4,000-seat Brooklyn-Fox Theatre and adjoining twelvestory office building at Flatbush Avenue, Nevins and Livingston Streets in Brooklyn have been sold by the Brooklyn Fox Corporation. The property was bought for cash over a first mortgage of $1,500,000 by the Fox Flatbush Corporation.

Sent foreign aid message to Congress; had breakfast with Democratic legislative leaders; met President Ahmadou Ahidjo of the Federal Republic of Cameroon at the airport and later held White House luncheon in his honor; met with ...

An issue of $65,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, due June 1, 1994, was awarded yesterday to an investment banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on their bid of 99.32.

Tape recorded educational talks and clinical discussions on rehabilitation will be exported this year in a program conducted by the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of New York University Medical Center.
A lawyer was acquitted last night by a jury in Bronx County Court of charges of grand larceny and conspiracy resulting from a report of a false automobile accident in the Bronx on Nov. 2, 1959.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)-- A Federal court jury acquitted two men and deliberated tonight on a verdict for the third man accused of dealing in bonds taken in a $12,000,000 Canadian bank burglary.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)--Spurred by Representative Carl Vinson, the House Rules Committee cleared today for a House vote legislation that would "order" the Administration to spend an extra and unwanted $320,000,000 on the controversial B-70 bomber program.

Miss Cathy Brown, a 17-yearold senior at Jamaica High School in Queens, made a sale yesterday. Her customer was Betty Furness, radio and television performer. The product was a decorative plant holder.
James H. Leonard, executive secretary of the New York Purchasing Agents Association from 1920 until his retirement in 1957, died Sunday night at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. His age was 74.
The Maine potato industry faces economic disaster unless a national marketing program for potatoes is adopted, a Federal hearing was told yesterday.
GUATEMALA, March 13--At least twelve teen-age students, including four girls, were wounded by gunfire today when the police attempted to disperse demonstrating students.
BUFFALO, March 13 (AP) --Dr. John Eross, a member of the Hungarian Cabinet before the Communists took control of the country in 1948, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 72 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- A marine expert told a House appropriations subcommittee today that the recent East Coast storms would have a marginal effect on prospects for game fishing there.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association asked Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges yesterday to hold up approval of operating subsidies for Isbrandtsen Steamship Company.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company had the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its history during the three months ended Jan. 31, the report disclosed yesterday.
CORVALLIS, Ore., March 13 (UPI)--Utah State staved off a rally in the closing minutes and beat Arizona State, 78-73, in a National Collegiate tournament first-round regional game tonight.
SOUTHBURY, Conn., March 13 (AP)--George Andrew Holmes, who waged a fight against the German-American Bund here in the Nineteen Thirties, died at a Waterbury hospital yesterday at the age of 82.

The announcement that rationing of staple foods, soap and detergents is to begin in Cuba next Monday is no surprise. In a real sense there has been rationing in Cuba through scarcities and--to a lesser extent--higher prices, for many months.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., March 13--Mr. and Mrs. H. Neal Jones have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jaren Jeryll Jones of New York, to Bruce Ducker. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Ducker of Manhattan and Neponsit, Queens, New York.

Senora George Bingham of Olivos, Buenos Aires, has made known the engagement of her daughter, Senorita Gladys I. Bingham, to Peter K. Grunebaum. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt H. Grunebaum of New York and Harrison, N.Y.

The new administrative leaders of the Amateur Athletic Union called yesterday for "everyone to get on the team" in a concerted effort to give the United States the strongest possible international sports representation.
ALBANY, March 13 (AP)-- Organized labor scored a victory today in the Assembly, where a bill to outlaw the use of so-called professional strikebreakers was passed, 82 to 34.
PARIS, March 13--The International Aeronautical Federation certified today the seventeen-orbit flight last August of Maj. Gherman S. Titov.
FRANKLIN, Pa., March 13-- Rollin R. Bleakley, a former president of the Franklin Trust Company, died last evening in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he had lived for twenty years. He was 75 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- A charge that some New York City principals and teachers "seem to be dragging their feet" in implementing the school system's integration policy was made at a Congressional hearing today.

NEWARK, March 13--The enrollment of a Presbyterian minister as a member of the presbytery of New Brunswick has been reversed because of his refusal to affirm his belief in the doctrine of the Virgin Birth of Jesus Christ.
FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J., March 13--Samuel Bowers, former Mayor and member of the first Town Council here, died yesterday in his home here at the age of 85.
Cocoa futures tumbled in active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices fell 34 to 45 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,148 lots of 30,000 pounds each.
BROKEN BOY, by John Blackburn (Mill: Morrow, $3.50). A novel of suspense.
COMMACK, L.I., March 13 (AP)--The New York Tapers erased a 12-point half-time deficit and defeated the Hawaii Chiefs, 102-98, tonight in an American Basketball League game.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 13 --A Carmelite monk living in Haifa sued in the High Court today for the right to settle in Israel as a Jew.
Gerard Piel, publisher of the magazine Scientific American, has been elected president of the Salk Institute for Biological Studies now being built in San Diego, Calif.

THE American Opera Society, which has always made a point of being different, succeeded in being different even from itself in Carnegie Hall last night. It presented "Die Lustige Witwe." ("The Merry Widow)."

AMMAN, Jordan, March 13 (AP)--An agreement between the Government of Jordan and the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company was signed at the Foreign Ministry here today under which Jordan would immediately receive $10,000,000 in arrears from the concern, plus more than $4,000,000 a year in royalties for pipelines crossing Jordan. The former royalty rate was $850,000 a year.
The long-standing pedestrian practice of scrambling across Broadway at Wall Street received official sanction yesterday.

WIESBADEN, Germany, March 13 (AP)--The United States Air Force disclosed today the specific charges on which a court-martial will try Capt. Joseph P. Kauffman, who allegedly gave information to East German agents.
ALBANY, March 13--Agreement on two bills to allow New York City to take over the strikebound Fifth Avenue Coach Lines was reached tonight by representatives of Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- President Kennedy asked Congress today to provide $25,000,000 for the Federal Government's participation in the 19641965 New York World's Fair. He called participation "essential."

BALTIMORE, March 13-- Since the ten-year development program of The Johns Hopkins Fund began in 1958, cash and pledges totaling more than $36,000,000 have been obtained for capital projects and new programs of The Johns Hopkins University and Hospital.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 13 (UPI)--The Laotian Government has reacted to the withholding of United States aid by announcing a sweeping austerity program.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Administration encountered a generally critical reception today as it opened its case in the House Commerce Committee for broad private ownership of a communication satellite system.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 13--An unusual high school of round and square units is planned for District 1 of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown.

St. John's and Fairfield were named yesterday as the recipients of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's fifth annual basketball team awards for outstanding performance during the regular season. The major college trophy went to St. John's on the strength of a 19-4 won-lost record.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 898 persons were hurt in car accidents here last week. This is an increase of seventy-six persons over the similar 1961 period.
The bond market continued to climb to new price heights for the new year yesterday, with long-term obligations of the United States Government furnishing the leadership.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Administration said today that a net gain in employment in the United States would result from increased exports in the next five years under President Kennedy's tariff program.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Newspaper publishers protested to Congress today that many newspapers would suffer hardships under a proposed surcharge in mailing rates.
Sports cars, like daffodils, bloom in the spring.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 13--For the second time in judicial history here, charges of criminal anarchy have been filed against defendants for their attempt to break down racial discrimination.
The city arranged yesterday for a broad public forum on Mayor Wagner's rent-control program.

DENVER, March 13 (AP)-- Mrs. May Bonfils Stanton, a daughter of the late Frederick G. Bonfils, co-founder of The Denver Post, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She entered the hospital last week-end.

WHEN the Seattle World's Fair opens April 21, the New York World's Fair will have a booth staffed by three young women wearing uniforms designed by Seventh Avenue's Jo Copeland. Thus New York's No. 1 industry, fashion, will be graphically displayed to the thousands of fair-goers.

Dr. Robert Soblen's conviction on charges of conspiring to commit wartime espionage was unanimously upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. The court also denied Soblen's application for a new trial based on "newly discovered" evidence.
An earthquake in Yugoslavia, an epidemic in the Phillipines, the lack of medical ...
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 13 (AP)--South African newspaper publishers said today they had adopted a "voluntary code of conduct" in handling news and editorials.
The Metropolitan Opera has changed its schedule for next Monday because of the illness of Dorothy Kirsten, who was to sing Puccini's "Tosca."

Sales of Eli Lilly Co. for the first two months of this year were about $37,700,000, for an increase of 21 per cent from the level of the 1961 period, Eugene N. Beesley, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting in Indianapolis, Ind., yesterday.
A Roman Catholic psychiatrist said here yesterday that any form of birth control, including the church-approved "rhythm method," was psychologically bad.

GENEVA, March 13--Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, interrupted their talks on the Berlin problem today, apparently to give Mr. Gromyko time to receive new instructions from Moscow.

GREENFIELD, Mass., March 13--Albert Vail Simis, who had served as a city editor on the old New York Evening Telegram during World War I, died here yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Russel B. Wilkes. He was 81 years old.

YONKERS, March 13--Former police Lieut. Jerome F. Linehan, who spent thirty-four years in the Yonkers Police Department as a motorcycle policeman and a detective, died last night in St. Joseph's Hospital at the age of 82. He lived at 44 Prospect Drive.

A 77-year-old grandmother will have her day in court soon in an effort to collect $10,000 rent from the Federal Government. She contends the Government has been parking a fleet of ships in her front yard on the Hudson River.

HIS approach to a case at law--pursuit of every last shred of evidence--once took Samuel Hazard Gillespie to the bottom of the Grand Canyon for three awesome but stifling nights. An airplane collision in 1956 had claimed 128 lives and, as lawyer for insurance companies, ...
MIAMI, March 13 (AP)-- Steve Barber, who conquered the New York Yankees four times last season, arrived in the Baltimore Orioles' spring training camp today on military leave.

Detroit Edison Company's anual report released yesterday showed that the giant utility had set in 1961 new highs in total operating revenues, total energy output, average domestic customer usage and a new daily peak load.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- President Kennedy asked Congress today for appropriations totaling $4,878,500,000 for economic and military foreign aid during the fiscal year beginning July 1.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The last ship of the fading Antarctic "summer" has headed north and some 285 Americans left behind are getting ready for the winter of isolation.

BEFORE dawn on Jan. 30, 1948, two men were hiding in a small room rented to travelers in the Delhi railroad station. They were both Maharashtrians from Poona. Naturam Vinayak Godse was a newspaper editor, a fanatical Indian nationalist and a member of a reactionary secret society. His friend and humble disciple, Vishnu Apte, owned the newspaper for which Natu worked and belonged to the same society.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I. March 13--When the Wheatley School dramatic club presents Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" this month, it will do so with the personal advice and best wishes of the playwright.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13-- Contrary to the usual medical belief, a rare and deadly form of cancer known as melanoma does not present an unusual hazard to women during pregnancy, a research team reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--United States military advisers have started training Thailand's army to fight Communist guerrillas, apparently in anticipation that Thailand may be the next target of the Red drive to control Southeast Asia.
BERLIN, March 13--Soviet planes scattered aluminum foil for a half hour today at two points near Berlin in what was considered to be a new attempt to interfere with Western radar communications.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)--The House Foreign Affairs Committee unanimously approved today legislation to double the Peace Corps in its second year of operation.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- President Kennedy signed a bill today that raised the Federal debt limit to $300,000,000,000, the highest since World War II.

Five criminal informations charging illegal rebating practices were filed in Federal Court yesterday by the Justice Department against the Waterman Steamship Corporation, seven importing corporations and six individuals.
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 13--Bergen County's immediate past, present and future were examined today by three experts, who found the outlook good.
JERUSALEM, March 13-- The defense brief appealing the court judgment on Adolf Eichmann and the death sentence imposed on him was made public today.
HONG KONG, March 13 (UPI)--The Hong Kong Government warned local textile manufacturers today against making any new commitments on the export of textile goods.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 13-- Congo, a ten-month-old, 150pound African lioness, licked the hands of a District Court judge here today to demonstrate her gentleness.
LONDON, March 13--Industrial shares and British Government securities responded to an increase in demand with long lists of gains in the stock market here today.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 13 (UPI)--Defense attorneys for James R. Hoffa, seeking dismissal of a mail-fraud indictment, entered as evidence today a statement allegedly made by President Kennedy in a campaign debate with Richard M. Nixon.
BOSTON, March 13--Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, the President's mother, successfully underwent surgery for a pelvic hernia today at St. Elizabeth's Hospital.
BONN, Germany, March 13-- A political storm erupted today in the wake of a statement by a leading member of the Free Democratic party that Germany had been at war with Russia for thirty years.
The four-story building at 116 East Fifty-fifth Street has been bought by the Radio Advertising Bureau, the sales and promotion organization of the radio broadcasting industry.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 13--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Lipton of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Lipton, to Gary Citrin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Citrin of Brooklyn.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it was "ready and willing" to cooperate with State Controller Arthur Levitt in an independent audit of its books and dealings.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 13--Frederick L. Bascom, an official of near-by Franklin Township for almost thirty years, died this morning after having suffered a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)--About a dozen youths held a sit-in demonstration for several hours today in Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's outer office. They protested the Administration's civil rights policies.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--Five "specific and realistic opportunities for expansion in coal consumption by 1967" have been suggested to the office of coal research, the Depart of the Interior announced today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 13--Yugoslavia's Communist Government granted an amnesty today to most of its political opponents, including members of units that fought against Marshal Tito's Partisans during World War II.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 13-- Rear Admiral Harold R. Lehmann, U.S.N., retired, died today at the Naval Hospital here after a six-month illness.
A New Jersey savings bank says that it has cut the time its customers must wait for tellers to an absolute minimum, thanks to a new electronic filing system.

PUTNEY, Vt., March 13--Dr. Kristian G. Hansson, who was a member of the examining boards of the New York State Medical Association and of the American Congress of Physical Medicine before his retirement in 1956, died Sunday in a nursing home in Brattleboro. He was 72 years old.
The Auxiliary of the James Ewing Hospital is arranging a benefit at the April 5 performance of "No Strings." The new Richard Rodgers musical opens tomorrow at the 54th Street Theatre.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 13--The Chamber of Deputies has ousted two Left-Wing nationalist leaders from the steer ing committee that will direct the work of the Chamber when its next session opens on Thursday.

President Kennedy asked Congress yesterday for $25,000,000 to build and furnish with exhibits a United States pavilion at the New York World's Fair, which is scheduled to open April 22, 1964. He thus confirmed his earlier promise of support. Now it is up to Congress to do promptly what has been too long delayed: endorse the planning and construction of a showcase that will document before the world our way of life.

With the war drums of rival financial institutions booming in the background, New York State's Superintendgent of Banking Oren Root issued a statewide plea for peace yesterday. Mr. Root's message was in the form of a letter addressed to the chief executive officers of all New York commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations.
PITTSBURGH, March 13 (AP)--Steel negotiators under pressure from President Kennedy, will resume contract talks tomorrow at 11 A.M.

District 65 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union announced last night it had reached agreement on new three-year contracts covering 4,000 workers in retail dress shops and shoe stores in the city.
ALGIERS, March 13-- French warships are reported to be patrolling off the Algerian coast, ready to intervene if needed in an emergency after a cease-fire in the Algerian war.

Television advertisers often fret about the fact that viewers do not pay sufficient attention to the commercials. When the commercials come on, they complain, too many viewers seem to doze or switch stations or head for the kitchen for a can of beer.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 13 (UPI)--An electrical fire at an Atlas missile defense complex south of here tonight triggered an Air Force alert. Officials said later the alert was erroneous and there was no danger.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 13 (AP)--Plans were announced here today for a permanent monument in Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr.'s home town of New Concord, Ohio, to commemorate his space flight.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Factory employment recovered in February more than it lost in January, the Labor Department reported today. Average working hours increased, too, contrary to the normal February trend.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- A bill to separate the security and policing activities of the State Department from its immigration functions passed the House today.

Susan Yorke, author of six previous novels, will have Malaya as the background for her seventh, called "Agency House, Malaya." The author lived in that country for three years while her English husband, E.A. Shuttleworth, managed a rubber plantation.

RYE, N.Y., March 13--Mrs. Richard J. Kelly has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Angela Duclos Kelly of New York, to William Heverin Hobson 3d. He is the son of Mrs. Hobson Jr. of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Hobson.

JAMES WATT, as every school boy is taught, saw a source of limitless energy when watching a kettle boil. He learned to harness it. Lee Krasner at the Howard Wise Gallery, 50 West Fiftyseventh Street, has watched abstract expressionism boil, and in her new pictures has harnessed energy too.

Leaders of the nation's two major shipping trade associations announced yesterday their support of legislation that would direct secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges to grant subsidies for the construction of two giant United Statesflag ore carriers.
A rare Northern European finch, called the "brambling," has unaccountably turned up in western Massachusetts.

Forbes Inc., publisher of Forbes Magazines, announced yesterday that it had signed contracts to buy the eightstory building at 60 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Twelfth Street, from the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.

A special committee of the League of New York Theatres held its first conference yesterday with Robert W. Dowling, Mayor Wagner's cultural executive, to solve problems ranging from ticket scalping to making theatregoing easier. As a result of the complex agenda, only one phase was touched upon, expanding the sale of tickets.

WASHINGTON, March 13--A spokesman for the Defense Department said today that predictions of widespread lay-offs at the Republic Aviation Corporation at Farmingdale, L.I., had "gravely distorted" the situation.

THE St. Patrick's Day parade is an annual favorite of the city's children. The parade will begin at noon on Saturday and progress up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth Street to Eighty-sixth Street, where it will turn east to Second Avenue. The reviewing stand will be at Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfourth Street.
ROME, March 13 (AP)-- World tea production rose 7 per cent in 1961, while the world's biggest tea consumer, Britain, was increasing its tea imports by almost 8 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The House approved today a hill to let the Justice Department compel companies to surrender documents in civil antitrust investigations. The roll-call vote was 338 to 58.
ROME, March 13--Pope John XXIII named today "celestial protectors" of airline hostesses and of men in the industrial field.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, one of the nation's largest tobacco manufacturers, once again has diversification on its mind. It was learned yesterday that the company recently formed a division for the purpose of bringing out new products.
There has been a marked decrease recently in court actions against landlords in the city's twelve neighborhood conservation districts.

In the Palace of Nations in Geneva, the former headquarters of the ill-starred League of Nations, in a council chamber bearing the warning inscription that "the nations must disarm or perish," the chief ministers of seventeen nations meet today under the aegis of the United Nations to make a "supreme effort" to halt the deadly armament race.

New York investors operating as Vasey Associates, Inc., have bought the twelve-acre industrial property on Jersey Avenue in New Brunswick, N.J., from Mack Trucks, Inc. Mack, which used the plant to make trucks and parts, is vacating it. Mack has moved to Maryland.
Spring-like settings remain fresh and perky as the International Flower Show continues to attract crowds to the New York Coliseum.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 13--Peter D'Aguiar, leader of the United Force, said today he feard that independence would bring revolution to British Guiana and that Cuba would intervene to support the Government, which he termed Left-wing.

Sid Abel, the coach of the Detroit Red Wings, and Doug Harvey, the player-coach of the New York Rangers, agreed yesterday that tonight's National Hockey League clash between the clubs at Madison Square Garden is a "make-or-break" affair for the fourth and last Stanley Cup play-off berth.
Union and management members of a Presidential commission studying a dispute on the manning of railroad tugboats disagreed yesterday on the value of a witness presented by the carriers.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 (UPI)-- The Federal Government received today bids totaling almost $178,000,000 in the first offerings of what was expected to be one of the richest tidelands oil and gas leases sale in history.

The disagreement over the design of the Protestant chapel to be built at New York International Airport has been resolved. The Port Authority announced yesterday the approval of designs for Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish chapels of "varied but related form, with stone exterior."
Eugene Ionesco, one of the avant-garde playwrights now attracting off-Broadway audiences, has made his initial foray into films.

Reactive Metals, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, said that it would get out of the steel business and concentrate on its titanium, zirconium and other special metals, National Distillers acquired complete control of Reactive about two weeks ago.

ST. LOUIS, March 13 (AP) --Harry Gallatin, once a star with the New York Knickerbockers, got the job today of restoring the St. Louis Hawks to their former heights in the National Basketball Association.
MOSCOW, March 13 (AP)-- A United States medical exhibition here was attacked today by the Soviet Health Ministry's medical newspaper, Meditsinski Rabotnik, as being untruthful.

Bankers and savings and loan association executives were cau tioned yesterday against reaching for mortgage loans to meet increased interest rates on savings. Dr. Saul B. Klaman warned against making loans that would be rejected under more normal conditions or liberalizing terms of other loans simply to gain higher yields.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13--The Security Council will meet tomorrow afternoon to consider Cuba's charge that the Organization of American States violated the United Nations Charter in voting to exclude Cuba from activities of the organization.
The discussion of remedial tax legislation may divert one's attention away from an older tax break.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)-- Grain futures finished under selling pressure today with most contracts at or near their lows of the day on the Board of Trade.

Informed sources in Wall Street expressed the expectation yesterday that the Curtis Publishing Company of Philadelphia was about to accede to the demands of dissident stockholders for two seats on the company's eleven-member board.
A newborn llama, unaccountably abandoned by its mother at the Bronx Zoo, is starting to thrive, thanks to the tender, loving care provided by a keeper and his wife.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 13--The appointment of Lieut. Gen. Harry P. Storke, retired, of Arlington, Va., as the president of the Worcester Polytechnic Institute was announced today. General Storke will take office April 1, succeeding Arthur B. Bronwell, who resigned last month.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Inter-American Development Bank approved today a technical assistance loan of $800,000 to help finance national development studies in Argentina.

A first-time novelist who used to be a Bellevue pathologist, a poet who subsists by molding anatomy models, and Lewis Mumford were named yesterday the winners of the thirteenth annual National Book Awards, before a large collection of literary celebrants at the Astor Hotel.

The Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation announced that it would discontinue production of spring wire products at its Palmer, Mass., plant and confirmed a report that it would sell an administrative office building at Buffalo.
MONTREAL, March 13 (UPI) --Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks has the National Hockey League scoring title and the fifty-goal mark within reach with less than two weeks remaining in the season.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Preliminary skirmishing flared on several fronts today in the battle over President Kennedy's United Nations bond program.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Congress passed its first major bill of 1962 today.
WASHINGTON, March 13--The focus of American foreign policy is now moving from weapons to economics and from the Senate to the House of Representatives.
BALTIMORE, March 13 (AP)--The National Football League asked the United States District Court today to dismiss the $10,000,000 antitrust suit filed against it by the American Football League.
The British Comet 4, that started the first trans-Atlantic pure jet service on Oct. 4, 1958, has exceeded 10,000 flying hours, the British Overseas Airways Corporation said yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 13--The United States will be represented by the largest number of competitors in the Second International Tchaikovsky Contest, which opens here April 2.
ALBANY, March 13--A bill that would prohibit discount stores from selling merchandise below standard or fair trade prices was approved by the Assembly today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 13--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru denied today that he had suggested recently that India "lease" to Communist China the road it had built across the Aksai Chin section of eastern Kashmir.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 13 (AP)--Floyd Robinson hit a three-run homer, two doubles and a single in four trips to the plate today as the Chicago White Sox routed the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-2, in an exhibition baseball game.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Export statistics showed today that Cuba herself had virtually ended her food purchases from the United States seven months ago. In a speech last night Premier Fidel Castro blamed a "brutal economic blockade" for drastic food rationing in Cuba.
MOSCOW, March 8--Every evening, long before the doors swing open at 7 o'clock, a line of impatient young people forms on Gorky Street beneath the neon sign of Molodyozhnoye, a youth cafe.

BOSTON, March 13 (UPI)-- The Boston Celtics broke the National Basketball Association record tonight for games won during the regular season. They scored their sixtieth victory by defeating the Syracuse National, 142--110.

Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta announced yesterday that he would take court action against a leading distributor of packaged cheese on a charge of improper marking of weight on packages sold in retail stores.
ATHENS, March 13--Greece disclosed today she suspended an agreement with Yugoslavia on free frontier traffic three weeks ago.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 13 (AP)--The International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers announced today a new wage agreement with the American Smelting and Refining Company.

Bette Davis, co-star with Margaret Leighton and Alan Webb in "The Night of the Iguana," is bowing out of the Tennessee Williams play. She will be replaced on April 4 by Shelley Winters, who has signed to stay with the attraction until January.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13--There is no telling these days which end of the Yankee batting order will do you the most damage.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)-- Contradictory evidence moved a judge to clear a 13-year-old boy today of any connection with a school fire in which ninety-five persons perished in 1958.

Bankers are by nature closemouthed about their business, even to the extent that they do not like to tell stockholders much. Since the boom in bank stocks last year, the banks have found themselves with many more stockholders and quite a few inquisitive ones.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 13--A bombardment that lasted only 110 seconds and produced three goals tonight virtually assured Sweden of the world amateur hockey championship.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 13--Francis Leo Lynch Jr., Professor of Mathematics at Seton Hall University in South Orange, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 48 Maplewood Avenue. He was 41 years old.
Flowers and the hobby of flower arranging are incorporated in a new advertising campaign for cordials by Hiram Walker, Inc., Detroit.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--Adlai E. Stevenson suggested today that if Maj. Yuri Gagarin and Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. worked together on "some hazardous yet exhilarating space project" they might help to improve United StatesSoviet relations.

MOUNTAIN LAKE, Minn., March 13--Twenty-five members of a touring Broadway troupe, including Eva Le Gallienne and Faye Emerson, the actresses, were marooned in this small Mennonite community today by heavy snows.
Awards to Stanley Dancer and his family, and the promise of increased foreign competition in harness racing this year, highlighted a Roosevelt Raceway luncheon yesterday at Shor's Restaurant.
Americans will win the "cold war" only when they make the Communists accept the religious values that are this country's heritage, Representative Walter H. Judd said last night.
NEW DELHI, India, March 13--Mrs. John F. Kennedy passed out lollipops to ailing Indian children today.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 13 (UPI)--Teams of doctors led by specialists fought today to save the lives of four critically ill babies at a hospital where seven infants have died since salt was mistakenly substituted for sugar in a batch of formula.

VIENNA, March 13--Kathpress, a Roman Catholic news agency, reported today that Athenagoras I, the Ecumenical Patriarch and Archbishop of Constantinople, had said the time had come to end the 900year schism between the Orthodox and Roman Catholic Churches.
A telephoned bomb threat sent the police to the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at Forty-second Street yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 (AP)--A former priest whose wife says he was spirited to California by the Roman Catholic Church must appear in Dommestic Relations Court here next Tuesday to answer charges of failure to support his four children.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, March 13--Difficult military, political and procedural questions still blocked today final settlement of the Algerian war.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--Chief Justice Earl Warren ruled today that Philip Bart may be released under $1,500 bail pending an appeal from a contempt sentence for refusing to answer questions about the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- If the Geneva conference reaches agreement on any disarmament measures, the United States will move immediately to put them into effect, President Kennedy said today.

Rochester Telephone Corporation's annual report released yesterday described 1961 as "the year of greatest accomplishment." The company is one of the nation's largest independent (non-Bell) telephone companies.

William D. Heller, executive vice president and general manager of the International Division of Revlon, Inc., leading cosmetics manufacturers, died yesterday, apparently of a coronary attack in the office of a physician at 630 Park Avenue. He was 49 years old.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 13--Major Rightwing groups in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland met tonight to form a consolidated Opposition party to the governing United Federal party.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--A contract for basic research and development of a low-thrust engine using a stream of electrically charged atoms to propel vehicles while in space was awarded today by the Air Force.
WASHINGTON, March 13 --Ahmadou Ahidjo, President of the Federal Republic of Cameroon, arrived today for a two-day state visit. The 38-year-old leader of the West African republic was greeted...
MESA, Ariz., March 13--The Chicago Cubs are the only club in baseball that can field an entire team of coaches and have one left over to umpire.
ALBANY, March 13--The Senate voted today to hold the primary election this year on Sept. 6, a Thursday, In only two state election years since 1934 has the primary been held on a later date.

A May wedding is planned by Miss Trude Brookfield Michel and Herman Jerome Jaffe of New York. Mrs. M. Brookfield Michel of New York has announced her daughter's engagement to the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Jaffe.
Public financing of the $121,530,000 pipeline of the South European Pipeline Company was advanced yesterday through the sale of $10,000,000 of sinking fund debentures in the United States market.
The Henry Kaufmann Foundation has awarded a $250,000 matching grant to New York University for the expansion of its programs in outdoor education.
President Kennedy's news conference, scheduled for 3:30 P.M. today in Wash ington, will be carried on a delayed basis on radio and television.

KANSAS CITY, March 13 (UPI)--Seventh-seeded Western Illinois rallied in the last two minutes tonight to defeat Pratt Institute, 76--70, in the first round of the twenty-fifth annual National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 13--President Kennedy warned wealthy and powerful interests in Latin America tonight that "those who make peaceful revolution impossible will make violent revolution inevitable." He issued the warning at a White House
GENEVA, March 13--Everyone here for the disarmament conference is talking about the unreal air about it.

Charles Ufford, the secondseeded amateur from the Harvard Club, eliminated Frank Iannicelli, the second-seeded professional from the Downtown Athletic Club, in a semi-final match of the metropolitan open squash racquets championship at the University Club yesterday.

Mrs. Lawrence Nelson Spyr was elected state president of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York at the organization's fiftythird annual meeting and luncheon at the Biltmore yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., March 13 (AP) -Tommy Lee snapped out of a riding slump at Bowie race course today, scoring aboard four mounts. He capped his day with a victory atop Mrs. Milton Erlanger's Gin Tuesday in the Carroiton Purse.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Following is the foreign aid message President Kennedy sent to Congress today:...

Events today: "Macbeth," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Orchestra of America, Richard Koin, conductor, Maureen Forrester, contralto, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Renata Rampfel, pianist, West Side Young Men's Christian Association, 8:30; Kroll Quartet, Ninety--second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:30;
ROLLE, Switzerland, Wednesday, March 14--Optimism returned to the Algerian rebel negotiators' camp late last night as they returned from day-long peace talks with the French.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)--The House Committee on Rules today cleared for House debate and a possible vote tomorrow President Kennedy's bill to curb abuses in the public welfare program.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that New York Mailers Union No. 6 had violated laws against secondary boycotts by directing newspaper employes not to handle supplements printed by a concern with which the union had a dispute.

Samuel S. Garfield, a leading defendant in a $5,000,000 stock fraud trial in Federal Court, collapsed in the subway late on Monday afternoon and was taken to Columbus Hospital for treatment for an internal complaint. As a result, the status of the trial has been left in doubt.

GENEVA, March 13--The United States approach to negotiations now starting in Geneva has been to seek points of possible agreement with Russia and to eschew another sterile propaganda contest. What we have, in fact, been doing is to try and find the base for a brushfire peace, to discern oases of accord in the vast desert of discord.

THE Fulton Fish Market, always a busy place in the morning hours before the sun is up, is the scene of even greater frenzy now during the Lenten season. For that wholesale fish center downtown must meet the increasing demand for its products on fast days from now to Easter.
POINT MUGU, Calif., March 13 (AP)--Porpoises have turned out to be so bright the Navy is going to send six of them to school.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)-- Wind-driven snow buried roads, darkened homes, stranded travelers and closed hundreds of schools in the Midwest and Northeast today.

FOR some time it has been Eric Sevareid's lot to be the Columbia Broadcating System's commentator in charge of significance. If the television network elects to have a discussion of one of society's great challenges, he normally is given the thankless task of baby sitting with distinguished authorities while they exercise their generalities.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The Federal Power Commission today barred its members and employes from getting involved in any off-the-record talks or other communications touching on contested cases before the commission.
Samples of the first coal ever mined on the Antarctic Continent have been brought to the United States, according to a scientist who returned late last month.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The General Services Administration announced today its plan for the future of Mitchel Air Force Base, near Hempstead, L.I.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--A Federal Trade Commission examiner issued today a preliminary order that would dismiss charges against Revlon, Inc., of New York and several other companies. They had been accused of an illegal conspiracy to fix retail prices on refillable lipstick cases.
THE Duesseldorfer Schauspielhaus, one of West Ger many's celebrated theatres, staged a sparkling production last night of Gerhart Hauptmann's "Vor Sonnenuntergang" (Before Sundown).
Richard M. Nixon has related how Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his top advisers wanted him to resign as the Republican candidate for Vice President in 1952.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., March 13--Richard H. Buehler, a New York textile executive, was found dead tonight in the kitchen of his apartment at 35 East Hartsdale Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 13 --The Albert Einstein Medal and Award for 1962 will be given to Dr. Shields Warren of West Newton, Mass., it was announced today by the trustees of the Lewis and Rosa Strauss Memorial Foundation. The award is a prize of $5,000.

PITTSBURGH, March 13 (UPI)--The Pennsylvania Supreme Court decided today that an "act of God" was no longer an acceptable defense in civil damage cases stemming from storms, heavy rains and other natural disasters.
DISCOUNTER ADDS 7 UNITS TO CHAIN Lewis Conger, once a New York housewares store, has been acquired by Floyd Bennett Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of four discount department stores.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 13 (UPI)--An attorney for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today the association would appeal a Federal Court program of gradual desegregation for Chattanooga city schools.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--An Army psychiatrist has told Senate investigators that United States troop indoctrination is "more often than not a failure, useless, or even negative in its effects."
Cotton futures were 10 cents up to 50 cents a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The bean bag, one of the oldest and simplest of toys, can serve a decorative purpose in a child's room. A new group of bean bags, designed by the young mother of two small boys, is made of brightly colored felt in a variety of animal, fruit and vegetable shapes.
Starting next week, New York's elderly persons will find two programs competing simultaneously for their attention.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 13--Dr. George Henry Danton, Professor Emeritus of Modern Languages at Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., died here Sunday at the age of 81.
The Transit Authority said yesterday it would be able to provide partial service within forty-eight hours after the city seized the strikebound Fifth Avenue Coach Lines.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., March 13--Richard H. Buehler, a New York textile executive, was found dead tonight in the kitchen of his apartment at 35 East Hartsdale Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 13 --The Albert Einstein Medal and Award for 1962 will be given to Dr. Shields Warren of West Newton, Mass., it was announced today by the trustees of the Lewis and Rosa Strauss Memorial Foundation. The award is a prize of $5,000.

PITTSBURGH, March 13 (UPI)--The Pennsylvania Supreme Court decided today that an "act of God" was no longer an acceptable defense in civil damage cases stemming from storms, heavy rains and other natural disasters.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 13--The Mets do have pitching. At least they had it today, and the result was a 4-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, who were the champions of baseball in 1960.
LONDON, March 13--The Liberal party came close to wresting a Conservative stronghold from the Conservative party in a Parliamentary byelection today.

VIENNA, March 13--The budgets of the Soviet-bloc countries indicate that they have increased military appropriations in 1962 by 5,150,000,000 rubles, the equivalent of $5,700,000,000 at the official rate.
Net income of the International Paper Company and its domestic and foreign subsidiaries rose to $72,002,094 last year from $71,668,594 in 1960.

Dr. and Frau Felix von Bormann of Bad Nauheim, Germany, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Frauelein Heidi Tatjana von Bormann, to Antony Campbell Smith. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Smith of New Canaan, Conn.
Market analysts talked of a "blue chip market" yesterday as stocks pushed ahead after an uncertain start and closed at their highs for the day.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 13-- Long Island leaders expressed bitter disappointment tonight at the Federal program for Mitchel Field.
The Travelers Insurance Companies of Hartford, Conn., have appointed Sterling T. Tooker as executive vice president, it was announced yesterday by J. Doyle DeWitt, president.
Magistrate Edward J. Chapman imposed a total of $3,960 in fines in ninety-seven cases yesterday in Housing Court. In addition, he accepted pleas and granted adjournments in thirtyseven other cases.
Michael H. Prendergast's petition for reinstatement as state Democratic chairman was thrown out of state Supreme Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--Senator Milton R. Young said today he would seek re-election this year as a candidate who was "a little right of center."
The Pennsylvania General State Authority borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of public works projects.
