ISLAMORADA, Fla., March 13--There is an argu ment that goes on about what appeals to fish. The unresolved debate goes on in the Florida Keys, where the list of fish to be caught is long and impressive, just as it goes on elsewhere all year long. This is why there are rich lure-makers.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 13--Plans for the acquisition of a seventy-two-acre tract in North Woodmere for a public park were approved here today after a public hearing by the Hempstead Town Board.
Burlington Industries, Inc., the world's largest textile producer, announced yesterday the election of Frank H. Leslie and William G. Lord as executive vice presidents.
A compromise agreement between the mangement of the Oxford Electric Corporation and a group of shareholders has ended a proxy fight, it was disclosed yesterday.
TRENTON, March 13--The state is preparing to extend the April 2 deadline for filing returns under its commuter tax since 160,000 of the affected taxpayers have not been given the necessary forms.

WICHITA FALLS, Tex., March 13 (AP)--James H. Allison, retired newspaper executive, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 82.

BZZZ-ZZZ, bzzz-zzz, bzzz-zzz droned a swarm of eight women as they started a fiveday quilting bee Monday. Presiding over the industrious colony was the almost five-foot, almost 80-year-old "queen," Mrs. Florence Peto. This tiny mistress of the crosstitch and applique was on hand to open Abraham Straus' second quilting bee.

The wholesale commodity price index rose to 84.5 on Monday from 84.2 on Friday.
ALBANY, March 13--Two new drives to raise the state's contributions toward school costs above the amounts recommended by a special legislative committee got under way today.

The Board of Justices of the Domestic Relations Court has submitted a brief to Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature urging broad changes in the new Family Court Act now under consideration.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--Harold C. Woodward of Chicago testified today that he would dispose of utility company stock he owns if his nomination to the Federal Power Commission was confirmed.
Winthrop L. Schnizer, who has been on the staffs of seven City Controllers, is retiring after thirty-two years of public service. Controller Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday.

TUCSON, Arizona, March 15-- "Let independence be our boast," the stern admonition in the old patriotic American anthem, is especially well served in Arizona, if the outcroppings of attitudes here are reliable signs of what lies below. For the outward appearance is that Arizona citizens are simultaneously for Barry Goldwater and John F. Kennedy. Dubious as is the political future of this conflicting preference, it reflects independent thinking.
Connecticut borrowed $53,680,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway construction.

Msgr. John J. McEvoy, pastor of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church, 307 East Thirty-third Street, died yesterday in his rectory; apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

The Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad sold yesterday $4,830,000 in equipment trust certificates to finance the purchase of rolling stock, valued at $6,452,627.

The appointment of Dr. Leonard J. Raider as president of United Medical Service, Inc., the Blue Shield surgicalmedical care insurance organization serving 5,000,000 persons in the metropolitan area, was announced yesterday. He succeeds John F. McCormick who has retired.
TABRIZ, Iran, March 13-- Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, they Shah of Iran, stood on a plain in Azerbaijan today and handed, land deeds to twenty peasants representing 520 families in seven villages.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14--The Continental Ball was held this evening in Whitehall, former winter residence of Henry Morrison Flagler, now the Flagler Museum, in aid of the American Cancer Society and the Heart Association of Palm Beach. Mrs. Frank McMahon and Mrs. Benson Ford were cocharimen and the expenses were underwritten by Mr. McMahon and Mr. Ford.
A single work of metal sculpture weighing about five tons and stretching 190 feet, will hang from the ceiling of the grand, foyer of Philharmonic Hall in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

RICHARD KORN and his Orchestra of America wound up their third Carnegie Hall season by covering a lot of geographical ground last night. Musically, however, they did not stray very far from home base.

LONDON, Thursday, March 15 --The resurgent Liberal party won a smashing victory in a by-election in Orpington, Kent, yesterday, ousting the Conservatives from one of their suburban strongholds.

Simon H. Rifkind will represent J. Truman Bidwell, former chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, in his trial in Federal Court on charges of income tax evasion.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- A joint resolution to establish the Alexander Hamilton home in New York as a national memorial was adopted today by the House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.
UTICA, N.Y., March 14-- Clarkson Tech will oppose the University of Michigan tomorrow night at 8:15 o'clock in the opening game of the National Collegiate hockey championship at Memorial Anditorium.

Dr. Jacob Griffel, a member of the executive committee of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, died Tuesday in his home at 1206 Bergen Street, Brooklyn. He was 62 years old.

TAIPEI, Tawian, March 14-- Assistant Secretary of State W. Averell Harriman and Admiral Harry D. Felt, United States commander in the Pacific, met tonight with President Chiang Kai shek for informal discussions of "matters of mutual concern."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14--The world champion Yankees gained their fifth straight victory of the exhibition season today. But this much can be said for the harried American League: The opposition is getting stronger.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Senate opened a civil rights debate today, quietly but with indications of storms ahead.
Shares of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reacted yesterday to rumors current in Wall Street.

Robert J. Kelleher, a 49year-old lawyer from Los Angeles, was named the United States Davis Cup tennis captain yesterday. He succeeded David Freed of Salt Lake City, who asked to be relieved of the post because of business pressure.
BEACH, Beethoven and Brahms are running neck and neck in a sportswear league that has always been better known for Micky Mouse, Bugs Bunny and Donald Duck or Yale, Harvard and Princeton.

David Levy, a 35-year-old reform Democrat, announced yesterday that he would run against Representative Charles A. Buckley for the Democratic nomination for Representative from the new Twenty-third Congressional District in the Bronx.
Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight boxing champion, will sign for his next title defense early tomorrow afternoon. There is little doubt the opponent will be Sonny Liston of Philadelphia.

UNITED NATION, N.Y., March 14--West Germany pledged today to buy $10,000,000 in United Nations bonds. The subscription was the first by a nonmember of the world organization. It brought the total amount of the proposed $200,000,000 issue pledged or already bought to $147,085,000.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 14--Peter d'Aguiar, leader of the opposition United Force, went on trial today on charges of having illegally organized and participated in a procession and a public meeting.
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, March 15--Mrs. John F. Kennedy made friends with an elephant yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 14 (AP)--Federal Judge H. Hobart Grooms signed an order today temporarily exempting Little League baseball from desegregation.

GARLAND, N.C., March 14 (AP)--An Air Force reserve pilot parachuted safely from his crippled F-100 jet fighter today, shortly before the plane crashed near here. It was the second time in three months that he had been forced to parachute from a stricken jet.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--Railroad management asked the five operating rail unions today to meet with its representatives in Chicago April 2 to iron out differences over new work rules proposed by the Presidential Railroad Commission.

The strong demand that has been pushing up the prices of prime fixed-income investments showed signs of slowing yesterday. Dealers insisted, however, that a firm undertone persisted, especially in local government bonds due in fifteen to twenty years.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Kennedy said today that Edward M. Kennedy, his youngest brother, was running "on his own" for the Democratic Massachusetts.
NEW DELHI, India, March 14--A budget of the equivalent of $2,875,593,000 was presented to the Indian Parliament today.

PARENTS will be paying up to $850 this summer to have their teen-age boys and girls dig ditches, shingle roofs, build fences, grease trucks, husk corn, milk cows, drive tractors and perform other jobs that are not always considered a privilege.

CHICAGO, March 14 (UPI)-- A Federal court jury today found a Chicago promoter, William Rabin, guilty of pledging stolen Canadian bonds against a loan in an American bank, a charge that grew out of one of the biggest bank burglaries on record.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- New York City's Superintendent of Schools told a Congressional subcommittee today that it would cost $50,000,000 to $60,000,000 more a year to give the city's Negro and Puerto Rican pupils the same educational opportunities as the white pupils.
LONDON, March 14--Britain's trade deficit last month was considerably smaller than in January. With exports down, the improvement was caused by a much sharper drop in imports.

ALBANY, March 14-Governor Rockefeller's bill to eliminate bingo abuses disclosed by a Moreland Act inquiry last year won unanimous approval in the Assembly today. It now goes to the Senate for concurrence.

Jacob B. Taylor of 50 East Seventy-ninth Street, vice president for staff of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, died yesterday in Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 63.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Edgar of 131 East Sixty-ninth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Eileen Edgar, to Edward Johnston Leutke. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Leutke of Clinton, Iowa.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)--President Kennedy expressed hope today that Congress would reverse the House Agricultural Committee's rejection of his temporary program to keep dairy price supports at their present level for the rest of the year.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)--The Senate Judiciary Committee sidetracked today and perhaps killed for this Congressional session--legislation by Senator Estes Kefauver aimed at reducing the price of prescription drugs.

IN all the boroughs of Manhat tan, there is probably no street with a more fascinating concentration of ethnic gastronomic wealth than Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village. It is Italian to the core and abounds in good things, both imported and domestic.

LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., Thursday, March 15--The Engineers Association went on strike today against the Sperry Gyroscope Company. The walkout may halt work this morning at the main plant here and at other plants on Long Island and in Queens.

JACKSON, Miss., March 14 (UPI)--The State Legislature approved a bill today that would permit the State Tax Commission to collect a 4 per cent per can tax on beer sold in the state's fifty-four counties in which its sale is illegal.
A landlord with a long record of convictions in housing cases was committed to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for psychiatric examination.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., March 12--Angus Cameron, a student at Syracuse University, was found shot dead tonight beside the driveway of his parents' large colonial home at 83 Kipp Street. He was 20 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The outer fringes of the earth's atmosphere have shrunk in the last few years so that the atmosphere at some 400 miles is now only a tenth as dense as it was in 1958-59.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation plans to accelerate its exploration program in Algeria as a result of the recent promising discovery there, according to E.L. Steiniger, president and chief executive officer, in the 1961 pamphlet report to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Kennedy rebuked today those who advocate cuts in his foreign aid program. "This program is just as important as our national defense," he' said.

BRADDOCK HEIGHTS, Md., March 14--Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Lowenthal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hannah Lowenthal, to Dr. Leslie L. Kelminson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kelminson of Flushing, Queens, New York.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)--Representative Carl Vinson said today his House Armed Services Committee would fight for an expanded B-70 bomber program despite Administration opposition to the move.

Inventories of home heating oil dropped 6,940,000 barrels, to 91,674,000 barrels, in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was the first time this season that supplies had declined below the level of a year earlier. A year ago, stocks were 95,888,000 barrels.
Volume expanded and most of the leading groups advanced yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange moved higher for the fifth consecutive session.

CHICAGO, March 14--Raymond W. Hilliard, Cook County public old director and a for mer New York Welfare Commissioner, began today a program to send at least 50,000 relief recipients to school within a year.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 14--The Fairfield County Chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union protested today a police ban on the sale of the paperback edition of "The Carpetbaggers."
With workmen showing the split-second precision of topflight jockeys, the $34,000,000 Aqueduct racing plant is being made ready for the opening of the thoroughbred season here on Tuesday.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 14 (AP)--The United States and Canadian teams retained outside chances of overtaking the leading Swedish unit for the world amateur ice hockey championship by scoring overwhelming victories tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--The Defense Department issued a draft call today for 6,000 men for the Army in May.
ALBANY, March 14--The first session of a State Senate inquiry into a deal assertedly offered to the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines by Mayor Wagner ended today in a stand-off.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 14--The regional office of the State Department of Public Works reported here today that it had received more than 100 communications in the last few days about a right of way for the controversial Interstate Route 87 from Brewster to Purchase.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14--The Security Council gave Cuba a hearing today on charges that the United States had inspired illegal action by the Organization of American States to exclude her from its activities and was even now planning armed aggression against her.
Shipments of finished steel products direct from mills in January aggregated 6,905,947 tons, the highest level in twenty-one months, the American Iron and Steel Institute has reported.

LONDON, March 14--The Ministry of Aviation reported today that aviation kerosene was generally a safer aircraft fuel from a fire risk point of view than JP-4, also known as wide-cut gasoline, a mixture of kerosene and gasoline.

The International Development Association extended yesterday an interest-free fiftyyear development credit of $2,800,000 to Swaziland, a British dependency in South Africa. The credit will help to finance the construction of a 112-mile allweather highway across Swaziland from the border of the Republic of South Africa on the west to the Mozambique border on the east.
The raucous but resplendent bluejay is starting to reappear in the metropolitan area after most, but not all, of the species had been virtually starved out by the failure of last year's acorn crop.
BOSTON, March 14--Edward M. Kennedy officially began today his campaign for the Senate seat once held by his brother, the President.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The Atomic Energy Commission entered a new and expanded role today as a national research center for the Government.
One of the last remaining predicted but undetected elementary particles in nuclear physics has been discovered, according to an announcement yesterday.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 14 (AP)--Directors of the E.F. MacDonald Company, a sales incentive and trading stamp company with headquarters in Dayton, have proposed a threefor-one stock split, the company announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--The Defense Department announced today that it would build a seismological observatory near Sparta, Ore., to help in research on detection of underbround nuclear weapons tests.

Martin W. Juster, New York and Westchester builder, has started construction of an eightstory apartment house on the east side of Overlook Terrace at West 190th Street in the Fort Tryon Park section of Washington Heights.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 14 (AP)--Four Air Force test pilots and two from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have been assigned to the Dyna-Soar space-glider program as pilot-engineer consultants, the Air Force announced today.

CAIRO, March 14--The Egyptian Ministry of Culture was criticized in the Cairo press today for having acted too hastily in suggesting that part of a collection of Egyptian antiquities touring the United States might have been stolen.
The director of a New York clinical laboratory has charged that a, state-wide "conspiracy" has been organized to block strict licensing of medical testing laboratories.

THE only living man of words capable of turning James Joyce's "Ulysses" and "Finnegans Wake" into a trilogy-- Charles Dillon Stengel--has instead produced a fine story of his life in baseball. He calls it, as fate long ago decided he would, "Casey at the Bat."*

A subsidiary of Webb Knapp, Inc., has purchased the thirty-seven-acre waterfront terminal of the American Dock Company in Tompkinsville, S.I., for $2,000,000. The transaction is believed to be the largest realty deal ever made on Staten Island.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 14 (AP)--President Nazem El Kodsi of Syria and Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq met tonight on the SyrianIraqi frontier, Baghdad radio announced.

A compromise appeal to the sometimes divergent preferences of men and women in scotch whiskies is depicted in an advertisement for Ambassador De Luxe Scotch, marketed by Quality Importers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)--President Kennedy made an unannounced appearance tonight at an annual St. Patrick's Day party sponsored by Representative Michael J. Kirwan, Democrat of Ohio, in the National Press Club ball room.

The Home Insurance Company showed an underwriting loss last year of $11,629,541, against a loss in 1960 of $3,816,792. This was reported yesterday by Kenneth E. Black, president, in his annual statement to stockholders.

"Prosperity" suddenly became a two-platoon word yesterday in the lexicon of the New York Titans as spokesmen for the American Football League club predicted major gains next season at the box office and on the field:

The seventeen-nation disarmament conference has opened in Geneva under an organizational agreement between the United States and Soviet Russia, which could be regarded under normal circumstances as a favorable omen.
Chief Justice John M. Murtagh of Special Sessions sentenced an unemployed laborer to ninety days in jail yesterday after he had pleaded guilty to killing his dog and violating the weapons law.
Inmates of Auburn Prison yesterday ended their sit-in strike against changes in parole procedures, and Sing Sing officials indicated they expected an end to the strike there tomorrow.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 14 (AP)A mix--up in babies was reported at Binghamton General Hospital today after six infants died as the result of an alleged substitution of salt for sugar in their formulas.

The problems of the middleaged mother who decides to get a job after her children have left home was discussed here yesterday at a symposium sponsored by the Jewish Vacation Association's Project on Middle Age.
Heavy liquidation of spot March potato futures, which went off the board yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, weakened most positions.

Passage of the $435-million manpower-retraining bill is an important first step toward equipping the unemployed with the skills needed to restore them to productive places in our changing economy. Even at the recession's low point a year ago, many thousands of jobs for skilled mechanical and white-collar workers went begging.

WHITE PLAINS, March 14-- A $44,198.18 income-tax lien has been filed here against Hazel Scott, the pianist and former wife of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of New York, for unpaid Federal income taxes for the years 1949 through 1955.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 14 (UPI)--The Government of the Bahama Islands has threatened to fire on commercial fishermen from Florida who invade its waters, Randolph Hodges, Florida Conservation Director, said today.
ALBANY, March 14 (AP)-- The following skiing conditions were reported" today to the State Commerce Department:

Within the last three days two important advertisers have parted company with their agencies. In both cases the agencies said they had resigned the accounts. But the clients said they had taken the initiative.

Net income of Marshall Field Co. for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 improved to $9,106,558 from $8,860,664 earned in the previous year, the annual report of James L. Palmer, president, disclosed yesterday.

The American Kennel Club has made it easier for those wishing to qualify as dog show judges in more than one breed to achieve their objective. After qualifying through the apprentice system for one breed they can apply for additional breeds without ever again being an apprentice. Four such apprenticeships ...

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 14 (UPI)--The Washington Senators produced eleven hits, including three homers and three doubles; and walloped the Cincinnati Reds, 12--1, today. A crowd of 1.556 saw the exhibition game.
Six executives of national magazines sad at a news conference yesterday that the postal rate increase bill now before the Senate would legislate scores of magazines out of business.

Mrs. Millicent Barnard Mills of Greenwich, Conn., widow of Van Stryker Mills, was married here yesterday afternoon to Julian Twells Trenholm of New York. The bride is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Horace Barnard. Her husband is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Julian deS. Trenholm of New York and Philadelphia.
ALBANY, March 14--The State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions agreed unanimously today to recommend a one-year extension of commercial and business rent control laws.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--New contributions toward understanding one of nature's big riddles--how the eye sees--were reported by scientists today.

AKRON, Ohio, March 14 (AP) --Early retirement is removing from top management posts in the forty-one-year-old Seiberling Rubber Company. Three sons of the two brothers who founded that $50,000,000 corporation.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14--The Dodgers have been doing considerable commuting to the West Coast of Florida this week. They fly across the peninsula in their swank private plane and this places Walter Alston in his element--up in the air.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 14 (UPI)--The internationallyowned Iraq Petroleum Company told the Iraqui Government it would hand over 160 boxes of oil facts covering geological and geophysical data on the concession territories I.P.C. was forced to surrender under the oil law passed in December.

WASHINGTON, March 14, (AP)--The Cameroon President, Ahmadbu Ahidjo, said, today that Communist China and other Communist nations were supporting elements in his country that are trying to overthrow the Government.
ALBANY, March 14--It was a bad day for the great horned owl, which has enjoyed the protection of the state since 1948.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The new Cuban system of controlling the distribution of foodstuffs and consumer goods calls for drastically short rations beginning Monday.
The United Gas Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday at Shreveport, La., that gross revenues for 1961 rose to $387,000,000 from $385,000,000 the year before.

When the Rangers Fan Club members named Andy Bathgate as the most popular player on the team Tuesday, they did it one day too early. They would have made it unanimous after New York's victory over the Detroit Red Wings last night.
WASHINGTON, March 14 --Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, who does not usually champion the cause of liberals in his party, led them today in an attack on high interest rates.

Six young singers have been selected from preliminary auditions to compete in the Metropolitan Opera Auditions. They will represent the eastern region in the national semifinals, which will begin at the opera house Tuesday.

Walter Cronkite, television news correspondent, will replace Douglas Edwards on the Columbia Broadcasting System's early evening programs on April 16. It is televised here at 7:15 P.M., Mondays through Fridays, but is carried by some network stations at 6:45 P.M.
The presence of a small percentage of emotionally disturbed children in many of the city's regular classrooms was said yesterday to be disrupting the education of other children in the rooms.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. March 14--Today, Cleopatra is in Rome, Lawrence of Arabia is in Spain, Gandhi is in England, and Tarzan is in India--and they should all be back where they belong, at home, in Hollywood.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 14--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Harlow Miller of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Gray Miller, to the Rev. Dr. George Cooper Hood of New York. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus S. Hood of Corning, N.Y.

The Schola Cantorum of New York will gives a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall on March 27. Proceeds of the concert and a prefatory cocktail party in the Carnegie Hall Bar will help to finance concerts across the country by the professional chorus under the direction of Hugh Ross.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--A bill to allow the Civil Service Commission greater discretion in imposing penalties for minor Hatch Act violations was approved today by the Senate Rules Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Kennedy said today that there had been no request from Communist China to purchase wheat from the United States.

OTTAWA, March 14 (Canadian Press)--Canadian wheat plantings of 24,600,000 bushels-- up 4 per cent from 23,792,000 in 1961--are indicated this year, Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. This is 11 per cent above the 1956-60 average.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 14 Gov. Ernest F. Hollings announced today that he would run against Senator Olin D Johnston in the Democratic pri mary June 12.

The six-story building containing forty-eight apartments and occupying a plot of 100 by 100 feet at 1085 Nelson Avenue, Highbridge, the Bronx, has been sold by Morris Rokowsky, realty operator. It has been bought by an investing client of Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., the broker in the deal, for cash above mortgages of $255,000.

The Hertz Corporation had the highest revenues and earnings in its history in 1961, reflecting good gains made by its Rent A Car, truck leasing and car leasing divisions, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, accused fellow Senators today of trying to stifle an fnvestiagation into troop indoctrination.

Edward C. McLean, a Republican lawyer, is being considered by President Kennedy for a Federal judgeship in the Southern District of New York.

The Aluminum Company of America has mapped an expanded program of capital expenditures, foreign investments and real estate investments for 1962, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday. These 1962 outlays will be in excess of $100,000,000.
Cotton futures were 5 cents off to 25 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

BONN, Germany, March 14-- The Bundestag (lower house of Parliament) closed the first reading today of West Germany's 1962 record budget, equivalent to $13,250,000,000, and referred it to the Budget Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- A group of rowdy youths cursed and scuffled with Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. outside a church-sponsored party for teen-agers last Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--The State Department reports the Soviet Union is conducting an intensified anti-religion campaign, but says there is no proof that Jews have been singled out for persecution.

Mrs. Jean Purrington of 50 Park Avenue was married here yesterday afternoon to Harmon Liveright Remmel of 200 East Fifty-seventh Street. The ceremony was performed in the Taylor Chapel of the Broadway Congregational Church by the Rev. Frank J. Scribner. There was a reception at the Plaza.
KEY LARGO, Fla., March 14--Tommy Gifford is a grizzled, no-nonsense, 65-yearold fisherman and sailor who has packed a tremendous amount of salt-water fishing achievement into his span of years.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)--A Boston judge and his former law partner refused to tell a House subcommittee today whether they once represented persons whose properties were acquired by the state for Federal highways.

The curtain will be raised tonight in Madison Square Garden on college basketball's oldest established national tournament of major status.
LONDON, March 14--British Government securities and industrial shares continued to make headway in the stock market here today, although the volume of trading declined slightly.

Earnings of the International Harvester Company in the fiscal ending Oct. 31, 1962, are expected to show a substantial gain over the $3.02 a share earned in fiscal 1961, Frank W. Jenks, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 (AP) Mrs. Charles W. Dow, 56 year old, wife of a New York business executive, was found dead today in an automobile in the garage of the family's winter home.
Steel production in February, totaled 9,704,000 tons, up nearly nearly 3,500,000 tons from the 6,239,098 tons of February 1961, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
A campaign to raise $285,000 for the New York Shakespeare Festival got under way officially at Gracie Mansion yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 14--Col. Nathan B. Rood, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Rood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Anne Rood, to Sydney S. Traum. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Traum of Belle Harbor, Queens, New York.
The executive vice president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has resigned to become director of finance for the Port of New York Authority.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 19 (UPI)--James R. Hoffa's mail fraud hearing turned into a shouting session today when a witness refused to say if he had tapped the Teamster president's telephone line for a Senate committee.
MOSCOW, March 14--Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, implied today that the Soviet Union's disarmament proposals had been attacked by the Chinese Communists.
A floor in the new Time Life Building, 1271 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) at Fiftieth Street, has been leased by Cannon Mills, Inc., as its sales headquarters.

Deputy Defense Secretary Gilpatric has spoken up in support of the Kennedy Administration's fall-out shelter program. It is his contention that this program could save as many as "forty or fifty million lives" in the event of a nuclear attack.
Dorothy Strumpf, a lawyer specializing in child adoption work, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She lived at 453 Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.
ALBANY, March l4--Governor Rockefeller renewed his appeal today that President Kennedy designate New York City and Long Island as a disaster area to qualify for Federal aid.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Four Republican Senators warned today that the recent imposition of death sentences on Jews in the Soviet Union might be the forerunner of even more widespread oppression.
The Securities and Exchange Commission's latest annual report to Congress has sounded a warning that deserves to be noticed.

GENEVA, March 14--The United Nations-sponsored disarmament conference opened today after a chilling Big Three foreign ministers' meeting where the Soviet Union said "no" to the idea of international inspection.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 William E. Lingelbach, a former national singles titleholder, and William I. Forbes Jr. won the opening match today in the United States amateur court tennis doubles championship at the Racquet Club.

Tadeusz Kerner, a 36-year-old Israeli pianist on the faculty of the Music Academy of Tel Aviv, made his United States debut giving a recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Kerner is a native of Warsaw, Poland, where he studied and first taught, and he has toured in many European countries.
The spotlight was on Ernst Deutsch yesterday when a group of West German actors met a group of American actors.
RICHARD RODGERS need not have worried. He is still a magician of the musical theatre.
Some of the prettiest flowers at the Coliseum Flower Show yesterday were not in pots or vases but on women's hats.
UTICA, N.Y., March 15 Clarkson Tech started fast and hung on grimly to upset Michigan, 5 4, tonight in the first East-West semi-final of the fifteenth annual National Collegiate hockey championship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 Reports that segments of television series may be running as long as an hour and one-half before the end of the year have caused considerable anguish among writers here and some unhappiness among actors.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had expelled one of its allied members and fined two regular members $5,000 each for violating exchange rules.

LONDON, March 15 Richard Austen Butler assumed today the latest of the many difficult appointments he has held in British Governments in a quarter-century's experience stretching back to the pre-war Government of Neville Chamberlain.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 15 (AP) Donald Jackson of Canada captured the world figure-skating championship tonight with the first series of triple jumps in figureskating competition. He rallied to overtake Karol Divin of Czechoslovakia.

GUAM, Friday, March 16 A Flying Tiger Line Super Constellation carrying 107 persons, including ninety-three United States soldiers, disappeared during a night flight from Guam to Manila early today. It was presumed to have crashed at sea.

Rain or shine, 120,000 marchers are expected to stride up Fifth Avenue tomorrow to commemorate St. Patrick's Day.

Prices in the high-grade bond market tended lower yesterday and the volume of business shrank. The halt in the upward movement was neither unexpected nor unwelcome to both dealers and investing institutions.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $37,000,000 to $53,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
President Ahmadou Ahidjo of Cameroon called on the nuclear powers yesterday to use negotiation to achieve "total, controlled disarmament."
Directors of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., a leading textile producer, decided yesterday to omit the scheduled dividend on the common stock.

FOR some forty years Margaret Kennedy has been writing good books, novels mostly, but a play, a biography of Jane Austen and several volumes of excellent literary criticism also. Never a major writer, never the subject of ponderous criticism, never the object of coterie enthusiasm, Miss Kennedy has serenely continued to write well. Her craftsmanship is sure. Her own intelligence and ironic sense of humor are superior.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15 The Yankees turned their guns on the National League today. Even though they tackled the champions of that loop, they weren't slowed down.
Daniel Persky of 243 East Fourteenth Street, an authority on the Hebrew language, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 74.

ALBANY, March 15 The State Senate inquiry into charges that Mayor Wagner had offered the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines a deal on fares ended today about where it began yesterday with the facts still in doubt.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15--Former President Janio Quadros said today that he resigned last August because his mounting conflict with Congress was leading toward the destruction of Brazil's democratic system.

Arthur Holly Compton was a major figure in the modern physics that has revolutionized our concept of matter and energy, of the atom and of the universe. He was only 35 years old when he received the Nobel Prize for his fundamental discovery of the phenomenon named after him, the Compton effect.

LONDON, March 15 The literary thunderbolt hurled last week by F.R. Leavis, a Cambridge don and critic, at the author C.P. Snow was hurled back today with fury.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 One of the most refreshing golf personalities to come sauntering down the fairways in recent years is Doug Sanders and he captivates the galleries for a variety of reasons. He is adopted instantly by every duffer on the premises because they can see in him a reflection of themselves, a golfer whose stance is too wide, whose backswing is too short and whose follow-through has no fluidity.
The Louisiana State Bond and Building Commission borrowed $15,000,000 yesterday to finance the construction of public buildings.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 15 (AP) The vast majority of Birmingham's public recreation facilities were desegregated by Federal court order today. But they remained closed.

There will be more championship racing under Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound auspices this year than ever before. A schedule of thirty-nine West-of-Rye regattas and one with forty events for clubs east of Rye were approved at the organization's spring meeting in the New York Yacht Club last night.

VIENNA, March 15 President Kennedy's crowded schedule has ruled out a visit to Washington this spring or summer by Chancellor Alfons Gorbach. The Austrian leader had hoped to enlist the support of the White House for Austrian associate membership in the European Economic Community.
WANAQUE, N.J., March 15 The North Jersey District Water Supply Commission has declared a "limited water emergency" at Wanaque Reservoir and has asked the communities it serves to conserve water.
PHOENIX, Arix., March 15--Human cells can be cooled to within a degree of absolute zero--some 460 degrees below zero on the Fahrenheit scale--and they show life when rewarmed.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 Three maritime unions were preparing today for a strike against all vessels owned by Pacific Coast operators.
ALBANY, March 15 A new formula for shortening the maximum sentences of wellbehaved state prisoners was approved today in the Assembly.
The Federal Government has attempted to simplify the personal income tax return and New York State has taken further steps to bring its return in line.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Maj. Donald K. Slayton of the Air Force has been ordered for medical reasons to withdraw as the Project Mercury pilot scheduled to take the next or bital flight.
The city's first award of its medal for outstanding performance by Civil Service employes was made by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
FORDYCE, Ark., March 15 (AP) A task force of tax agents will move out of this southern Arkansas town tomorrow, leaving the 3,890 residents somewhat shaken.
The New York Metropolitan area can marshal close to 175,000 pieces of transportation equipment in a military or civilian emergency.
The establishment of a privately owned Thailand overseas shipping enterprise was announced here yesterday by Nils O. Seim, president of Motorships, Inc.
OSLO, March 15 (AP) Eero Maentyranta of Finland won the fifteen-kilometer crosscountry race of the Holmenkollen ski festival today.

The housewives who tread the aisles of the nation's supermarkets are a tough breed to impress. Many have long since grown accustomed to the fancy packages, the "5 cents off" special offers' and the elaborate coupon deals. They also have become indifferent to packages containing free cutlery or towels.
PARIS, March 15 Andr Malraux, Minister of Cultural Affairs, has informed A.M. Julien, general administrator of France's National Theatres, that he will be out of a job next month.
DENVER, March 15 (AP) Sweden moved closer to the world hockey championship tonight by routing Great Britain, 17 to 0.
The wholesale commodity price index was unchanged on Wednesday from 84.4 on Tuesday.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 16 (AP) The Washington Senators continued their distance slugging today as Dale Long hit two home runs and Joe Hicks one in a 9-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, March 15--Congress approved and sent to the White House today legislation to tighten controls over welfare and pension funds of nearly 100,000,000 workers and their dependents.

ALBANY, March 15 (AP) The State Lottery Control Commission, now being legislated out of exstence, never actually obtained control over the legalized bingo it was supposed to regulate, Thomas B. Gilchrist Jr., special state commissioner, said today.

AGRA, India, March 15 Mrs. John F. Kennedy took a short course in Indian history today. It began with an hour-and-ahalf tour of the sprawling abandoned city of Fatehpur Sikri, which dates to the sixteenthcentury reign of the Mogul Emperor Akbar the Great.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that Federal limitations on actions of states was "closely related" to the courage and vision of the Governors and legislators of the states.
MONTREAL, March 15 (AP) Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League, said today a penalty shot awarded to Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers last night was "perfectly legal."

ROME, March 15 Thirtyfive centuries of Colombian art went on exhibition here today at the National Gallery of Modern Art. This is the first major exhibition of Colombian art ever seen in Europe. From Rome the display will travel to Cologne, Stockholm and other European cities.
A union official yesterday accused Governor Rockefeller of "vacillation and inaction" on legislation that would permit New York City to seize the strikebound Fifth Avenue Coach Lines.

WASHINGTON, March 15 United States military training personnel in South Vietnam have exchanged fire with Com munist guerrilla forces.
BALTIMORE, March 15 (AP) The National Football League was ordered today to continue with defense against the multimillion-dollar antitrust charges leveled by the rival American football League.

The Flying Tiger Line, which describes itself as the world's largest air freight and charter passenger carrier, began operations sixteen years ago with one plane a squat Budd Conestoga.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy urged Congressmen of both parties today to get behind the Administration's civil rights proposals.
In a move to combat graft in the Department of Buildings, Commissioner Harold Birns yesterday named a new assistant to clear the inspection services of "corrupt operators."
WASHINGTON, March 15 Exports declined and imports rose in January, according to Commerce Department reports.
IN Looking-Glass Land the Red Queen told Alice: "It takes all the running you can do to stay in the same place." The world of bridge often presents enough paradoxes to resemble Looking-Glass Land.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 15 President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province arrived here today for talks with Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo but found Mr. Adoula had gone.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Children can give adults a good lesson in wholesome racial attitudes, a Congressional subcommittee was told today.

ALGIERS, March 15 Three Europeans and three Moslems were lined up against a garden wall and "executed" with tommyguns today in a terror raid ascribed by the police to the Secret Army Organization.

Federal Judge William B. Herlands said yesterday that Samuel S. Garfield, a defendant in a stock fraud trial, was "genuinely sick" and probably would endanger his life by appearing in court during the next three weeks.
LONDON, March 15 Industrial shares turned irregular in the stock market here today and the advance in British Government securities was virtually halted.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy has begun a crackdown on taxicab drivers who overload their cabs or overcharge their riders.
Former State Senator John H. Farrell was reported last night to be in line for election today as chairman of the New York County Democratic executive committee.
LONDON, March 15 Courtaulds, Ltd., made a conciliatory gesture to Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., today.
WASHINGTON, March 15 A former Government auditor testified today that United States foreign-aid supplies had helped build a multi-milliondollar Soviet aid "showpiece" in Cambodia.
Dr. Howard A. Rusk, director of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. New York University Medical Center, was honored yesterday by Cancer Care as "volunteer of the year."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) The Glass Bottle Blowers Association announced today the signing of a nationwide contract for production workers and described one of its provisions as an innovation in job security.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 15 The Soviet delegate asserted today in the Security Council that the United States "is openly preparing within its own armed forces units of mercenaries to engage in a new intervention against Cuba."

Because of the great Congressional and public interest in the B-70 bomber and RS-70 reconnaissance-strike programs, I have within the last week furnished to interested members of the Congress our latest analyses of these two aircraft. In line with our policy to keep our citizens informed on major defense issues, I believe as much of this information as security considerations permit should also be made available to the general public.
LONDON, March 15 Prime Minister Macmillan announced today that R.A. Butler, Home Secretary, was assuming special responsibility for Britain's relations with the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Administration officials disclosed today that a United States trading concern had applied for permission to send grain worth $400,000,000 to Communist China and North Korea.

WASHINGTON, March 15 The 100-piece United States Army Band played obscure and popular versions or the National Anthem today to support a Representative's view that there really should be only one way to play it.

The United States Treasury gold stock sustained another loss last week, the fifth in the ten weeks of 1962. The most recent decline, covering the week ended Wednesday, amounted to $20,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

TRENTON, March 15--Gov. Richard J. Hughes confirmed today that the state was considering the purchase of large tracts of oceanfront beach that were stripped of man-made structures by last week's storm.

PITTSBURGH, March 15 (UPI) Top negotiators for the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America denied today that their bargaining had been influenced by outside sources "either private or Government."

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had no plans for revoking the broker-dealer registration of Sutro Bros. Co. despite its allegation that the concern had violated the Federal securities laws.
A long, tireless search for the schoolmates he knew a halfcentury ago ended last night for a very curious man named Nathan Smith.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 15 The Women's Emergency Committee for Public Schools sent letters to eighty-four United States Senators today protesting the nomination of Pat Henderson of England, Ark., as United States marshal for the Eastern District of Arkansas.

Consumers, by definition, include us all. They are the largest economic group in the economy, affecting and affected by almost every public and private economic decision. Two-thirds of all spending in the economy is by consumers. But they are the only important group in the economy who are not effectively organized, whose views are often not heard.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that the Sperry Gyroscope Company was guilty of unfair labor practices. It affirmed the right of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers to represents the company's employes.
The American Electric Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that earnings for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28 were a record.
The captain of the Flying Tiger airliner lost in the Pacific was the hero of a daring crash landing in Jamaica Bay in Queens on June 21, 1957.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)--Practices in the acquisition of highway land in Massachusetts were labeled a "miserable mess" today after an investigation. A House Works subcommittee ended its inquiry...

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Representative Richard E. Lankford, Maryland Democrat, said today the $6,082 in American and foreign money he spent on a recent thirty-eightday world trip had been spent on official and justifiable business.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 Dr. Arthur Holly Compton, Nobel Prize-winning physicist, educator and one of the key men in the development of the atomic bomb, died this morning at Alta Bates Community Hospital in Berkeley. He was 69 years old.
GENEVA, March 15 The Soviet Union rejected today the inspection safeguards that President Kennedy had demanded as a prerequisite for changing his decision to resume nuclear tests in the atmosphere.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York opened its twenty-fourth annual campaign last night to help meet the needs of Jews in Israel and over the world.
Cotton futures were 10 cents off to 50 cents a bale up yesterday.
PARIS, March 15--The new Michelin Guide for France was published today and all across the country there were happy restaurateurs and those who were absolutely disconsolate.

SOME artists are very difficult to write about. Occasionally this may be because of the problem of thinking up some circumlocution less wounding than saying "Mr. X's work is bad." Other artists are difficult to write about because they create experiences that are purely visual and abstract. Here one is often immediately happy to pronounce "Mr. Y's work is good.
JERSEY CITY, March 15 The City Council adopted today a record 1962 budget of $67,546,638, which calls for a property tax rate of $114.45 on each $1,000 of assessed valuation.

BOSTON, March 15 (AP) Stockholders of the Gillette Company were told today that earnings for the first quarter of 1962 were expected to approach $11,000,000, compared with $10,045,170 for the 1961 period.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) A Federal grand jury indicted two officials of the Communist party in the United States today on charges of failing to register with the Justice Department on behalf of the party.
Mrs. Dorothy Quick Mayer of 880 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L.I., a writer who treasured a childhood friendship with Mark Twain, died yesterday at her home here after a long illness.

KEY LARGO, Fla., March 15 A fisherman in Flori da waters finds himself playing an endless guessing game guessing what will be at end of his line when he reels it in. The species are numerous and the names given to them are colorful.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) President Kennedy signed a bill today for a vast project of teaching new skills to unemployed workers.
A major segment of maritime labor urged Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges yesterday to approve a Maritime Administration authorization of operating subsidies for Isbrandtsen Steamship Company.
The selection of Mrs. John H. Mundy as head of the Professional Children's School, effective July, 1, was announced yesterday by Mrs. John Davies Stamm, president of the board of trustees.
A NEW star shone on Broadway last night. Donald Brooks, a well-known Seventh Avenue designer, made a smash hit in his first major venture of designing for the stage.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., March 15 Two hundred and fifty residents of this village joined tonight in an interracial movement to establish a recreation center for children "regardless of race, religion or creed?"

LONDON, March 15 Led by Prime Minister Macmillan, who confessed to "shock," and Iain Macleod, party chairman, who offered his clan motto, "Hold fast," Conservative leaders strove today to rally their shaken followers.

American Airlines announced yesterday that it planned to start Convair 990 jet service Sunday between New York and Chicago. On April 1 similar flights from New York will be added to Detroit and St. Louis, and on April 15 to Dallas.

Consolidated net income of W.R. Grace Co. last year rose to $18,830,028 from $16,220,381 in 1960, J. Peter Grace president, reported in his annual statement to stockholders yesterday. The 1961 net is equal to 3.68 a share of common stock compared with 3.16 a share the year before, giving effect to the 2 per cent stock dividend paid in 1961.

NEW HAVEN, March 15 Lynwood Straw, a Yale sophomore, and John Pringle, a Harvard junior, became the first individual champions as the twenty-second annual Eastern Seaboard intercollegiate swimming championships began today.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Industrial production rose 1 per cent in February, but it barely reached the record pace of December and it marked a gain of only 2 per cent in six months.
The American Machine and Foundry Company set records last year for earnings, sales and rentals, Morehead Patterson, chairman, reported to stockholders in the annual statement yesterday.

The work that Tommy Trotter and his assistants did in January and February to attract thoroughbred horses to the New York area was evidently successful. Indications are that the stalls at Aqueduct and Belmont Park will be occupied to capacity shortly after the season starts at 1:30 P.M. Tuesday at Aqueduct.
Complaints by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes about municipal red tape brought quick City Hall endorsement yesterday.

Bank clearings in the twentysix leading cities of the nation totaled $28,500,002,000 in the week ended Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell group last year had record sales and operating income of 2,789,949,000, or $7,811,857,200, according to annual report for 1961. This compares with 2,673,740,000, or $7,486,472,000, in 1960.

Two charitable agencies of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will receive the proceeds of a flower sale and card party to be held May 7 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) Grain futures made their broadest general advance in two weeks today as a rallying tendency, apparent from the opening gong, finally took hold near the close.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, March 15 French and Algerian negotiators brought a cease-fire in the Algerian war-appreciably closer to signature today by settling the most difficult military questions.

WASHINGTON, March 15 One of the interesting paradoxes of the Kennedy Administration is that a great many of the progressives, innovators, and reformers close to the President come from the politically conservative areas of the Middle West and West.
DETROIT, March 15 New car sales during the first ten days of March were the highest for that period since 1956.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15--Thunder, lightning and the fiercest rainstorm here in recent years transformed this normally picturesque area today into a scene from a horror movie. Storm flags were hoisted and tornado warnings posted. If there was a bright spot anywhere in the state, it was not visible to the local citizenry.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 A Paul Klee oil painting, stolen from a display of Ruth McC. Maitland's collection on Christmas Day in 1959, has turned up in the West Berlin Museum.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 15 Bill van Breda Kolff, basketball coach at Hofstra College for the past seven years, was named to a similar post at Princeton University today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics.
Construction work on Park Avenue South has already given a hint of what the avenue will be like when it is divided by a mall, as Park Avenue has been for decades.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 15 (UPI) The state police laboratory confirmed today that there had been a heavy concentration of salt in a formula fed thirty babies at Binghamton General Hospital. Six of the babies died.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 15--The preparation for the opening of a horse-race meeting often is like a musical comedy rehearsal, with everyone seemingly at cross-purposes. You get an impression of confusion, disorganization and impatience and wonder how the directors will ever get out of the mess and ready for the first curtain.

The Ford Foundation, with a potential $2,500,000,000 to spend in the next decade, is conducting a full review of its grantsin-aid policies and operations. It is the first over-all survey since the foundation's trustees approved a basic plan in 1950 to govern its world-wide activities.

The home of Alexander Hamilton on 141st Street, Manhattan, has somehow managed to survive the vicissitudes of nearly two centuries, during which a spot that was once far out in the country has been engulfed by a vast metropolis. Hamilton's memory survives in other ways on our ten-dollar bills and in the kind of government we have.

DETROIT, March 15 (UPI) Bruce Gamble turned in his first National Hockey League shutout tonight, a 4-0 victory against the Detroit Red Wings. It kept the Boston Bruins from equaling the longest string without a triumph in the league's history.

WASHINGTON, March 15 There were no chuckles in today's production of the weekly "Ev and Charlie Show." To the contrary, the predominant mood was melancholy. The show is conceded to fall short of its intended purpose, which is to compete with the White House's control over political communications in this country. And the two stars seem to know it.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) A top military analyst said today that there was no greater percentage of weaklings in the nation's fighting forces now than there was at the Alamo, Gettysburg, Valley Forge or Bastogne.

"Beverly Hillbillies," a filmed comedy series starring Buddy Ebsen and Irene Ryan, has been added to the Columbia Broadcasting System schedule for next fall. It will be televised on Wednesdays from 9 to 9:30 P.M.
Among economists and business analysts there have been three groups of thinkers the super-optimists, the optimists and the sub-optimists.
The stock market was "nervous" yesterday. Traders were waiting to see if the spring rally would continue for a sixth day. It did, although on a diminshed scale.
MARILYNN MOTTO is out to prove that the Gideon Bible is not the only memorable fixture in a hotel room.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 Roger Noble Burnham, a sculptor and a former art instructor, died here last night. He was 85 years old.

The National Invitation Tournament, New York's twentyfifth annual spectacle of the dribble, the screen and the cheerleader, had a brilliant opening on the Wisconsin pinewood boards at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) The House passed today a bill that would reform the Federal-state welfare program along lines recommended by President Kennedy. But at the same time it increased his budget for welfare payments by $140,000,000.
A touch of spring and the presence of thousands of wideeyed, pony-tailed girls enlivened the normally staid Columbia University campus yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 15 The Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, retired pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church, Newark, and former Republican State Senator from Essex County, died of cancer today in Princeton Hospital. He was 73 years old and resided at 61 Little Brook Road.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 15 (AP) The defending champion, Wittenberg of Springfield, Ohio, and Southeast Missouri, the 1961 runner-up, were eliminated today in the quarter-finals of the National Collegiate college-division basketball tourna ment.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Should the United States keep secret a flashing light in space? This question has caused a sharp disagreement between the scientific community and the Pentagon.

The six-story office and store building at 166 Madison Avenue near Thirty-third Street has been purchased for investment by William J. Kaufman. It was sold by clients of Walter Scott Co. for cash over a mortgage of $100,000. The sellers, who bought the property recently, were represented by Saul Cohen. William Krieger was the broker in the resale. The plot is 25 by 100 feet.

WASHINGTON, March 15--The civilian and military chiefs of the defense establishment told Congress today that a military foreign aid program would be needed for the nation's security even if the Soviet Union accepted promptly the United States disarmament proposals.
WASHINGTON, March 15 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the proposed B-70 bomber project had serious technical shortcomings, even if the plane could be developed.

Business loans at the major New York City banks rose by $187,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. During the corresponding week of last year the increase was $362,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 15 The United States will soon grant Okinawa more self-government and offer Japan a cooperative role in the island's economic development.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 The Brazilian state oil company, Petrobras S.A., today reported record sales and profits and the attainment of national self-sufficiency in refined oil products.

Trading in world sugar futures was nervous but prices were strong most of the session yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final quotations rose 7 to 11 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 8,850 tons. The market closed at or near the highs of the day.
President Ahmadou Ahidjo of the Cameroon Republic declared, here yesterday that scientific achievements had bound every race and nation in a march to a common destiny.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 A strike by three maritime unions tied up twenty-two ships operated by member-companies of the Pacific Maritime Association today.
PARIS, March 16 Two problems are gradually emerging as the toughest in the negotiations for Britain's entry into the European Economic Community.
Two officials of the Communist party in the United States were release here yesterday in $5,000 bail each.

IN the waning weeks of the season, "Elektra" finally turned up at the Metropolitan Opera. It was given its first performance of the season last night, mostly with familiar singers in the leading roles with one rather important exception. Gerda Lammers, a German soprano, made her debut in the title role.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 16 Premier Gyrille Adoula returned to Leopoldville today, but made no immediate move to confer with President Moise Tshombe, who was waiting to confer with him.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 16 Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq and President Nazem el Kodsi of Syria announced plans tonight for close military and political cooperation and invited other Arab countries to join.

A WOMAN went into a Fifth Avenue department store one day last week in search of an understated pink wool suit. She was leafing through the racks of clothes in her size when a saleswoman came up and offered to help. The customer told the saleswoman what she wanted, and the saleswoman shook her head.

Two Viennese symphonies were enough to make up yesterday's Philharmonic program. Since one of them was Mahler's Seventh, however, the concert actually ran several minutes longer than usual. Schubert's Third was the other, and William Steinberg was on hand to conduct both.

Commodity futures were dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices closed irregularly. The domestic sugar contract and lead rose; world sugar futures, potatoes and hides declined, and price movements for cottonseed oil, cocoa, coffee, wool and copper were mixed.

LONDON, March 16 Paul Chambers, chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., declared today it had no intention "in present circumstances" to buy any more of Courtaulds, Ltd., common shares or to sell what it had.
A ranch model home with three bedrooms has been completed at Greenwood Manor, a colony of thirty-seven houses on Route 37, west of Main Street, in Toms River, N.J. It is priced at $13,990.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., March 16 Cats tom cats, reclining cats, snarling cats and docile pussy cats were given silent birth by the fingers of a group of second-grade pupils recently at the Waverly Park School here.

Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller, a legal resident of New York for more than thirty years, has divorced the Governor and has departed Nevada, probably forever. Because of the primitive ritual of New York divorce law, virtually unchanged in its cruel and unrealistic rigidity since 1787, she established "residence" in Nevada by living six weeks at a ranch motel there.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) United States scientists are planning to beam a powerful red light at the moon soon, hoping that it will be reflected back to earth.

TAMPA, Fla., March 16 If, as appears likely, Sherman (Roadblock) Jones wins a starter's role with the New York Mets, Manager Casey Stengel will have a fellow who can throw hard, think fast and cope with most any pitching emergency.

LONDON, March 16 The stock market closed the week wearily and quietly. Yesterday's cut in the dividend by Associated Electrical Industries depressed shares in the electrical and capital goods industries. But tobaccos recovered part of their recent losses.

St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Richmondtown, S.I., will observe its 100th anniversary today.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 16 The Yankees covered a lot of ground today but otherwise accomplished nothing that could be considered helpful toward improving their already highly developed baseball skills.

The Police Department is making a full investigation into charges that policemen were brutal in dispersing peace demonstrators from Times Square on March 3.
NEW DELHI, India, March 16 Communist China has appealed to India for an "early" negotiated settlement of their Himalayan border dispute.

Time, Inc., the large publishing company, had a drop in earnings on record revenues in 1961, according to the annual report of James A. Linen, president, and Andrew Heiskell, chairman.

EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, March 16--The French and Algerian peace negotiators were still short of complete agreement tonight after nearly ten more hours of discussion.
NEW ORLEANS, March 16 (UPI) The Federal Government today received high bids totaling $268,000,000 on 210 Gulf of Mexico oil and gas bottomland tracts.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 18 Survival of the political agreement under which Colombia, has been governed for the last four years is the major question at issue in the nationwide Congressional elections that will be held Sunday.

KEY WEST, Fla., Saturday, March 17 Premier Fidel Castro this morning denounced leaders of his revolution for creating chaos and declared wholesale changes must be made.

LONDON, March 16--Despite Soviet intransigence, Britain will make "a new effort" to negotiate agreement on a nuclear test ban, Prime Minister Macmillan said today.

Paul Bartholet, former executive director of the National Association of Investment Companies, now known as the Investment Company Institute, died Thursday in Bombay, India, after an operation. He was 57 years old.

Following stockholder approval at the annual meeting, the American Mercury Insurance Company formally declared a 2 per cent stock dividend, payable on May 1 to holders of record of April 2. The company did not pay a stock dividend last year.

Pete McArdle, a 31-year-old mechanic representing the New York Athletic Club, missed a new course record by two seconds in winning the fourth annual five-mile run around the outside of Yankee Stadium yesterday. His time was 24 minutes 51 seconds.

GENEVA, March 18 The United States and Britain plan to offer this week another refinement of their conditions for a treaty to ban nuclear testing. Experts in Washington and London are said to be revising the Western plan again to minimize, as much as President Kennedy will allow, the international controls to which the Soviet Union has objected so vehemently.
Four Purim scrolls that arrived here recently from Israel will be put on exhibition Saturday at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 18 (AP) Two New Yorkers were killed early today by a car that sped by on the side of the road as they were examining their own car.
Chenangoes, men who load and unload lighters, barges and railroad floats, will be under the jurisdiction of the Waterfront Commission effective April 9.
A young, successful musical comedy author has given Yale University a substantial interest in one of his Broadway hits in memory of a professor who had inspired him to write.

Two Protestant Episcopal priests, the Rev. Dr. C. Kilmer Myers and the Rev. Clifford S. Lauder, renewed yesterday morning their annual Lenten practice of exchanging pulpits. Dr. Myers spoke at All Souls' Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, where Father Lauder is the rector, and Father Lauder preached at the Chapel of the Intercession, Broadway and 155th Street. Dr. Myers' church.

Plato once censured the Athenians for their love of cockfighting. Twenty-two New York policemen followed his example yesterday by arresting eighty-two men on cockfighting charges in Brooklyn.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines demanded yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the transit industry, immediately order employes of its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., back to work.

THE Association of Producing Artists, a repertory group that has been slowly but steadily building itself a company and a repertoire in various sections of the country during the last year and a half, is making its first New York appearance, having begun a stand at the Folksbiene Playhouse on East Broadway over the week-end.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18 It may be that Al Lopez was merely whistling a merry tune to buoy his spirits today as he discussed his Chicago White Sox before they took the field against the Yankees.
WASHINGTON, March 18--When lobbyists lobby against a tax "break" for lobbying, there must be a hitch.

SYRACUSE, March 18 (AP) The Philadelphia Warriors moved into a commanding lead in their Eastern Division semifinal play-offs in the National Basketball Association today with a 97-82 victory over the Syracuse Nats.
PARIS The signing of a cease-fire agreement ending the Algerian war represents the completion of the principal part of the contract President de Gaulle made with the French nation in June, 1958.

PARIS, March 18 President de Gaulle appealed to the French people tonight to support the peace accords reached today between French and Algerian negotiators. They will be presented to the Cabinet at a meeting tomorrow.
ALAN SILLITOE, one of the most alive, alive-o of the younger British writers, digs deeper into his talent in his third novel, "Key to the Door."*

PITTSBURGH, March 18 Steel mills reported steady demand last week. New orders were holding at about the levels of the last month. Mill officials looked for April shipments to come close to those of March.

Ohio State and Cincinnati, the nation's top-ranked college basketball teams with a total of only three defeats in fifty-five games, were favored yesterday to meet again in the final of the National Collegiate championship Saturday at Louisville.
Three Israeli folk musicians called the Oranim Zabar gave a study in how to build a diverting folk-music program at Town Hall Saturday night.
A Rockaway civic leader is charging that the Wagner administration's "conservation program in the Rockaways is a total flop" in trying to prevent spread of slums.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 18 A racially mixed audience of 1,282 filled the auditorium of Scarsdale High School this afternoon to hear a benefit concert for Freedom Riders arrested in the South.
LONDON, March 18 With relatively little to justify the trend, stock market prices moved slightly upward during slow trading last week.

President Kennedy's catch-all message to Congress on consumer protection spotlights one of the chief anomalies of our Federal Government. All of us are consumers, yet for the most part our governmental institutions relating to the economy have been set up to protect and further producer interests.

After a prolonged revision process that began in January, 1954, on Mayor Wagner's initiative and involved three separate committees of preparation, a new City Charter was approved last November by the voters.
WASHINGTON, March 18 The combination of a good dog and a good handler produced a perfect dog show week-end for a Pomeranian at the National Capital Kennel Club event tonight.
ALBANY, March 18 The Legislature is ready to approve this week a bill giving New York City the power to seize and repair slum properties.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 Just about everyone who is anyone in the New York Mets' organization was at Al Lang Field today during the fledgelings' fourth straight setback in the Grapefruit League.

Extensive improvements in the working and living conditions of grooms, exercise boys and "hot walkers" at the state's thoroughbred race tracks were recommended yesterday by an official commission of inquiry.
Two Jewish human rights agencies charged yesterday that the State Board of Regents was creating a form of "public school religion" because it sponsored a prayer in the public schools.
Peter J. Crotty, Erie County Democratic leader, predicted yesterday that New York Democrats would run Mayor Wagner for Governor, and that they would win this year's state election hands down."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 18 Frank Rice won top hunter honors in the Thomas School horse show today riding Mr. Don, a bay gelding owned by Harold Parsons. Mr. Don won two events and placed second in another.

PARIS A professional diplomat with seemingly inexhaustible patience and two politicians with a reputation for charm and finesse conducted the French side of the negotiations for peace between France and the Algerian Moslem nationalists.

The Cities Service Company increased its consolidated net income 7.6 per cent to $46,476,087 last year from $43,206,550 earned in 1960, according to the annual report released today, by Burl S. Watson, chairman.
WASHINGTON, March 19 The Administration was deeply disturbed today by the losses suffered by supporters of President Arturo Frondizi in yesterday's Congressional elections in Argentina.
New York City completed preparations early today to take over the strikebound Fifth Avenue Coach Lines after the Legislature completed enabling legislation late last night.

During a sanctioned perfect (300) game a bowler must roll twelve consecutive strikes bowling five on one lane and seven on another. It is especially difficult because the bowler must alternate between lanes until the tenth frame. Then he must get three consecutive.
The Basic Products Corporation has acquired six related grain and seed companies with annual gross sales of $10,000,000, Dudley G. Seay, president of Basic Products, announced yesterday.

William King, the sculptor, faced two dozen unabashed critics yesterday who wanted to know, among other things, why he had created mahogany acrobats with no heads, a bronze female figure with a face like a flower and a politician with a mouth full of broken coffee cups.
WASHINGTON, March 19 President Kennedy announced several actions today that would give the Ryukyu Islands a larger voice in their own affairs and spur their economic development.

Sales and other revenues of the Gulf Oil Corporation last year reached a new peak of $3,285,662,527, according to the pamphlet report for 1961. This represented an increase of about 1.5 per cent over the $3,240,627,132 in 1960.
WASHINGTON, March 19 The Supreme Court held today that a verdict of acquittal in a Federal criminal case, however erroneous, may not be set aside by a higher court.

LAMB is in particularly good supply now, a fact that probably will be greeted with more enthusiasm in the Northeast than in any other part of the country. Twice as much lamb is sold in this area of the country as in any other.

As an aid to Long Island and Westchester commuters, City Council President Paul R. Screvane suggested yesterday that the city look into building a midtown bus terminal on the East Side.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 18 (AP) Woody Hayes of Ohio State urged his fellow coaches today to do more than teach football.

An incubus that has burdened France and the entire West, bedeviling their policies and conscience, has been banished as a result of the cease-fire between France and the Algerian rebels that heralds an independent Algerian state.
Members of an invesment group have held two or three meetings to "explore possibilities" of purchasing The New York Post, it was disclosed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 19 True to form, the course of the Administration's big tax-revision bill took another unexpected turn today.
WASHINGTON, March 19 President Kennedy has directed the Atomic Energy Commission to take "a new and hard look" at the need for nuclear power and at its future commercial role.

WASHINGTON, March 19 There was mounting concern on Capitol Hill today that Britain was urging the United States to abandon its insistence on a system of international inspection to safeguard a treaty banning nuclear tests.

Milburn McCarthy Associates, Inc., a public relations concern, has leased space for its New York headquarters in the Pan Am Building, which is being constructed at 200 Park Avenue adjoining Grand Central Terminal. H.K. Negbaur Co. was the broker. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., is the agent for the building.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (AP) Bobby Nichols, a long-driving 25-year-old, turned in an eight-under-par 64 today and won his first professional golf tournament, the $20,000 St. Petersburg open, with a 72-hole total of 272.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 The General Assembly's reorganized Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space got off to a harmonious start today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 19--Brazil's new plan to fight inflation will be explained to United States officials and bankers next week by Finance Minister Walther Moreira Sales.

Continued long liquidation and selling of potato futures by local dealers touched off heavy stop-loss orders yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Short covering and trade buying raised prices from the lows of the day.

The Magnavox Company realized a 38 per cent profit increase last-year on a sales gain of 13 per cent, its annual report disclosed yesterday. Both sales and earnings set a record for the electronics producer.

WASHINGTON, March 19--President Kennedy ordered today stiff increases in duties on imported carpets and glass.

ALBANY, March 19 Upstate Republicans, still bristling over Governor Rockefeller's opposition to a Korean War veterans' bonus, tonight voted down a Rockefeller plan for a memorial to Dag Hammarskjold at United Nations headquarters.

Only 1,876 tickets from a total of 68,000 remain to be sold at $2 each for the student audience program at the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn.
