Kim Stanley and Patricia Neal will co-star in Tad Mosel's original television play "That's Where the Town Is Going!" It will be presented Tuesday, April 17, from 10 to 11 P.M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
In a sudden surge of beneficence the House of Representatives has voted to give President Kennedy $140 million more than he asked to liberalize welfare payments to the needy.
The American Iron and Steel Institute reported that the nation's mills produced 2,387,000 tons of raw steel last week, up eight-tenths of 1 per cent from the 2,367,000 tons poured the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, March 19 The Senate approved unanimously today a bill to give tax relief to victims of the recent Atlantic coastal storms and floods elsewhere. It would permit them to charge off losses in their income tax returns, due April 16.
The British poet and critic I.A. Richards was named winner of the Loines Award for Poetry yesterday. The announcement was made by the national Institute of Arts and Letters.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today it was "disgraceful" that service men's housing allowances had remained unchanged for ten years. He urged that they be increased by $300,000,000 yearly.
ULTRA-MODERN decor, silently slithering escalators and large, roomy departments are not the only change that Franklin Simon has made in its move to Thirty-fourth Street.
MOSCOW, March 19 The Soviet Union formally recognized the Algerian nationalist Provisional, Government today and proposed the establishment of diplomatic relations.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 19 Paul K. Lynner was named varsity basketball coach at Hofstra College today. He succeeds Bill van Breda Kolff, who has become head coach at Princeton.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 More often than not, when Casey Stengel talks to others it is funny. Today, however, the 72-year-old manager of the New York Mets appeared to be talking to himself after his team had lost, 1 0, to the Baltimore Orioles. And it was hardly a laughing matter.
DETROIT, March 19 (AP) A review of 1962 auto production shows sharp changes from a year earlier.

Guests to a luncheon and fashion show in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East on March 28 are requested to bring donations of rummage, which will later be sold at the Girls Club Third Shop at 1458 Second Avenue.
ALBANY, March 19 Three leading educators were named today as consultants to the State Education Department in the preparation of a survey report on instruction in the New York City public schools.
HOLYOKE, Mass., March 19 (AP)--George Sylvester Viereck, poet, novelist and pro-German propagandist during both World Wars, died last night in Holyoke hospital. His age was 77.
WASHINGTON, March 19 Organized labor endorsed with enthusiasm today President Kennedy's plan to reduce or remove tariff rates in helping to expand the nation's international trade.
The stock market continued to mark time yesterday. It was almost a repetition of Friday's performance when stocks drifted desultorily after six consecutive sessions in which they had advanced.
Problems of racial segregation, associated primarily with the South, are being attacked with new vigor in northern communities across the country.

PARIS, March 19 The French Government named one of its top-flight diplomats today to carry out the peace settlement in Algeria. Parliament was summoned to meet tomorrow to hear an explanation of the Government's plans.

Anticipation, the state that is reputed to be more euphorid than realization, is being acutely enjoyed by many thousands of houseslavers in the Greater New York region today. WASHINGTON, March 19 The American Bar Association declared today that Irving Ben Cooper lacked "both the judicial temperament and judicial experience" to sit as a Federal judge.

CAIRO, March 19 President Gamal Abdel Nasser held out hope today that the Algerian cease-fire might open the way for a renewal of friendship between Egypt and France. The research performance of this country's textile industry "has not been outstanding," Robert T. Stevens, president of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., told members of the Textile Research Institute yesterday.

KEY LARGO, Fla., March 19 The bonefish has been given such fanciful designations as greyhound of the sea, phantom of the flats and silver shadows. Anglers tend to get emotional about them. They are perfectly useless for anything except puncturing the ego of any angler who thinks too much of his skill and ability with a rod.

BONN, Germany, March 19 A political week-end trip into West Germany by a member of the Communist East German Government has brought an uproar in the press and an official acknowledgment that Bonn lacks the legal means to prevent such incidents.

DETROIT, March 19 A top official of the United States Steel Corporation declared here today that Americans must find a way to end an extended period of wage inflation that he attributed to monopolistic union power.

A dinner dance will be held in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane on May 17 for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Proceeds of the eleventh annual benefit, which is being sponsored by the Lower East Side committee of the service, will be applied toward a deficit incurred last year when 300,000 nursing service visits were made to patients in their homes.

WASHINGTON, March 19 President Kennedy was reported today to have chosen Col. Justice Marion Chambers to be deputy director of the Office of Emergency Planning.

Prices of United States Government securities moved forward yesterday, with five of the longer-term issues reaching new high prices for the year.

OLIVE YAZID, nee La Guardia, belongs to that adventurous breed of American women who could set up housekeeping with aplomb anywhere in the world. Sporadic... danger, language barriers and newness of custom and climate have not fazed her in her temporary home in Carthage, Tunisia, and she now looks forward to opening a house in Algeria, her husband's country.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 19 The ruling Liberal-Conservative coalition retained a substantial majority today over its opponents in yesterday's Congressional elections.
WARSAW, March 19--Fourteen persons, including a prominent Warsaw editor, went on trial today charged with having smuggled millions of dollars worth of contraband across the Polish border.
Nearly 200 persons, including a number of city officials, attended the dedication yesterday of Chatham Green, a middleincome cooperative housing project at the edge of Chinatown.
LONDON, March 19 Prices of industrial shares and British Government securities tended to ease in the stock market today. Falls seldom exceeded a few pence.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. Barksdale Hamlett, an artilleryman, was named second in command of the Army today.
MADRID, March 21--Juan D. Peron has accused the Pentagon of "meddling" in Argentina's political crisis to help keep his supporters from power it was reliably reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)--Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the Federal Power Commission defended today the agency's new Natural Gas Advisory Council as necessary to provide a better understanding of the industry's functioning.

The ABC Vending Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income for the last year of $2,644,108, or $1.02 a share, on the average of 2,591,079 shares outstanding. This compared with $2,513,988 and $1 on 2,502,276 shares a year earlier.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21--Alfred Hitchcock is using his own money to finance his latest movie, it was learned today. Although the cost of the picture is not known, it will be well in excess of $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--Representative Emanuel Celler said today that if Congress delivered a global space communications network "into the hands of a few vested-interest companies" it would "make such give-aways as Dixon-Yates look like petty larceny."
Inquiries by the Civil Rights Commission and the Justice Department have fully exposed the misuse of literacy tests in some Southern states to keep qualified Negroes from voting.
CHEKHOV'S wry. tender view of lamed, unfulfilled lives is enduring in its validity. Yet its universality emerges most eloquently when his plays are produced in the spirit of their time and place.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Country music and Cuban refugees, a medical Peace Corps and nuclear fall-out in milk.

Henry Baker and associates have contracted to buy the fivestory building with twelve apartments and four stores at 801 Ninth Avenue, northwest corner of Fifty-third Street. The parcel, which is 25 by 100 feet, is the fourth to be acquired recently by the purchasers on Ninth Avenue.
Sponsors have been announced for the gala benefit dinner in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria next Thursday for the benefit of Project Hope.
Joseph v. McCabe, a lawyer and New York County Commander of the American Legion from 1935 to 1937, died Tuesday in his home at 144-48 Eightyseventh Road, Jamaica, Queens. His age was 69.
GENEVA, March 21--The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union failed again today to break the deadlock over inspection that has held up a treaty to prohibit nuclear testing.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- President Kennedy welcomed today Premier Khrushchev's offer to cooperate in space. He expressed hope that the basis had finally been laid for "practical cooperation" between the two nations.
An appeal for positive support of the Police Department and its policemen "when they are right" was made yesterday by Commissioner Michael J. Murphy in a talk to port and waterfront officials.
NEW DELHI, India, March 21--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today he would not "rule out" arbitration of the Chinese-Indian border dispute by a third party.

Representative Carl Vinson of Georgia, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has not been called "The Swamp Fox" for nothing. His tactical retreat yesterday on the floor of the House from a position which many had thought was untenable was gracefully done, and Mr. Vinson's forces are still in good order and full of fight.

PEGGY ROTZELL of Philadelphia, one of the high est-ranking tournament players, reports notable bridge hands each month in the Contract Bridge Bulletin published by the American Contract Bridge League.

Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, told a Presidential commission yesterday that railroad tugboats here could not be operated with fewer than the five crew members they now had.

Zionist leaders criticized both the United Nations and the United States yesterday for what they called the failure of both to take immediate steps to achieve a permanent peace between Israel and the Arab states.

SQUAW VALLEY Calif., March 21--This may have been the first day of spring but as seventy-five skiers from eighteen schools tuned up for tomorrow's start of the three-day National Collegiate championships this winter resort continued to be entombed in snow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21--Major changes are in prospect this year for thousands of farm families in Pakistan. The final stages have been reached on two water control projects, opening the way for double and even triple-cropping on thousands of acres of former wasteland.

The American Stock Exchange made known yesterday the following changes in stockholdings reported by officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue an insiders report this week.
Argentina is struggling to find at least a temporary solution of its political crisis that stays within the field of constitutionality.

THE 47-year-old victor in the Governorship election in Buenos Aires Province, who challenged yesterday the Argentine Government's military seizure of five key provinces, has been a kind of partisan commander under orders to continue resistance after the main troops flee.

The premiere of Igor Stravinsky's first composition for television, with the composer conducting the orchestra, will be presented on "Noah and the Flood" on June 14 from 9 to 10 P.M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

First-quarter sales of the Eaton Manufacturing Company were about 22 per cent above the 1961 level and "we are forecasting that net income for the quarter will be more than double a year ago," John C. Virden, chairman and president, told the annual meeting in Cleveland yesterday.

Plans are under way for the Commonwealth Ball of the New York branch of the EnglishSpeaking Union. The event will take place May 11 at the Plaza with proceeds assigned to educational work required to promote closer understanding between the United States and the British Commonwealth.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would take early action to enlist Federal and state agencies in the city's campaign to prevent and cure narcotics addiction.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 --West Coast shipowners and striking seafaring unions agreed today to resume negotiations under the eye of a Federal mediator.

PARIS, March 21--The flow of economic aid and loans from the United States. Western Europe and Japan to the under-developed countries reached a record $8,000,000,000 in 1960, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today. Preliminary data indicate another record in 1961

Nothing that has happened thus far in the twenty-fifth annual National Invitation Tournament produced so much excitement as the semi-finals are virtually certain to generate at Madison Square Garden tonight. High-altitude shooting stars, talented little men and teams with contrasting modus operandi will be on display.
Special to The New York Times.

RABAT, Morocco, March 21 --The Moroccan King and people gave a heroes' welcome today to Mohammed Ben Bella and four other Algerian nationalist leaders released Sunday by the French Government after more than five years of imprisonment.

The New York Rangers, protecting a one-point lead over the Detroit Red Wings in the tense fight for the fourth and last berth in the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs, left for Boston last night convinced that their task was to beat the Bruins tonight in the Boston Garden.
CHICAGO, March 21 (UPI) --The Walgreen Company announced today it would enter the discount department store field with the acquisition of two discount chains in Houston, Tex.
The urge to reform is breaking out all over. The Salt Lake City Exchange, the Toronto Stock Exchange, the London Stock Exchange, the Paris Bourse--all have recently undertaken various reforms.
A Civil Aeronautics Board hearing was told yesterday that the American Airlines jet that crashed here March 1 had rolled completely on its back like a fighter plane peeling off into a dive.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21--Robin Roberts learned today that there was a vast difference between pitching for a team like the Phillies and one like the world champion Yankees.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), March 21--Adolf Eichmann will appear in an Israeli court tomorrow to appeal against the judgment and death sentence meted out to him last December.
Purdue University, Lafayette, Ind., sold $8,000,000 of dormitory revenue bonds, due from 1965 to 2002, at competitive bidding yesterday.
THERE seems to be a general belief that the major spring delicacies known as shad and shad roe are more abundant in recent years than ever before. According to John von Glahn, a director of ...
An over-supply of hotel and motel rooms in this city by the end of 1964 was foreseen yesterday by two leaders in the field.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- The Administration bill to add medical care for the aged to the Social Security system has a "good chance" of passage this year. President Kennedy indicated today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21--A former Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia rebuked the British Government today for its policies in Southern Rhodesia and warned that the colony's new Constitution is "a great victory" for the white settlers there.

Both in tone and content Premier Khruchev's reply to President Kennedy's message a space cooperation is one of the more constructive Soviet statements of recent years. For once the Soviet ruler avoids blatant propaganda, offers to begin negotiations looking toward So viet-American collaboration on all the possibilities President Kennedy mentioned, plus some additional ones, and thus raises hope of some concrete accomplishment. Though agreement on
PARIS, March 21--Inconclusive debate on the Government's settlement in Algeria--probably the last debate of the present National Assembly--ended today.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 21 --There were no railbirds at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A driving rainstorm, with occasional snow, pelted the racing strip and the brightly lighted clubhouse. Racing conditions were miserable and only the hardier harness-racing addicts turned out.

HOMESTEAD, Fla., March 21--The sight of endless miles of untouched wilderness gives a special pleasure to the wildlife buff and outdoors enthusiast. In the more than 2,000 square miles of the Everglades National Park that make up the southern tip of Florida he can obtain special pleasure found nowhere else in the country.
MADRID, March 21--The French Army's obedience to President de Gaulle will decide the fate of the Secret Army Or- ganization in the coming weeks.

PARAMUS, N.J., March 21 --A force of sixteen local policemen, supported by their Bergen County colleagues, struggled with a massive traffic jam here this morning as first-day shoppers converged an Alexander's newest department store.
GENOA, Italy, March 21 (AP)--Rex Harrison married Rachel Roberts, the British actress, today in a ceremony that shifted abruptly from one room to another.
Thomas E. Enright Jr. Fiance of Miss Ryan

IN "The Blood of the Lamb" by Peter De Vries the light comedy of his earlier novels deepens into unfathomable trag edy. Yet we are always aware that it is the same author writing, moving from rippling absurdity to the shaking elements of grief beyond endurance.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 21--Premier Tancredo Neves ordered air force planes and navy transports today to rush and rice into the eight states of Brazil's northeast region. Prices for food staples in the northeast have risen more than 100 per cent since the first of the year.
PARIS, March 21--A 33year-old French artist who produced Braques and Picassos to order has been arrested here after having deceived art experts for two years.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- The Soviet Union has become a member of the International Cotton Advisory Committee.

ALBANY, March 21--Senator Walter J. Mahoney predicted today that Mayor Wagner and the Democrats would reap a political profit next fall from the Legislature's refusal to reapportion its districts now.
ALBANY, March 21--Two bills designed to prevent "deals" involving bus franchises and fares in New York City were filed tonight under the sponsorship of Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney.

EXCLUSIVE men's wear shops, like bars that have "Tables for Ladies" signs, are becoming increasingly aware of the woman patron. Although she is often confined to a nook, she is permitted to buy the same imported tweeds that her male colleagues favor and have these materials made into suits and dresses.
The bond market scored new gains yesterday on broadened trading, with most of Treasury's interest-bearing securities reaching new high prices for the year.

The country's largest dog shows had the poorest judging and the worst of all was at the Westminster Kennel Club event in Madison Square Garden, said Dr. Dan M. Gordon of Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday. He also charged that ...

For the first time since World War II, non-Spaniards can buy and sell Spanish stocks and bonds and get their money-- dividends, interest or the capital itself--without restriction. However, non-Spaniards are still not permitted to own more than 50 per cent of any Spanish company.
President Kennedy announced the appointment yesterday of nine experts to study the New Haven Railroad and make recommendations within sixty days on its reorganization problems.

TRENTON, March 21--The New Jersey Blue Cross asked the State Department of Banking and Insurance today to approve an over-all increase of 29.2 per cent in its hospitalization insurance rates, effective Sept. 1. The over-all increase for group contracts would be 29.3 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- President Kennedy and Representative Carl Vinson reached a truce today that abruptly ended the battle of the B-70.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- President Kennedy said today that he had no evidence of an impending Cuban attack on the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21--Vernon Quinn, author and editor, died today at St. Francis Hospital. Miss Quinn, whose full name was Elizabeth Vernon Quinn, lived at Stormville. She was 81 years old.

James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, yesterday urged passage of the city's proposed rent control law, "not as a shield" for bad housing "but as a sword in the battle for better housing."
CLEVELAND, March 21 (AP) --The heads of the five rail operating unions, representing 200,000 employes, agreed today to start national negotiations in the work-rules dispute on April 2 in Chicago.

The blockfront on the east side of Hudson Street, between Worth and Leonard Streets, which was under contract of purchase by Harry Horwitz, realty investor, from the Duke of Roxburghe, has been resold to an investor. William Tarnapol, the buyer, has taken title and plans to renovate the buildings.

BALTIMORE, March 21 (AP) --Clint Murchison Jr., owner of the Dallas Cowboys of the Natinal Football League, testified today he once offered to divide the prospective franchise 50-50 with Lamar Hunt, founder of the American Football League, or turn it over to him completely.
Federal mediation officials continued efforts here yesterday to avert a flight engineers" strike scheduled for 7 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, tomorrow, against Pan American World Airways.
The city took over all the franchises and property of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines last night except for ten routes in Manhattan.
ALBANY, March 21--State Controller Arthur Levitt has refused to refund $150,000 of state income taxes claimed under a law approved by the 1959 Legislature.

James F. Oates Jr., president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, said yesterday that he was "very gratified" that the State Senate had approved the Gordon-Liebowitz Bill. Equitable, the nation's third-largest life underwriter, was an early advocate of legislation allowing New York life insurers greater investment flexibility with respect to pension and annuity funds.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended March 14:

Although the crowd at Aqueduct yesterday was half the opening-day turnout of Tuesday, there was no viewing with alarm on the part of the New York Racing Association, which conducts thoroughbred meetings here.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--Headquarters of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers said today that if its members walked off their jobs tomorrow as threatened at eight Atlas missile bases, other union members would be brought in to replace them.

In trading that was largely without character, stocks moved gently lower on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Here and there were patchy gains or patchy losses and only the savings and loan holding companies moved forward in concert.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes yesterday ordered the replacement of all antiquated signs on Manhattan's two shorefront highways to conform with the latest standards.

ALGIERS, March 21--French military policemen battled with Right-Wing terrorists in the center of Oran for two hours today. European snipers fired at the gendarmes from housetops as others threw grenades out of windows at them.
SEBRING, Fla., March 21-- Some of the fastest cars entered in Saturday's twelfth annual twelve-hour race here were sent out for practice on the 5.2-mile course today.

Sales and earnings of the Adams-Millis Corporation's hosiery operations "continue to grow moderately," J.H. Millis president, told the annual meeting in High Point, N.C., yesterday. However, he added, "some of the company's other divisions are not doing too well."
WASHINGTON March 21 (UPI)--President Kennedy is expected to remove tomorrow the secrecy on information about a dozen commodities in the government's stockpile of strategic materials.

ALBANY, March 21--The Senate approved today the Gordon-Liebowitz bill expanding the investment powers of New York life insurance companies with respect to pension funds. The measure now goes to the Governor.

Acquainting myself attentively with your message of March 7 of this year, I note with satisfaction that my appeal to you of Feb. 21 with a proposal that both countries should pool their efforts to explore outer space, has been met with the necessary understanding of the United States Government.

At one time the tailoring of women's slacks made it appear that another traditional male garment had been commandeered. In recent years, however, manufacturers of women's apparel have decided to leave the

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The forty-eight nation coffee study group opened a special meeting here today to seek basic agreements for signing a world pact designed to stabilize the trade and prices of coffee.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- A spokesman for anti-Communist groups announced plans today to swamp Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy with letters demanding a "get-tough policy with internal conspirators."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21--For the New York Mets, suddenly it was spring. Reeling under the weight of a six-game losing streak, the "infant" National Leaguers squeezed out a 1-0 decision over the highly regarded Detroit Tigers today. The Tigers are expected to finish second in the American League.

THE Guggenheim Museum today opens a selective re view of paintings done during the last fifteen years by Antoni Tapies, a Spanish abstractionist who has risen rapidly to international fame and favor. Tapies, who was born in 1923, had his first American show in 1953 at the Martha Jackson Gallery, and won the first prize at the Carnegie International of 1958.

BUENOS AIRES, March 21-- A wrangle among military leaders, dissension among the democratic parties and a call by Peronist unions for a general strike Friday deepened Argentina's political crisis today.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that new city taxes were "going to be very difficult to avoid" in the fiscal year beginning next July 1.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- A vital part of the Administration's carefully laid plans to soften textile-industry opposition to the foreign trade bill has met with potentially embarrassing difficulty.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Senator Jackson of Washington has now powerfully enforced the mounting concern and mystification in Congress and public study groups over the primary influence in shaping the foreign policy of the United States that President Kennedy has increasingly granted to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- President Kennedy commiserated today with impatient Reservists who were mobilized in the Berlin crisis last fall and now are clamoring to be released.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- --President Kennedy said today that the United States should act "to build" in Algeria "rather than attempting for political purposes to exploit a situation."
Cotton futures advanced 5 to 30 cents a bale higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

PRESIDENT KENNEDY-- Good afternoon. I have one announcement. I received this morning Chairman Khrushchev's reply to my letter of March 7 on outer space cooperation. I'm gratified that this reply indicates that there are a number of areas of common interest.
The controlling interest in Avis, Inc., the second largest car rental agency in the nation, is about to pass into the hands of Lazard Freres Co., the international investment banking house.

SOUNDS and sound combinations in great variety were heard during the fourth "Music in Our Time" concert presented by Max Pollikoff last night at the Ninetysecond Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Of compositional styles and techniques, there was more of a sameness.

AS the calendar says, spring is here. To turn a phrase of the late Oscar Hammerstein, Manhattanites haven't seen a crocus or a rosebud or a robin on the wing. However, the vegetable stands currently are supplied with that notable harbinger of the season, fresh asparagus, and that is as sure a sign as shad roe.
ALBANY, March 21--Governor Rockefeller's proposal to raise the state's minimum wage won final legislative approval in the Assembly today.
After ten days of talk the Geneva disarmament conference is compelled to face up to a complete deadlock on all the issues discussed, including a nuclear test ban, general disarmament and Berlin.
The free world's leading fiscal and monetary experts will hold a financial summit meeting in May behind closed doors in Rome to discuss international economic and monetary prob lems.
The National Association of Manufacturers called yesterday for a $5,000,000,000 cut in the Federal budget for 1963, con- tending that its size would retard economic growth.
Flight engineers of Pan Amer- ican World Airways called off a strike last night that had been scheduled against the airline for 7 A.M. today.

As far as anyone knows, there is no device through which a 6foot-10-inch basketball player can be restrained legally by low-altitude opponents. This being the case, LeRoy Ellis did just about as he pleased at Madison Square Garden last night, and St. John's scored a 75-65 triumph over Duquesne.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 22--The Parent-Teacher Association Council announced today its refusal to support a proposed $9,000,000 Board of Education operating budget on the ground that the council had been excluded from its preparation.
TRENTON, March 22--New Jersey and Pennsylvania will make a combined plea to New York tomorrow to raise its minimum drinking age from 18 to 21 years without delay.

Dream On, Mrs. Harriet Robinson's 4-year-old filly, enjoyed the experience of leading all the way in winning the feature purse at Aqueduct yesterday. The result was not unexpected by the crowd of 25,632, because Dream On was the 7-5 favorite. Her margin was two and a half lengths over Dotty Kirsten in the six-furlong race. [
STUART, Fla., March 22-- The king mackerel is Mack the Knife in a sea full of accomplished bait cutters. But sometimes, as in the comic books, justice triumphs.
West Germany has decided to increase the landing charges at ten major airports by 35 per cent on April 1, the Interna- tional Air Transport Associa- tion reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- Leaders took the Senate into a brief night session tonight in a new effort to wear down the Southern talkathon against the poll tax amendment. Senator Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, warned his colleagues that they could expect to be going until midnight.
In a recent issue of Newsweek Magazine, the Hyster Company, a Portland, Ore., heavy equipment manufacturer, placed an advertisement that was headlined, "The Fruits of Your Labor."

PELHAM, N.Y., March 22-- George Willard Kirk of 1 Hillside Avenue, former owner of the Chelsea Bookshop on West Eighth Street, New York, and in recent years an electronics mechanic, died today of cancer at Manhattan General Hospital in New York. He was 63 years old.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 22--Reactions of anger and suspicion mounted among key officials of the European Common Market today as an aftermath of President Kennedy's decision earlier this week to raise tariffs on carpets and glass.
One of America's major industrial empires believes in the old adage: "If at first you don't succeed, try, try again." That is Alcoa meaning, of course, the Aluminum Company of America.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday inspected the first car delivered to the New York Central Railroad of an order of fifty-three new air-conditioned coaches. The cars will be put into commuter service.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- A much-revised version of the Administration's tax bill drew high praise from President Kennedy today as the last barriers to House action were lifted.

Federal Judge John F. Dooling upheld yesterday the Government's complaint that CDC capsules were misbranded because the label adopted the weight-control program and other claims that appear in the best-selling book, "Calories Don't Count."

The Committee of FrenchAmerican Wives, which has arranged the Bal des Berceaux for March 31 at the Pierre, has announced the patronesses for the annual dinner dance. Mrs. Edward J Elliott and Mrs. James Wood Johnson are ...
NEWARK, March 22--A tenyear, $232,000,000 urban renewal program for Newark was submitted to the Mayor and the City Council tonight.

A former French airline Stewardess, whose ten-year pri- son term for smuggling was re- versed by a higher court, was sentenced to four and one-half years yesterday. She had plead- ed guilty to bringing more than four and one-half pounds of her- oin into the country.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22--Largely responsible for the widespread criticism of television drama today is the assembly-line process for feeding scripts into Hollywood's socalled "sausage factory."

LOUISVILLE, March 22--An air of excitement, akin to that stirred up by the Kentucky Derby, gripped this bustling center today. The twenty-fourth annual National Collegiate basketball finals begin here tomorrow night, and everyone is worked up over the likely prospect of another title game between Ohio State and Cincinnati.

News that the Shah of Iran will pay a state visit to the United States comes at a time when the Iranian kingdom is making a determined new effort to solve its social and economic problems and avert Communist schemes for revolutionary upheaval. A vigorous new Government under Premier Ali Amini is attempting, with considerable success, to suppress corruption, rationalize the country's administration, promote new industries and push a new agrarian reform program.
The Board of Estimate yesterday ordered a preliminary study of a proposal for an elevated truck route on Manhat tan's West Side.
The wholesale commodity price index dropped to 84.2 on Wednesday from 84.3 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 86.4 on March, 15, 1961.
The election of George C. Wildermuth and David S. Rabinowitz as trustees of the Kings County Trust Company was announced yesterday by John F. Lynch, president.
The Consumers Power company reported yesterday that sales of electricity and natural gas for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28 were new highs.

DURHAM, N.C., March 22 (AP)--Dr. Franz Schrader, former chairman of the Zoology Department at Columbia University, died at his home here early today. He was 71 years old. Survivors include his widow, Dr. Sally Hughes Schrader, a research associate in the Zoology Department at Duke University.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- In the dimly lit caucus room of the House of Representatives today, a committee of Congress and a group of scientists dis- cussed whether life exists in other worlds.

BUENOS AIRES, March 22-- A group of 300 Argentine military officers pledged themselves today to defend Argentina against dictatorship and extremisms. The pledge was made as the officers stood beside the burial place of the general who led the revolution that overthrew Juan Peron.
BERLIN, March 22--East German policemen fired at a car of the United States military mission attached to Soviet forces in East Germany, an Army spokesman said tonight.

An open-air performance of Verdi's Requiem, three operatic productions and a chambermusic series are among the plans for this summer's Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy. Theatre, dance, art and cinema events for the festival will be announced later.
ROME, March 22--A public consistory in St. Peter's Basilica this morning and a closed consistory in the Vatican this evening brought ceremonies for the creation of ten Cardinals to a close.

Cocoa futures fluctuated sharply in nervous trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market opened barely steady, fell sharply, recovered and then eased again toward the close. Final quotations were 3 to 10 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) off on 816 lots.

The troubles--mostly in keeping time schedules--that confront officials of the New York World's Fair 1964-1965 were outlined yesterday by its president, Robert Moses. He spoke at a luncheon at the Plaza Hotel given by directors of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

The United Federation of Teachers broke off negotiations with the Board of Education yesterday after rejecting an offer of $27,000,000 in salary increases. The federation, which has threatened a strike, announced that "only the immediate intervention by the Mayor can resolve this impasse."
Directors of Bell Howell Company, meeting in Chicago yesterday, approved an agreement for a merger with Ditto, Inc., under the name of Bell Howell.

A 26-year-old art dealer who allegedly stole a painting by the late Paul Klee valued at $50,000 and sold it to a German museum for $3,000 was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

BUENOS AIRES, Friday, March 23--A twenty-four-hour strike ordered by Peronist-controlled Argentine unions began here at midnight, but its effect was expected to be blunted by a split in the ranks of organized labor.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22--Venezuela joined today the series of countries in the Security Council that have condemned Cuba's efforts to get a ruling from the International Court of Justice on the legality on her exclusion from the operations of the Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--Bills to establish a Youth Conservation Corps and to reduce adult illiteracy were approved today by the House Education and Labor Committee.

TWO weeks ago the Duesseldorfer Schauspielhaus brought to town an admirable production, in German, of "Nathan the Wise," Gotthold Lessing's play about racial and religious tolerance. Last night an English adaptation --the first here since 1942-- was presented at the 78th Street, Theatre somewhat less effectively.

Production of lumber in the nation totaled 234,862,000 board feet in the week ended Saturday, according to reports received from regional associations. This compared with 233,218,000 board feet in the preceding week and 216,811,000 board feet in the 1961 week.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- United States officials said today that the newly ordered tariff increases for glass and carpets would not affect American imports of those products.

Some seals destined to become famous one way or another went on public display yesterday at the Aquarium at Coney Island. To begin with, they were probably the first seals to be caught by helicopter, or to ride in one.

Edward N. Costikyan, the Democratic County leader, has asked all district leaders to list all elective or appointive offices held by members of their organizations. The step was the first in making an inventory of the party's political patronage in Manhattan.

CAIRO, March 22 (UPI)-- Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight champion, needed the help of fifty fist-swinging military policemen to make his way to a dressing room tonight, after putting on a six-round exhibition bout before 10,000 spectators.

KAWIT, the Philippines, March 22--The old man sat near the band listening to the waltzes, and when the President of the Republic and the Ambassador of the United States and the admirals and generals came to wish him a happy birthday, he grasped them briefly by the hand because he could not see them very well.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 Twenty-five Federal judges pledged their cooperation today in speeding civil suits arising from last year's antitrust actions against manufacturers of heavy electrical equipment.
Bus service on sixty-five routes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines in Manhattan and the Bronx is scheduled to be restored at 6 o'clock this morning.
Cotton futures closed 15 cents a bale up to 35 cents off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The U.N.'s value in American foreign policy has been questioned by Senator Jackson, Washington Democrat, at the very moment that the Administration is trying to get Congressional approval for the purchase of $100 million worth of U.N. bonds to help meet the deficit caused primarily by the successful Congo operation.

LONDON, March 22 (AP)-- Mrs. Judy Devlin Hashman of Baltimore, the defending champion, gained the semi-finals of the all-England badminton championships today by defeating Mrs. Tonny Holst-Christensen of Denmark, 11--4, 11--1.

THE musical theatre can be provoking. Three months ago it succeeded in proving that there was no fun in a dedicated commitment to not making money. Last night it established that an equally passionate determination to make money could be grim.

At least $150,000 will be added to payroll costs in the city's 1962-63 expense budget because of action taken by the Board of Estimate yesterday. The board voted to give raises and set up new jobs in several city departments, effective immediately.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose by $80,000,000 to a level of $133,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- The railroad and trucking industries reported today that freight loadings last week were substantially above the preceding week and the 1961 level.

PATERSON, N.J., March 23 --The Passaic County Area Redevelopment Board has called for the creation of 15,000 new jobs by 1970 in a preliminary plan for economic development presented to the Board of Freeholders.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)--Marian Anderson, the contralto, exchanged mementos with President Kennedy today. The visit preceded a concert she gave here tonight for top officials and diplomats.
A pedestrian who drew a pistol when a policeman warned him against jaywalking in lower Manhattan yesterday was disarmed after a struggle.
Shipbuilding on the Pacific Coast costs approximately 4 per cent more than in East Coast shipyards, according to a Maritime Administration study made public yesterday.

LONDON, March 22--Ameri- can children's wear, traditionally the subject of rave notices in the United States, was successfully introduced in London yesterday to a cross section of British society, including Mrs. David Bruce, wife of the American Ambassador to Britain. The collection, including thirty-five dresses, suits, coats and play clothes designed by Helen Lee, is believed to be the first of its kind ever shown in England.

The American Immigration and Citizenship Conference will be the beneficiary of Thursday's performance of "All American" at the Winter Garden. Francis L. Kellogg and Mrs. Albert J. Murphy are benefit co-chairmen and Angier Biddle Duke is president of the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Gentle reader, the Government of the United States loves you. It cares. It wants you to know that, if you have a problem and Dear Abby can't help, all you have to do is get in touch with kind old Uncle Sam.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 22--The attorney for Adolf Eichmann served notice before the Israeli Supreme Court today that the former Nazi officer would appeal to the Council of Europe if he was not extradited to West Germany for trial.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--A House subcommittee disclosed today that the United States Government was suing the Royal Bank of Canada for not stopping payment on a $352,000 check to Cuba.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22--Sometime in the distant future there may be an all-New York world series between the Mets and the Yankees. Until this phenomenon comes to pass, what happened today will stand high among the ...
ALBANY, March 22--Legislation to permit narcotics addicts who are not hardened criminals to be hospitalized rather than imprisoned after arrest was signed by Governor Rockefeller today.

WARSAW, March 22--Poland and the Soviet Union belatedly announced this week their 1962 agreement on bilateral trade, which is to exceed a billion dollars for the first time. The target for total commerce between the two countries is $1,125,000,000, up 18 per cent over the 1961 level.
The sale of Black, Start Gorham, Inc., will mark the end of an era for the Gorham Corporation in the retail end of the silver and jewelry business.
ALBANY, March 22--The Assembly approved a bill today that would give savings banks the right to accept up to $20,000 in individual savings accounts.
BOULDER, Colo., March 22 (AP)--The Student Senate at the University of Colorado has urged the college administration and regents to suspend inter collegiate football.
The directors of the Colonial Life Insurance Company of America elected Richard D. Nelson yesterday as president. He succeeds Richard B. Evans, who was elected chairman.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., March 22--The National Col legiate skiing championships were postponed today until tomorrow because of a snowstorm that began shortly before dusk yesterday. It was still raging this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- A success story in the development of atomic power was related to Congress today. The story concerns the atomic plant built at Rowe, Mass., by ten New England electric utilities with assistance from the Atomic Energy Commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22--The Council of Europe's Commission on Human Rights, to which Eichmann's defense counsel said today he might take an appeal, was set up under the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.

After a three-week interruption, bus service will be resumed on some routes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines. The legal contest over constitutionality of new state law and city condemnation continues. Thus far it has gone against the company which, under the new management of the Harry Weinberg interests, had demonstrated such callousness toward employe and public that it provoked swift and drastic retribution in the form of government ownership.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 22 (AP)--A former member of the New York Giants revealed today that Bobby Thomson's dramatic pennantwinning homer in the 1951 National League play-off with the Brooklyn Dodgers was helped by a sign-stealing clubhouse spy.

BALTIMORE, March 21-- When railroad passengers first entered the Mount Royal Station here in 1896, they saw a columned hall of marble elegance and oak simplicity. A spirit of American innocence came shining through the station's studied European grandeur.
BONN, Dec. 22--Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, special military adviser to President Kennedy, spent more than three hours today with Bonn officials. They discussed "questions of mutual interest."

ALBANY, March 22--The state will meet $10,000 of the salary of each of the judges of the new New York City courts to be established under the court reorganization plan that will go into effect Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, March 22--The writers of the Constitution, in establishing a triune Federal Government of coordinate, separate powers, both specified and implied, gambled that the conflicts embedded in the arrangement would usually be averted by the principals from head-on collisions threatening orderly, constructive government in the United States.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP)-- A late demand lifted some grain futures contracts into a firm range today on the Board of Trade, but the market generally was barely steady.

Ramon Novarro, who thrilled legions of movie fans as the hero of "Ben-Hur and "Scaramouche," will make his Broadway stage debut this season. The 63-year-old star of silent films has been signed for a featured role in "Infidel Caesar," ...

The high grade bond market here was carried to new price heights yesterday by demand for prime debt securities that was touched off by the reduction in Britain's official bank rate from 5 to 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--The White House Rose Garden is not being eliminated, but the roses are in for some competition.

A new issue of $29,000,000 of Kentucky Turnpike Authority bonds for financing the Eastern Kentucky Toll Road extension was offered yesterday for public subscription by a syndicate headed by Allen Company, John Nuveen Co., B.J. VanIngen Co., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., A. C. Allyn Co., and the Kentucky Company. }

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 21--A bright sun turned the icy streets of Bucharest to slush today, heralding the end of one of the longest and snowiest winters Eastern Europe has shivered through in many years.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 22 --The persistence of a German Shepherd Seeing Eye dog was credited by the police here today with probably saving two blind adults and a child from death by gas.
BISSAU, Portuguese Guinea, March 21--The Portuguese secret police have arrested leaders of a nationalist organization here.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- The House Rules Committee cleared a bill today authorizing $3,063,500 to reimburse the New York City Police Department for protecting the heads of government and other officials who visited the United Nations in 1960. Floor action was expected in a week or so.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22--The great man made a delayed arrival. Early-morning rain in the Sunshine City had not prevented the New York Mets from taking their usual batting practice at Miller Huggins Field. But it sure short-changed the New York Yankees in their slightly unfamiliar role as visitors from Fort Lauderdale for their historic first meeting with the Mets. The Bombers had no batting practice at all.

Gimbels is attempting to make Paris fashions available to women of varying sizes. The store has copied some of its European purchases in women's and junior sizes as well as the usual misses size range. The collection includes some designs not bought by other stores, as well as the popular belted and flared skirt of Nina Ricci and and the matchbox skirt of Monsieur X.

A half-hour biographical program about the Duke and Duchess of Windsor that was to be televised tonight by WNBC-TV has been canceled because of a protest by the Duke's legal representative.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation made a sharp recovery in its operations last year, registering record sales and earnings. This was in contrast to 1960, when a loss of $42,934, 000 was incurred.

GENEVA, March 22--The Soviet Union was said today to have proposed again that an international authority supervise a free city of West Berlin and access to it. As before, the suggestion was promptly rejected by the United States.

GUATEMALA, March 22-- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes has appealed for help from three anti-Communist parties that sought last week to overthrow his regime. "He asked them to stop supporting his Communist opponents.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at the times indicated in paren theses.
LONDON, March 22--The Government avoided debate in the House of Commons today on a motion censuring Lord Beaverbrook's alleged press "vendetta" against the Royal Family.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 22 (AP)--An undersea volcanic eruption has freed the South African polar supply ship Republic of South Africa, trapped for eight days in Antarctic pack ice off Queen Maud Land, according to radio messages received here today.

Photo-engravers struck yesterday against two-thirds of the commercial plants in the city that produce picture cuts for printing shops and magazines. The strike was called at 4:15 P.M., at the end of the day shift. It involves between 1,400 and 1,500 members of Local 1 of the International Photo-Engravers ...

MIAMI, March 22 (AP)-- Playing in tricky twenty-fivemile-an-hour winds over a tough new course. Jack Nicklaus and Bobby Nichols shot three-under-par 69's today and tied for the first-round lead in the $50,000 open golf tournament at the Doral Country Club.

SEEMS to me here's a kind of broody note in the coot's conversation today," said Herbert Johnson, superintendent of the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge. Leaning into the wind, he was looking and listening for signs of spring in his domain of 12,000 acres of water, sand and swamp grass. It is situated thirteen air miles from the tall needle of the Empire State Building that pierces the northwest sky.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (UPI)--Wilt Chamberlain broke his National Basketball Association play-off record tonight with 56 points and led the Philadelphia Warriors to a 121104 victory over the Syracuse Nationals. The Warriors thus gained the Eastern finals against the Boston Celtics.

BOSTON, March 22--The New York Rangers just about wrapped up the fourth and last Stanley Cup play-off berth tonight as they beat the Boston Bruins, 4--3, in a National Hockey League game in the Boston Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO March 22 --Despite optimism in some areas, the "limited character" of the country's advance since last fall was declared today to be attracting "close attention, if not outright concern."

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 22 (AP)--Hal Price Headley, owner and breeder of thoroughbred horses, died today while supervising training of his horses at Keeneland. He was 73 years old. Mr. Headley bred winners of more than $9,000,000 and race horses that earned more than $3,500,000. He had nearly 100 stakes winners.

LONDON, March 22--The stock market responded to the cut of one-half of 1 pet cent in the bank rate with a modest, but by no means wholehearted, advance. There were still many dull spots among industrial shares.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--The National Education Association charged today that Government neglect and broken promises were seriously affecting the education of the children of United States service men stationed abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--United States authorities are cautiously optimistic that the tide may soon start turning against the Communists in South Vietnam's guerrilla warfare, it was indicated today.

Spokesmen for several cemeteries in the city declared yesterday that it would be "unfair and discriminatory" for the state to require cemeteries under its jurisdiction to remain open for week-end burials.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- The battle of the RS-70 ended on a sunny Tuesday afternoon when the President of the United States took the Swamp Fox of Georgia on a stroll in the Rose Garden of the White House.
Civil Aeronautics Board investigators explored further yesterday the possibility that a cockpit fire had contributed to the jet airliner crash here March 1 that killed ninety-five persons.

The Senate-sponsored storm-damage bill that President Kennedy is expected to sign momentarily will carry a double benefit for New York State taxpayers. A spokesman for Governor Rockefeller in Albany said that New Yorkers qualifying for storm loss deductions on their Federal returns this year would get the same concession from the state under existing law.

NEW YORK still harbors grocery markets where quality and service are the most important products. Their number, however, could probably be counted on one hand, in which case one finger would have to be reserved for the Venice Market.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)--The Defense Depart- ment abolished today the sepa- rate Army, Navy and Air Force contract appeal panels and set up a new all-service board to handle such disputes.
The size of nuclear weapons has grown to the point where they "no longer have any function as a continuation of for eign policy," according to this country's chief assessor of Soviet atomic blasts.

PARIS, March 22--The French Communist party found itself today, for the first time since the liberation of France, technically on the same side of a question as the President. The Communist Central Committee called on its partisans to vote "yes" in the referendum called for April 8 to solicit ...

STILLWATER, Okla., March 22 (AP)--A surprising Wyoming team put three men into the quarter-finals of the National Collegiate wrestling championships tonight and tied the defending champion, Oklahoma State, and Lehigh for the lead.

ALBANY, March 22--A new formula for increasing state financial assistance to local public school systems was agreed on today by Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislators. It will increase aid by $114,500,000 a year immediately and by $229,100,- 000 a year by 1964-65.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican of Ohio, said today that the Labor Department was threatening to cut off unemployment compensation funds to Ohio unless the state adopted Federal rule changes that were in conflict with state law.

First-quarter sales and earnings of the Monsanto Chemical Company are expected to exceed those of a year earlier, Charles Allen Thomas, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in St. Louis.

LAHORE, Pakistan, March 22 --Mrs. John P. Kennedy received a horse today from President Mohammad Ayub Khan in a day of Pakistani pomp and ceremony. She also saw the Shalamar Gardens, of which she said: "It's even lovelier than I dreamed."

ALGIERS, March 22--Rightist terrorists, armed with automatic weapons, attacked Government security forces in the heart of Algiers tonight. They also attacked in the eastern and western sections of the city. The fighting in the center of Algiers appeared to be the heaviest in months.
LONDON, March 22--For the second time in two weeks, the Government reduced the bank rate today by one-half of 1 per cent.

After completing five weeks of training, Benny (Kid) Paret, the world welterweight champion, and Emile Griffith, a former champion, arrived in New York yesterday for their tenround title fight tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 --Federal Judge George B. Harris told shipowners and striking maritime unions today that if military cargo was not moved by private industry it would be moved by the Government.

TWENTY years ago a skep tical mother asked her daughter's fiance: "How can you make a living playing with children?" The question was asked of Sol Rafel, who had just embarked on a career in social work. Two summers as a camp counselor at a Bronx House camp had convinced him that his future lay in working with people.

NEWARK, March 22--The Port of New York Authority has Just leased the initial $19,- 000,000 terminal in its $150,- 000,000 development of Port Elizabeth and is starting the $16,500,000 second phase of that project.

ALBANY, March 22--A bill requiring automobile manufacturers to install safety belts in the front seat of every new car sold in the state after June 30, 1964, won final approval in the Legislature today.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, March 17, were 1 percent below the level of a year earlier.

Puccini's three most famous heroines--Mimi, Butterfly and Tosca--have at least two things in common. One is that they each sing their first notes offstage. The second is that Licia Albanese has sung them all beautifully with the Metropolitan Opera this year. Last night she sang her first Tosca of the season.

Governor Rockefeller's proposal for legislation to speed the construction of state university facilities is a step in the right direction. Unfortunately, it is also too limited a step to promise accomplishment of the essential task. Ever since the report by the Heald committee in 1960, the need for dramatic and speedy action has been clear.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)--Small town publishers said today that enactment of postal rate increases endorsed by the Administration would doom many weekly and small daily newspapers.

Hulan E. Jack, who forfeited the Manhattan Borough Presidency as a result of having accepted a $4,400 loan from a real estate operator, moved in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday to clear his name.

ALBANY, March 22--Governor Rockefeller and Republican leaders of the Legislature have agreed to go along with a modification of New York City's proposal for financing new subway cars by issuing bonds.

SEBRING, Fla., March 22 Oliver Gendebien, a 37-year-old Belgian star whose winning performances in long-distance auto racing events surpass those of any other active driver, hasn't given a thought to retirement, he said today.
Thousands of New Yorkers lined the sidewalks of lower Broadway yesterday to give the city's traditional ticker-tape welcome to President Sylvanus Olympio of the Republic of Togo.
MONTRAEL, March 22 (UPI)--Jean Beliveau scored one goal and set up two for Gilles Tremblay tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4--1, in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)--The National Science Foundation has donated $149,000 toward construction in Australia of a gigantic radio telescope expected to make "many new discoveries" about the structure of the universe.
Business loans at the major New York City banks rose by $267,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Remains have been discovered in Africa of a creature that lived 14,000,000 years ago and, in the broad stream of evolution, seems to lie midway between the early apes and man. This was reported here today by Dr. Louis S. B. Leakey, the British anthropologist.

A GOLEM stalked the stage of the City Center last night. He looked about 10 feet tall (aided by 6-inch lifts), 6 feet broad, drank blood and choked people to death. Outside of that he did not scare anybody in the audience, no more than Boris Karloff did as Frankenstein's monster.
LONDON, March 22-- Austria's interest in European integration does not extend to the abandonment of her neutrality, her Chancellor declared today.
Stocks were sluggish yesterday. Volume dipped, most of the important stocks were little changed and the averages were a shade lower.

The marketing of 2,250,000 shares of the Ford Motor Company held by the Ford Foundation will be directed by an enlarged group of syndicate managers, according to reports in the financial district yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 22--Western observers here have found what they believe to be evidence of an extensive system of bomb shelters in Soviet cities. In earlier surveys, these observers were unable, because of lack of information, to identify ...

CHICAGO, March 22 (UPI) --A lawyer expressed fears today that a barrage of demands for public service time on commercial television could make station executives so "gun shy" they might wreck their stations' appeal to viewers.

Four agencies of the Federal Government have leased more than 180,000 square feet in the two Manhattan Terminal Buildings at 30 and 50 Church Street. The agencies are in several downtown buildings and will move about May 1 after modernization of the new quarters.

After spending more than $6,000,000 on geological and geophysical exploration over a three-year period, the Tidewater Oil Company announced yesterday the start of drilling operations on its first test well in West Pakistan.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., had record gross revenues of $3,800,000,000 last year, according to the company's pamphlet report for 1961.

SHIMMERING and flashing like a school of goldfish in rapid movement, Richard Lippold's cascading metal construction designed for Lincoln Center dominates the show "Collaboration: Artist and Architect" at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 22 --Roosevelt Raceway, which pioneered harness horse-racing events of international stature in 1952, will present another foreign-born horse to local fans tomorrow night.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., March, 22 (UPI)--Phillips Petroleum Company said last night it was rescinding an agreement to let ten Russian natural gas specialists inspect its facilities in the Texas Panhandle because of opposition by residents in the area.

A 7-year-old girl has complained to Manhattan's Borough President that his proposal to replace a Park Avenue armory with a housing development is not a good idea at all because the armory is really a castle and it has lots of horses that go in and out and they are "brownish and redish horses" and so "please don't take the armory away."

EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., March 22(UPI)--The New York Titans and East Stroudsburg State College reached an agreement today for the American Football League club to conduct preseason training here this summer.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)--David Sarnoff, head of the Radio Corporation of America, supported today the Administration's plan for public investment in a communications satellite corporation.
The Longines-Whittnauer Watch Company took no action on the regular quarterly dividend on common stock at its director's meeting yesterday.

Four men who pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct were sentenced to fifteen days in jail yesterday for their part in a demonstration March 5 in front of the New York offices of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Macy's is going into the theatre ticket business. The store said it was the first retailer to have such a service. Licenses, costing $200 each, were obtained yesterday from License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell by the newly organized Macy's Theatre Club ...
Avis, Inc., the nation's second largest car rental company, has elected a new president and chairman and has reconstituted its board of directors.

THE American Contract Bridge League is wealthy and profitable. Last year its profit from fees paid by members to play in tournaments and to record their master points amounted to $65,058, although the administration tried to keep profits down.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 22--Sonny Liston of Philadelphia today inspected Convention Hall as a possible training site for his world heavyweight championship fight with Floyd Patterson.
The City Council adopted "home rule" resolutions yesterday to clear the way for the Legislature to make three changes in the new City Charter.

Consumption and production of newsprint rose in February from the levels of the 1961 month, according to trade as sociation reports.
The American Hull Insurance Syndicate announced yesterday that it had incurred $8,500,000 in claims on the total loss of ten vessels during its 1961 fiscal year.
An offering of $35,000,000 in sinking-fund debentures of the National Dairy Products Corporation was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers.

THE fresh strawberries that are being shipped here from Florida now cannot be recommended as bargains, but their excellent looks and taste do deserve mention. The price of this fruit varies from day to day, depending on the size of the shipments. It also seems to vary from store to store.

SHAKESPEARE always gave his plays alternate titles. Following this practice, an alternate title for today's column is "Almost, but Nott Quite." The artists discussed here, or many of them, come close enough to success for one to wish they had made it. But with the best will in the world, a critic cannot push artists over jumps too high for them.

Cotton futures fell 25 to 60 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

LOUISVILLE, March 23 The anticipated repeat all-Ohio final for the National Collegiate basketball title materialized tonight. But the expected conclusion of the championship semifinals was not reached without a drastic departure from script.
Cooperative apartment buyers in a Queens building now under construction won't have to wait until they move in before having their telephone installed.
WARSAW, March 23(AP) The United States defeated West Germany and Poland's second team by 12-4 scores today in the opening competition of the Warsaw international saber tournament.
PARIS, March 23 President de Gaulle ordered tonight the "pitiless" repression of "the armed insurrection" in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, March 23 The Pentagon learned today that it is easier to refuse large sums of money than to get relatively smaller sums.

The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives has completed work on a new tax bill and received from President Kennedy a letter of congratulation on its labors. Mr. Kennedy thinks the bill will help "to make America strong and vigorous," and hopes that the House will give it prompt approval.

LONDON. March 24 Speculation on the London Stock Exchange these days is not confined to shares. There is more speculation, of a different kind, about the short-term capital gains tax the Government has been talking about.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 The Security Council rejected today Cuba's request that the International Court of Justice be asked to rule on the legality of Cuba's exclusion from the work of the Organiza tion of American States.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The first United States patent granted to a resident of the Soviet Union in almost a decade was issued this week. By coincidence, a party of Soviet officials has arrived here to study the American patent system.
A Spanish merchant ship is being held in Philadelphia while her cargo-handling gear is tested to determine if it meets safety standards of the Labor Department.

QUILMES, Argentina, March 23--A group of striking Peronist workers stood in front of their homes today discussing the nostalgic past, the vexing present and the uncertain future.
Any increase in state educational aid to the city will be added to the Board of Education's budget, Mayor Wagner promised yesterday.
The city plans to open a recruiting drive for nurses here and outside New York in an effort to "overcome a brutal shortage" in the municipal hospital system.

Twenty-three Protestant clergymen issued a statement yesterday calling on the Legislature to approve a bill that would extend collective bargaining rights to employes of voluntary, nonprofit hospitals.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The index of primary market prices declined one-tenth per cent to 100.6 per cent of its 1957-59 base during the week ended March 20, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. Farm products prices advented, while the index for processed foods dropped. Average prices of industrial commodities remained unchanged.
Charles Abrams, former State Rent Administrator, said yesterday that the city's "continuing demolition policy" way the chief cause of its housing shortage.

The Bon Ami Company assertedly raided six years ago for its $3,000,000 cash holdings by a group of alleged stock market conspirators, was paid for largely with its own money, a Federal Court jury was told yesterday.

An industry spokesman said yesterday that the photoengravers' strike will affect delivery of cuts to about 10,000 letterpress printing plants in the city producing magazines, commercial packaging, brochures and annual reports.

Heavy short covering and chart buying pushed wool positions to new highs for the move yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Profit taking and hedge selling supplied the contracts. Prices closed at the highs of the day in heavy trading.
ALBANY, March 23 Governor Rockefeller urged the trustees of the State University today to consider establishing a school of criminology.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) A Federal grand jury today indicted Peter H. Olson, former secretary-treasurer of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, on charges of stealing $35,000 from the union's treasury.
Bank clearings in the twentysix leading cities of the nations came to $33,576,033,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., has reported.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) Britain and France will start talks Monday aimed at producing a jointly built supersonic airliner capable to carrying 120 passengers from London to New York in three hours, the Ministry of Aviation announced today.

CINCINNATI, March 23 (AP) William O. DeWitt, whose trades and front-office stringpulling helped the Cincinnati Reds win their first National League pennant in twenty-one years last season, won an agreement today to buy the club for $4,625,000.
The Ford Motor Company confirmed yesterday that it was considering the introduction of a new small car about the size of the German-made Volkswagen late this year.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) President Kennedy won a victory today in the first Congressional skirmish over his plan to force farmers to accept tough production controls or lose Government price guarantees.

LONDON, March 23 A dispute over the speed of Britain's efforts to enter the European Economic Community developed today between Edward Heath, Lord Privy Seal, who is in charge of the negotiations, and John McEwen, Australia's Deputy Prime Minister.
The Town of North Hempstead. L.I., is planning to sell at public bidding $2,285,000 of aerial bonds on April 3 to finance public improvements. The bonds will come due from 1963 to 1990.
An eighteen-minute color movie of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. during his orbital flight was shown last night at the fifty-eighth annual Explorers Club dinner at the Commodore Hotel.
Governor Rockefeller gave assurance yesterday that he would sign a bill mandating seat belts in all new automobiles sold in the state after June 30, 1964.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., March 23 The calendar was turned back 150 years here as officials and residents observed the town's sesquicentennial today.
WASHINGTON, March 23 The United States is preparing major shifts in the disposition of its military forces in Europe. They are designed especially to regroup noncombat units.

DETROIT, March 23 Retail sales of Chevrolet cars set a new record in the second ten days of March, K.K. Staley general sales manager of the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation said today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 La Salle Academy of New York was upset by Mackin of Washington, 44 38, in the first round of the Knights of Columbus basketball tournament at Georgetown University tonight.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., March 23 Jim Gaddis, one of this country's tallest Alpine stars, raced down a fifty-twogate course twice today with rhythmic precision and won the National Collegiate slalom championship.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) Senator Carl Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, told the Senate today that advertising and auditing contracts of a Government-controlled corporation had gone to friends of President Kennedy and Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.

On Wednesday evening at 7:30 o'clock the Charles Theatre at Avenue B and Twelfth Street will present its fifth consecutive program of films by unknown moviemekers in a carte blanche policy believed to be unique in New York commercial theatres.
CINCINNATI, March 23 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit rejected today the plan under which Memphis, Tenn., began token desegregation of its public schools last fall.

Stockholders of the G. C. Merriam Company at a special meeting yesterday in Springfield, Mass., approved a ten-forone stock split. The capital stock of the company was increwed from 45,000 shares of $100 par value to 450,000 of $10 par, effective to holders of record of April 6.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee chided the automobile industry today for "doing far too little" to solve health problems created by automobile exhaust fumes.
An unusual audience of Broadway stars, drama students, actors and poetry lover arrived at West Fifty-Fourth Street yesterday to attend a show that closed after one performance.
NORFOLK, Va., March 23 (AP) Shell Oil Company plans oil explorations off the Atlantic Coast from New York to Virginia about May 15.
VANDERBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 23 President Kennedy witnessed a successful launching of an Atlas-D missile here today.

In some fast-moving trading yesterday spot sterling declined in relation to several foreign currencies. The drop was a reaction to the news that the British Government had reduced the bank rate by of 1 per cent to 5 per cent. The United States dollar, for example, gained in relation to the pound, which reached $2.81 13-32, down 3-32.
Fourteen top sprinters are entered in today's fifth-third running of the six-furlong Paumonok Handicap at Aqueduct, with the likelihood that the favorite will go off at 4-1 or better.

A bi-level ranch model with eight rooms has been completed at Colonial Estates, a group of thirteen houses at Pomander Walk and River Road in Teaneck, N.J. It is priced at $34,990. A foyer leads to a living room with fireplace, a dining room and a kitchen with door leading to the rear yard.
The Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships opened last night at the New York Athletic Club with seventy-four combatants, no vilians among them.
Theodore Kheel, Impartial chairman of the New York transit industry, proposed last night that the Legislature authorize the city to subsidize private bus lines.

Seashore apartments, long favored by New Yorkers in search of vacation retreats close to home, are now gaining popularity for year-around living.

TROY, N.Y., March 23 (AP) A nuclear-science engineer who has been training in this country for seven years has been ordered by the United States Immigration Service to return to his homeland of Turkey by April 20.

The Port of New York Authority announced plans yesterday to extend La Guardia Airport's two runways to handle short-haul and medium-haul jetliners.

An official of the New York Telephone Company said yesterday that plans for the formation of a centralized information and ticket distribution system for Broadway were not only "feasible" but also "very logical."
THE annual spring tournament of the American Contract Bridge League begins today in the Phoenix Hotel in Lexington, Ky., and will continue through April 2.
LONDON, March 23 Tobacoo shares slumped on the stock market today following Viscount Hailsham's strong attack on cigarette smoking.

Spencer C. Young, who was City Treasurer from 1946 until his retirement in 1953, died on Thursday in the Veterans Hospital at Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 68 years old and had lived at 218-15. Forty-third Avenue in Bayside, Queens.
LONDON, March 23 Clement Davies, former leader of the Liberal party, died tonight at the age of 78. He had entered a private hospital a week ago after a cerebral thrombosis.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 23 (AP) One of the battles being fought in South Vietnam involves the problem of finding out what is going on and reporting it to the people of the United States.
Buses of the struck Fifth Avenue Coach Lines began rolling affair yesterday morning, with the Transit Authority operating the sixty-five routes seized by the city.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday he believed the question of raising the minimum age for drinking in this state should be fully explored at public hearings.

Thousands of passengers welcomed the buses back yesterday in a manner that warmed the hearts of many bus drivers. The end of the three-week stoppage made passenger-driver relations as bright and sunny as the spring weather.

Net income of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., last year amounted to $15,030,000, equal to $3.51 a share. This compared with $11,817,000, or $2.78 a share, for 1960, the report of Leonard H. Goldenson, president, disclosed yesterday.

Two nursing homes have been closed here because of unsatisfactory conditions, the Department of Hospitals announced yesterday.

The country club, once regarded are a pleasure haven for the wealthy, has begun to open its doors to families of modest income.
