The State Department has this week released another volume of the documentary record of United States relations with China. The new volume, the second of a special China series, covers the year 1943 and comes six years after the first volume dealing with 1942.
The ancient precepts of the Koran were invoked in Brooklyn yesterday morning to solemnize an Indonesian wedding in the Islamic tradition.
STILLWATER, Okla., March 23 (AP) Oklahoma State won its twenty-third National Collegiate wrestling title tonight as six Cowboys moved into the finals.

The General Dynamics Corporation, had a net loss of $143,203,459 last year. It is believed to be the largest deficit incurred by any industrial company in one year in United States business history.

A measure intended to prevent employment agencies and individuals from hiring strikebreakers was introduced in the City Council yesterday at Mayor Wagner's request.

BELHAVEN, N.C., March 27 Spring seems about ready to lay its warm hand on the coastal country around here. According to the calendar it's spring already, but if one sets one's clock of natural events by waterfowl, it's not quite that time yet.
Handy-Andy made a dramatic appearance at the Aquarium at Coney Island yesterday.

We sent our girl Elizabeth to cover The New Yorker magazine annual meeting again. She came back loaded with notes but disappointed: Meeting not so peppy this year without Botsford. [S.B. A plea for more and better vocational guidance for girls was made to leaders of the Girls Clubs of America at its seventeenth annual conference yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today consumer spending had picked up but the economy was operating below the level predicted in President Kennedy's budget message.

Irwin Shaw, novelist and scenarist, is taking another whack at playwriting with "Children from Their Games." Sam Wanamaker, who is better known as an actor, will produce and direct the play for a London presentation in July.

The community activities of the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women, will be aided by the proceeds of an art sale. Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had requested $7,667,000 in Federal funds to help repair public property damaged here and on Long Island during the storm three weeks ago.

Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman, Mayor wagner and other officials wielded shovels yesterday at the groundbreaking ceremonies for the New York City Terminal Market in the Hunts Point area of the Bronx.

WHEN Ernst Barlach died in 1938, among the few friends at his graveside were George Kolbe, Kathe Kollwitz, and Gerhard Marcks all members of the small confraternity of persecuted German artists. He died at a bad time, stripped of his honors by the National Socialists, his work rejected, his drawings confiscated, all exhibitions closed to him.
ALBANY, March 27 Governor Rockefeller today approved a decision by Republican leaders in the Legislature to hold off revision of the state's per capita aid formula for at least another year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 27 The United States and the Soviet Union held their talk today on cooperation in space research.

Doctors at Roosevelt Hospital reported a "very slight improvement" last night in the condition of Benny (Kid) Paret. It was the first indication from the hospital that the 24-year-old Cuban boxer might be coming out of his coma.

Mr. Adoula said that unless Mr. Tshombe's attitude changed he must take the blame for a breakdown in the meetings of the Congolese leaders.
MARA VARRO, Frencheducated pianist who is living in Vancouver, B. C., gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall.
Preliminary plans for the redevelopment of Washington Square Park call for the construction of a band shell in the park.
WASHINGTON, March 27 The Administration will make a sharp cut in the dairy pricesupport level this week because of the build-up of surpluses.

WASHINGTON, March 27 Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy hailed today the Supreme Court's decision on legislative apportionment. He called it "a landmark in the development of representative government."
Only two of the seven parking meter companies invited to compete for New York City's patronage met the initial test devised by Traffic Commiser Henry A. Barnes, the Commissioner said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 27 Eastern Europe's forward drive in industry resulted in a 7 per cent increase in the area's average national output in 1961. However, a generally disappointing performance in agriculture limited the possibility of raising average living standards.
ORAN, Algeria, March 27 A five-hour general strike was observed today in sympathy for the Europeans killed yesterday in Algiers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 27 President Sukarno said today Indonesia still preferred a peacefull settlement of the Netherlands New Guinea dispute despite an impasse with the Netherlands over the future of the Dutch-held territory.

John Canarina, one of the three assistant conductors of the New York Philharmonic, has been appointed conductor and music director of the Jacksonville (Fla.) Symphony for the 1962-63 season.
Dr. William C. Schuman, the president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, has decided to add motion pictures to the cultural center's repertory.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 27 Attorney General Gideon Hausner assailed today the image of Adolf Eichmann as a small wheel in the Nazi machinery of destruction.
PARIS, March 27 Edmond Jouhaud, once a general and head of France's Air Force, now sits in Sante Prison in Paris awaiting trial and perhaps death for open rebellion against his country.
The Norfolk and Western Railway agreed yesterday to lease the Pittsburgh and West Virginia Railway if the N. W.'s far-ranging merger plans are approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 27 Steve Boros is an avid student of literature and American League pitchers. The young Detroit third baseman talks like a college professor and there were times last season when he also hit like one. If there is any strength in the power of thought, Boros will be a .300 batsman this year because he has analyzed his problem with the perceptive detail of a Ted Williams.

WEST MILFORD, N.J., March 27 For two months, merchants in this northern New Jersey town have been filling telephone orders from High Crest Lake, a near-by development. For some reason, much of the merchandise has been sent back unwanted and unneeded.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, March 28. The Syrian Army announced today that it had toppled Syria's three-month-old Government, dissolved Parliament and taken over control of the country again.

PARIS, March 27 Extensive application of tariff-free trade between the European Common Market and the United States will require new international rules in many fields other than tariffs, the French Minister of Finance said last night.
Continued strong volume in potato futures trading and increased activity in sugar were the highlights of an otherwise dull day in New York commodity markets yesterday.

SPRING has come to Jamaica in a blaze of flowers on the sixth floor of a department store. It is an all synthetic spring. The "Almost For Real" flower show at Gertz, highlight of the store's fifty-first anniversary sale, displays more than $12,000 worth of artificial blossoms and plants. Scheduled to close this Saturday, the show may be held over for another week because of its popularity with customers.
ALBANY, March 27 New York State took title to 98.5 acres of downtown Albany today over the protests of the city's Democratic Mayor.

CHICAGO, March 27 (UPI) A bill pending in Congress to require full disclosure of interest rates would place consumer credit "in a strait-jacket of Federal regulations." Senator Wallace F. Bennett. Republican of Utah, told a bankers' meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) President Kennedy's request for power to use farm surpluses in United Nationssponsored international food aid programs was rejected overwhelmingly today in the House of Representatives.

Dr. Archie Leigh Dean, former Professor of Urology at the Cornell Medical College, died yesterday at Sarasota, Fla. His age was 70. He lived in Pleasantville, N.Y., and had his office at 30 East Fortieth Street.

Henri L. Asset, a retired export-import executive and formet research engineer, died on Sunday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He lived at 71 Orange Street in Brooklyn, and his age was 84.

Eastern Air Lines moved yesterday to win converts to its air shuttle operation among large traveling groups, particularly those now using buses and railroads.

CHICAGO, March 27 Mrs. Louise Osborne Rowe, former Commissioner of Public Welfare here, died yesterday at Resthaven Sanitarium in Elgin, where she had lived for two years. She was 73 years old and the widow of Cole Yates Rowe, a printing executive.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Abraham A. Ribicoff said today the Kerr-Mills medical care program was inadequate. Price changes in yesterday's bond market were at a minimun. United States Government obligations closed the trading session mixed. Scattered gains among some of the long-term obligations were offset by declines of like extent among the issues of intermediate maturity.

It permits young persons arrested on relatively minor charges of drug possession or use to be hospitalized rather than jailed.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) The Peace Corps won unanimous praise today at a hearing in which the House Rules Committee approved a $63,000,000 program for the agency.

Norman Atkins, baritone, sang the title role in last night's perforfance of Abraham Ellstein's opera "The Golem" at the City Center. This was the third performance of the work this season but the first time Mr. Atkins had undertaken the role.

Mayor Wagner submitted to the Legislature yesterday a bill to give the city the power to impose a graduated occupancy tax on tenants in commercial buildings.
LONDON, March 27 Prices of Industrial shares and British Government securities drifted downward in the stock market today. Activity was slight.

The National Cash Register Company will offer $50,000,000 of debentures to the public and 319,090 of additional common shares to its stockholders today. The securities are being underwritten by a group headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.
Supreme Court Justice Vincent A. Lupiano cleared the way yesterday for the Consolidated Edison Company to buy the site of St. Luke's Women's Hospital for the construction of an electrical substation.
LONDON, March 27 (AP) Billy Walker, a heavyweight with a fine amateur record, made a successful professional debut tonight before a sellout crowd of 12,000 at the indoor Wembley Stadium.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that the critical injury suffered by Benny (Kid) Paret in New York last Saturday night might force tighter legal restrictions on professional boxing or even its elimination.

GARFIELD, N.J., March 27 Miss Marjorie A. Colton, who is credited with devising the common household waxed paper roll, died yesterday in Deaconess Hospital, Evansville, Ind., after a long illness. She was 65 years old.

The birth pangs of the new Algeria are terrible to behold. When men, women and children are slaughtered in the streets of Algiers many shot in the back it seems as if a culmination of horror has been reached.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 27 There may be any number of good reasons why the exports are picking the Yankees as a shoo-in in the American League while they believe the New York Mets will be lucky to finish the season.

A strike of public school teachers would be illegal under New York law tested to the highest state court and there found constitutional by the Court of Appeals. The teachers in New York City set a bad example in ethics and in standards of conduct among governmental employes to threaten such a strike.

LOS ANGELES, March 27 (UPI) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon filed nomination papers today as a Republican candidate for governor and took the opportunity to describe the Democratic incumbent, Gov. Edmund G. Brown, as a "wobbly, weak-kneed governor."

LEESVILLE, La., March 27 (AP) Pfc. Bernie Owen, who was outspoken in meetings at which Army reservists sought release from active duty, was sentenced today to six months at hard labor in the Fort Polk stockade.

TORONT0, March 27 Superior skating and a particularly strong job by Tim Horton gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 4-2 victory in the opener of a fourof-seven semi-final series in the Stanley Cup play-offs tonight.

Mrs. Wilson W. Phraner of Brooklyn has made know the engagement of her daughter, Miss Caroline Westervelt Phraner, to the Rev. Joseph T. Hourani. He is the son of Mrs. Tamir Hourani of Deir Mimas, Lebanon, and the late Mr. Hourani, an early preacher in the Evangelical Church of Lebanon.

MIAMI, Fla, March 27 (AP) Jack Britton, who won the world welterweight boxing title twice in a ring career that spanned twenty-six years, died here today. Mr. Britton, who was elected to the Boxing Hall of Fame in l958, was 74 years old.
The waterborne arrival today of ten new subway cars will be heralded with a fanfare usually reserved for new ocean liners and visiting dignitaries.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines abandoned its plans yesterday to run buses with strikebreakers. The decision came late in the day, after 2,000 Transport Workers Union pickets and 500 policemen mounted, afoot, in radio cars, uniformed and in plain clothes had spent many hours at or near the company's main garage at 605 West 132d Street.

RABAT. Morocco, March 27 The disclosure in Paris tonight of the names of the twelve men who will constitute the transitional executive body in Algeria was greeted here in Algerian nationalist circles with general approval and the un-official comment that the nationalists expected to work very closely with the new group.

The man who owns the candy store on the corner and other individual proprietors may be able to save money when they file their income tax returns this year because of a recent decision of a Federal court.
Cotton futures closed 15 cents a bate up to 15 cents off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading continued narrow and dull, aided by commission house support and a scarcity of contracts.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) Representative William C. Cramer, Republican of Florida, contended today that a community could finance a golf course with Federal money under President Kennedy's proposed $600,000,000 public improvements program.

WASHINGTON, March 27 The Administration will soon propose to Congress the creation of an Office of Science and Technology in the White House to strengthen the planning and direction of the nation's scientific program.

New York State has strict licensing laws for physicians and for eleven other professions allied to medicine, but it has no controls on clinical laboratory technicians who carry on tests for the medical profession.
IS the export of American television programs tarnish ing the image of the Western world?
LONDON, March 27 Prime Minister Macmillan expressed regret today that the West had not done more to overcome Soviet intransigence in the talks at Geneva on a nuclear test ban.

The Brooklyn Paramount Theatre, which for years combined film presentations with live shows starring crooners, swing bands and rock 'n' roll performers, will assume an academic air this September when Long Island University takes over the property.
State legislation to permit city employes, under certain conditions, to receive both a salary and a pension from the city was requested by the City Council yesterday.

Some Brooklyn hospitals were accused of neglect yesterday because they had failed to transmit records of critically ill patients transferred by ambulance to Kings County Hospital. Some of the patients had arrived dead.

The United States Supreme Court's decision in the Tennessee reapportionment case imposes a clear duty on the New York Legislature to reexamine the basis on which its members are elected. It is now on notice that if it fails to undertake the correction of existing evils voluntarily it may be ordered to do so.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation offered to the public yesterday $50,000,000 of 4.90 per cent sinking fund debentures due April 1, 1987. The company also released its 1961 annual report, which showed new highs in sales and revenues and net income.
"A strong pickup in business activity throughout the country," has caused the F.W. Dodge Corporation, construction news analyst, to revise upward its construction forecast for 1962.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 21 (AP) Niagara Falls and neighboring American and Canadian communities were jolted for about ten seconds today by what a seismologist said was "a tremor or a very weak earthquake."

ALBANY, March 27 The bill authorizing the Port of New York Authority to build a World Trade Center in Manhattan and to acquire and rehabilitate the Hudson Manhattan Railroad was signed today by Governor Rockefeller.
President Kennedy sent his personal greetings last night to all of the distinguished participants in a program celebrating World Theatre Day.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews presented awards yesterday to persons and organizations in the mass communications industry "for outstanding contributions to good human relations" in 1961. The field included newspapers, magazines, books, motion pictures, radio and television.
The Board of Governors of the American Stock Exchange unanimously elected Edwin D. Etherington as president at a special meeting yesterday.
HONG KONG, March 27 The National People's Congress, Communist China's Parliament, convened today in Peiping for the first time in two years.

In the Griffith-Paret fight, I scored the first five rounds for Emile Griffith. Paret has often been known to be a fighter who in the boxing jargon seems to 'come on.' Many times in some fights he looked like he was in trouble but through his courage and stamina, he would start to take the play away from the other fighter and come on to win the fight.

ALBANY, March 21 The Republican-controlled Legislature moved ahead today with its plan to create new Supreme Court judgeships in districts where the election of Republican judges is virtually certain.

Four singers wil1 make their City Center debuts during the center's Gilbert and Sullivan season, which opens on April 11. The singers are Shirley Chester and Eileen Schauler, sopranos; Marlene Kleinman mezzo-soprano, and David Smith, baritone.
A suit to rescind Walter Hoving's controlling stock interest in Tiffany Co. was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court.
PARIS, March 28 Prince Rainier III published a royal ordinance today proclaiming that Monaco's fifty-one-year-old Constitution was back in force.
GENEVA, March 28 The Communist and Western nations engaged in procedural maneuvers today as the seventeen nation disarmament conference tried to settle down to work.
ROME, March 28 Michelangelo's statue of the "Pieta" (Pity) will be moved from St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican and shown in the pavilion of the Holy See at the New York World's Fair of 1964-65.
Western Electric Company reported yesterday a slight drop in demand for its products and services in 1961. The annual report showed sales of $2,608,000,000, about 1.3 per cent below the 1960 level.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) After eight years of preparation, the Army is forming its first troop of helicopterborne cavalry.
Tallulah Bankhead and Nancy Carroll will co-star in a televiion comedy drama on the United States Steel Hour" on May 2 from 10 to 11 P.M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Do people join organizations to lose themselves or to find themselves? Both, according to a community leader who addressed the recent annual conference of the Child Study Association of America.

The State Liquor Authority said in its annual report yesterday that $84,185,475 was realized from taxes on alcoholic beverages, license and permit fees, bond claims and miscellaneous collections last year. The total was $905,058 more than in 1960.

BENCAT, Vietnam, March 28 Deep in a rubber plantation four miles north of here, South Vietnamese and Americans are engaged in an important test in isolating the rural population from the Viet Cong Communist guerrillas.
CHICAGO, March 28 The nation's near-term economic prospects are good, Allan Sproul told the American Bankers Association today.
WASHINGTON, March 28 Cultural achievements of the United States will be honored at a "Star-Spangled Ball" to be held Nov. 7 at the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria hotel in New York.

A public offering of 450,000 shares of common stock of United-Overton Corporation, licensed department store sales enterprise, is proposed in a registrailon statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 (AP) The Pan American Petroleum Corporation and Standard Oil of Indiana denied today Governments charges that they violated Federal antitrust statutes in Pan American's acquisition last October of certain assets of the Honolulu Oil Corporation.
An Issue of $30,000,000 of Belgian bonds was offered here yesterday by a syndicate headed jointly by Morgan Stanley Co. and Smith, Barney Co.

TULSA, Okla., March 28 (AP) Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company announced today a call of $24,000,000 worth of preferred stock, and approval of plans for a $75,000,000 refinancing plan which could lead to a call of additional preferred.
WASHINGTON, March 28 The Senate adopted by a voice vote today a resolution that would establish the home of Alexander Hamilton, first Secretary of the Treasury, as a national monument.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) An African diplomat said today he was leaving the United States "satisfied that progress is being made" against racial discrimination.
WASHINGTON, March 28 The Senate Democratic leadership called up the United Nations bond purchase plan today in confidence that it would be passed by a safe majority.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) A color television film on the defense system of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be made available on a nonprofit basis to every television station in the country, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 Representative Carl Vinson ordered today an investigation of newly formed unified defense agencies to determine whether Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara had gone "too far" in certain managerial changes.

TORONTO, March 28 Despite the New York Rangers' 4-2 defeat by Toronto last night, the Maple Leafs have considerable respect for the Blues in the best-of-seven semifinal Stanley Cup series between the clubs.
The City University of New York will receive only $1,000,000 of the $6,300,000 that it had requested in state aid to expand its graduate programs through the doctorate.

The job security drive by a ship engineers union against Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., took a new turn yesterday. The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association began picketing the company's pier at the foot of Twenty-ninth street, Brooklyn.
NEW DELHI, India, March 28 King Mahendra of Nepal will arrive here April 18 for a four or five-day state visit, the Indian Government announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) The music critic former President Harry S. Truman once threatened to beat up today accused Birgit Nilsson of a "shocking display of bad manners" and "spoiled pettiness."
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) Raymond F. Male, New Jersey Commissioner of Labor and Industry, has been charged with violating the Hatch Act, the Civil Service Commission announced today.

The Pepsi-Cola Company attained the highest sales and earnings in its history during 1961, the annual report of Herbert L. Barnet, president, disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, March 28 Mariborough House, once the resiidence of British princes, dowager queens and the Dukes of Marlborough, was given to the nation today. It will be used as a Commomwealth center.

The record-setting Port of New York Authority made news last year by failing to set a record. After years of unbroken increases in traffic volume on its bridges and tunnels the agency lost momentum. It attributed this to the severe winter of 1961.

The actions of the Republican-controlled State Legislature in creating new judgeships during the past few days has given the unfortunate impression that politics is the first consideration in the selection of judges.

Stockholders of the Plymouth Oil Company, at a meeting held yesterday in Pittsburgh, approved the sale of the company's assets to the Ohio Oil Company. Walter S. Hallinan, chairman, said stockholders would receive liquidating dividends of at least $35.50 a share.

The BMT Myrtle Avenue subway was out of service for an hour and six minutes yesterday afternoon while power was turned off so that firemen could stretch hoses across the tracks and put out a brush fire.

How is the lending business for banks these days? Yesterday the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported that short-term loans to business by New York City banks bore slightly higher interest rates in the first half of March than they did in the first fifteen days of December. The average rate was 4.73 per cent, compared with 4.67 per cent.

ANN SCHEIN, 22-year-old Washington pianist who made her debut here the summer before last at the Lewisohn Stadium, last night gave her first New York recital. It was at Carnegie Hall and, word of her talents having spread, there was a large audience.

Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday morning set into motion a bargemounted rock drill to start the construction of a new $5,000,000 pier for the Cunard Line.

New York City is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $108,000,000. The date of sale has been set for April 24. The city's last market borrowing was on Feb. 15, when $89,400,000 of bonds were sold at an interest cost of 3.2094 per cent.
ROME, March 28 Pope John XXIII received the Right Rev. Dr. Archibald C. Craig, Moderator of the Church of Scotland, in a thirty-eightminute audience today.

By a vote of 77 to 16 comfortably more than the two-thirds required for such action-the Senate has given its approval to a constitutional amendment banning the poll tax as a prerequisite for voting in national elections. A $14,000,000 contract for the construction of two giant ore carrers which Bethlehem Steel Company had hoped to build in the United States, has been awarded to a West German shipyard.
An hour-long four-alarm fire that swept through three stores and a business office at Grand Concourse and 188th Street, the Bronx, yesterday resulted in injuries to two firemen and a civilian.
HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, March 28 (UPI) Dutch marines and policemen fired on a band of armed Indonesian soldiers in Waigeo Island and forced the invaders to flee, it was announced today.

CALCUTTA, India, March 28 Political trouble is expected in the Himalayan kingdom of Sikkim, a protectorate of India. Three of its four political parties are agitating for reforms and threaten to boycott the coming general election.

Now is the time for all good men to draw upon those inner, untapped pools of reserve strength that will help get a hungering soul through until Sunday. Then it will be legal to lead trout down the primrose path that ends in a creel.

UTOPIAN literature is a futuristic stick the present uses to beat the past. Multitudes of authors have imagined strange and wonderful variants of what Don Marquis called the almost-perfect state. And they like to lecture their contemporaries and forebears pretty severely in these hotly cautionary tales.
Police detectives will mosey up to toy gun counters during the next few weeks and figuratively give the order to "Draw!"

WASHINGTON, March 28 The Council of the Organization of American States will meet tomorrow to approve a resolution urging fair trials for the rebels captured in last April's unsuccessful invasion of Cuba.
WASHINGTON, March 28 Associate Justice Charles Evans Whittaker of the Supreme Court is recovering from physical exhaustion brought on by the volume and pressure of the court's work.

PARIS, March 28 Christian Fouchet, who as High Commissioner will exercise French sovereignty in Algeria during the transitional period leading to independence, has been described as "more Gaullist than de Gaulle."

A protest about religious observances held recently aboard commuter trains brought this reaction yesterday from the Long Island Rail Road: "Any and all requests from any and all denominations" will be honored when details can be worked out.

BERLIN, March 28 Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, President Kennedy's military adviser, reasserted today the West's determination to keep Berlin's vital air corridors to West Germany's open despite Soviet harassing tactics.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28 The Security Council heard bitter charges by Syria and Israel today that both had committed systematic aggression.

CHICAGO, March 28--Sears, Roebuck Co. reached its seventh consecutive annual sales record in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. Its annual report also showed a new high in profits. Charles H. Kellstadt, chairman of the board, said the company was headed for new peaks in both categories this year.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) The Republican leadership in Congress accused the Kennedy Administration today of wasting $150,000,000 in the farm program. The Republicans said that sum had been paid for acreage supposedly taken out of corn production.

The sociologists tell us that regional differences in the United States are diminishing, and this may well be true. But marketing men continue to be puzzled by the sharply contrasting consumption patterns that persist in different regions and in different cities.
One hundred seventy-six candidates for the Police Department collectively lifted four tons of barbells and chinned themselves at least 530 times yesterday.
LIVERRPOOL, England, March 28 (Reuters) A six-day-old strike of Liverpool dockworkers continued to spread today, bringing the total of men off the job to more than 10,000, with eighty ships idle.
ROBERT BENCHLEY, the late humorist, once re marked that there are two ways of traveling first class or with children.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 28 A four-day test of "theatrevision" a marriage between Broadway and closed circuit television started here tonight.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 28 Industrial workers demonstrating for higher cost-of-living allowances rioted today in Ramat Gan, a suburb of Tel Aviv.

President Kennedy's extraordinary announcement yesterday of his decision to postpone for sixty days application of the new higher tariffs an carpets and glass was accompanied by unofficial explanations that he wished to ease hardships on foreign producers making goods already ordered. No doubt this is part of the story, but

Commodities: Potato Futures Are Weaker Trading in potato and sugar futures contracts continued to dominate activity in the New York commodity markets yesterday. Prices of other commodities moved narrowly in light trading.
HONG KONG, March 28 The Chinese Communist National People's Congress met again today in complete secrecy, according to reports received here from Peiping.
NEW ORLEANS, March 28 UPI) A Federal judge ordered two Negroes admitted to white Tulane University today.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 28 (AP) Coup d'etat, owned and trained by Leslie Lear, scored a front-running victory today in the $16,625 Suwanee River Handicap at Gulfstream Park.
An invitation to a professional anti-Communist to discuss Marxist ideology at their trade convention at Miami Beach has brought the Toiletry Merchandisers' Association to a fast political boil.
A leader of the American Council for Judaism assailed Israel and the Zionist movement last night for what he termed "exploitation" of the Eichmann trial judgment.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 28-The national mixed pair championship in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament was won here yesterday by Grant Marsee arid Mrs. Jessie D. Cook of Detroit.

WASHINGTON, March 28 House Republicans lost the first skirmish today in their battle to revamp the Administration's big tax-revision bill. They failed to open it up for separate votes on three major amendments.

MONTREAL, March 28 (Canadian Press) The board of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada today approved a prospectus offering 149,176 new shares of the company's common stock to be used to acquire the 522,118 shares of common stock of the Avalon Telephone Company of St. John's. Nfld.

Highroad Productions, Inc., producer of the motion pictures, "Guns of Navarone" and "The Bridge Over the River Kwai," has leased 7,000 square feet in the Corning Glass Building, 717 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-sixth Street. The Joel E. Mason Company was the broker, Harry N. Masson, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., was the agent for the owner of the building.
WASHINGTON, March 28The State Department announced today that J. Robert Schaetzel, a career officer, world be made a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Atlantic Affairs.

The nation's supply of gasoline declined 1,321,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. This was the first weekly drop in gasoline supplies this year. It reflected a decline is refinery operations and the seasonal increase in demand.
WASHINGTON, March 28 The Administration's effort to prevent a sharp drop in dairy price supports was killed today by the Senate Agriculture Committee. The vote was 11 to 5

The New York City Opera Company revived Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Consul" at the City Center last night. In doing so, it delivered an implied but pertinent rebuke to a great deal of the large-scale operatic compositions that have gone on in the twelve years since this work was new.
The completion of the new Vivian Beaumont Theatre, one of the units in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, has been delayed.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 Dr. Israel I. Blumenfeld, Jewish leader here since 1952 and the inspiration for "Mila 18," a best-selling novel about the Warsaw ghetto, died last night in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 48 years old.
Directors of the American Enka Corporation declared yesterday a 40-cent quarterly divident, payable to common stockholders on April 19.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 John Cassavetes said today that his project for directing a series of low-budget, high-quality movies for Paramount has been shelved.

BUENOS AIRES, Thursday, March 29 Argentina's War Ministry announced early today that it had taken command of the Government and that President Jos Maria Guido of the Senate was replacing Dr. Arturo Frondizi as chief of state.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 "The law of averages owes me plenty," said. Charlie Neal. He bit off the words with an intensity that is not normal for him because his placid temperament is not usually marked by flare-ups or undue emphasis.
LONDON, March 28 Britain's international balance of payments position showed a substantial improvement last year.

The appointment of Marvin Kratter as chairman of the 1962 Joint Defense Appeal campaign was announced yesterday. He is chairman and president of the Kratter Corporation, real estate investment company.

Car Float 6051 of the ErieLackawanna Railroad made history yesterday. In a trip from Hoboken, N.J., to Hunts Point, the Bronx, it received a water salute from four fireboats and a greeting from the liner Queen Elizabeth.
PHILADELPHIA, March 28 The Delaware River Basin Commission today adopted a plan for the first phase of a multi purpose development of the basin's water resources.
EDINBURG, Tex., March 28 (UPI) The Rev. John B. Feit, a Roman Catholic priest charged with attempted rape, pleaded no defense today to a lesser charge and was fined $500.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines dropped its plans for court action yesterday to keep the city from operating six bus routes for which the company holds perpetual charters.
A 16-year-old New Yorker was named the national scholarship winner of the Girls Clubs of America last night.
The fitting of a steel keystone into an arch rib yesterday brought the Alexander Hamilton Bride over the Harlem River a step nearer to completion.
PARIS, March 28 Thirteen Bombs exploded in Paris tonight, apparently marking a new offensive by extremist opponents of the peace settlement for Algeria. Two women were slightly injured.

Richard M. Nixon has added a footnote to the second printing of his book, "Six Crises," further explaining his charge that President Kennedy was told during the 1960 campaign of United States aid being given a planned Cuban invasion.
David L. Luke 3d was elected president of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company yesterday, succeeding his father, David L. Luke, who was named chairman and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved legislation today to grant President Kennedy's request for $63,750,000 to put 9,700 volunteers in the Peace Corps by the fall of 1963.
CAIRO, March 28 The immediate reaction here to the Syrian coup was restrained. But the mood of the capital today reflected deep satisfaction with the developments in Damascus.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 28 A plan for the integration of all Montclair junior high school pupils has been submitted to the Board of Education by s citizens' committee created by the board.
WASHINGTON, March 28Erwin N. Griswold, dean of the Harvard Law School, told Congress today that it had the constitutional power and the duty to curb discriminatory literacy tests for voting.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) Twenty-seven physicians formed a voluntary committee today to rally doctors behind President Kennedy's plan, for health care for the aged under Social Security.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 Robert Moore, deputy director of the Federal Mediation Service, abandoned efforts today to bring about agreement between West Coast shipowners and three unlicensed offshore affiliates of the Seafarers International Union.

Under Secretary of the Treasury Robert V. Roosa said yesterday that several European countries had agreed to buy more than $1,000,000,000 worth of military equipment and services in the United States.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 28 (Reuters) The International Olympic Committee today expressed regret at the exclusion of East German teams from recent international competition. Olympic Games will be held only in cities guaranteeing free access for all recognized competitors, the committee added.

WASHINGTON, March 28 W. Averell Harriman, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affair, said today he was convinced that sooner or later a coalition Government would be formed in Laos. He just returned from a trip to the Far East.
WASHINGTON, March 28 President Kennedy told Congress today that the United States had made a start toward balancing its international payments, but that the problem remained urgent.

The Bay Shore Handicap, the one-mile event for 3-year-olds that proved so popular with horsemen that it had to be run in two divisions at Aqueduct yesterday, had a pair of thrilling finishes. The first half was won by James W. Rodgers' Duc d'Or by a neck and the second half was taken by the Tartan Stable's Western Warrior by a nose.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 28 Brig. Gen. Robert Reese Neyland, under whose leadership the University of Tennessee became a ranking football power, died today in New Orleans. He was 70 years old.

ALBANY, March 29--The State Court of Appeals unanimously dismissed an appeal by the international Longshoremen's Association today contesting the constitutionality of a section of the Waterfront Commission Act.
ALBANY, March 29--Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had ordered a staff study of legislative reapportionment in the light of this week's United States Supreme Court decision.

The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses. It is important to note that spring skiing conditions change quickly.
JACKSON. Miss., March 29 (UPI)--Hinds County Judge Russell Moore dismissed breach of peace charges today against Mark Lane, Manhattan Assemblyman, and Percy Sutton, New York N. A. A. C. P. official.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth announced today that he had ordered elimination of a section in a fitness report that would rate officerwife teams.
BURLINGTON, Vt., March 29 (UPI)--Chancery Court Judge Harold C. Sylvester or dered the Vermont Legislature today to reapportion the State Senate.
The picketing of two Isbrandtsen freighters by ship engineers seeking guarantees of jobs now Within their jurisdiction went into its second day yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--President Kennedy announced today that President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy of Ecuador would come to the United States in July on a state visit. The Ecuadoran is scheduled to reach Washington July 24 to confer with Mr. Kennedy, Secretary of State Dean Rusk and other high officials.

BUENOS AIRES, Friday, March 30 (AP)--The communique issued by the military leaders early today said that Senator Guido, "who took the constitutional oath yesterday, after consultations with the commanders in chiefs of the armed forces, in conformity with them resolved to assume formally the post in a public ceremony at noon today."
The executive committee of the Greenwich Village Association made public yesterday its proposals for the redevelopment of Washington Square Park.
CAIRO, March 29--Mustafa and Ali Amin were restored today to prominence in the Cairo publishing world.

A self-styled financial wizard described as "fantastically unlucky in the stock market" was indicted here yesterday on charges at stealing $266,000 from twenty victims. Among the victims were his father and mother-in-law.

Official reports on Benny (Kid) Paret yesterday were substantially the same as those issued earlier this week: The injured Cuban boxer still was in a "moderate coma" at Roosevelt Hospital and his condition was described as "critical."

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil. March 29 (UPI) Gov. Leonel Brizola of Rio Grande do Sul State plans to seize the American-owned, $5,000,000 Rio Grandense Light and Power Corporation as soon as legal formalities can be completed, it was announced today.

CHICAGO. March 29--Warren Wright, who served two terms as Treasurer of Illinois, died of a heart attack today at his home in suburban Park Ridge. He was 69 years old. Mr. Wright ran for office in Illinois ten times as a Republican, then supported Otto Kerner, a Democrat, in his successful campaign for Governor in 1960.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP)-- The Detroit Pistons staved off elimination in the National Basketball Association's Western Division final playsoff tonight with a 118-117 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Senator Clifford F. Case proposed today the coordination of mass transportation and highway systems in urban areas. To accomplish this, the New Jersey Republican urged the local planning be accelerated.

The prospective steel labor agreement removes a dark cloud over the economy. The ability of the steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America to reach a basic accord more than three months before the contract deadline is made doubly welcome by memories of the 116day strike which paralyzed the industry three years ago and contributed greatly to the 1960-61 recession.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Kennedy sought today to discourage any belief that the United States would support the Chinese Nationalist Government in an effort to put forces on the Communist mainland.
The Board of Estimate wrestled in executive session last night with the problem of balancing the city's 1962-63 expense budget without imposing new special taxes.

WASHINGTON March 29 (AP)--A four-stage scout rocket blazed away from Wallops Island, Va., today carrying a ninety-pound payload designed to probe 4,000 miles into space and transmit information about the ionosphere.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Kennedy proposed today the creation of an Office of Science and Technology in the White House. He said the move would strengthen direction of the nation's expanding scientific efforts.
ALBANY, March 29--Legislation making the first major changes in the court structure of the state in more than a century neared enactment tonight.
ALGIERS, March 29--The president and six members of the provisional executive council that will rule Algeria during the transition period leading to independence arrived on Algerian soil today.
How much, if at all, will astronauts' flying skills tend to deteriorate during a seven-day round-trip to the moon?
HAVANA, March 29--Approximately 2,000 people a week are leaving Cuba, it was estimated here today.

A team of Rockefeller Institute scientists has reported the first isolation from mammalian cells of a chemical messenger that is believed to play a vital role in the process by which inheritance is determined.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29--The Committee of Seventeen on Colonialism accepted today an invitation to discuss British territories with Government officials in London.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--The United States Public Health Service made public today its recommendations on use of polio vaccines-- both the needle-injection and take-by-mouth types--during 1962.
In a move that broke with precedent. Mayor Wagner appointed J. Raymond Jones yesterday as a political secretary through whom he will deal with the Democratic party organizations of the city.

WHITE PLAINS, March 29 --Agencies representing Westchester business and labor have endorsed the plan to unify the county's sixteen cummunity funds and chests as a Westchester Fund, the Westchester Council of Social Agencies announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 Mrs. John F. Kennedy arrived home tonight from her journey abroad. The President was at National Airport to meet her when the Caroline, the family's plane, landed at 7:28 P.M. As soon as... the steps of the aircraft were lowered, the President entered the plane and greeted her.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The railroad and trucking industries reported yesterday that freight loadings last week continued to exceed 1961 levels.
Annual Dinner Dance at Pierre April 25 to Aid Hospital for Animals The fourteenth annual Spring Frolic of the Humane Society of New York will be held on April 25 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage in Monterey, Calif., last Saturday of Miss Elizabeth Griffith Manning Coale, daughter of Mrs. Griffith Bailey Coale of New York and Stonington, Conn., and the late Mr. Coale, to Richard Fenner Anderson Jr. of Winston-Salem, N. C. His paren's are Mr. and Mrs. Anderson of Burlington, N. C.

A public offering of 200,000 shares of common stock of American Biltrite Rubber Company, Inc., is proposed in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Polo Grounds, haunted by the ghosts of Giants these past four years, is now being preened for a cast of living baseball players. They are called the Mets. They hope to become a match for the ghosts.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Every President since General Washington has received a lot of free advice about how to pick a judge for the Supreme Court of the United States, and now it is President Kennedy's turn.
CHICAGO, March 29--Herschel D. Newsom, master of the National Grange, challenged today the Government's ban on sale of food to Communist China.
BUENOS AIRES, Friday, March 30--Leaders of the Argentine armed forces announced early today that they had agreed to let Jose Maria Guido, head of the Senate, be inducted as President at noon.

Buses rolled yesterday as of old on most of the routes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines --except for two differences. One was that they were under the control of the Transit Authority which is operating them after city condemnation.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 29 (AP)--Nathaniel Dyke Jr., a lumberman and business executive, died yesterday at the age of 70.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 29-- Mrs. Ryan's lawyer said today that the former priest's offer of support for his children and for disposition of the Fort Salonga property was unacceptable.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)--Two Administration witnesses defended President Kennedy's communications satellite system bill today against advocates of a Government ownership plan.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 29 --Only two teams re mained undefeated in the contest for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup as the sixth round of play began in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here tonight.
The first of 10,000 subway and bus posters urging the public to accept "free life inrules for fire prevention was placed yesterday in a Times Square-Grand Central shuttle train.
David Wayne and John Forsythe, who starred on Broadway in "The Teahouse of the August Moon," will re-create their stage roles in a television adaptation of John Patrick's comedy.
Alfred E. Perlman, the president of the New York Central Railroad, submitted himself yesterday to lampooning by the Circus Saints and Sinners, a men's club devoted to charity and raillery.

THERE seems little doubt that this year will mark a high point for recreational camping in this country. Each year the pastime has been growing by leaps and bounds. The rucksack hasn't quite replaced the putter as a status symbol, but there is every hope for the future.

The Curtis Publishing Company, which marked its seventieth birthday last year, also registered its first deficit--a net loss of $4,193,585 for 1961. For the year before the company had a net income of $1,634,566.
A twenty-eight-minute color film of the 1961 Maccabiah Games was shown for the first time yesterday by the United States Committee for Sports in Israel, Inc.
Wall Street continues to pour more and more money into its drive to draw women into the stock market.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Kennedy said today that efforts to reach an agreement to ban nuclear testing seemed to have reached "a real impasse" as a result of Soviet refusal to accept international controls and inspection.
Stanley Yancovitz, a 19year-old junior from Massapequa, L.I., was named captain of Columbia's 1962-63 varsity wrestling squad yesterday.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sec tor), March 29--Eliahu Elath, former Israeli Ambassador to the United States, was elected president of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem today.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Justice Charles Evans Whittaker retired from the Supreme Court today on his doctors' advice.

Comment by leading Broadway figures yesterday concerning the potential value of transmitting shows on closedcircuit television ranged from optimism to skepticism. Their views were expressed after the first of five transmissions of "Gideon" on Wednesday night from the Plymouth Theatre here to the Auditorium Theatre in Rochester, N.Y.

The Board of Education last night awarded the first major school construction contracts here since the building program was stopped last spring by the investigation of irregularities and inefficiency.
Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company, at a special meeting in Rochester yesterday elected Dr. Albert K. Chapman as chairman. He succeeds the late Thomas J. Hargrave.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)--The Labor Department today issued minimum wage rates for Mexican migrant farm laborers for twenty-two states. The rates range from 60 cents to $1 an hour.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP)-- Automotive News reported today that United States auto makers would build 138,742 cars this week, a gain of 36.4 per cent over last year's similar week, but down 1.3 per cent from last week's 140,559. In the 1961 week, production totaled 101,698 units.
Jennie's Joy of the Mac Sweetie Stable and George Zauderer's Kisco Kid fought it out to the finish line and beyond in the featured six-furlong race at Aqueduct yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority is planning to sell this year two issues of long-term bonds, each aggregating $25,000,000. Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the agency, said yesterday.
LONDON, March 29--Communist China made a large sum of money through sales of silver on the London bullion market and on the Continent last year.

IN the garment industry, there is perhaps no greater gulf than that which separates the manufacturer who makes the clothes and the sales person who sells them. Although the geographical distance is often only the two blocks between Seventh Avenue and Fifth Avenue, the twain rarely meet. When they do, the two groups often eye each other suspiciously.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29--The Maharaja of Jaipur, Sir Sawai Man Singh Bahaldur. was elected to the Rajya Sabha, or upper house of the Indian parliament, today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 29--The Supreme Court of Israel rejected today a request by Adolf Eichmann's defense counsel. Dr. Robert Servatius, for permission to present new evidence and witnesses.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The recent Administration action increasing tariff rates on carpets and sheet glass was defended vigorously today by President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Marshall Sylvester Carter, 52-hear-old career Army man, won quick and unanimous approval of the Senate Armed services Committee today to be deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
PARIS, March 28 (Reuters) --The United States plans to launch twelve satellites in connection with the International Quiet Sun Year in 1964-65, a United States scientist said today.

WASHINGTON, March 29--If the currently hopeful prospect is realized of a two-year contract between the steel industry and its unions excluding inflationary wage rises for a year, this will establish the ...
Kenneth Collins, for many years a leading figure in New York City advertising and newspaper work, died yesterday at his home in Almonte, Ont., after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., displayed yesterday its first entry in the dry office photocopy equipment market.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 (UPI)--Gov. Edmund G. Brown said tonight that former Vice President Richard M. Nixon had been "almost entirely irresponsible--and frequently contemptuous of the truth-- in his attacks on the national Administration."
An eight-year psychiatric study of a midtown Manhattan area has concluded that four out of five of its residents suffer from mental disturbances ranging from mild to severe.
A lease agreement covering the largest block of space ever rented in an office building in the city was signed yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 29--Frederick Stanley Clulow, a retired vice president of the Shell Oil Company, died here last night at his home at Brookside Park after a long illness. His age was 65. He also maintained residences at Booth Bay Harbor, Me., and Palm Beach, Fla.
The first live television broadcasts across the Atlantic, serving viewers from Los Angeles to Moscow, are being planned for early summer.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted a $13,000,000,000 authorization bill today for ships, aircraft and missiles in the Administration's military spending program.
ALBANY, March 29--Governor Rockefeller said today he would have an announcement on the Benny (Kid) Paret boxing inquiry "in the next day or so."
HAVANA, March 29--The Castro Government put 1,182 prisoners on trial today behind closed doors at Principe Prison, in Havana's suburbs.
ALBANY, March 29--The Legislature worked its way steadily through piles of pending bills today, pointing toward adjournment of the 1962 session tomorrow.
The Transport Workers Union announced plans yesterday to picket American Airlines operations in fifty-six cities today in its contract dispute with the airline.

Advances in cocoa futures, prices, unusually active trading in hides and continued strong volume in potato contracts were the highlights of an otherwise lackluster day on New York commodity markets.
SMITHTOWN, L.I., March 29--Angry residents of the Village of the Branch were joined with others today in forcing a hearing on a road-widening project to move to more spacious quarters.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--President Kennedy said today that both the Soviet Union and the West had handled the touchy Berlin dispute "with a good deal of care." He voiced hope for "a very happy solution" if this kept up. [Question 7, page 12.]

ANY number of interesting menus can be planned from the inviting variety of fresh foods offered by groceries here now. Meat supplies are particularly encouraging. Shoppers may choose from a good selection of veal, lamb, beef and poultry.

MONTREAL, March 29 (UPI) --The Montreal Canadiens scored three third-period goals in three minutes and defeated the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 4--3. The victory gave the Canadiens a 2-0 lead in their four-of-seven Stanley Cup semifinal playoff.
Construction in March was about 1 per cent below the level of the 1961 month, if price rises are considered, the Department of Commerce announced yesterday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Robert F. Kennedy, Attorney General, told Senators today he had strong evidence that major public officials in communities in the South, East and West "are on the payroll of big-time gamblers."

ALBANY, March 29--The Court of Appeals upheld today the designation of Dr. George Baehr by the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York as its arbitrator in a dispute with several New York City medical groups.

BRUSSELS, March 29--Douglas MacArthur 2d United States Ambassador to Belgium, has returned to the United States at a moment when officials and newspapers here are criticizing his country's decision to raise tariffs on carpets and glass.
The annual dinner dance in behalf of the Karen Horney Clinic will take place April 7 at the Plaza.
LONDON, March 29--Britain will consult the Commonwealth Prime Ministers before deciding whether to enter the Common Market.

President Frondizi has lost his extraordinary fight to preserve both his own post and, what was infinitely more important, constitutionality in Argentina. Nothing can now disguise the fact that there has been a military coup d'etat.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 29 --Murray Rose of Southern California successfully defended his 1,500-meter free-style title today as the thirty-ninth annual National Collegiate swimming championships opened in Ohio State's pool.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 29--Maj. Gen. Achmad Jani. chief Indonesian military planner for a possible invasion of Netherlands New Guinea, said today that increased patrolling by both the Netherlands and Indonesia in border areas of the disputed territory "has greatly increased possibility of armed clashes."

A SHORT. box-shaped man with a fringe of silver hair sat behind a long dining table in a reception room at the Nippon Club on a recent afternoon. His coal-colored eyes peered through horn-rimmed glasses at two pussy willow branches and a pair of dead twigs.

PECOS, Tex., March 29 (UPI)--Federal Bureau of Investigation agents tonight arrested Billie Sol Estes, millionaire Pecos rancher and business man, and accused him of conspiracy involving forged mortgages.

Trans World Airlines. Inc., reported yesterday that it had a net loss of $38,713,000 last year after special charges of $23,968,000 from sales and write-downs of obsolete piston aircraft and related equipment.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The House of Representatives gave President Kennedy a major legislative victory today by approving his tax-revision program, 219 to 196.

MIAMI, March 29 (UPI)-- Federal narcotics agents announced today the seizure of a half million dollars worth of cocaine, believed smuggled from Cuba, and the arrest of five persons. Included in the haul was four and one-half pounds of cocaine, said to have a value on the retail market equal to $500,000.
A $35,000,000 issue of Lone Star Gas Company debentures was offered yesterday and oversubscribed.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)--President Kennedy apparently disposed today of any doubts that he planned to seek a second term in 1964.

LONDON, March 29 (AP)-- Prime Minister Macmillan was reported tonight to have told Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor that Britain was unable to take on a larger share of North Atlantic Treaty Organization responsibilities because of her overseas commitments.

The Original Piano Quartet, which began its career in 1941 as a radio ensemble of some musical pretensions, gave its first local concert since 1949 in Town Hall last night. Three of the performers, Adam Garner. Edward Edson and Frank Mittler, are charter members: William Gunther joined the group in 1957.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Council of the Organization of American States voted today to express a "firm hope" that the rebel prisoners in Cuba would have every legal guarantee at their trial.
LONDON, March 29 (UPI)-- The British Broadcasting Corporation took steps today to curtail violence on its television programs.

BONN, Germany, March 29--The United States Army has suspended the activities of its mission with the Soviet Army in East Germany because the Russians have failed to guarantee the safety of its members.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The balance of payments has improved in the first quarter of the year but the outflow of gold has become increasingly worse.
Tape recordings to instruct physicians and nurses will be distributed this year in Peru by Project Hope, Dr. Howard A. Rusk said last night.

A week later he had found it was not only "difficult" but impossible.
