VERO BEACH. Fla., March 29--Even a club as smooth as the world champion Yankees can come down with a crash.

Ignoring one of the prize rings's respected maxims, Dick Tiger of Nigeria has punched his way to the No. 1 position in the pecking order of middleweight title contenders. He usually wins fights by adopting the style and tactics of his opponents.
MELBOURNE, March 29-- Two major rocket firings were made successfully at Woomera testing range tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Following is the roll-call vote by which the House today refused to strike two key provisions from President Kennedy's tax bill:
PITTSBURGH, March 29-- President Kennedy warmly praised the steel industry and union today for "their desire to meet their responsibilities to the country here and abroad."
LONDON, March 29--Most sections of the stock market were firmer today following the news of Britain's improved balance of payments position.

DAMASCUS, March 29 (AP) --The Trade unions said today that the military coup was "a salvation from reactionaries and imperialists." Newspapers unanimously supported the takeover from President el Kudsi, who advanced an anti-nationalization program.

Production of lumber in the nation totaled 234,753,000 board feet in the week ended Saturday. according to reports received from regional associations. This compared with 234,862,000 board feet in the preceding week and 212,054,000 board feet in the same week a year ago.
PERHAPS Shakespeare has the last word when he makes Hamlet speak to Polonius about "the abstracts and brief chronicles of the time" that "pleased not the million; t'was caviare to the general."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29--The United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space ended its session today in the same harmonious spirit that prevailed when it started work ten days ago.

The deadlock in Laos continues despite a visit to Vientiane from the United States Assistant Secretary of State for the Far East. Mr. Harriman not only spoke sternly last week in an effort to get Vientiane Government leaders to enter a coalition with the neutralist and Communist-led Laotian factions.
The State Social Welfare Department charged yesterday that the City of Newburgh had denied relief arbitrarily to some applicants and had used various pressures to keep needy persons off relief rolls.
FREEPORT, L. I., March 29 --A bookstore closely allied with the John Birch Society has been opened in the heart of the business district here.
RABAT, Morocco, March 25 --The American Friends Service Committee, a Quaker agency, has been unofficially representing the United States among the Algerian refugees here for nearly three years.
A four-hour brush fire swept a large, wooded area in the Rossville section of Staten Island yesterday. Near-by homeowners brought out garden hoses to help 250 firemen.

WASHINGTON, March, 29 (AP)--George Meany, presi dent of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today a depression this fall "is not outside the realm of possibility." If it comes, he said "it will start with 5,000,000 unemployed and go on up."
WHITE PLAINS, March 29 The scarcity of housemaids who will work long hours for moderate pay has resulted in the mushrooming of a new agency that imports young women from South America.
Edwin D. Etherington, president-elect of the American Stock Exchange, said yesterday that the exchange's most important immediate task was to overhaul its administrative setup.
State Controller Arthur Levitt called yesterday for an easing of conflict-of-interest regulations where they affect nonsalaried local officials.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 29 --Fordham Prep and All Hallows, New York City's entries in the twenty-fifth annual Eastern States Catholic invitation basketball tournament, bowed out of the championship bracket today.
Otto Lowell Miller, a catcher with the Brooklyn Dodgers from 1910 to 1923, fell or jumped to his death yesterday from a fourth-floor window at the Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital.
GENEVA, March 29--The departure of big-power foreign ministers from the disarmament conference was completed today when Andrei A. Gromyko returned to the Soviet Union.
Two leading Swiss cabaret entertainers have come to town with a delightful repertoire that punches holes in the foibles of people and places in Europe.

NO one is less astonished than Joseph Papp by the new outdoor theatre that is rising in one of the loveliest corners of Central Park. He regards it as a logical part of his New York Shakespeare Festival.
TRENTON, March 29--Gov. Richard J. Hughes today signed a package of bills that will provide $12,000,000 for the rehabilitation of shore areas severely damaged in the storm of March 6 and 7.

Drugs and tobaccos were the two strong groups on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Steels continued to be the center of conversation but not of trading interest. Prices of steel shares moved little and over-all volume dropped again.

Alice Esty has made an annual event of giving a recital in which she sings works that she has commissioned. In the latest such program, presented last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, the soprano gave the first performance of Ben Weber's
The Board of Education warned teachers last night that the strike scheduled by their union for April 10 was illegal and urged them to consider the penalties provided by law.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 (AP)--A former priest offered today to pay $100 a month for the support of his three daughters after his wife returns religious chalices and vestments.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 29 --The Syrian high command, which seized control of the country yesterday, arrested more than 100 prominent persons, including the former President and Premier and all but one member of the Cabinet.

HOLLYWOOD. Calif., March 29--A new approach to the fight against cancer will be initiated on television Sunday night during the one-hours how that will feature some of the nation's most famous performers.
AN outmoded, often dowdy highway was beautifully resurfaced with history and poetry last night for a smooth and fascinating trip on Channel 4.
Firmness prevailed throughout the high-grade bond market yesterday in a trading session of moderate activity.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- The United States watched Argentine developments carefully today. While Administration officials want to avoid any "permanent alienation" of Argentina, they nevertheless do not wish to appear to endorse the military coup that ousted Arturo Frondizi from the presidency.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- United States authorities have concluded that the rift between the Soviet Union and Communist China will become deeper than it is now and be of long duration.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP)-- The Detroit Lions moved today to bolster their weak offense by acquiring Milt Plum, the National Football League's top passer the last two years, in a three-for-three trade with the Cleveland Browns.

TORONTO. March 29--The New York Rangers didn't do enough forechecking and were beaten to the puck too often tonight as they lost their second straight Stanley Cup play-off game to the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2--1.

NEW BRUNSWICK N.J., March 29--A Flemington girl's study of the effect of medication on dreams and a Gillette boy's exhibit of anti-corrosive coatings won top prizes today at the ninth annual Central New Jersey Science Fair.
Pleasure boatmen have many supporters in the legislature at Albany. They have some also in the Congress at Washington.

TOKYO, Friday, March 30 (AP)--Japan's Socialist party agrily boycotted today all proceedings of the Diet (Parliament) in protest against a Government bill to repay $490,000,000 in United States post-war aid.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Representative Brent Spence, Democrat of Kentucky, said today that he would not run for re-election because he was physically "unable to make the kind of campaign I would like to make."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 29-- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek reaffirmed today his belief that his 600,000-man army must invade the Chinese mainland as soon as possible to overthrow the Peiping regime. He said this would save the world from cer tain disaster.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 29 --In days gone by, the principal mode of transportation was the horse.

PARIS, March 29--Irving Brown, international representative of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, was appointed today as representative of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions at the United Nations.
SPARTA, Wis., March 29 (UPI)--Maj. Donald K. Slayton said today that "ignorance of the problem and resulting panic" had played a part in his removal as the nation's next orbital pilot.
Jack Paar did his final late show for the National Broadcasting Company last night after a run of almost five years.
ALBANY, March 29--A deluge of protests from bird lovers resulted today in the killing of a bill that would have eliminated the great horned owl from the list of protected birds.

ALTHOUGH the terms sound mutually exclusive, there are foods that are nutritious, delicious and inexpensive. High on any such list must come the chicken liver, a food that would surely by considered a great delicacy were it not so abundant in this chicken-plentiful world.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined by $47,000,000 to a level of $86000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that a $5,000,000 contract would be awarded to the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I., for the construction of two experimental re-entry spacecraft.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- State legislatures were urged by President Kennedy today to correct inequalities in voters' representation in line with last Monday's decision by the Supreme Court on apportionment.

The six-story elevator apartment building at 147-15 Northern Boulevard in Flushing. Queens, has been sold by the Milsonat Corporation to an investing client of Mervin Stenzler, lawyer. It is on a plot 100 by 225 feet and contains ninetyfive apartments. The sales was negotiated by Milton H. Tittlebaum of the William K. Langfan Company, broker, for cash over mortgages of $596,000.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29--When grandfather was a boy, there was a pitcher named Nick Altrock. He was a screwball left-hander with many unusual characteristics. Some of them were so zany that he eventually became a baseball clown, teaming for a while with the quite funny Al Schacht.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29--Gov. William F. Quinn of Hawaii flew here today to appeal to West Coast ship owners and striking unlicensed seamen to find a way to preserve the flow of essential goods to the fiftieth state.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29 --Premier Tancredo Neves expressed the hope today that Brazil could continue to count on its ties with Argentina.
WORTHING, England, March 29--A group of British nurserymen will leave Sunday for West Germany to seek a wider market for the chrysanthemums, carnations and other produce they grow in hothouses.
Caddies are vanishing in Scotland because of high employment in other fields. As a result, more and more golfers are using fewer clubs and carrying their own bags as they play the game.

Albany, March 29--Governor Rockefeller and State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. said today that a new $l,000,000 state contribution to the City University should get its graduate education program off to a flying start.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--The Senate sidestepped today a dispute over Republican charges of an attempt to turn civil servants into propagandists for the New Frontier and passed a money bill without action on the complaint.

ORAN, Algeria, March 29--More than 3,000 citizens of Oran crowded silently into the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart this morning to... attend a funeral service for the European victims of fighting earlier this week in Oran and Algiers.

Many persons who owe New York State income taxes moved in or out of the state during 1961. Now that New York State permits nonresidents to itemize deductions, there is some question in the minds of those who moved whether they need to file both a resident and a nonresident return as was the case in the past.

ALEXANDRIA, La., March 29 (AP)--Roman Catholic schools in northern and central Louisiana will not be desegregated, a spokesman for the Most Rev. Charles P. Greco, Bishop of the Alexandria Diocese, said today.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Following is the text of a statement today by President Kennedy on nuclear test inspection as released by the White House:

THE READER: In your new novel of the absurd, M. Ayme, there was one sentence in particular that had a mar velous mixture of sex and politics. The one that went: "Off with the petticoats and sleeping around right, left and center are all right when father's there to foot the bill." That struck me as a typical French novelist's ...

THE nickel that was intended to make a psychological dif ference between a price of $19.95 and $20 is disappearing. Up and down Fifth Avenue the large stores are gradually rounding out their prices to an even dollar.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) --A spring storm brought snow to northeast North Dakota today and a mixture of snow and rain to Iowa and Nebraska. Flood dangers increased in scattered sections of Iowa.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, March 29 (UPI)--Gov. Leonel Brizola of Rio Grande do Sul State plans to seize the American-owned $5,000,000 Rio Grandense Light and Power Corporation as soon as legal formalities can be completed, it was announced today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--The Braves, the team with the most anemic record in spring training, were made to look good by the Mets today.
The Department of Licenses has taken over from the Police Department the licensing and fingerprinting of entertainers and employes in public dance halls, cabarets and coffeehouses.

Antonietta Stella, the Italian soprano who sang leading roles at the Metropolitan from 1956 to 1960, will not be allowed to sing in this country for a year. The American Guild of Musical Artists has found Miss Stella guilty of breach of contract with the Met, and has imposed a year's suspension on her.
The President did not do too well at his press conference yesterday when he sought to justify the tariff rises he has ordered for carpets and glass.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29--The Administration used the soft sell here today in an effort to win support for its foreign trade program from the cotton textile industry.

Business loans at the major New York City banks declined by $76,000,000 during the week ended Wednasday the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. A year ago the decline was $15,000,000.
ALBANY, March 30 The Legislature gave the go-ahead tonight for a sweeping inquiry to determine whether professional boxing should be outlawed in the state.
Commissioner Michael J. Murphy announced yesterday that the Police Department would present the first of a series of weekly half-hour television programs over Station WUHF, Channel 31, today.
OTTAWA, March 30 The northern port of Churchill on Hudson Bay is growing steadily in importance as a shipping center, according to figures made public today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, said today he saw no need for people immunized with Salk anti-pollomyelitis vaccine to take the new oral Sabin vaccine.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30--Leaders of the nation's textile industry gave resounding support tonight to the Kennedy Administration's foreign trade program.

WASHINGTON, March 30 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today he had very little hope that consumers of milk, butter and dairy products would benefit from the sharp cut he made in Federal dairy price supports.

In a now familiar phrase, Colombians can say "two cheers for democracy." They held Congressional elections on the same day the Argentines had their election and the results were rather gratifying for democracy, for civic peace and for the Alliance for Progress. The contrast with what has happened in Argentina could not be greater.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 30 The commander in chief of the Syrian Army, Maj. Gen. Abdel Karim Zahreddine, indicated today that the officers who staged a military coup Wednesday were in no hurry to restore civilian rule.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN, absent from the subscrip tion concerts of the New York Philharmonic since last Nov. 5, returned yesterday afternoon, and even made a speech to the audience, although the occasion was not a Thursday night "preview."

WASHINGTON, March 30 Like the slave of Aladdin's lamp, automatic machinery has to be told what to do. A device patented this week lightens man's chief remaining task in automated industry the giving of orders.

DODDSVILLE, Miss. March 30 (UPI) Senator James O. Eastland said tonight that Deputy Attorney General Byron R. White would make "an able Supreme Court Justice" and that he would support his nomination.

Operation Tennis Airlift, the project of the People-to-People Sports Committee to fly a planeload of players from the world over to the United States national amateur championships, is bumping along in an air pocket.
New Yorkers who once regarded the hills of New Jersey as too remote for commuting are now moving across the Hudson River in increasing numbers to find apartment-house comfort in suburban settings.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- The White House reached a settlement with Senator George D. Aiken today on the issue of emergency financing for the United Nations.
The cost of homes on Long Island is expected to rise as a result of new wage increases for construction workers.

Scott McKay will join the cast of "Mary, Mary" at the Helen Hayes Theatre for two weeks starting Monday. Mr. McKay will substitute for Barry Nelson, who is taking a vacation. Mr. McKay will have the same role with the national company, which will have the California in June. No theatre has been selected yet.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 30 A week-long battle of words between Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo and President Moise Tshombe of Katanga province subsided today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Three members of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today that, despite export controls, the United States and its allies were shipping militarily useful goods behind the Iron Curtain.
KANSAS CITY, March 30 (AP) An Air Force Reservist filed a Federal court petition today for a writ of habeas corpus to win his release from active duty.
GENEVA, March 20 (AP) The United States and the Soviet Union sparred today on the issue of how to guarantee enforcement of any general disarmament treaty.
ALBANY, March 30 A lastminute political power play involving New York City's fiscal program and a proposed Lincoln Center ballet theatre developed here tonight.
The Public Housing Administration has decided to set up a panel of design consultants to help solve the problem of dullness in much of the country's low-rent public housing.

A smokey sun hung like a dab of mustard over the mobile hot-dog stand on Eighth Avenue yesterday; a man with a pushcart cried, "Idaho potatoes, six pounds for a quarter"; a woman in a housecoat watched a slice of the world from a tenement window, and on the Ranger bench in Madison Square Garden Andy Bathgate. a toothless capitalist, sang an original work called "Three Frogs on an Ice Pond."
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) An area surrounding Roi Namarr Island in the Kwajelein Atoll will be off-limits to aircraft "for at least several years," a Pentagon spokesman said today.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 30 Samuel Graydon, a founder of the American Institute of Graphic Arts and the Advertising Club of New York, died today at his home at 25 Mine Street. His age was 83.

LOS ANGELES, March 30 (UPI)--Archie Moore knocked out Alejandro Lavorante in thirty-eight seconds of the tenth round tonight, and the exhausted Argentine heavyweight was carried from the ring on a stretcher.

The presidents of seven major United States symphony orchestras met here on Thursday for an informal discussion. It was called "in the light of a growing feeling that some form of Government assistance may become necessary if the symphony orchestras in this country are to continue to flourish."
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee knocked out a $65,000,000 fund today for the space agency to buy land at Cape Canaveral and in Mississippi.
WASHINGTON, March 30 The Opera Society of Washington presented Richard Strauss' "Ariadne auf Naxos" this evening in Lisner Auditorium.
LONDON, March 30 A request that Britain share her nuclear capability with her European allies is expected by Brit ish and Allied diplomats here.
WASHINGTON, March 30 President Kennedy today named Byron R. White, the Deputy Attorney General, to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the new Soviet Ambassador, presented his credentials to President Kennedy today.

Brig. Gen. Faymonville was recognized as one of this country's leading experts on Soviet Russia. During World War II, as chief of the American Military Mission in Moscow, he was a key figure in the administration of Lend-Lease in the Russian capital.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 30 Two propositions for a new school and the improvement of old schools in Tarrytown and North Tarrytown were defeated in a referendum yesterday.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 30 (UPI) Billy Martin, who drifted to six major league clubs after the New York Yankees traded him away in 1957, was released unconditionally today by the Minnesota twins.

WHEN Wealey Tann wanted a job on Seventh Avenue, no one was interested. Now that he has made a name for himself off the avenue, the dress designer refuses to leave his quarters in Manhattan's wholesale flower district, a loft the size of a large closet.

While public notaries were recruited from the ranks of slaves in the Roman era, their status quickly rose during the Renaissance and today most of them seem blithely liberatedexcept, possibly, in New York City. Here, many notaries said yesterday they're still slaves.
Two of New York's bestknown synagogues will observe anniversaries tomorrow. They are Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, and the Park Avenue Synagogue, 30 East Eighty-seventh Street.
MOSCOW, March 20 The Soviet Union was reported yesterday to have established a new research station in the Antarctic. It is the third post that will operate during the 1962 winter season.
TRENTON, March 30 Edward G. Wilms, a regional director of white collar members of the United Automobile Workers, was elected today as executive director of the Democratic State Committee.

Keeping food from hungry people is not in the American tradition, but in view of the circumstances the Administration was right to refuse an export license to an American firm seeking to clear the way for a possible sale of American grain to Communist China. No approach from Peiping had been made.
CAIRO, March 27 The drive of President Gamal Abdel Nasser to broaden his base of popular support is laying increasing emphasis on winning the approval of youth, particularly university students.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 --Gov. William F. Quinn of Hawaii appealed to President Kennedy today for the third time, asking him to intervene in the West Coast maritime strike. The walkout is now entering its third week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 United States and Soviet delegates ended four days of talks on cooperation in space research today with a statement that "they hare now concluded their preliminary discussions" and would meet again.

The ninth annual Antiques Show sponsored by the Women's Club of Salem, N.J., opens Wednesday in the Salem Armory on New Market Street. The show will be open on Wednesday and Thursday from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M.; on Friday, the final day, from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) The United States agreed today to permit international inspection of four of the nation's atomic reactors, Officials expressed the hope that the Soviet Union would follow suit.
MIAMI, March 30 The Yankees played their first game of the year under lights tonight, and for all the illuminating effect it had on them they might just as well have played it in the dark.
PARIS, March 30 The recent monetary experience and policy of France is adding fuel to the long debate over whether there is or is not sufficient "international liquidity."
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Farm product prices rose a point between mid-February and mid-March.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 30 (AP) Meadow Stable's fleet filly, Cicada, drew the inside post position today for her race against ten colts in the $125,800 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park tomorrow.

HAIRDRESSERS sometimes may seem akin to home economists because of their theories on nourishing the hair. Common food products used in many salons include beer, lemon juice, vinegar, eggs, olive oil and tea. The latest addition to the hairdressers' grocery list is milk.

NORWALK. Conn., March 30 The Norwalk Teachers Association has accepted a proposal of the Board of Education for a $150,000 blanket raise for teachers for the 1962-63 school year. Starting salaries of $5,000 would be instituted.
TOLEDO, Ohio. March 30 Dr. Frank U. Quillin, chief of employment for the United States Veterans Bureau in Washington under President Warren G. Harding, died today at the age of 82.
A major shift in bridge usage and a slight increase in traffic volume and revenue were reported yesterday by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
An oceanic robot to eavesdrop on whales and porpoises was described here Thursday.

INTERNATIONAL television is making news in many ways these days; last night there was the importation of hilarity from the British Broadcasting Corporation in London. Two of the B.B.C.'s top comedians, Tony Hancock and Eric Sykes, appeared in items of beautifully turned nonsense that should lead to a return engagement on these shores.

PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., March 30 (AP) Union picketing endedtoday at Atlas missile sites near here, but an Air Force colonel expressed concern over construction delays caused by the picketing yesterday and today.
Major organizations in the civil rights field are expanding their staffs in preparation for a South-wide Negro voter registration program.
A marine engineers' picket line at a Brooklyn pier yesterday interfered with the luncheon plans of Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges.

Forty-two religious leaders representing four major Protestant denominations with a total membership of nearly 20,000,000 will hold their first formal meeting on April 9 and 10 to discuss a possible merger.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30 Two meet records were broken tonight as Ohio State's host squad took a commanding lead in the race for the team title in the thirty-ninth annual National Collegiate swimming championships.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 30 (AP) Bi-racial talks have continued here since five stores voluntarily desegrated lunch counters, without incident, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Anyone who has ever thought of writing a letter to the editor and has not written it may have some idea of what Harold Harris went through today.
Stocks continued their downward trend yesterday, ending a week in which only wednesday showed anything resembling strength. Not a single major group was higher.
ALBANY, March 30 The Republican and Democratic legislative leaders acknowledged in a statement tonight that they had been unable to resolve the controversial question of grand jury presentments.

The poll was close twelve votes would have swung matters the other way but by that slender margin the House of Representatives has given its approval to the Administration's somewhat amended tax bill. The measure now goes to the Senate, which has often been a stumblingblock in the way of new tax legislation. It will need there some of the help which the President gave it in the House.
ALGIERS, March 30--Abderrahmane Fares, Moslem President of the provisional executive council of Algeria, warned Algeria's European residents tonight to cease their...
A Federal District Judge ruled here yesterday that Herman F. Marks, the Americanborn former executioner for Fidel Castro in Cuba, was a man without a country.
With his latest Broadwaybound vehicle, "We Take the Town," temporarily halted for repairs, Robert Preston has signed to make a new film.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) Maj. Donald K. Slayton's fellow astonauts have appealed to President Kennedy to reverse the decision disqualifying him from the second United States orbital space flight, it became known today.

The Government obtained a $1,100,940 judgement yesterday In Federal Court against Paul J. Carbo, known as Frankie Carbo and reputedly the underworld car of boxing. The sum represents income taxes, interest and fines covering seven years.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., March 30 (UPI) A Federal grand jury handed up today an indictment detailing the nuclear secrets that, it charged, George John Gessner handed to the Russians.
A Board of Health requirement that containers of milk sold in New York City be dated goes into effect tomorrow.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 30 (AP) Two off-duty policemen were suspended as the result of an automobile chase that culminated in the shooting of William Bergan, 25-year-old-son of Presiding Justice Franis Bergan of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Albany.
WASHINGTON, March 30 The United States and Brazil are near agreement on a $276,000,000 program of combined aid for poor and droughtstricken northeast Brazil.
The Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution will hold its annual bridge party the afternoon of April 26 at the Colony Club.

The Fairbanks Whitney Corporation had a net loss of $83,583 on net sales and operating revenues of $141,290,143 in 1961, David Karr, president, reported yesterday. The company had net income of $733,116, includ ing a special credit of $595,000, on revenues of $145,371,328 in 1960.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Harold C. Woodward of Illinois was sworn in today as a member of the Federal Power Commission, becoming the fifth new member of the five-man commission in nine months.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Saturday, March 31 (AP)--Navy surprised the defending champion, New York University, and took the lead after the first day of the two-day National Collegiate fencing championship.
NEW DELHI, India, March 30 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru suggested today that the Patriarch of the Roman Catholic Church in Goa was helping to block Indian aims there.

MIAMI, Fla., March 30 (UPI) --Federal narcotics agents today seized six pounds of cocaine from a cache of narcotics that they valued at $1,250,000. The agents said the narcotics had been shipped from Cuba in a Communist plot to demoralize Americans.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 30 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George S. Koch of the marriage in Norman, Okla., on March 23 of their daughter, Miss Gwende Ann Koch, to James Albert McComas. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. McComas of Tulsa, Okla.
Times Square's biggest electric spectaculars are darkened. but the incandescent glow of lesser lights still enchant visitors.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Hard bargaining is under way on rentals and landing charges for the new Dulles International Airport, Najeeb E. Halaby, Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, has said.

COUNTING jelly beans has become a matter of grave importance to children in the neighborhood of upper Madison Avenue. The beans in question colorfully pave the window of The Little Shop Around they Corner at 28 East Ninety-first Street. Whoever guesses most accurately the number of beans on view mill receive a basked of goodies from the children's party store.
Mayor Wagner will take New Yorkers on a guided television tour of City Hall under an arrangement that is being worked out.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 30 DeMatha High School of Hyattsville, Md., and Trenton Catholic High School moved into the final of the Eastern States Catholic invitation basketball tournament tonight.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 30 The New York State Harness Racing Commission completed its investigation today of John Edmunds, a Roosevelt Raceway driver who was reported to have said he bet on another horse in a race that he (Edmunds) won.
With Johnny Rotz rating him to perfection, I.J. Collins' Whitechapel raced to victory over the heavily favored Bal Musette in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange showed a small decline in March and for the first three months of this year.
PARIS, March 30 The Government declared tonight that arrests of underground agents had prevented a Right-wing terrorist offensive in France against the Algerian peace accord.
WHITE PLAINS, March 30 The systematic disappearance of kitchen cabinets, sinks, lumber and hardware from a housing development at 1200 Midland Avenue, Yonkers, mystified the police of that city.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 30 The Nassau Community College will offer a double session of day and evening classes this summer to help students accelerate or make up scholastic deficiencies.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 30 A paleontologist from the American Museum of Natural History carefully scraped away some dirt and uncovered both sides of the lower jaw of a mastodon here this morning. He said the prospects for finding the rest of the 8,000-year-old skeleton, or a substantial part of it, were good.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 30 All but four of the 8,800 union machinists employed at the Republic Aviation Corporation in Farmingdale have been ordered to strike if a new contract is not negotiated with the company by 12:01 A.M. Sunday.
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., March 30 (AP) A 3-year-old girl was rescued today after eleven hours on a rocky ledge to which she had fallen while playing on the bank of the lower Niagara River.
ORADEL, N.J., March 30 Miss Jennie Belle Madden, a senior at Smith College, and George Stephen Mason, a graduate student at Columbia, plan to be married in July.
TAMPA, Fla., March 30 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds routed the Detroit Tigers, 8 1, today behind the seven-hit pitching of Sammy Ellis and John Klippstein.

WASHINGTON, March 30 Average prices in primary markets fell one-tenth of one per cent to 100.5 per cent of their 1957-59 base during the week ended Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Decreases were recorded for both farm products and processed foods. Prices of industrial commodities were steady.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 30 (AP) Alabama will vote May 1 on a constitutional amendment with far-teaching effect on voter-registration procedure.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Fowler Hamilton head of the Agency for International Development, announced today the appointment of James H. Ingersoll. 43-year-old Chicago manufacturer, to head the United States aid mission in the Philippines.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera. "La Gloconda," at 2 P.M. and "La Traviata" at 8: "Porgy and Bess." City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra.

Senora Maxima Crespo, the mother of Benny (Kid) Paret, arrived by plane from Havana via Miami yesterday and went directly to Roosevelt Hospital to see her stricken son. Through an interpreter, she said: "I will stay in New York until my son will be getting well."

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Gus Hall and Benjamin J. Davis, identifed as top officials of the United States Communist party, pleaded not guilty today on arraignment on charges of violating the Internal Security Act of 1950.
The salient features of the two-story home and the splitlevel have been combined in a new 160-house colony in Baldwin, L.I.
TRENTON, March 30 A prolonged controversy over the form and location to an interchange between the Garden State Parkway and the proposed Essex East-West Freeway was settled amicably today.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, March 30 Dutch marines routed a band of Indonesian invaders yesterday in a brief battle on the island of Gag off the tip of Netherlands New Guinea, a military communique reported today.
BOSTON, March 30--Edward M. Kennedy, a candidate for a Democratic Senate nomination, admitted today that he had withdrawn from Harvard College as a freshman in 1951 at the college's request.

LE CASTELLET, France, March 30 Let us say the fable goes like this. A Puerto Rican nationalist movement, headed by the island's Independence party, has started a miniature rebellion against the United States. This, despite strong military reaction, cannot be squashed.
The sins of the father are visited often enough upon the son, but as Igor Oistrakh will probably testify, the old man's virtues may well prove an even greater burden.
DENVER, March 30 (UPI) Byron R. White said today he was surprised and honored by his nomination to the Supreme Court. Mr. White, in Denver for several speaking engagements, said:

HAVANA, March 30 Sitting on benches on an outdoor basketball court, nearly 1,200 prisoners captured in the invasion of Cuba last April went through the second day of their military trial today. Morning newspapers said they had already "admitted their guilt."

ALEXANDER OSTROVSKY'S 100-year-old drama, "The Storm," which was revived at the Masque Theatre last night, possesses a general tone of extravagant emotion. Its dialogue is stilted and sometimes inadvertently amusing to the spectator. Still, the work is capable at times of being movingly expressive, intense and evocative.

AINTREE, England, March 30 (AP) Thirty-two horses were named today to start in the Grand National Steeplechase tomorrow. Nicolaus Silver, a big gray 10-year-old, is favored to win for the second straight year.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Almost without notice, the private home-building boom is fading away, and at the same time, rental housing is becoming more popular.
A persisting demand for long-term United States Government bonds from banks and other investing institutions imparted to the bond market its strongest look of the week yesterday.

WINDOW shoppers enjoying the warns spring air might troll over to Creations 'N Things at 1467 Second Avenue, just off Seventy-sixth Street, where attractive furnishings and equally attractive price tags offer interesting discoveries. For example, officers' folding stools with colorful damask seats and match ing painted wood
LEXINGTON, Ky. Saturday, March 31 New York contract bridge teams were favored as the Vanderbilt Cup contest reached its eighth round, with play proceeding into the early hours of this morning.

AMARILLO, Tex., March 30 (AP)--A group of finance companies deeply involved in West Texas agricultural mortgages prepared to file suit today against Billie Sol Estes, a business man who was arrested last night on fraud charges.

THE electronic range is speedy in cooking but slow in gain ing acceptance. Since 1955, when the first microwave ovens became available for home use, 10,000 units have been sold, although manufacturers optimistically had predicted that sales by 1960 would reach 100,000 a year.

PEIPING, March 30 (Reuters) One of the few indications that the Chinese Communist National People's Congress is meeting for the first time in two years is a heavy concentration of automobiles outside Peiping's Great Hall of the People.

Not many musical events this season will come as close to perfection as did last night's concert in Town Hall. The program had a classic simplicity, given over to two masterpieces in contrasting styles Schumann's "Dichterliebe" song cycle, and Leos Janacek's "The Diary of One Who Vanished," which is best described as a mono-drama for tenor, mezzosoprano, piano, and an off-stage chorus of three female voices.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., March 30 (AP) The only new prospective defender of the America's Cup was reported 60 per cent completed today and headed for launching just before midnight on May 19.
Fixed-interest securities valued at about $310,000,000 are slated for offering next week.
WASHINGTON, March 30 The United States said today that the matter of whether it would formally recognize the new Argentine Government was "under study."

BONN, Germany, March 30 Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss has begun what amounts to a re-education course for the Bundeswehr, the West German armed forces, to de-emphasize their need of nuclear weapons.
Harold Fields of 23 West Seventy-third Street, who retired last September after a fifty-two-year career with the city school system, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 71 years old.

The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street is attempting to widen employment opportunities for blind people in professional fields through the new Lighthouse Professional Placement Service.
About 6,000 members of Masonic lodges in the metropolitan area will participate tomorrow in their seventeenth annual services of worship and dedication breakfasts.

The volume of new stock offered to the public here in March exceeded the totals for both the preceding month and March, 1961. Bond offerings, on the other hand, dropped below the levels of February and the yearearlier month.

There is a deceptive atmosphere of cool reserve when the two master musicians at the Village Gate make their appearances. But in a matter of moments Sabicas, the flamenco guitarist, and Sam (Lightning) Hopkins, the Texas blues man, start a heat wave with their music.

Four thousand persons crowded into the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday for the opening of Interpex, the International Philatelic Exhibition. Ceremonies marked the first day of issue of stamps honoring the World Health Organization's campaign to eradicate malaria.
ALBANY, March 30 Lastminute problems with two major proposals today forced a day's delay in the adjournment of the 1962 session of the Legislature.

GOLDEN fresh pineapples mainly from Puerto Rico currently are welcome additions to the local produce scene. Priced as low as 39 cents, they offer a delicious and refreshing change for jaded palates and require a minimum of preparation.
WASHINGTON, March 30 The following table shows the Supreme Court appointments of Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower and John F. Kennedy:

Thomas Cardinal Tien, 71year-old exiled archbishop of Peiping and Primate of China, arrived by plane last night from Shannon, Ireland, for a month's stay in this country. He had visited President Eamon de Valera while in Ireland.

A SURVEY of the music of Lester Trimble, 38-yearold American composer, was presented late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. A former music critic who now is general manager of the American Music Center, Mr. Trimble has been turning out works sparely, but they have invariably been well received.

WASHINGTON, March 30 The Defense Department has cleared without change an article on the Marine Corps by one of its officers after refusing to clear it earlier because of its interpretation of an interservice struggle during the Truman Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 The Economic and Social Council, which will open its spring meeting Tuesday, is expected to approve a major expansion in United Nations efforts to speed the industrialization of underdeveloped nations.
PITTSBURGH, March 30 The early, noninflationary settlement in basic-steel labor negotiations, if it unfolds here tomorrow as expected, will be the result of a combination of influences.

HANCOCK, Md., March 30 Miss Clurie Bowles Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Leslie Warwick Williams of Cleveland, was married this morning to Warren G. Bennis. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Joseph Langer of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and the late Philip Bennis of New York.
The 1962 session of the New York Legislature, watched with especial interest as the prelude to the state election, has made a reasonably good record.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 History may be repeated at Namtu, in northern Burma, if sucess attends a twoyear survey of lead and zinc mines that the United Nations special fund has allocated $676,000. The objective is to determine the feasibility of exploiting commercially the lowergrade ores available, estimated at 5,000,000 tones.

PARIS, March, 30 The United States set out today to clarify what are believed to be misunderstandings in France and elsewhere in Europe about President Kennedy's new trade program.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Spring blew in on the first warm breeze off the Carolinas this week to touch the treetops with green haze and stir the essential juices of daffodils and politicos alike.

RABAT, Morocco, March 30 The end of the long Algerian war, which has been a large factor in Morocco's politics ever since she became independent in 1956, has created new problems for King Hassan II and his Government.

EIGHTY-EIGHT art exhibition openings have been announced for next week, a hurricane warning that makes the last week's fifty-six seem like a light breeze. This breeze, on the whole, was not too refreshing. Bringing a modicum of fresh air, it stirred up a lot of trash of the kind that is always lying around.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Byron Raymond White is one of those increasingly rare specimens who prove that the Greek and Renaissance ideal of the well-rounded man has validity in the twentieth century.

The appointment of Col. Milton M. Miletich to succeed Col. Charles M. Duke as New York District Engineer for the Army Corps of Engineers was announced yesterday. The appointment is effective next summer.
Sone city and state officials expressed disappointment yesterday that the Legislature had not strengthened laws regulating the recruitment of domestic workers from outside the state.
WASHINGTON, March 30--The Kennedy Administration threatened today to set up schools for children living on Federal bases if local public schools did not desegregate.

Carl E. Youngdahl, president of C.E. Youngdahl Co., Inc., general building contractor at 29-28 Forty-first Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, suffered a heart attack Thursday and died later in the day at Flushing Hospital in Queens. He was 64 years old and lived at 46-54 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing.
The Consolidated Edison Company's offering of 946,454 shares of new convertible preference for subscription by company shareholders is in effect.
Potato futures prices closed up 9 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to 1 point off yesterday on the Mercantile Exchange here. The volume was 1,578 cariots.
The Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York has sharply criticized the practice of some moving van concerns of deliberately giving low estimates on moving charges.

A ruling by the Condemnation Court, a part of the state Supreme Court, on how much New York City must pay the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines for having seized all but a small part of its assets may not be given for months, or even years.
The Wells College Club of New York is having a theatre party at "All American" at the Winter Garden on April 5. Proceeds will go to the scholarship fund of the college in Aurora, N.Y.
Hartford, Conn., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $6,516,000 of improvement bonds. City Treasurer John J. Mahon said that bids would be received on April 11.
A combination residential and commercial-industrial development is planned on the former site of Camp Shanks in Orangeburg, Rockland County.

The United States Conference for the World Council of Churches announced yesterday that the Rev. Dr. Martin Niemoller, noted German church leader and one of the six presidents of the World Council, would arrive in this country tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee today recommended a Federal expenditure of $17,000,000 for United States participation in the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. This is $8,000,000 less than President Kennedy had requested.
The city's seizure of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., was declared unconstitutional yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 30 (UPI) Syrian and Turkish troops exchanged fire today when two Syrian border guards accidentally crossed the border into Turkey, exploding a mine.

Whats ahead for the stock market in April? Based on the record for past years, the chances are a little better than 50-50 that stock prices at the end of April will be higher than yesterday's closing level for March.
BUENOS AIRES, March 30 Jose Maria Guido, 51-year-old Patagonian lawyer and former head of the Senate, formally took over the Presidency of Argentina today with the approval of the armed forces.
LOS ANGELES, March 30 One of the first major tests of the voting strength of rightwing conservatism will be staged in California's unexpectedly vigorous Republican primary on June 5.
LONDON, March 30 Industrial shares remained irregular in the stock market here today. On balance there was a tendency for prices to edge upward.

PALERMO, Sicily, March 30 The regional Parliament of Sicily has petitioned the national Parliament in Rome to investigate the Mafia secret criminal association, which continues to take a heavy toll of lives and wealth.

ANDERSON, S.C., March 30 (AP) The weekly Anderson Free Press has been advised that a postal inspection will be made to determine if its list of subscribers is large enough to warrant second-class mailing privileges.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 30 Pi's were tossed about and practically every known angle was worked at the second annual Suffolk County Math Fair here today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Members of a House Government Operations subcommittee, which had complained that the Administration had not provided enough information, came to terms with President Kennedy today.

William F. Rickenbacker testified in Federal Court yesterday that he had refused to answer 1960 questionnaire sent by the Census Bureau to every fourth household because it was unconstitutional and unlawful discrimination. He is enarged with failure to fill in the form, a misdemeanor.

Friends of Brandeis University have lent more than seventy paintings for the exhibition of modern French works and nineteenth and twentieth-century masters arranged by the university's Poses Institute of Fine Arts. The event will take place at the Wilderstein Gallery from April 11 through April 25.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30--For the first time in their short history, the New York Mets today were called upon to play extra innings in an exhibition game. Philadelphia forced Casey Stengel's men to go ten innings before the Phils bowed, 2--1. A slim crowd of 1,179 watched the game at Al Lang Field.

Plans to transform a dilapidated one-block stretch of East Fifth Street into an outdoor recreation area for all age groups are being put forward by a community association in the lower East Side neighborhood.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 30 (Reuters) President Kennedy sent a letter to President Sukarno today that apparently urged renewed Duch-Indonesian talks on the dispute over Netherlands New Guinea.
Evidence that the cells called neurons may be formed in the brains of adult mammals, possibly including man, was reported yesterday to the journal Science.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Senator Wayne Morse said today he would try to delay action on legislation urged by President Kennedy to set up a privately owned communications satellite corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) Federal school officials giving the three-year-old National Defense Education Act top marks, have asked for an immediate increase of $16,000,000 for loans to college freshmen this year.
HOUSTON, March 30 (AP) A lawyer said today that the nation's seven astronauts had accepted offers by Houston's home building industry to give them free homes.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 30 Sir Roy Welensky said tonight that he had resigned as Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nvasaland and called a general election because he had unwittingly misled the electorate.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Robert Amory Jr. has resigned as deputy director for intelligene in the Central Intelligence Agency, a post he has held since 1953.
A "research rush" of modest proportions may get under way next month in Canada, a land known more heretofore for its gold strikes and oil wells.
A self-appointed gypsy queen accused of stealing $118,273 from a lonely widow testified yesterday that she had never seen the widow until four years after the alleged theft.

A first-class system of highways and sewers in Queens would cost $465,000,000 and take forty to sixty years to construct at the present rate of spending, Borough President John T. Clancy said yesterday.
CHICAGO, March, 30 Chicago's first taxicab strike in twenty-five years was settled today, twenty hours after it began.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 23 Prospects appear slight for the emergence in the near future of a real political opposition to President Chiang Kai-shek's Chinese Nationalist regime.

STORM JAMESON'S "The Road From the Monument" is one of the most in teresting novels about English authors and their tribal ways since Somerset Maugham's "Cakes and Ale." The intellectual cannibalism that ventures of this kind require is presented by Miss Jameson with acute skill.
New records in revenue and in the number of vehicles and miles traveled on the New York State Thruway were reported yesterday by the Thruway Authority in its annual report for 1961.
The total of bonds called for redemption before maturity in March rose to $30,056,000 from $29,626,000 in February, but, were considerably below they $52,458,000 redeemed in March, 1960.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Representative Edith Green, Democrat of Oregon, called today for a close watch on the "wild right" and a more discriminating liberalism.
Forty-four high-ranking police officers were transferred to new commands yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.
THE week's most magnificent act of innocence, if not the week's best art, was surely on display in Edward Melcarth's exhibition at Durlacher's. 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The music of George Garratt, presented last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, had moments of brilliance, drama and lyricism. Performed were his Duo for 'cello and piano, five "Statements" for piano, Second Sonata for Violin and Piano, a trio for violin, 'cello and piano and the Piano Sonata No. 3.

NUTLEY, N.J., March 30 Federal Laboratories, Inc., a division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, signed a new twoyear contract with two unions today six months before the old contracts expired.
The New York Savings Bank raised its interest rate on twoyear deposits to 4 per cent yesterday, the highest savings bank rate in modern times.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday the termination of their joint ownership in the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company. This action follows and agreement by the companies in November, 1960, through which the assets of Standard-Vacuum would be divided equally between them.
THE adventurous gardener will look past the cab bages and carrots to some of the more nobel vegetables for planting this season. There are many little-known kinds that will add new zest to menus.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Unemployment, a stubborn ailment in a generally improving economy, moved President Kennedy to ask Congress this week for a fast-acting, localized remedy in the form of $600,000,000 worth of public works.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell of New York, who has built a reputation as an almost unsurpassed absentee through his years in Congress, now has a $13,000-a-year secretary who also does her work in absentia.
While the controversy about the relationship between cigarette smoking and lung cancer is still far from settled, the problem is entering a new phase.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The Administration's newest recruit in the fight for liberal foreign trade legislation has decided not to march up Capitol Hill in support of the cause, at least for the time being.

A prominent French television figure, a Parisian nightclub owner and a Brooklyn father and son pleaded not guilty in Kings County Court yesterday to charges of conspiring to possess $3,500,000 worth of heroin.
A return to the Metropolitan Opera next season will be made by Lotte Lehmann for the company's revival of "Der Rosenkavalier."
WASHINGTON, April 4-- President Kennedy sent the Senate a letter today designed to gain votes for the United Nations financing bill.
George Zauderer, New York realty operator, has bought the Rock Gate Farm, a former milk processing site on Route 117 at Bedford Hills in northern Westchester County.
Thousands of persons filed past the body of Benny (Kid) Paret in a Bronx funeral home yesterday while demands increased here and abroad for an end to professional boxing.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- President Kennedy plans to visit Brazil this year.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., April 5--Roy Saari, a 17-year-old high school senior from El Segundo, Calif., swam 1,500 meters tonight faster than it had been done by anyone else anywhere in the world.

Walker, former major general in the United States Army and now candidate for the Governorship of Texas, charges before a Senate committee that he has been the "scapegoat" for our Government's deliberate collaboration with communism, there is no reason to question his good faith. No doubt this is what he honestly believes.
LONDON, April 5--The Government warned today that concentration of Communist effort in civil service unions was "most dangerous" to Britain's security.

BUENOS AIRES, April 5-- Argentina is rapidly moving to a new political showdown. The week-old Government, which is propped up by the military, must decide before May 1 what to do about the parties that support Juan D. Peron, the former dictator.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- Senator John L. McClellan challenged the Douglas Aircraft Company today to furnish proof that it had earned $29,800,000, not $63,900,000, in seventeen years of developing and producing components for the Nike guided missile.

CHICAGO, April 5--Elmer A. Claar of suburban Northfield, a nationally known horticulturist, died yesterday in Hawaii while on vacation. He was 70 years old.
The American Stock Exchange tightened listing and delisting requirements yesterday, generally in line with recommendations made last January by a special Wall Street investigating committee.
School and union officials will meet with Mayor Wagner this afternoon in an effort to end the confusion over how much money will be available for teachers' pay increases.
Supporters of Boys Towns of Italy held their annual Ball of the Year last evening in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

LONDON, April 5--The Commonwealth Immigrants Bill was approved today by the House of Lords. It now requires only Queen Elizabeth's signature to become law.

Economy is the watchword in Wall Street these days. Because of the sharp drop in the volume of trading this year, brokerage houses are trimming costs, doing away with frills and even reducing employment.

The Superintendent of New York City's schools is now on record as saying that if the unionized teachers strike, as they threaten to do next Tuesday, they will automatically lose their jobs under the state's Condon-Wadlin Law.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Edwin A. Walker, who resigned from the Army to take up the cause of "Constitutional" conservatism, challenged today the loyalty of Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

If spring is here can the Shakespeare festivals be far behind? Apparently not, since eight groups in this country and one in Canada already have completed plans for the presentation of a variety of Shakespeare's comedies, tragedies and chronicle plays.

Underlying the transportation message President Kennedy sent to Congress yesterday is a recognition that railroads, airlines, buses, trucks and water carriers can no longer be viewed as unrelated entities. Our chaotic system of laws and regulatory agencies needs revision to provide a coordinated approach to what ought to be a closely linked network of carriers to meet the nation's needs efficiently and economically.

Dr. Horace Mann Snyder of 169 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, principal of the old Manual Training High School, Brooklyn (now the John Jay High School), from 1917 until his retirement in 1943, died Wednesday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 89.

LOOKING at the world from the vantage point of an 8x15-foot cubicle may not inspire universal optimism. MOSCOW, April 5--A Harvard historian has completed a series of lectures at Leningrad University on conservative Russian thinkers of the nineteenth century who are virtually ignored in Soviet teaching.

HOLDEN ROBERTO, a leader of the Angolan rebel movement who announced the formation yesterday of a National Front for the Liberation of Angola, is scholarly and dignified in appearance. He does not fit the popular image of a firebrand revolutionary.
CHESTER, Pa., April 5--The hull of the 12,528-ton American Export Lines cargo ship Export Courier slid into the waters of the Delaware River here this afternoon.

A 31-year-old jilted factory worker shot and killed his for mer wife yesterday before crowds in a downtown building and then put the pistol to his head and critically wounded himself. The woman died in the arms of her new husband.

ROME, April 5--The InterAmerican Development Bank, with headquarters in Washingiton D.C., invaded the Italian money market today with a bond issue of fifteen billion lire ($24,200,000 ).

Beau Purple of Jack Dreyfus' Hobeau Farm is projecting himself into the thoroughbred racing speed picture with emphasis. Competing in the one-mile purse that served as the feature on yesterday's program at Aqueduct, the 5-year-old won by six lengths.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- President Kennedy called on Congress today to write a basic national transportation policy.

A petition signed by 550 prominent Americans seeking a pardon for Junius I. Scales has been sent to President Kennedy by Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 5-- There were persistent rumors here tonight that Premier Ismet Inonu had threatened to resign and that another political crisis was brewing.

Louis A. Kempf, a retired accountant who practiced in Newark and later in Bloomfield, N.J., died yesterday in a nursing home in Richmond, Va., after a short illness. He was 83 years old.

MONTREAL April 5 (UPI) --The Chicago Black Hawks withstood a Montreal rally and defeated the Canadiens tonight, 4 to 3. The victory enabled the Hawks to gain a 3-2 lead in the four-of-seven game Stanley Cup semi-final series.

Stocks staged a rally in the final ninety minutes of yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The final net gain was almost as great as the loss in the big break on Tuesday.

Business loans at major New York City banks rose by $26,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Slightly more than 7,000,000 automobiles, trucks and buses entered or left New York City during a typical week in January, according to the Metropolitan Traffic Study.

Thirty mothers staged a "sit-in demonstration yesterday to keep a power shovel from digging up a play area of the John Lovejoy Elliott Houses. Three members of the City Housing Authority came out to try to get the work resumed.
ROME, April 6 The tomb of an Etruscan "gambler," the first Etruscan tomb to be found containing an intact piece of wooden furniture, was uncovered today in Cerveteri, twenty miles northwest of Rome.
WASHINGTON, April 6? Two Army generals assured the Special Senate Preparedness Subcommittee today that Army troops were undergoing intensive anti-Communist indoctrination.

New York and Los Angeles have begun taking into account the effect of noise and fumes from airplanes on the assesssed valuation of homes near airports.

Not a restful week, ladies and gentleman. But a rewarding one.

With his transportation message last week President Kennedy has put before Congress the full design of the legislation he considers necessary this year for national prosperity, security and the discharge of our world obligations. The range of his proposals has been impressive; the accomplishments to date meager.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 8 (UPI) The world's top-ranked amateur tennis players, Roy Emerson and Rod Laver, of Australia swept into the final of the Masters invitation tennis tournament with one-sided victories today.
APPOMATTOX, Va., April 8 (AP) After ninety-seven years a working copy of the surrender agreement between Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and Gen. Robert E. Lee was returned to Appomattox today.
"A gallant, grim Spartanism" cannot suffice for a Christian today, the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The Federal Trade Commission cast serious doubt today on the right of manufacturers and distributors to put retail price tags on nationally distributed products.

The New York City Opera Company concluded a brief season of contemporary opera at the City Center yesterday. Douglas Moore's "The Ballad of Baby Doo" was given in the afternoon, and Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Consul" was performed last night.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The prison-or-ransom verdict in the trial of the captives taken in last year's Cuban invasion was received here today with considerable interest but no official comment by the Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 8 President Kennedy is reported to be searching for a way to win President de Gaulle back into a working partnership with the Western Alliance.

ORAN, Algeria, April 8 Secret Army Organization gunmen and French security forces engaged in a noisy but inconclusive exchange of mortar and small-arms fire here today. The casualty toll was tentatively placed at three soldiers and one civilian wounded.
CRANSTON, R. I., April 8--Best-in-show honors at the fifty-eighth annual dog show of the Rhode Island Kennel Club today went to a 2-year-old Dalmatian, Ch. Roadcoach Spice.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 8 An ultramodern building that would be in sharp contrast with the Dutch Colonial tradition of this Sleepy Hollow village is being considered by the planning board.
Waterman Steamship Corporation, winner of a $2,811,733 tax refund suit last week, will eventually gain $5,000,000, according to a company official.

RICHMOND, Va., April 8 Whitey Ford will be the starting pitcher and Tom Tresh will be at shortstop when the Yankees open their 1962 championship season at the Stadium against the Baltimore Orioles on Tuesday.

A professor at Columbia University's College of Pharmacy surprised the school last week with a pledge of a $1,000,000 bequest.
WHEN a long-established Manhattan department store recently moved to a new location, a gray-haired woman in Brooklyn was prompted to write its president a letter.

Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, declared last night that peace in the Middle East could be achieved only if Israel and her Arab neighbors could be forced to discuss their differences outside the United Nations.

CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI) Glenn Hall stopped shots with his body and stick tonight in leading the Chicago Black Hawks to a 2-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens. The triumph enabled the Hawks to take the series, 4 2, and reach the finals of the Stanley Cup play-offs for a second straight year.

MIAMI BEACH, April 8 A principal United States delegate to the United Nations sharply indicted the ultra Right-Wing movement today for what he described as its "irrational criticism" of the world body.

Alfred E. Cosden, a breeder of horses who retired in 1915 as president of the Riker-Hegeman Drug Company, died here yesterday at the age of 89.

Wheeling (pop. 53,400) is the state's oldest, most Catholic, most "Northern" city a sooty crust of stiff, old, red-brick houses, abandoned steel mills and a railroad viaduct, tucked into the east bank of the Ohio River sixty miles from Pittsburgh.

ALTHOUGH only one of the six authors who appear in "Stories From Modern Russia"* is likely to be known to American readers Mikhail Sholokhov the stories themselves will seem familiar enough, not necessarily in detail, but in mood, in theme and in structure.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 Samuel Wyman Rolph, former president of the Electric Storage Battery Company and the Franklin Institute, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Germantown.

A proposal to ask the International Olympic Committee to consider the return of tennis to the Olympic program in 1968 will come before the Committee of Management of the International Lawn Tennis Federation in Paris Saturday.

YONKERS, April 8 Robert Samuels, one of the country's leading interior decorators and antiques dealers, died today at his home, 96 Chittenden Avenue, Crestwood, after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

Andr Previn, who had been piano soloist with the New York Philharmonic two years ago under the direction of Andr Kostelanetz, returned for a second appearance with the orchestra Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, this time under the direction of Leonard Bernstein. Shostakovich's First Piano Concerto was the vehicle.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The Commandant of the Marine Corps has ordered the Marine Inspector General's office to investigate a ceremony at Norfolk, Va., last week in which a young marine was drummed out of the corps.

CHICAGO, April 8 A Norwegian elkhound named Ch. Gladjac Royal Oslo supplied the surprising ending to a dog show that had a few other surprises tonight. Royal Oslo became best in show of the twentysecond International Kennel Club event, the largest of its kind in the land.

Washington and Cincinnati will jump the gun with special baseball opening games today and the rest of the major league field will start play tomorrow. The two-day opening is expected to attract about 340,000 fans.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., April 8 This was the most trying day for Casey Stengel since his return to baseball as field manager of the New York Mets.

The New York Mets came home last night to a welcome thunderous in its silence. It was almost as if they were tip-toeing through the back door.

PENNINGTON, N.J., April 8 T. Hart Anderson Jr., marketing consultant and former board chairman of Anderson Cairns, Inc., New York advertising agency, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home on Mount Rose Road. His age was 66.

Mrs. Hortense Gabel, head of the city's new rent-control agency, said yesterday that New Yorkers could expect a gradual rise in their rents.

MOSCOW, April 8 The housewives of Moscow signaled the end of the Russian winter today. In thousands of apartments, they stripped away the paper tape that had sealed the windows and kept out the subzero cold.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 8 The heads of state of the Casablanca bloc of African nations will consider a plan to create a joint defense command when they meet in Cairo next month, reliable sources said here today.

GENEVA, April 8 The Swiss stock markets failed to sustain their rally last week and prices again retreated on a broad front. The losses, however, were narrow and accompanied by a contraction in volume.

READING for pleasure and for cultural growth should be instilled in a child by parents as early as possible, according to Mrs. Augusta Baker, the Coordinator of Children's Services of the New York Public Library.

MOSCOW, April 8 An open letter by the former Foreign Minister of independent Latvia was a major topic of conversation in Moscow's diplomatic circles today. The letter related Soviet terror and repressions in the Baltic country in World War II.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) At a signal from William E. Miller, Republican national chairman, twenty-six House Republicans from fourteen states introduced almost identical bills last week to provide medical care for the elderly.

JESUP, Ga., April 8 (AP) A police dragnet captured thirteen of twenty-five escaped prisoners today after one of the biggest prison breaks in Georgia history.

Cosmetics companies rank high on the list of Madison Avenue's most fickle clients. Only two months ago, for example, Hazel Bishop, Inc., announced its fifth advertising agency shift in two years. Now another big cosmetics concern, Max Factor Co., has realigned its agency set-up.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The United States faces an airport shortage because of mushrooming suburbs, rising land costs and lack of sufficient municipal interest, according to the Aerospace Industries Association.

The 1962 Legislature which adjourned a few days ago was inconspicuously busy at one of its favorite pastimes, amending the New York State Constitution. In this game the Legislature can only propose, while the voters dispose. An amendment must be approved by two separately elected Legislatures; it then goes to the people in November referendum.

Dr. Adolf Berger, Visiting Professor of Roman Law at City College and an internationally recognized authority in his field, died yesterday after a brief illness at West Hill Sanatorium, the Bronx. He was 80 years old and lived at 74 West Sixty-eight Street.

Beckley (pop. 18,642), until after the Korean War, was a coal-dazzled city, perched on a hilltop in southern West Virginia's rich bituminous country. On Saturday afternoons, as one wistful merchant recalled recently, "You couldn't get by on the sidewalk, there were so many people in town. A miner would trade in his car every year without thinking twice."
PARIS, April 8 A sort of "double standard" in international financial relations is troubling a number of leading officials in Western Europe.
CHARLESTON, W. Va. Gov. William Wallace Barron flew to Washington one sunny day this March seeking a helping hand from the man West Virginia helped put in the White House.
TRENTON, April 8 A.J. Foyt of Houston erased all the track speed records at Trenton Speedway today in winning the season's first 100-mile race for Indianapolis-type cars.

LAS VEGAS, April 8 (UPI) The National Boxing Association middleweight champion, Gene Fullmer, said today he was ready to accept Paul Pender's challenge to clear up the title in the 160-pound division.

HAVANA, April 8--The 1,179 prisoners seized in the invasion of Cuba a year ago have been convicted of treason. But the Castro regime is offering to free them on the payment of a total of $62,000,000 in ransom.
This is that time of year when taxes worry just about everybody.
PARIS, Monday, April 9 The French people approved the peace settlement with the Algerian nationalist rebels by a heavy majority yesterday.
SEVILLE, Spain, April 8 Juan Belmonte, one of the most famous bullfighters Spain has ever known, died tonight of a heart attack. He would have been 70 years old next Saturday.

The marriage of Miss Suellen Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Stone of Manhasset, L.I., to Alden Scher Harris took place here yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Louis Harris of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mr. Harris.
TOKYO, April 8 Millions of Japanese went to Tokyo's parks today to admire spring in bloom, taking sake bottles with them and leaving inhibitions at home.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 8 Jake LaMotta, former middleweight boxing champion of the world, was questioned tonight on the statements of two witnesses in the investigation of the murder of Maitland Brenhouse here last week.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., April 8 (AP) Tunney Hunsaker, the heavyweight boxer, emerged tonight from his second brain operation within forty eight hours. His doctor said he was "not out of the woods yet by a long shot," although the boxer spoke to his wife shortly after the operation.
Almost 8,000 safety workers, public officials and educators are expected to take part in sessions of the thirty-second annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council, which begins today.

Webster Springs (pop. 1,132) crowds into the narrow Elk River valley, almost lost among the mountains that crouch over it like great black bears. The town sits at the end of 108 miles of winding road from Charleston, and, as one resident put it, "ninety miles from any place else."

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) The Kennedy Administration and the chief executive of the European Common Market will begin a five-day series of conferences tomorrow on the future relations between the Common Market and the United States as well as the rest of the world.
Work on the first phase of a municipal $25,000,000 pier building and rehabilitation project for United States Lines will get under way next Monday.
PARIS, April 8 The United States Government finds itself these days toning down abroad part of what it has been preaching at home about President Kennedy's trade-expansion program.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner, who have been at odds over state financial aid to New York City, made common cause yesterday in praise of Hellenic freedom.

The latest addition to the Ford Motor Company's fleet of Great Lake ore carriers will go into service Wednesday after rechristening in Detroit. The 639-foot vessel, formerly the Charles L. Hutchinson, will be renamed the Ernest R. Breech in honor of the former chairman of the board of the automobile company.
THE Harvard Undergraduate Bridge Club will be host to an Eastern Intercollegiate Bridge Tournament this coming week-end at Cambridge, Mass. Sixty colleges have been invited.
Joseph Malfitano, a member of the violin section of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, gave his third Carnegie Hall recital last night.

Felix B. Graham, director of electrical engineering and a partner in the firm of Syska Hennessy, Inc., 144 East Thirty-ninth Street, died Saturday after a brief illness. He was 41 years old and lived at 825 West 187th Street.

BALTIMORE, April 9--The largest shareholder of the Alleghany Corporation refused today to vote his one-third stock interest for a management-nominated slate of directors of the multibillion-dollar holding company.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 9 (AP)--Meadowbrook Stable's Destiny's Turn, ridden by an apprentice, Bobby Perna, beat the favored Lou Pelton by a nose today in the featured sixth race at Gulfstream Park. Todd W. finished third and Gold Sky was fourth.
PARIS, April 9--Georges Auric, the composer, today was named general administrator of France's national lyric theatres, the Opera and Opera-Comique here. He will succeed A.M. Julien.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --Witnesses from Congress and industry began a fight today for legislation to curb what they called unethical price-cutting of brand-name goods. They, contended that such practices usually resulted in costing the public more.
WARSAW, April 9--William L. Brett, a New York business man who has been detained for two months in Poland, was found guilty today of illegal currency manipulation.

A leading Belgian Communist has suggested a new way to end the Soviet-Chinese split.
The delegate assembly of the United Federation of Teachers voted at 3 o'clock this morning to postpone the teachers' strike scheduled to start today.
