City Hall, an example of Federal architecture, has little in common with Yankee Stadium, which is brewery Roman, but yesterday the New York Yankees 1961 World Championship flag flew proudly over the Hall.

Bearishness in steels and tobaccos appeared to dominate the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Stocks fell considerable distances on relatively light volume. Once again prices seemed to be marked down rather than forced down.
HACKENSACK, N.J., April 9--Two brothers pleaded guilty, here today to having taken part in a $280,000 insurance-premium swindle on two banks. They and another man were arrested in March, 1961.

ALBANY, April 9--Governor Rockefeller announced today that the state was prepared to advance $12,000,000 to $17,000,000 to New York City as a means of averting a teachers' strike tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- President Kennedy, like every President since William Howard Taft, made the first pitch at the opening of the baseball season today.

DETROIT, April 9 (UPI)-- New policies allowing an easy flow of goods and investment capital in the non-Commonunist world are necessary if it is to compete successfully with the Soviet bloc, an oil industry executive said today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 9 (UPI)--Roy Emerson of Australia defeated his countryman, Rod Laver, 6--1, 6--4, 6--1, today and won the Masters invitation tennis tournament.

LONDON, April 9--Industrial share prices advanced strongly ahead of the budget statement today, which came after the market's close. In after hours dealings, prices went further ahead, except for the shares of companies affected by higher taxes. Turnover was heavy.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP)-- Corn futures fell in the steepest slide in several months today with old-crop contracts losing almost three cents a bushel on the Board of Trade. Other deliveries declined major fractions or more.

Socially prominent women will portray stars of the Golden Age of Opera in the Parade of Flowers, a fashion show revue and luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza today. The event will benefit the Dual-Century Fund of St. Luke's and Woman's Hospitals.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)--Management and union officials today opposed ending the West Coast maritime strike with a Taft-Hartley injunction. They said such action would not settle the basic issues.

ABOUT an hour's drive from Manhattan is one of the East Coast's most estimable restaurants, It is La Cremaillere at Banksville, N.Y., and it is extraordinary on many counts. The menu offers fresh langouste from Europe's Brittany coast and turbot, one of the most delicate of fish from European waters.

The American Stock Exchange's program of reorganiration and change, much of it resulting from the recent Securities and Exchange Commission investigation and sub-... sequent exchange actions, has cost between $725,000 and $775,000 in extraordinary expenses.

Dr. Mary Holmes Stevens Hayes, a sociologist and former chairman of the national Girl Scouts executive committee, died yesterday in her home at the Carlyle Hotel, 35 East Seventy-sixth Street. Her age was 80.
Gary Gubner has reached the crossroads. This week, the world's best shot-putter will learn whether he also can become the world's best weight lifter this year.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- The first in a series of church unity talks that may drastically alter the format of modern American Protestantism began here today in an atmosphere of goodwill.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 9-- The Women's Auxiliary of St. Joseph's Hospital in this city will hold its first major benefit of 1962, the annual spring luncheon and fashion show, on April 24 at the Longshore Country Club in Westport.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 9-- Figuring that life may have begun again for the ancient Caduceus, John A. Cashman Jr., Roosevelt Raceway's young racing secretary, showed renewed interest in the 12-year-old New Zealand pacer this morning.
ALBANY, April 9--All eleven state District Tax offices will be open Saturday from 8:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. to give assistance in person or by telephone with state income tax returns.
ANOTHER chapter in the tension and drama of Marine Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr.'s orbital flight was unfolded last night with the release of the official films of his space voyage.

The Soviet Union was accused here yesterday of exploiting seven European Communist regimes to the extent of $5,028,000,000 by overcharges on exports and underpayments for imports from 1955 through 1960. Continuing similar profits of $1,000,000,000 and more a year were forecast.
Sharp drops in sugar futures prices highlighted trading on the New York commodity markets yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9--"I should have won the Masters five times in a row, but I was lucky this year," summarized Arnold Palmer after receiving the plaudits of the crowd and the winner's check for $20,000 today.

SEVILLA, Spain, April 9 (AP) --Preliminary steps for an intercontinental television service by means of satellites were announced today in a statement of the European Broadcasting Union. The group today ended, a conference of delegates from twenty countries.
Ruland Benjamin-Earle Callen, Inc., a realty brokerage company that was established in 1867, and Hanfield, Hillyer Bell, Inc., a leading Greenwich Village realty management concern, have merged.
Steel production dropped sharply last week from the preceding week's level, reflecting what observers took to be an end of inventory building against the possibility of a strike.
HOUSTON, April 9--Major league baseball will make its bow in the Southwest tomorrow and this booming metropolis is a11 set to give the Houston Colt .45's a typically breezy Texas welcome.
ATHENS, April 9--The Greek Government floated today an internal loan of 990,000,000 drachmas ($33,000,000) to finance its economic development program.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- President Kennedy challenged adults today to continue trying to make the United States "a happy nursery" for children.
Radio station WINS has been sold to the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company.

The Jim Walter Corporation told Wall Street security anaslysts yesterday that its net income for the quarter ended on Feb. 28 plummeted to $151,000, or 8 ents a share, from $1,291,265, or 66 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.
OTTAWA, April 9--The House of Commons engaged today in an argument over charges that Canada had sold out to the United States on they Columbia River Treaty.
The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday there would be relatively little difference between the new prices it will charge at Philhadmonic Hall at Lincoln Center and those at Carnegie Hall.

MADRID, April 9--Juan Belmonte, the Spanish bullfighter who died last night, was reported today to have committed suicide. According to reports in Seville, his native city, he had been in poor health for a long time.

JACKSON, Miss., April 9 (UPI)--Saying they were acting out of respect to the Protestant Episcopal Church, prosecutors dropped breach-of-peace charges today against a sonin-law of Governor Rockefeller of New York and fourteen other Episcopal ministers. The group had challenged racial segregation here.
The Maritime Administration has set May 2 for a preliminary hearing on the application of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company to re-enter intercoastal shipping.

HOUSTON, April 9 (AP)-- Young tennis players went through forty-eight matches today in qualifying play of the twenty-eighth River Oaks tennis tournament to determine the players to oppose sixteen exempt stars. Most of the youngsters on the courts today were collegians.

LOS ANGELES, April 9 (UPI)--Eager citizens, proud civic leaders and jubilant baseball dignitaries today joined to dedicate the Los Angeles Dodgers' new multimillion-dollar 56,000-seat stadium in Chavez Ravine.
Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran and his Empress are making a state visit to this country at a particularly opportune time. The outlook for their kingdom has recently much improved.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Treasury bill rates declined on today's sale of the regular weekly issues.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 9 (UPI)--The Carroll Lanes of Mount Carroll, III., took first place in the booster team division of the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9--Following is the text of a United States-British resolution on the Palestine question that was adopted by the Security Council today:
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --A witness for the utility industry urged the Senate Finance Committee today to enlarge an investment tax credit benefit for the industry rather than eliminate it.
Coogans Bluff, the most nostalgic chunk of mica schist in the world, overlooked a new generation's baseball heroes yesterday--the New York Mets.

THE M-boys and their associate fencebreakers are scheduled to resume their harassment of American League pitch ers at the Yankee Stadium today. The longawaited opening of the baseball season is at hand, a season of such historical implications that it will be the biggest ever, even though it won't necessarily be the best.
A strike by the city's teachers could expose those taking part to loss of jobs under the 1947 state Condon-Wadiin Act. The law once led to jailing of union leaders here.

CRITICS are dreadful people. After sustained com plaints about the similarity of much abstract painting to drivel, battalions of figure painters have been standing with brushes at attention, nudging each other and saying, "Soon it will be our turn."
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9-- Arnold Palmer proved again today to be an amazing golfer as he won the Masters tournament for the third time.
JOAO PESSOA, Brazil, April 9--Joao Pedro Teixeira was killed on a dirt path six days ago by four rifle shots as twilight lengthened the shadows under the green mango trees.
LONDON, April 9--A diary begun nearly 400 years ago and still almost intact has shed new light on Sir Walter Raleigh, the versatile gallant who dreamed of empire for England in the New World.
THE play that made the contract in this deal causes little difficulty to knowledgeable bridge players, but it is likely that few of them know its history.
POTNT ARGUELLO, Calif., April 9 (AP)--The Air Force launched its fifth secret satellite rocket today--an AtlasAgena B combination like that used for Samos and Midas sky spies.

The police were accused in Manhattan Arrest Court yesterday of having beaten an unemployed economist with nightsticks and having dragged a housewife along the street during a peace rally in Times Square on March 3.
TRENTON, April 9 (AP)-- New Jersey today adopted new experimental boxing rules to prevent the occurrence of any serious injuries or deaths in the ring.

Girls are emerging in groveing strength in the city's public schools as talented junior scientists. And, as one predicted, happily yesterday, "Don't be surprised if a woman becomes President of the United States one day."
FROM Atlantic City comes information that a new trapshooting set-up is under construction there with a completion date set for mid-June.
American-International Aluminum announced yesterday that, by amendment to its by-laws, the board of directors of the corporation has been reduced to three directors.
The voices at the other end of the phone are always friendly and mellifluous.

WITH the death of Robert Samuels on Sunday, the last echo of an era of palatial mansions in America disap peared. Robert, brother of the late Mitchell Samuels, who was co-founder of French Co., began his decorating career in 1908 when the prevailing style was rococo.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)--The House Agriculture Committee approved today three more sections of the Administration's farm bill, leaving only the controversial milk provisions still to be acted on.
The Yankees will be aiming for their twenty-seventh American League pennant when they open the 1962 championship season today against the Baltimore Orioles at the Stadium.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 9 (AP)--Stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., were given an encouraging picture today of the chemical company's prospects this year.

The settlement (or neighborhood) house movement began here in New York seventy-six years ago when the University Settlement started to work for the welfare of the European immigrants who flooded the lower East Side.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru chose today an expanded but otherwise little changed Cabinet to serve with him during his fourth term of office.

PARIS, April 9--President de Gaulle and Premier Michel Debre whose policy of peace with Algeria was overwhelmingly endorsed in a referendum yesterday, met today to discuss the possibility of elections next month.
A dinner dance, "Up in Central Park," will be held at the Tavern-on-the-Green on May 7 for the benefit of the Association for Homemaker Service, Inc.

Though the Yugoslav Government has given no public reason as yet for its decision to rearrest Milovan Djilas, the circumstances make plain that this action was closely connected with the scheduled early publication here of Djilas' latest book, "Conversations With Stalin." The book presents evidence that Stalin was primarily responsible for the cold war.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 9-- A four-man team from the United States Army military advisory force fought desperately for thirty minutes yesterday morning before being overcome by the Vietcong Communist guerrillas in Quang Nam Province.
The Board of Education announced yesterday it would replace the city's fifty-four local school boards by twenty-five new and "revitalized" boards on July 1.

Six of the theatre's leading ladies, assembled to discuss the question of whether Broadway had become a "woman's world," adroitly skirted the issue yesterday but all agreed emphatically that they liked men--i. e., directors.

Activity in the bond market subsided yesterday from the space of business that had pre vailed last week. The general tone continued strong. However, price declines of mostly slight extent were registered in longer-term United States Government securities.

Douglas Campbell will be elevated from the name role in "Gideon" to that of God when he replaces Fredric March on April 30. At the same time, Gerald Hiken will take over the stint now held by Mr. Campbell.

The last-minute agreement by the United Federation of Teachers to put off the threatened teachers strike has probably averted a course that would have been disastrous to the city and the teaching profession. WASHINGTON, April 9--The Washington Senators, whose 61-101 won-lost record last season prompted the adoption of "a better view in '62" as their slogan for this year, will find it hard to improve on the vantage point they earned today.
WRITERS who attempt a play within a play had better face up to the terrible risk they run. If the thing doesn't work out, it will seem like two poor plays instead of just one.
PORTLAND, Me., April 9 (AP)--The engagement of Mrs. Jean Gannett Williams of Portland to J. Richard Arnzen of Bath has been announced.

Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of city transit, was back in New York from a Florida business trip yesterday prepared to advise Mayor Wagner that he could not be drafted to oppose Representative Charles A. Buckley for Congress in the Bronx.
A $75,000,000 issue of 5 per cent debentures of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company was offered to the public yesterday. It was priced to yield 4.92 per cent and was quickly oversubscribed.

A radically styled powerpacked sports coupe has been added to the Studebaker-Packard Corporation line for late summer introduction. The car, called the Avanti (Italian for Forward), will be shown for the first time at the International Automobile Show that opens on April 21 at the Coliseum at Columbus Circle.

CINCINNATI April 9 (AP) --The Philadelphia Phils, who lost their first seventeen games with Cincinnati last year, started the season on a more cheerful note today, defeating the Reds, last season's National League champions, 12--4. The Phillies routed five Cincinnat pitchers and receiving a nine hit pitching performance from Art Mahaffey.
Mayor Wagner submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday a record expense budget of $2,771,202,762 for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
ROME, April 9 (UPI)--The Italian Football League said today that at least three First Division clubs had drugged players during championship games.
Southern Company directors, meeting yesterday at Atlanta, Ga., approved a revised construction program calling for an outlay of $154,000,000 this year, against $148,000,000 in 1961.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara denied today that he had criticized the Eisenhower Administration's handling of the program for the RS-70, reconnaissance strike bomber.
BONN, Germany, April 9-- France, Italy and West Germany have apparently succeeded in revitalizing the project for a political union of the six Common Market countries.
State Supreme Court Justice Walter R. Hart denied yesterday a request by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association for arbitration of its dispute with Isbrandtsen Company, Inc.

GENEVA, April 9--Arthur H. Dean of the United States chided the Soviet Union today for its opposition to war propaganda by challenging Moscow to outlaw books by Marx, Lenin and Stalin asserting that war was inevitable.

Overseas developments continued to depress shares of domestic cigarette manufacturers yesterday. The decline came after a recent report by the Royal College of Physicians in England that cigarette smoking was a cause of lung cancer.

ORAN, Algeria, April 9-- The Government suspended publication of the morning and afternoon editions of two Oran newspapers today to prevent the European extremists from using them for anti-Government propaganda.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --Tariff policy would revert to logrolling politics if the dutycutting power President Kennedy seeks were made subject to Congressional veto, Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati told Congress today.
A woman who supplied solutions to nationally advertised contests was charged yesterday with having given the wrong answers to the Internal Revenue Service. She was indicted on income tax charges.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 9 --A member of the Scarsdale Board of Education was accused in a personal confrontation tonight of having sworn in 1940 that he was a member of the Communist party.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, April 10 (AP)--A 'cellist from St. Louis moved Muscovites to tears in a performance yesterday and won rave reviews from Russian critics.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 9 (AP)--A Federal court test of Virginia's legislative redistricting plan was filed today by four General Assembly members from northern Virginia.

ALBANY, April 9--Mrs. Hortense Gabel, head of New York City's new rent agency, was accused today of "outright falsehood" in blaming the Republican-controlled Legislature for the prospect of rent increases in the city.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- The United States announced today the establishment of a new nuclear testing area--a vast circle in the central Pacific centered on Johnston Island.
LONDON, April 9--Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, gave Parliament today a 1962-63 budget that was promptly dubbed the give-andtake budget.

BONNIE Cashin's dedication to clothes that are functional, colorful and becoming is evident in the imaginative aprons that she has designed for workers of the Lighthouse for the Blind to make. Sold at Lighthouse Craftshop stores, they are in every respect practical and, at the same time, pretty enough to keep any cook happy with her chores.

KANSAS CITY, April 9 (AP) --Dick Barnett scored 10 points in the final quarter as the Cleveland Pipers defeated the Kansas City Steers, 106--102, for the American Basketball League championship tonight.
OTTAWA, April 9--Donald Fleming, Minister of Finance, told the House of Commons today that his 1961-62 account ran a deficit of $791,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9--The Security Council reaffirmed today by a vote of 10 to 0 a 1956 resolution that condemned reprisal raids by Israel on Syria.

ONCE more, but for the last time in New York until fall, a large group of antiques dealers gathered yesterday with highly diverse merchandise, quite a bit of which prompts the query: "What was it for?"

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)--The House Armed Services Committee expressed serious concern today that military construction contracts were being awarded to "entrepreneurs" with little or no building experience.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 9 (UPI)--Representative Walter H. Judd announced tonight his intentions to retire from politics at the end of this term, his tenth.
DALLAS, April 9 (UPI)-- Harry Moore Jr., receiver for the Billie Sol Estes interests, came here today to confer with Federal officials.

Up Scope of the Darby Dan Farm enjoyed the muddy going at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Helioscope registered an eight-length victory in the feature event, the Horace Harding Purse. He covered the six furlongs in the good time of 1:10 4-5.

Computer-derived astronomical tables are enabling a Brown University scholar to determine ancient Babylonian day-to-day fluctuations in the cost of barley, the height of the Euphrates River, the incidence of winter storms and disease outbreaks.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 9-- One type of radiation may help protect the body against another damaging type, according to a report today to the Aerospace Medical Association.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 9--"West Side Story" overwhelmed all opposition tonight to become the best picture of 1961 and win nine other Oscars at the thirty-fourth annual presentation of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9-- At the age of 85 an enthusiastic but relaxed Pablo Casals outlined today a "personal crusade for peace" that he expects will take him to cities in many parts of the world in the next two years.

Bobby Fischer, former United States chess champion, sought a court order yesterday calling for the resumption of the controversial sixteen-game series he forfeited to Samuel Reshevsky last summer. Mr. Reshevsky also is a former United States champion.

THOMAS SCHERMAN chose the music of Rich ard Strauss to end his current season and presented two works not too familiar to current New York programs.

WHAT Jonathan Daniels calls the graduation from piracy to plutocracy was fitful and startling on the Natchez Trace. Various scoundrels rode it as a short cut to oblivion. Benny Goodman listed yesterday eleven of the jazz musicians and the vocalist who will accompany him to Moscow on May 27.

TRENTON, April 9--The Judiciary Committeee of the State Senate released for confirmation today the appointment of Ned J. Parsekian as state Director of Motor Vehicles. The Senate will act on it next Monday.

LONDON, April 9--Qualified sources said today that the joint statement to be issued by President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan would blame the Soviet Union for the lack of progress on a treaty to ban atomic testing.

The Mayor's $2,771,202,764 executive budget represents a $223,748,027 increase in spending proposed for fiscal year 1962-63. WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --Two top defense leaders told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today there could be no letdown in this country's guard against the Communist threat.

BALTIMORE, April 9--Mrs. Thomas Cover 3d and J. William Hill Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Carroll Hill, to Austin McLanahan Taliaferro. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Catesby Taliaferro of Owings Mills.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 (AP)--Juan Marichal hurled a three-hit shutout today and his bat helped send Warren Spahn to the showers early as they Giants whipped the Milwaukee Braves, 6--0, in their National League opener.

After staging a strong recovery yesterday morning, worl sugar futures fell as much as 14 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) from the day's highs and closed off 4 points to up 5 on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume was 13,300 tons, one of the most active sessions of the year.

BONN, Germany, April 10 --Chancellor Adenauer said today that decisions on the "atomic equipment" of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would be taken at the NATO ministerial meeting in Athens next month.

Birmingham, Ala., borrowed $5,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance expansion of its water supply system. The money was raised at an interest cost of 3.2037 per cent by the, sale of serial revenue bonds to a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation.

The whole of New York City and Erie, Suffolk, Chemung, Oneida and St. Lawrence counties have been selected for the study of local welfare practices by the New York State Moreland Commission on Welfare.

DUBLIN, April 10--The Government of Premier Sean Lemass presented to Parliament today a record budget that abollishes the entertainments duty and gives benefits to farmers and pensioners but increases the tax on cigarettes, beer and spirits.
WASHINGTON, April 10-- Gen. Lucius D. Clay is expected to return here from Berlin tomorrow night with a report that his special assignment to raise morale there has been accomplished.

The not-so-well-rounded but promising high school student is about to get a better break for college admission. A $125,000 grant was made by the Ford Foundation yesterday to Willians College for a ten-year study of students who are admitted "with less-than-outstanding grades and test scores but with promising qualities that defy scientific measurement."
Trustees of the Bronx Hospital and the Lebanon Hospital last night approved a merger of the voluntary, nonprofit institutions.

The production and value of agricultural crops can be increased sharply through the use of a thin mulch, or ground covering, of petroleum, the Esso Research and Engineering Company reported yesterday.

LONDON, April 10 (AP)-- Guy Sumlin, a welterweight from Pritchard, Ala., scored an eight-round technical knockout over the British champion, Brian Curvis, tonight although the Briton rocked the American in the seventh.
An issue of $20,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company was offered at competitive bidding yesterday.
An American satellite has detected a rain of particles from the outer Van Allen radiation belt sufficiently heavy to empty the belt completely within a day or two.

A woman demonstrator and Patrolman Thomas E. Keefe offered different versions in Upper Manhattan Arrest Court yesterday on her conduct and the conditions of her arrest at a Times Square peace rally on March 3.
HONOLULU, April 10 (UPI) --Raymond S. Coll, editor emeritus of The Honolulu Advertiser who led editorial campaigns for statehood for Arizona and Hawaii, died yesterday at the age of 90.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 10 --A repayment of appropriations investment is being made to the United States Treasury by the Tennessee Valley Authority under a schedule. The schedule provides that $1,000,000,000 of the appropriations investment be repaid in about fifty-four years.
RICHMOND, Va., April 10 (AP)--The president of Philip Morris, Inc., told stockholders today there was "no clinical proof to support the theory" that cigarette smoking causes lung cancer.

Colmbia scored its second straight baseball victory yesterday by defeating City College, 9--1, at Baker Field. The Beavers outhit the Lions, twelve to four, but they committed seven errors and yielded eight bases on balls.
LOS ANGELES, April 10-- The Los Angeles Dodgers opened the baseball season today in their resplendent new stadium in Chavez Ravine. The sun came out brightly and so did 52,564 pennant-hungry fans.

DANANG, Vietnam, April 10 --United States Army officers said today that two wounded American sergeants were murdered by their Communist captors Sunday. Two other American sergeants, who were captured unwounded, are still prisoners of the Communists, the officers said.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad expects to report a loss of $4,800,000 for the first quarter of 1962, compared with the deficit of $10,500,000 incurred for the 1961 period, Milton G. McInnes, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP)-- Renewed support turned grain futures in the direction of a recovery today after the broad setbacks in the previous session on the Board of Trade.

Federal taxpayers in storm disaster areas will get faster refunds if they attach statements to the front of their tax returns indicating that they are claiming casualty losses under the law recently signed by President Kennedy.
